HEADLINE: In Last Days For Comment, Victims' Fund Is Under Fire 

BYLINE:  By ELISSA GOOTMAN 

 BODY:
From the day the overseer of a fund to compensate victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks announced a set of draft regulations for distributing the money, there have been those who have criticized his guidelines on various grounds.
 Now, with a deadline looming for changes to the regulations, which will go into effect Jan. 21, some politicians and victims' relatives are stepping up their opposition to the guidelines set forth by the fund's special master, Kenneth R. Feinberg. 
 The fund represents the federal government's attempt to compensate victims' relatives, who would in exchange forgo the right to sue over the disaster. Those who apply to the fund stand to receive compensation for noneconomic losses like pain and suffering, which Mr. Feinberg has said will vary according to whether a victim left behind a spouse and children, and for economic losses, which will vary according to a victim's earning potential. 
Yesterday, four members of Congress and dozens of relatives of victims gathered for a news conference outside Mr. Feinberg's Manhattan office, charging that he had set too low a figure for compensating families for their noneconomic losses. For such losses, Mr. Feinberg's guidelines call for a uniform award of $250,000, with an additional $50,000 for a surviving spouse and for each child. Some families have argued that these awards should vary with each family's circumstances.
"If these families went to court, I believe they would receive far more," said Representative Peter T. King, a Republican from Long Island who set up the conference. "He says, 'I don't want to play Solomon with people's pain and suffering.' Well, that's what juries do every day." 
Mr. King's other chief complaint is more complicated, related to the economic compensation that the families of the highest wage earners stand to receive. While Mr. Feinberg has said there is no cap on the compensation, he has also said that awards of more than $3 million would "rarely be appropriate." 
Mr. Feinberg has estimated that the average award under the guidelines would be about $1.65 million, before offsets for life insurance and death benefits. 
In addition, tables that Mr. Feinberg released, showing the rough correlation between the awards, and income and age, did not include salaries above $225,000 -- leading some observers to believe that Mr. Feinberg will impose a cap on compensation for families of high earners. 
Mr. King, who was joined by Representatives Carolyn B. Maloney, Felix J. Grucci Jr. and Vito Fossella, said that given that the World Trade Center was a target partly because it was seen as the embodiment of financial success, those who achieved such success should see that reflected in their awards. 
"They were the symbols of American capitalism, the symbols of American business, and they were murdered because of what they were," Mr. King said. "Now they shouldn't be deprived of what they're entitled to." 
Interviewed yesterday, Mr. Feinberg noted that he has a great deal of discretionary power and said he would evaluate the particular circumstances of each case, and determine an award accordingly. 
"The guidelines are just that, guidelines," he said. "Anybody can come in with their own tailored information and explain why the guidelines are inapplicable to them." 
Mr. Feinberg stood by his prediction that awards of more than $3 million would be rare, but said this was because few people would be able to prove such high earnings, not because of limits. He said he was still meeting with families and keeping an open mind about the guidelines, which are the subject of a 30-day comment period that ends Jan. 20. 
"I want as many people as possible to be supportive of the program," Mr. Feinberg said. "If it takes some adjusting to bring more people on board, we'll do what we can. We'll take everything under advisement."

HEADLINE: Let the Mayor Run the Schools 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael Bloomberg wants to take responsibility for New York City's troubled public schools. It is a worthy mission for the new mayor, and the State Legislature should make certain he gets the authority he needs to do it.
 At this point, Democrats in the New York State Assembly, led by Speaker Sheldon Silver, are standing in the way. They have sent signals that Mr. Bloomberg's wish to abolish the city's Board of Education or at least add enough new appointees to give him control is a newcomer's fantasy. Assemblyman Steven Sanders, the Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the education committee, declared mayoral control of schools "highly unlikely." Maybe Mr. Sanders and Mr. Silver are simply stating a negotiating position, part of a vastly more complicated strategy interwoven with questions about teachers' salaries, state school aid and more. This issue does not need to suffocate under all that intrigue. School governance, as this matter is generally called in Albany, deserves its own separate spot on the agenda. More than that, it deserves to be dealt with swiftly. 
 A year ago, a group of New York City business executives appealed to Albany to streamline the education system and give the mayor more power. Their reasons were straightforward: the current division of power doesn't work, and New York City schools are not producing enough graduates who can thrive in a competitive economy. Unfortunately, former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who supported the group in principle, used such harsh rhetoric to make his case that he helped make the argument for his opponents, who fear mayoral power. But if Mr. Giuliani presented his arguments badly, the underlying rationale is compelling. There must be a clear line of responsibility and authority for the quality of the city's schools, ending at the city's top elected official. It has been altogether too easy for any mayor to shrug off any problems with schools by blaming the school board or the chancellor picked by that board.
The board itself is an odd governmental contraption, seven members, one appointed by each borough president, and two appointed by the mayor. Its purpose was to dilute the mayor's power over schools and to give each borough some chance to demand its share of educational benefits. To no one's surprise, what goes missing often is a citywide view of what is best for the system as a whole.
The board does, at least in theory, provide the public with more lines of access into the school system. One proposal from people who like that aspect of the status quo has been to expand the board to 11 members, giving the mayor a majority of the appointees. The fact that Mr. Sanders did not seem to leave the door open for such a compromise strongly suggests that the Assembly's concern has more to do with protecting political perks and power than with improving the educational system.

HEADLINE: Bush's South Asia Strategy: Keeping Terrorism as Villain 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WACO, Tex., Jan. 6 

 BODY:
In the three weeks since a deadly attack on the Indian Parliament, President Bush and his foreign policy team have scrambled to avoid war in South Asia with a simple formula: in daily phone calls to both sides, they have tried to reframe the conflict as a battle over terrorism, not territory.
 They have carefully offered no opinion on the question of who should control Kashmir, an emotionally explosive issue in both countries. They have not volunteered to oversee negotiations, a role the United States has played so often in the Middle East and elsewhere. 
 Instead, they have acted as if the Islamic extremist groups accused of carrying out the assault were stateless terrorists similar to Al Qaeda and perhaps linked to it -- and that they threaten the stability of Pakistan, where they are based, as surely as they threaten India. 
It is partly a convenient fiction. President Bush has made no public mention of the fact that the terrorist groups he says must be crushed have often acted as a surrogate for Pakistan's intelligence service. 
Yet so far the strategy appears to have worked, or at least bought some time for the opponents, who met this weekend at a tense summit meeting in Nepal. Page A6. 
The president's aides here and in Washington say they believe that their constant barrage of telephone calls to India and Pakistan probably prevented a rapid escalation of the conflict into a war between two hot-headed nuclear powers.
"We decided early on that the purpose now is not to solve Kashmir; it is to defuse the crisis," one senior administration official in Washington said the other day. 
Another added, "The question is how long will that work -- how long can you keep both sides from making a big mistake?"
At the core of the strategy has been constant pressure on Mr. Bush's new ally, Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan. At the urging of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, and then the president himself, who called from his ranch, Mr. Musharraf has begun a roundup of the leaders of the Islamic groups suspected in the attacks, and a few who are not suspected. The administration's thinking was that each round of arrests makes it more difficult for India to justify an attack that would almost certainly turn into war. 
Mr. Bush, describing his conversations with Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India, said last week that, "while I understood his anger," he should "give us all a chance to work with President Musharraf to bring the terrorists to justice." 
"Terror is terror," Mr. Bush said, before buying a cheeseburger in the small gas station and deli near his ranch, "and the fact that the Pakistani president is after terrorists is a good sign."
The Indians were suspicious of the strategy. They had been outraged at Mr. Bush's characterization of the two main terrorist groups operating in Kashmir as "stateless," which they saw as a crude pander to Mr. Musharraf. And they noted that despite repeated acts of terrorism in the last few years, Lashkar-e-Taiba, or the Army of the Pure, and Jaish-e-Muhammad, or the Army of Muhammad, were never placed on the State Department's list of terrorist groups. The administration belatedly remedied that on Dec. 27, more than two weeks after the attack on the Parliament.
Now Indian officials say they want "guarantees" from the United States that Pakistan would wipe out the groups. Administration officials say they have heard no such request, and they doubt they could offer such a guarantee anyway.
But they can continue to pressure General Musharraf, who by all accounts has so far offered little resistance to the American call for a crackdown, perhaps seeing an opportunity to consolidate his own power.
While General Musharraf has long identified himself with the Kashmir issue, American officials were betting that he was nervous about the Islamic radicals in his midst and the terror groups' brewing anger about Pakistan's decision to side with the United States in the war against the Taliban and Al Qaeda. 
"The unspoken part of this deal," said one White House official, "is that Musharraf has a brief window of opportunity to act against these guys before they threaten him. And he's feeling a lot stronger than he did a few months ago." But in many conversations with senior American officials, General Musharraf expressed growing alarm about the size of the Indian military buildup on his border. 
Defusing a crisis of this magnitude is not what the Bush administration envisioned when it came to power. All last spring and summer, the president and his aides focused on India, not Pakistan. While Mr. Bush's team has few charitable comments about Clinton-era diplomacy, they saw an opportunity to build on Mr. Clinton's courting of Indian leaders, and the strengthening of economic ties. 
In contrast, they saw little potential in building a relationship with Pakistan: its support of the Taliban, its proliferation of missile technology and its constant dalliance with economic default made it seem, in the words of one American diplomat, "only a few shades better than North Korea." Hard-liners in the Pentagon, moreover, thought a tilt toward India would help in the containment of China, India's other great rival. 
Sept. 11 changed all those calculations. Now Washington finds itself, to India's distress, with an equal interest in both countries. But it does not yet have a strategy to meet that new reality.
Assuming that the current crisis can be defused, officials say Mr. Bush must begin to address both the substance of the Kashmir dispute and the threat posed by both countries' nuclear arsenals. Eventually, that will require creating some kind of arms control framework that gives officials in Islamabad, New Delhi and the rest of the world some assurance that a firefight over the Line of Control does not risk rapid escalation into a nuclear exchange.
But for now the Bush administration is starting small. On Friday, Secretary Powell suggested that he was ready to send an American envoy to the region. That envoy may be Secretary Powell himself, or his deputy, Richard Armitage, or Richard Haass, who heads the State Department's policy planning operations and has long experience in defusing past India-Pakistan crises.
The hope is that the envoy will convince both sides to pull back their troops, reducing the chance of an inadvertent disaster. They are mindful, they say, of the warning from Brig. Muhammad Yaqub, the Pakistani Army's commander in Kashmir, who told a reporter the other day, "When you've got two armies standing eyeball to eyeball, even a little accident can lead to a chain reaction."

HEADLINE: White House Letter; 
Recent Bushisms Call for a Primer

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
Like a cantankerous parent telling teenagers they cannot have the family car for a road trip, President Bush announced in California on Saturday that the Democrats would reverse his tax cuts of last year "over my dead body." Actually, Mr. Bush said "not over my dead body," thereby mangling a familiar idiom, but the crowd's roar of approval indicated that everyone knew what he meant.
 So did the headline writers, making the president's "my dead body" the first memorable Bushism of 2002, and the first since Sept. 11 to address the indisposed economy. But it was only the latest in a string of phrases, from "smoke them out of their caves" to "the evil one," that have punctuated Mr. Bush's speech and are destined to live on as signposts of his presidency. 
 Herewith, a primer of the newest Bushisms.
"Over my dead body": White House aides said that Mr. Bush was speaking in California from notes, not a text, and that the remark was ad-libbed. The declaration immediately evoked memories of Mr. Bush's father's reneged and politically disastrous promise, "Read my lips: no new taxes," but in fact "over my dead body" has been a favorite of politicians, sometimes with unpleasant results, for some time.
Ronald Reagan announced in Little Rock, Ark., in his 1984 re-election campaign that there would be tax increases only "over my dead body," a promise he had to modify in his second term. Prime Minister John Major of Britain said in 1992 that the pound would be devalued only "over my dead body," and soon enough the currency was down 15 percent. 
White House officials did not return calls yesterday seeking to determine if Mr. Bush had used the phrase with his own twin daughters, or if he had heard "over my dead body" from his parents while growing up. But Homer may have been the first to use it, in the "Iliad," when Hector tells his wife, Andromache, that he will "let the earth come piling over my dead body" before he will allow the fall of Troy and hear her cries as she is dragged off by the Greeks.
In that same passage, in what could be read as another literary allusion to the family Bush, Hector lifts his infant son and asks the gods to grant that the boy "rule all Troy in power and one day let them say, 'He is a better man than his father!' "
"The evil one": Mr. Bush has regularly used this phrase to describe Osama bin Laden. Among evangelical Christians, it is an obvious reference to Satan, and appears throughout the Bible. (From Matthew, in the New American Standard Bible: "When anyone hears the word of the kingdom and does not understand it, the evil one comes and snatches away what has been sown in his heart.")
Mr. Bush was raised an Episcopalian, became a Methodist after his marriage and then in 1986 said he was recommitting his heart to Jesus Christ -- a born-again experience, at least in the words of evangelicals, although the president has not used that term to describe himself. Still, evangelicals recognize the terminology of "the evil one" as their own.
But some in the evangelical movement have questioned the phrase.
"The problem with 'the evil one' is that in Christian thought, the only one who is totally, hopelessly evil is Satan," said Richard J. Mouw, the president of Fuller Theological Seminary in Pasadena, Calif., the largest seminary in North America for the mainstream evangelical movement. "We don't really believe that anybody is beyond redemption until their dying breath, if they reject Christ." Calling Mr. bin Laden "the evil one" supernaturalizes him, Dr. Mouw said. He added that saying Mr. bin Laden was wanted dead or alive, as the president had done, trivializes human life. "That's not an example of moral leadership, or spiritual leadership," Dr. Mouw said.
"Smoke them out of their caves": Mr. Bush has with great relish promised to smoke the Taliban and Al Qaeda out of their hiding places. In the early days of the war, his reference to caves was thought by some to be metaphorical. But the bombing of Tora Bora proved that the president was speaking more literally than most people may have realized.
Then on Dec. 19, appearing on the South Lawn of the White House with Gov. Mike Foster of Louisiana, Mr. Bush suddenly used the phrase in connection with rabbits, leaving the press corps perplexed.
"I know the governor likes to hunt rabbits down in Louisiana," the president said. "Sometimes those rabbits think they can hide from the governor. But, eventually, he smokes them out and gets them. And that's exactly what is happening to Mr. bin Laden, and all the murderers that he's trying to hide in Afghanistan."
Mr. Foster later explained that Mr. Bush was referring to a rabbit hunting trip he took with Mr. Bush on the Louisiana coast during the 2000 presidential campaign. "You let beagles loose, and they howl and go after the rabbits and chase the rabbits out in front of you," Mr. Foster said.
"I guess you could smoke them out," Mr. Foster added, "but I don't know anybody who hunts them that way."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
2002 Follies: New Cast, Familiar Plot

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
 A new year, a new mayor, a new set of predictions:

DEMOCRACY IN ACTION -- Bitter arguments about an appropriate memorial at the World Trade Center site will prevent approval of any design this year. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will ask Nathan Leventhal, his favorite troubleshooter, to make peace.

DEMOCRACY AND INACTION -- The new City Council, intent on replacing the iron leadership style of Peter F. Vallone, the former speaker, with openness, will find itself more deadlocked than liberated.

BLESSED BE THE DONORS -- Two major scandals will erupt from the distribution of money from Sept. 11 charities.

JOBS FOR THE UNNEEDY -- Unemployment will continue to rise, except among politicians forced out by term limits, though few are likely to match the $125,000 a year for Howard Golden, the former Brooklyn borough president just named executive director of civic and governmental affairs by the district attorney in Brooklyn, Charles J. Hynes.

NOVEMBER SURPRISE -- Imaginative cost-cutting, restructuring of the debt and the national economic rebound will wipe out sizable city and state deficits and yield modest surpluses to be announced just before Election Day.

CAMPAIGN REDUX -- Just as in last year's mayoral contest, the Democrats will indulge their well-practiced art of self-destruction. H. Carl McCall and Andrew M. Cuomo will duel themselves out of contention and hand a third term to Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican.

SPOKESWOMEN -- The Bloomberg women (his former wife, Susan Bloomberg, his elder daughter, Emma B. Bloomberg, and his girlfriend, Diana Taylor) will continue to give interviews to help protect the mayor's desire for privacy.

LET'S MAKE A DEAL -- Mayor Bloomberg, working for a dollar a year, has promised to cut his office budget by 20 percent; he will include his uncollected salary in his count, shaming the resistant city comptroller and public advocate into making reductions of at least 15 percent.

SYMPATHY VOTE -- New York City will get commitments this year to hold the Democratic and Republican National Conventions in 2004. Rudolph W. Giuliani, president of Lincoln Center, will be his party's keynote speaker.

CITY HALL DROPOUTS -- As in most administrations, at least two deputy mayors will end the year with so little to do they may leave office altogether.

ROUND TWO -- Mark Green will lead a campaign to revamp the city's campaign finance law, to help candidates running against billionaires. He will fail, thwarted once again by Mayor Bloomberg.

RAISING THE ROOF -- Following the lead of "The Producers," now selling $480 tickets, several Broadway theaters will be renovated, to install corporate sky boxes.

WORK NOW, PAY LATER -- The city's contracts with unionized workers will offer healthy increases -- payable in 2004 and 2005.

UNION MUSCLE -- The teachers' union will get its new contract only if its president, Randi Weingarten, agrees to use her influence with the State Legislature to lobby for significant mayoral power over the Board of Education.

PAX PRESIDENTIAL -- The Rev. Al Sharpton and Mr. Giuliani will finally appear in public together at joint rallies, as Mr. Sharpton and Mr. Giuliani test the national political waters.

HOME AWAY FROM HOME -- The Clintons come clean and admit they have been staying in a Park Avenue apartment but vow to visit Chappaqua every Election Day, to vote in their "home" district.

MOBILE BETS -- To satisfy a statewide desire for gambling, Governor Pataki will design casinos on wheels. Competing mayors and county executives may volunteer as drivers.

PUBLICITY PREACHMENTS -- Senator Charles E. Schumer will receive an honorary doctor of divinity degree in recognition of his Sunday television sermons.

PILLOWS ON THE PEWS -- Houses of worship, having won the right to shelter the homeless on their front steps, will match their civility with humanity by allowing them to sleep inside.

NICE TRY -- Sympathy for firefighters will defeat the efforts of Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta to close underused fire houses.

REFINANCING -- The Yankees and Mets will offer to sell two players each to pay for their new stadiums, valued at a combined $1.6 billion.

BACK TO NORMAL -- David Letterman will signal New York's recovery by resuming his nasty old put-downs of the city.

HEADLINE: Tribe Prepares for Renewed Fight Over Gold Mine 

BYLINE:  By NICK MADIGAN 

DATELINE: WINTERHAVEN, Calif., Jan. 5 

 BODY:
The only sound in the desert is a whistling wind, almost imperceptible. Chips of black volcanic basalt and white quartz mingle underfoot, like a jumbled, prehistoric chessboard. As afternoon falls, waves of sand turn to shimmering gold.
 Standing on a small hill, Lorey Cachora, an archaeologist and member of the Quechan tribe, pointed to a path in the rocky terrain where his ancestors ran, sometimes for hundreds of miles, to deliver messages and trade with sister tribes south into Mexico and north along the Colorado River. Bending down, Mr. Cachora pointed to faint markings on a rock, and said they were made at least 7,000 years ago by Quechan storytellers, who wove powerful myths through "dream trails" and other spiritual tools. 
 It is here, on what is now federal property administered by the Bureau of Land Management, that Glamis Gold Ltd., a company with mining operations in Nevada, California, Mexico and Honduras, wants to dig a 1,600-acre, open-pit gold mine. The company's eight-year effort gained ground two months ago when the Bush administration reversed a ruling by Bruce Babbitt, President Bill Clinton's interior secretary, that digging such a mine would irreparably harm the environment of the Quechan ancestral lands.
"We're going to fight until the end on this," said Mike Jackson, 54, the president of the Quechan Tribal Council. 
Mr. Jackson, sitting in his office at the Fort Yuma Indian Reservation, 14 miles southeast of the proposed mine at Indian Pass, said he had tried to arrange a meeting with Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton to express tribal opposition to the mine, to no avail. "Gale Norton really needs to meet with us," he said. "If she doesn't listen, we're headed for a meltdown. Right now, across the country, all tribal nations are very disappointed in the Bush administration. Nobody's history should be destroyed. Putting this mine here would be like putting a McDonald's on the South Lawn of the White House."
Ms. Norton suggested in an interview in The New York Times in November that the decision to rescind the Babbitt order was part of an effort to counteract the Clinton administration's pro-environment tilt. "Many of the things that we have done are to put in place common-sense approaches that we feel are a better balance," Ms. Norton said.
Mark Pfeifle, a department spokesman, said that the Babbitt order denying permission to mine at Indian Pass had sprung from "baseless legal reasonings." Nevertheless, Mr. Pfeifle said, a Bureau of Land Management official told Mr. Jackson and the tribe's lawyer, Courtney Ann Coyle, that Ms. Norton's retraction of the Babbitt order was simply one step in a long process and that the bureau had yet to decide whether Glamis Gold had a valid claim.
"Once that's done, it would be at that point in time that the economic concerns, the environmental concerns and the spiritual concerns would be evaluated," Mr. Pfeifle said. "We're committed to working and listening and cooperating with the American Indians and hearing their concerns."
David Hyatt, vice president of investor relations at Glamis, said the company was willing to alter its plans out of respect for the tribe. "We've offered to move some of our waste stockpiles to accommodate these trails of dreams and whatnot," Mr. Hyatt said. "We certainly understand their feelings. We've tried to sit down with the tribe, but each time they and the antimining groups change their demands. What they don't understand is that miners are just as much environmentalists as they are. We don't want to destroy the environment where we live and work."
Speaking from Reno, Nev., Mr. Hyatt said that, in any event, the Quechan ancestral landscape was already scarred by railroads, highways, power transmission lines and pipelines, although there are none of those intrusions at Indian Pass, where the only evidence of modern man is a row of mining-claim stakes driven into the ground in the midst of creosote shrubs, cholla cactus and cat's claw trees.
For at least 10 years, about 150 miners would toil in three open pits, each as deep as 850 feet. Two pits would be filled in after mining, but the third would be left open. 
"It's not cost-effective to fill in the last hole when you're done mining," said Mr. Hyatt, whose company this year expects to reap about 225,000 ounces of gold -- worth some $70 million -- from its various mines.
Thirty-one members of Congress, including Senators Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein of California, signed a Dec. 6 letter to Ms. Norton saying that the "unmitigable environmental and cultural impacts" of the proposed mine required denial. They wrote that Mr. Babbitt's decision to stop the project was based on a public review process lasting five years and an exhaustive study of the social, cultural, economic and environmental consequences of the plan.
Ms. Coyle, the Quechan lawyer in San Diego, said she was troubled by the administration's willingness to roll back rulings long in the making. "When can anyone ever rely on the decision of a government when a succeeding administration can reach back in time and undo that decision?" she asked. "It raises a lot of serious questions about how this government feels about Native American sovereignty."
The Quechan, who number about 3,000, held most of this territory as recently as the 1800's, when they had some 880 square miles. Their reservation now is about 45,000 acres, much of it unsullied desert, although there are several mines, some dating back to gold-rush days in the 19th and early 20th centuries.
In Winterhaven, a down-at-the-heels, one-strip town with two liquor stores, a closed nightclub and a senior center, the prospect of an economic revival stemming from a new mine was not enough to make some of the locals go along.
Mr. Jackson, the tribal president, said it was crucial to preserve the past etched in the land so that it could be passed down.
"Since time immemorial, no one has touched it," Mr. Jackson said. "It's a pristine area and we just want to keep it that way."

Indians fear that the precious metal will trump their precious heritage now that a Clinton-era ruling has been reversed. HEADLINE: FACING OFF; 
On the Front Line in the O.R.

 BODY:
Certified registered nurse anesthetists are nurses who complete three years of advanced training in anesthesia that legally allows them to give anesthesia without a doctor's supervision in 50 states. But Medicare rules, which tend to set standards for all patients, require physician supervision in hospitals. In November, the Bush administration rejected a Clinton administration proposal to let nurse anesthetists work unsupervised in hospitals. Gale Scott spoke to members of opposing professional groups about the issue. Following are edited excerpts of those interviews. 
 YES. Certified registered nurse anesthetists offer safe quality care to their patients. One indicator of that is that our malpractice insurance premiums have decreased 50 percent over the last decade. According to the National Practitioners' Data Bank, nurse-anesthetists made one-seventh the malpractice payments that doctors made in 1990 to 1997. 
 What is really at issue here is a turf war between doctors and nurses, not patient safety. The proposed change in Medicare rules that would have allowed us to work without direct physician supervision was in the best interests of all Americans. Instead we're left with a rule that lets states opt out of that requirement only if they meet cumbersome requirements.
In two-thirds of the nation's rural hospitals nurse anesthetists are the sole providers of anesthesia. There's a shortage of physicians who want to work in these hospitals and many inner-city hospitals because the pay isn't that high. The new rule would have helped these facilities.
Instead there may be less access to care for patients who use these hospitals. The 28,000 nurse anesthetists in our organization are part of a profession that started administering anesthesia over 100 years ago. The first anesthetists were nurses at the Mayo Clinic who gave patients chloroform and ether to relieve pain and suffering. 
The issue of supervision arose because surgeons have been given the idea that they are responsible for what the nurse-anesthetist does. This is a misconception. Case law has shown time and again that a surgeon's liability is the same whether anesthesia is provided by a nurse or a doctor. 
When we are caring for a patient we are not working alone. We have the ability to consult with an array of specialists if a problem arises.
Even in a rural setting where there is less staff, whatever is available to a physician providing anesthesia is available to us. 
We get nearly the same training in anesthesia as a physician, including training in resuscitating a patient in an emergency. We don't have a medical school background; we have a nursing school background. But as far as the technicalities of administering anesthesia, we are on a parallel educational track. 
Anesthesia is safer than ever because of advances in technology. That's been documented by two groups that monitor patient safety. Six studies since the 1960's have shown that there is no difference in patient outcomes when nurse anesthetists provide anesthesia compared to the outcomes when doctors provide it.
Our concern is that if surgeons continue to push to have another doctor present to supervise us, surgical services and thus anesthesia services will become more costly and less available. Surgical services generate revenue. For struggling rural hospitals less revenue could mean closures and a big impact on patient care. 
NO. The Bush administration was absolutely right to restore Medicare's anesthesia safety standards. The Clinton administration's attempt to allow nurses to deliver anesthesia without supervision would have been a step backward. It's a question of patient safety. Hospitals know that. 
In a study at the University of Pennsylvania -- a review of the medical charts of 217,000 Medicare surgical patients -- for every 10,000 patients there were 25 to 40 more needless deaths when an anesthesiologist was not involved in care. 
Many people don't realize that our job is to keep patients alive while the surgeon does things that could kill them.
We delicately balance the delivery of drugs and gases with sophisticated monitoring to allow the brain and the heart and other vital organs to survive the trauma of surgery. 
Over the years we've seen remarkable changes in the specialty. When I started out 30 years ago there were only about 8,000 anesthesiologists in the United States. We had a high volume of patients, and we trained nurses to provide us with technical help. 
But the results were not good. One patient in 5,000 was dying from an anesthesia mishap.
That was an alarming rate. So we campaigned to recruit more physicians to enter the field of anesthesiology. We pioneered research on monitoring patients, drug interactions and protecting organs.
Our efforts have paid off. Today there are more than 30,000 anesthesiologists practicing. The mortality rate has dropped to fewer than one death in 250,000 patients. 
Nurses are very valuable because they can extend our ability to give care. The problem comes when there's a patient who has a heart attack under anesthesia, or an asthma attack. 
As physicians, anesthesiologists have from 12 to 13 years of medical training, including college, medical school and residency training under intensive supervision.
Nurse anesthetists have far less education. A nurse with a two-year nursing certificate can get another two years of training and become a certified nurse anesthetist. One study found that many did not have college degrees.
Nurses are valuable, but they are no substitute for trained physicians who give comprehensive medical care before, during and after surgery. 
The issue of guaranteeing quality medical care in rural hospitals goes way beyond anesthesia. Some 96 percent of these hospitals are regularly referring complex procedures to regional medical centers where more sophisticated equipment and personnel are available. They don't want to handle these cases.
Nor is this an economic issue. Medicare reimburses the same amount for anesthesiologists and nurse anesthetists. Nurses practicing independently might actually cost more because they lack medical expertise and need more medical consultations and more lab tests for their patients. That can cause delays and canceled procedures, a big expense for hospitals.
It comes back to patient safety. When you are on that table in the operating room, you want the best trained person available -- and you deserve it.
The very fact that nurses believe they are the same as doctors is dangerous. Patients' safety should not be negotiable through politics.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 1, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The Facing Off column in Science Times on Jan. 8, about the roles of anesthesiologists and nurse anesthetists, misstated the conditions in which state laws permit the nurse anesthetists to work. In most states, nurse anesthetists can administer anesthesia only with a doctor's supervision, not without it. 
The column also misstated the organizational title of Dr. James E. Cottrell. He is president-elect, not president, of the American Society of Anesthesiologists. 
The column misstated two of Dr. Cottrell's assertions. He said that nurse anesthetists now receive additional anesthesia training after earning bachelor's degrees, not after earning two-year nursing certificates. And he said that in a survey 96 percent of rural hospitals reported that they were doing all the surgery they wanted to do -- not that 96 percent of rural hospitals regularly referred complex surgery to regional medical centers.

HEADLINE: Argentina Devalues, and the Spanish Feel the Loss 

BYLINE:  By EMMA DALY 

DATELINE: MADRID, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
When the Argentine government decided over the weekend to devalue the peso, it also decided on several measures to spare its citizens some of the pain of devaluation. The brunt of the costs of those measures will be borne in Spain.
 Banks in Argentina have been told they must allow loans of less than $100,000 to be paid off in pesos at the predevaluation exchange rate, rather than the dollars they were promised. Two of Argentina's biggest banks, with one-fifth of the market, are Spanish-owned. 
 Gas, electric and telephone utilities have been told they must keep their rates the same as before devaluation and must accept payment in pesos. Most major utilities in the country are Spanish-owned. 
A new tax on oil exports is intended to help the government pay some of its debts. The largest oil company in Argentina is Spanish-owned.
In all, Spanish companies have some $39 billion invested in Argentina, more than those of any other country. According to a report by Santander Central Hispano, Spain's largest banking group, they stand to lose nearly $3 billion almost immediately because of the devaluation. 
Investors were so concerned about the exposure of Spanish blue-chip companies in Argentina that they hammered the benchmark Ibex index down 3.4 percent today.
Amplifying the frustration for Spanish companies is the fact that many of their investments are recent ones. Spanish companies have been leading buyers of privatized Argentine businesses, whose value depended in part on the dollar revenues they generated before the devaluation. The roster includes five of Spain's largest companies -- Santander and its main banking rival, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria; Repsol-YPF, the oil company, whose stock plunged almost 8 percent today; Telefonica, the dominant Spanish phone company; and Endesa, the biggest electric utility. None have yet officially commented on the crisis, pending talks with Argentine officials; many businesses in Spain were closed today for the Epiphany holiday, though the stock market was open.
The Argentine devaluation marked down the value of the peso, which had been held at parity with the American dollar for a decade, to 71.4 cents. During the decade of parity, the great majority of bank assets and liabilities in the country were denominated in dollars. Now, the government's edict that all bank loans, including mortgages, of $100,000 or less be converted to pesos at the one-to-one rate squeezes banks in the middle, with customers repaying loans in pesos but the banks' own liabilities still payable in dollars. The banking industry as a whole will lose some $10 billion to $20 billion from the change, according to bankers -- or $6 billion by the government's calculations.
The two Spanish banks have about $15 billion in loans outstanding in Argentina, including $6.5 billion to governments and state-sponsored entities, two-thirds of that by Banco Bilbao and $2.4 billion by Santander. Between them the two have already set aside $1.25 billion to cover bad debt losses in Argentina; a Banco Bilbao spokesman said those provisions now look insufficient.
Merrill Lynch analysts estimated that the crisis would cost Banco Bilbao $940 million and recommend that investors sell its stock. Other analysts were even gloomier, predicting losses of up to $1.6 billion for Santander and $1.5 billion for Banco Bilbao in Argentina.
Santander shares fell 4.37 percent in Madrid on Monday, while Banco Bilbao was down 3.25 percent.
Responding to widespread criticism that its policy will wreck the banking system, the Argentine government has said that it plans a new oil export tax, producing up to $5 billion in revenue over five years that may be used to back bond issues that could help shore up the banks.
But the tax will punish Repsol-YPF, which stands to lose as much as $257 million a year in the worst case, according to analysts in Madrid. The company had not been expected to suffer much from the peso devaluation because its exports could still be sold for dollars, so the new tax plan rattled investors. Repsol's stock has fallen 11.5 percent since Thursday. 
Miguel Pareja, a broker at Eurodeal, told Reuters that operations in Argentina were likely to account for half of Repsol's earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization in 2002. 
The freezing of utility bills will hammer Spanish companies that had enthusiastically bought privatized assets the last few years. Telefonica earns about an eighth of its global operating income from its Argentine fixed-line subsidiary. Endesa gets about 7 percent of its global revenue in Argentina.
Analysts at Ibersecurities in Madrid said that the price freeze could reduce Telefonica's pretax operating income by $536 million this year. But they said those losses were already factored into its stock price, which fell 4.4 percent today. "What is hurting its price is uncertainty," the analysts' report said.
Endesa, which had poured $12 billion into Latin American investments the last decade, has now postponed plans to invest a further $3.7 billion in the region. Analysts said Endesa was expecting about one-tenth of its operating income in 2002 to come from Argentina.
Gas Natural, a rival Spanish utility owned by Repsol, said that its Argentine affiliate, with 1.3 million clients in Buenos Aires, would suffer, but that only 5 percent of its global profit depended on Argentina; its stock traded off only 2.06 percent today.
"I think the program will be very negative for Spanish companies, especially the banks," said Ramon Ortega, a trader at the Safei brokerage house in Madrid.
Government and European Union officials were less worried. Pedro Solbes, the union's economics commissioner, told an interviewer on Spanish national radio that Spanish companies would get through the crisis. "I am convinced that they are in a good health and can weather the storm," he said.
Jose Maria Aznar, the Spanish prime minister, was said in news reports here to have had a tense telephone conversation last week with the Argentine president, Eduardo Duhalde, reminding him that Spain had contributed $1 billion to an international bailout package two years ago. But this week, officials of the Spanish government, which currently holds the rotating European Union presidency and sees itself as the bridge between Europe and Latin America, were keen to emphasize Spain's close ties to Buenos Aires.
"Relations are solid and historic," said one official. "Spain is willing to help."
Representatives of the Spanish companies are scheduled to meet with the new Argentine government in Buenos Aires on Tuesday, with the banks expected to argue that without modifications the new policy will destroy the banking system. Some analysts said they expected the banks to threaten to abandon the market unless they received some compensation. Spanish news media reported today that Telefonica, Repsol, Endesa and Gas Natural were discussing joining forces to begin legal action against the utility price freeze.
But the Spanish foreign minister, Josep Pique, said that everyone must do what is necessary to support the reform plan. "Given the gravity of this situation, all sectors must make an effort and make sacrifices, and of course, that includes business interests, whether they are Spanish, foreigners or Argentines," he said.
The Spanish economic daily Expansion tried today to evaluate the costs of the reform package to Spanish businesses but concluded that it was too soon to know. "At this level we do not believe that the institutions themselves really know what the cost of these measures will be, but the minimum estimates are around 1,500 million euros," said analysts at Link Securities who were quoted by the paper.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Compaq to Post Profit And Beat Estimates

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

 BODY:
Compaq Computer, the No. 2 personal computer maker, said yesterday that it would report stronger-than-expected sales for the fourth quarter and a profit instead of the narrow loss it had predicted.
 With little elaboration, Compaq said preliminary figures from the quarter ended Dec. 31 indicated that the company had surpassed its own forecasts and the expectations of Wall Street analysts. 
 Sales still lagged the fourth quarter of 2000, by nearly one-third, but showed sharp improvement from the troubled third quarter, when the Sept. 11 attacks and other unexpected events cut sharply into sales and profits, the company said. The company suggested that the progress reported yesterday served to refute claims by rival computer makers that the beleaguered plan for Hewlett-Packard to acquire Compaq had distracted both companies from their daily business. 
"These results represent strong execution and Compaq's solid momentum in the marketplace," Michael D. Capellas, chairman and chief executive of Compaq, said in a statement. "I am extremely proud of our employees and their continued focus on our business and our customers."
Compaq, based in Houston, said it would report sales of at least $8 billion, compared with its earlier prediction of $7.6 billion to $7.8 billion. The better-than-expected sales will yield a profitable quarter, the company said, beating Wall Street's expectations of a loss of 3 cents a share.
Arch Currid, a spokesman for the company, said it would report a profit "no matter how you slice it," either including or excluding one-time items, when it reports final results on Jan. 16.
Wall Street analysts, who predicted a dreary fourth quarter for many computer vendors, said Compaq was helped by better-than-expected sales in Europe and in American retail stores.
Gateway, a rival computer maker, failed to improve its sales from its third quarter. Gateway yesterday repeated its prediction that it would post a profit for its fourth quarter, excluding one-time items, but said preliminary figures indicated sales of $1.16 billion, down from $1.4 billion in the third quarter.
According to a study put out yesterday by Salomon Smith Barney, consumers in the United States bought more personal computers during the holidays, after poor demand for most of 2001. Sales doubled during Thanksgiving week and finished the year strong, leading to a 30 percent gain from the third quarter to the fourth. Compaq gets about 15 percent of its revenue from consumer PC sales.
Still, Richard Gardner, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, said that corporations continued to spend frugally on new computers. PC makers sold fewer machines during the holidays than during the comparable period in 2000 -- an excellent year for computer sales. Salomon Smith Barney said it did not expect that trend to reverse until the economy begins to recover, possibly in the second half of the year.
Shortly before Compaq released its preliminary figures yesterday morning, Lehman Brothers upgraded its rating on the company's stock to strong buy. Daniel T. Niles, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, said he thought that programs begun last year to cut costs, reduce inventory and better mimic the direct sales model used by Dell Computer would bear fruit in 2002.
Mr. Niles said corporate customers have apparently stayed with Compaq, despite growing uncertainty surrounding its deal with Hewlett-Packard. A bitter proxy fight between Hewlett-Packard and one of its board members, Walter Hewlett, has threatened to derail the merger plans. But since the deal was announced in early September, Compaq has continued to sign large contracts with customers like Ericsson, Raytheon and General Motors.
Mr. Currid, the company spokesman, said Compaq had beaten Dell, the world's leading PC maker, and other rivals in head-to-head competition for several contracts since the merger was announced in early September. "We're continuing to win in the marketplace," he said.
In regular trading, shares of Compaq rose 29 cents, to $11.68. Gateway gained 43 cents, to $10.25.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: DIPLOMACY; 
China, Russia and 4 Neighbors Seek Common Front on Terror

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
After a daylong meeting here, foreign ministers from China, Russia and four Central Asian countries said today that the fall of the Taliban in Afghanistan did not end the terrorist threat and that their governments would continue to work together against "terrorism, separatism and extremism" to promote regional stability.
 In their joint statement, the ministers tried to link their countries' sometimes controversial efforts to suppress Islamic fundamentalists and separatists within their own borders to the larger United States-led war on terror. The six countries, which have formed a loose economic and security alliance called the Shanghai Cooperation Organization, had long "been threatened by terrorism and drugs" from Afghanistan, the statement said, adding that they "have actively participated in the international alliance against terrorism and have adopted measures to further strengthen the group's antiterrorism work. 
 "It should be ensured," the statement said, "that there is an effective struggle against terrorist threats at every level -- globally, regionally and nationally -- and this struggle should not engender bias or adopt double standards." 
On a broader level, today's meeting represented an effort by China and Russia to form a counterweight to growing American influence in the region.
In addition to urging "restraint" in the conflict between India and Pakistan, the ministers warned against outside interference in Afghanistan. 
Today's declaration made few specific recommendations, other than encouraging the development of an international "Comprehensive Covenant on Terrorism," and announcing that the group would establish an "antiterrorist body" based in Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan. The statement sought to gloss over national differences, giving members relatively unqualified support for combating "terrorism," however they might choose to define that term.
In addition to China and Russia, the organization includes Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. All of the countries have Muslim movements that their governments would like to rein in, although these groups often have little in common other than their religion. 
Russia has been fighting a prolonged battle with Chechen separatists, some of whom were trained in Afghanistan. China has experienced little more than occasional car bombings, thanks in part to intense surveillance and repression of its Muslim Uighur ethnic minority. While many Uighurs in China's far western Xinjiang region say they yearn for an independent homeland, that interest is at least as much cultural as religious. There is little interest in Islamic fundamentalism there.
Still, since the beginning of the United States-led campaign, China's government has asserted that about 1,000 Uighurs have trained in Al Qaeda camps in Afghanistan, and a few Chinese citizens have recently been detained in Afghanistan.

HEADLINE: Ford's Plans for Revamping May Shut New Jersey Plant 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
A Ford Motor Company plant in Edison, N.J., which makes Ranger pickups, might be shut down as part of the major reorganization the automaker is set to announce on Friday, a top Ford official said today.
 "It is a vulnerable plant -- we have to say it -- as are several others," said the official, James J. Padilla, Ford's new vice president for North American operations. 
 "It's because of the product, not because of the work force," Mr. Padilla added. "If not Edison, then where? It's one among the ones we have to look at." 
Ford is expected to report a loss for 2001, its first annual loss since 1992. Under its new chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., the company has continued the cost-cutting begun under his predecessor, Jacques A. Nasser, in an attempt to return to profitability and to stabilize its tumbling market share.
Speculation about Ford's financial shape has hung over the North American International Auto Show this week and has overshadowed Ford's introduction of new vehicles here, including a jumbo canary yellow pickup, the Ford Mighty F-350 Tonka, a concept vehicle modeled on one of Hasbro's toy trucks.
The plant in Edison, a community about 25 miles southwest of New York City, is seen as a low-hanging fruit by some financial analysts who say that plant closings and thousands of additional job cuts should be part of the plan Ford announces this week.
Edison is one of Ford's older plants. Even though the Ranger has been a top-selling compact pickup for more than a decade, it has not been redesigned in several years, and its sales have been slowing.
Mr. Padilla said that the overall market for compact pickups had declined somewhat and added, "I'm not eager to have plants producing products that don't sell."
Ranger sales fell 17.5 percent from 2000 to 2001, according to AutoData, a research firm in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.; during that year, Ford's overall market share fell to 21.9 percent from 23 percent.
The Ranger is also produced in St. Paul. Many analysts say that Ranger production will be consolidated as part of Ford's revamping.
Mr. Padilla said that neither Edison nor St. Paul was an optimal site. Much of the work in the automotive industry is now done by suppliers, and having their assembly plants as close to the suppliers as possible enables automakers to reduce inventories and control costs. Engines and transmissions for the Rangers come from Michigan and Ohio, he said.
Still, Ford seems to have tipped its hand in picking between Edison and St. Paul. In December, it announced it would shut down one of Edison's two shifts in February, idling some 600 of the plant's approximately 1,700 employees.
The current mood in Edison -- even at the offices of Local 980 of the United Automobile Workers -- seems to be largely wait and see.
The mayor of Edison, George Spadoro, said he had tentative plans to go to Detroit next week. "I would certainly like to speak with Ford to understand better the economic reasons and see if we can craft a plan to save the plant," he said. Still, he added, the community was big and diverse enough to withstand a closing.
Employees, too, were measured in their response. "The bottom line is the company needs to make money, just like we all do," one assembly line worker said. "It's been rumored for a while," he added, "but until the fate of the plant is sealed there is no use being worried."
In Detroit, Mr. Padilla said: "We know in this market there is excess capacity. We've set some targets for where we think the industry is going to be and what we think a realistic share for ourselves will be."
"Having said that," he added, "we have to right-size our business to take care of what we think is a realistic piece of the action."
The bar set for the turnaround plan is high. A confluence of factors is clouding the outlook for Ford, including a strengthened General Motors, Asian automakers empowered by strong products and a weak yen, an expected decline in overall vehicle sales and the automaker's burdensome costs for incentives like low-interest loans and cheap leases to attract customers.
Ford also has morale woes, quality problems and withering margins at its financing arm, Ford Credit.

HEADLINE: N.J. Transit to Increase Bus and Train Fares 10% 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
New Jersey Transit today approved an average 10 percent fare increase for its 380,000 daily train and bus riders, but withdrew or modified some other parts of its original proposal, which had drawn sharp criticism at public hearings around the state last week.
 The fare increase, which will take effect on April 1, will be the first in a decade for the nation's third-largest public transit system, which has been run by the agency since 1979. 
 Several of the agency's board members said that although they were approving the increase reluctantly, it was long overdue;the system's farebox revenues fell 29 percent since 1991, adjusted for inflation, while expenses rose 67 percent.
"In the first decade of N.J. Transit's operations we probably raised fares too often," said John L. McGoldrick, who has been on the board from the agency's beginnings as an agglomeration of troubled and bankrupt commuter lines. "But in the second decade of N.J. Transit the fare increases came too infrequently. This is a fair fare increase." 
Tom Wilson, a spokesman for Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, said that the governor had approved the board's action this afternoon, just hours after their vote and a day before he officially leaves office at noon on Tuesday. Mr. Wilson said Mr. DiFrancesco believed that the board's modifications strengthened an already reasonable plan. 
Jo Astrid Glading, a spokeswoman for Governor-elect James E. McGreevey, said -- as Mr. McGreevey's office has said since the fare proposal was unveiled on Dec. 11 -- that he had not had a chance to review it and would have no comment. 
Among transit advocates and officials in Trenton, it was widely speculated that the timing of the increase and its approval by a lame-duck governor were intended to lessen the political fallout. In response to some of the criticisms leveled by scores of speakers at public hearings last week, Jeffrey A. Warsh, the agency's executive director, had recommended that several of the original proposal's features be dropped, and board members agreed.
These included lowering the discount for riders 62 and older to 50 percent from the current 55 percent discount; eliminating round-trip, off-peak excursion discounts, and consolidating some bus zones under a higher fare.
At Mr. Warsh's urging, the board also withdrew its proposal for automatic fare increases in each of the following five years, pegged to the inflation rate. The board can still seek such increases, but members agreed that public hearings must be held first.
The features that were deleted drew some of the most critical comments at six hurriedly scheduled public hearings held simultaneously around the state last Wednesday.
"We take our roles as public stewards seriously, and we heard the public outcry on some of these proposals," said Mr. Warsh, taking note of the widespread cynicism about the pace of the process. 
"We heard loud and clear that some people thought that the automatic inflation increases were a violation of their rights. We heard person after person say that we were railroading it through when we knew all along that it was a very fluid proposal."
With the changes, the fare increase will generate $38 million in additional revenue for the agency rather than the original projection of $44 million, Mr. Warsh said. The increased revenue is meant to help the agency close an annual deficit estimated at $169 million. 
Many of the transit advocates and commuters who turned out for the board's meeting today applauded the modifications to the plan.
But they generally continued to oppose fare increases without efforts to increase state subsidies or draw more support for transit by increasing the state's gasoline tax.
"I applaud the board for the sensible changes they have made in the proposal," said John Weber, a spokesman for New Jersey Citizen Action. "But for many people this 10 percent increase is still a one-way ticket to the poorhouse." Vito Forlenza, chairman of the New Jersey State Council of the Amalgamated Transit Union, which represents 5,000 employees of New Jersey Transit bus lines, said the increase was fair and necessary, allowing the agency to more properly spend its capital funds on new equipment.
But repeatedly, speakers said that the idea of fare increases should be deferred to the administration of Mr. McGreevey, who will take office on Jan. 15.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Why Do More With Less? Just Whistle

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
OUR new mayor has called for all New Yorkers to make sacrifices during these lean times, but the message doesn't seem to have gotten to the union whistle-blowers on my street. 
 These are not the kind of whistle-blowers who report on union scandals. They are literal whistle-blowers. Since November, they have been congregating on the sidewalk to blow a chorus of whistles. Sometimes they've awakened the block at 8 a.m. and blown the whistles all day; sometimes they go for an hour around noon. The unpredictability may be part of the torment. 
 Their gripe is with my landlord, who is building six new floors on top of an old six-story building of rental apartments on the Upper West Side. Living in the middle of a two-year construction project is even worse than you might imagine, but it does at least offer an education on housing issues. We could put a sign over our front door: "New York's Permanent Housing Crisis: A Case Study in Unaffordability." 
In 2000, as some readers might recall, we tenants got a firsthand look at the hassle and cost ($12,500 per apartment) of installing new sprinklers in old apartments. Neither the tenants nor the landlord thought the sprinklers were worth the expense and aggravation, but we were no match for the labor unions and sprinkler companies that lobbied for the new law mandating them. 
Now we're getting another look at union muscle. On a typical weekday, a dozen guys in hooded sweatshirts gather across the street, next to a 15-foot-high balloon of a rat, to protest the nonunion workers building the new floors. The protesters blow whistles and shout at the nonunion workers and the drivers delivering materials. They chant slogans like, "We are the union, the mighty, mighty union."
They hand out fliers accusing the nonunion contractor of "lowering the quality of life in New York," not a terribly persuasive argument to tenants whose quality of life has been destroyed by six weeks of whistling. The protesters, though, say that we're getting off easy. "At other sites we've blown the whistles for 12 straight hours every day," one carpenter told me. 
He said the protest is for our own good, because it's not safe for us to live under floors built by carpenters making $20 per hour instead of the union wage, $58 (including benefits). I share his concern for safety, since I prefer not to have the floors collapse on my home. But I also suspect that the owner of the building and his insurance company have given that possibility a lot more thought than anyone in the carpenters' union. 
So why isn't he using union labor? "Because this project would be unaffordable," said the owner, Adam Katz. "It would cost 30 to 50 percent more with union workers, and it wouldn't be any safer or better. The union guys can't compete economically, so they have to resort to economic terrorism." 
The guys on the picket line, as well as officials with their unions, all insisted to me that there was no threat of violence. But it was easy to see why the owner had hired round-the-clock guards, and why so many other developers would rather not build than risk union wrath.
OF all the reasons for New York's housing shortage, probably the single biggest factor is the high cost of union labor. Wage rates here are typically a third to a half higher than in Chicago, Los Angeles and other cities, according to a 1999 study at the New York University School of Law. Even more problematic than the wage rate, some developers say, is the unnecessary cost of peculiar work rules and featherbedding. 
These extraordinary costs are accepted as inevitable here. "New York is a union town," progressive politicians have long said with pride. But now that the city is desperately short of cash for new housing, now that politicians want radical steps to speed to rebuilding downtown, why is it still taboo to ask for sacrifices from construction workers? These workers, after all, stand to pocket a hefty share of the billions in federal aid for reconstruction. Couldn't they give something back?
The unionized carpenters outside my building may think of themselves as oppressed workers, but their wages are not exactly proletarian. James A. Parrott, the deputy director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a labor-backed research organization, estimates that the median hourly wage in New York State, including benefits, is $15 to $20.
Why is it progressive to defend carpenters demanding three times the norm? They themselves seem to realize it's artificially high. If their work was really worth $58 per hour, they wouldn't need to reach into the toolbox for a whistle.

HEADLINE: Judge's Domestic Violence Ruling Creates an Outcry in Kentucky 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 4 

 BODY:
The violent arena of domestic abuse litigation has grown a bit more volatile here, now that a judge has decided to hold two women in contempt of court for returning to men who had been ordered to stay away from them.
 "You can't have it both ways," said Judge Megan Lake Thornton of Fayette County District Court in recently fining two women $100 and $200 respectively for obtaining protective orders forbidding their partners from contacting them, then relenting and contacting the men. 
 Ruling that the order was mutually binding, Judge Thornton also cited the men for contempt.
"It drives me nuts when people just decide to do whatever they want," said Judge Thornton, who is experienced in the state's thick domestic abuse docket, which produces close to 30,000 emergency protective orders a year. Kentucky officials say there is a virtual epidemic of abusive relationships in the state. 
Judge Thornton's ruling has alarmed advocates for battered women, who plan to appeal it. The advocates say the finding goes beyond existing law and is unrealistic because some renewed contacts often prove unavoidable in domestic abuse cases, which involve economic and family dependency and other complications of daily living.
The state office on domestic violence has pointedly agreed, warning that the ruling could cause abused women to hesitate in bringing their plight before the courts for fear of being chastised for their trouble.
"The reality is it's easy to say they should never have contact," said Sherry Currens, executive director of the Kentucky Domestic Violence Association, an advocacy and legal protection group. "But we're talking about people in long-term relationships. They may have children in common. It's pretty hard to say, 'Never speak again.' People have financial difficulties. They may love the partner. It's not an easy thing."
But Judge Thornton declared in court, "When these orders are entered, you don't just do whatever you damn well please and ignore them."
The ruling stunned Cindra Walker, the lawyer for the two women, who is with Central Kentucky Legal Services, which represents many of the thousands of indigent women caught in abusive relationships.
"For over five years, I've been in court practically every day on these abuse cases," Ms. Walker said, "and I've never before had a victim threatened with contempt." 
"The domestic violence law is a tool for victims to use to be safe," not a device to punish them, she said. 
One of the women in the ruling said she eventually moved back with her partner while the other had occasional contacts, Ms. Walker said.
Judge Thornton's office said judicial rules barred her from commenting on the cases. But her two rulings made clear that she expected the original orders against all contact to apply equally to the person suspected of abuse and the abused.
"They are orders of the court," the judge declared, according to court transcripts obtained by The Lexington Herald-Leader. "People are ordered to follow them, and I don't care which side you're on."
Carol Jordan, the director of the Governor's Office of Child Abuse and Domestic Violence, said she disagreed with Judge Thornton's ruling even as she sympathized with the professionals who must try to oversee violent domestic situations.
"These are tough cases for judges," Ms. Jordan said. "They are dealing with complex human emotions. They are dealing with danger."
But if the ruling stands, Ms. Jordan warned, some abused women will conclude that they will not be treated fairly if they seek refuge in the courts. This sort of ruling "absolutely increases abused women's level of risk" by seemingly encouraging their abusers, Ms. Jordan said.
In Kentucky, as in much of the rest of the nation, abuse victims have increasingly turned to the courts as protective orders have become more accepted, said Billie Lee Dunford-Jackson, assistant director of family violence law and policy for the National Council of Juvenile and Family Court Judges. Most judges "have been making clear to the batterers that the issue is between the state courts and them," Ms. Dunford-Jackson said, rather than a domestic issue between two parties. 
A "sizable minority" of judges may still regard the conflicting parties equally in their rulings, she said, but newer state laws have increasingly put the focus on violent abuse as the main problem requiring state intervention.
Ms. Walker's two clients, Jamie Harrison and Robin Hull, declined to be interviewed.
Ms. Walker, one of two legal service lawyers handling hundreds of abuse cases in 17 counties, said, "Our big concern now is the chilling effect this will have."
Two years ago, the Kentucky Legislature considered a proposal to apply the protective orders equally to the accused and the victim, Ms. Jordan said, but the notion of mutual protection, equating the two parties, is not part of state law.
Judge Thornton's ruling, she contended, will "establish a barrier that stops abused women from seeking protection of the courts."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Cindra Walker, right, the lawyer for two women recently fined by Judge Megan Lake Thornton, above, for contacting their partners after they had won emergency protective orders against them. (Lexington Herald-Leader); (Janet Worne for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Teenager Drew 1,000 Investors And the S.E.C. With His Plan

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
The Internet stock bubble may have burst, but the dream of getting rich quick lives on.
 How else to explain the success of Cole Bartiromo, a California teenager who raised more than $1 million from investors late last fall by guaranteeing returns of up to 2,500 percent? In less than two months, Mr. Bartiromo, 17, persuaded more than 1,000 people to send him money by promising to make risk-free bets on sporting events, according to a complaint yesterday from the Securities and Exchange Commission. Then he transferred much of the money to an account he held at a casino in Costa Rica. 
 The high risks of investing in the Internet or biotechnology stocks were not for Mr. Bartiromo's financiers. They preferred the safe, sure riches promised by wagering on collegiate and professional sports.
Through his Web site, Invest Better 2001, Mr. Bartiromo promised investors that he had a "team of bettors who were very good at what they did and only bet on sure things," said Alexander Vasilescu, senior trial counsel for the S.E.C. "It's fair to say that some people who invested weren't sophisticated."
Some early investors did receive the promised returns, as Mr. Bartiromo paid off his first backers with money from later investors, Mr. Vasilescu said. But by early December, the scheme had begun to break down, and investors were complaining on a bulletin board on the Invest Better Web site that their money had disappeared.
On the site, which proclaimed that "Invest Better 2001 is already the No. 1 investment service in existence," Mr. Bartiromo gave investors a choice of four investment packages. They offered returns that ranged from 125 percent for three days to 2,500 percent for six weeks -- the "Christmas Miracle" package.
On Dec. 13, the S.E.C. filed an enforcement action in federal court in Manhattan to stop Invest Better 2001 from raising more money, although it did not name any individuals in its complaint.
Yesterday, the S.E.C. amended its action to identify Mr. Bartiromo, who lives with his parents in Mission Viejo, Calif., north of San Diego, as a principal of Invest Better.
Mr. Bartiromo agreed to return profits from the fraud to investors, including $900,000 he had transferred to the casino account, Mr. Vasilescu said. The S.E.C. and Mr. Bartiromo have not reached agreement on how much money he will ultimately have to return or whether he will face fines or other civil penalties.
The complaint does not name other defendants, and Mr. Vasilescu declined to say whether Mr. Bartiromo acted alone or had help. 
A lawyer for Mr. Bartiromo did not return calls for comment. Mr. Bartiromo did not return a message left at his parents' house.
About two years ago, a 15-year-old New Jersey student, Jonathan Lebed, made almost $800,000 using the Internet to inflate the prices of penny stocks before the S.E.C. forced him to stop. In September 2000, Mr. Lebed settled an S.E.C. complaint and was allowed to keep almost $500,000 of his profits.

HEADLINE: With Ceremony Under Somber Skies, QE2 Returns 

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
An idyllic cruise-ship-brochure day? Not. Evil winds buffeted the Queen Elizabeth 2 yesterday morning as it docked at Pier 88 on the West Side of Manhattan and hundreds of shivering passengers headed up the gangplank, pelted by a pitiless confetti of snow under a titanium-gray sky. 
 Nevertheless, the boarding was "a symbolic moment, and we're pleased and proud to be here today," said Paul Wright, the liner's master -- or captain, to landlubbers. 
 Though the 33-year-old liner has tied up in New York hundreds of times, it was the first time that any scheduled trans-Atlantic cruise ship had picked up travelers in the city since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, when passenger ships were banished for security and logistical reasons. The QE2, on its way to Manhattan that day from Southampton, England, was diverted to Boston.
The QE2's return was the first hopeful sign of a reprise of sunnier days. "We sincerely hope that this signals the start of a return to normalcy," said Pamela Conover, president of the Cunard Line, the QE2's operator. 
The cruise-ship industry annually pumps $600 million into the New York State economy and accounts for 11,000 jobs, according to NYC & Company, the city's convention and visitors bureau.
About 400 New York passengers endured stringent security procedures with good humor as they waited to join 800 passengers who had boarded in other ports. "We are hoping for more sun in Hawaii," said Wolfgang Altmueller, a computer engineer who had flown in from Germany with his wife, Barbara, to join the six-continent, 108-day world cruise. Those sailing on the 1,791-passenger liner were paying $24,195 to $374,515 for the privilege. 
The QE2 began its day in New York Harbor before sunrise. At 6:45 a.m., the crew slowed the liner's engines, lowered its flag to half-mast and laid an evergreen wreath offshore from the World Trade Center site. Virtually all of the passengers and crew members assembled on deck for the memorial, and endured chilly breezes until they had all finished singing "Amazing Grace." The ship then gave three long memorial blasts of its whistle. 
Before the QE2 set sail in the late afternoon, Cunard gave a 100-guest luncheon for what Captain Wright called New York's "unsung heroes," the chefs, hoteliers and hospitality managers who fed, housed and welcomed the ground zero recovery workers and their families. "This group of heroes has gone unnoticed for too long," said Cristyne L. Nicholas, president of NYC & Company, which sponsored the luncheon. 
"I'm in awe," said Don Pintabona, chef at Tribeca Grill. He was honored at the luncheon for spearheading the three-week volunteer effort to provide 500,000 meals for recovery workers at ground zero, prepared mostly on donated Spirit cruise ships anchored in the harbor. "If only we'd had the galleys of the QE2 to work with after 9/11." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: As the snow flew yesterday afternoon, the liner Queen Elizabeth 2, which had docked in New York in the morning, left on a round-the-world cruise. (Vincent Laforet/The New York Times)
