HEADLINE: Turkey, Well Along Road to Secularism, Fears Detour to Islamism 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
Nowhere does the war against Islamic extremism have more resonance than in Turkey: for eight decades, the country has used draconian laws and the threat of force to crush pro-Islamic politicians and protect secular ideals.
 But with Turkey haunted by economic stagnation, scandals and weak leadership, the generals, who wield the real power, have had their hands full containing the popularity of a former Istanbul mayor who is trying to shed his fundamentalist background and wrap himself in a cloak of moderation. 
 The government's problems are giving the ex-mayor, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, a chance at a national electoral victory in 2004 that no aggressively Islamic politician has ever achieved.
Mr. Erdogan was a rising star in Turkey's Islamic political movement as Istanbul's mayor in the 1990's; even critics acknowledge that he cleaned up the streets, improved public services and reduced the endemic corruption. 
But his insistence that religion play a greater role in political life collided with secular Turkey's unbending prohibition against mixing religion and politics. He was forced out of office and jailed for publicly reciting a poem that was deemed seditious.
Today Mr. Erdogan (pronounced ehr-doh-han) is making a strong comeback at the helm of a new party, aided by public disenchantment with the three-party governing coalition and its inability to halt inflation and curb rising unemployment. 
"The world is a different place and I am a different person," Mr. Erdogan, 47, said in an interview at the sleek headquarters of his Justice and Development Party in Ankara. "Turkey should become a model for the Muslim world in terms of science, lifestyle, international relations and economics."

The Nation
The Tug of War Between Old and New
Mr. Erdogan's popularity suggests that he could become the next prime minister, but the prospect of an Islamic politician, however reformed, leading Turkey sends shudders through secular-minded Turks and Western allies, particularly the United States. 
In the aftermath of Sept. 11, Turkey gained new importance to the coalition against Osama bin Laden, and for all its flaws on human rights, Turkey is a stable synthesis of democracy and Islam in a volatile Islamic world. Many regard it as a model for moderate Muslims and a counterweight to the angry voices of radicals.
With Muslims worldwide rejecting the secular values of the United States and Europe, Turkey reflects the faith's less ferocious and more tolerant face. Even its most ardent religious leaders and Islamic-oriented politicians do not advocate violence or oppressive orthodoxy.
On a practical level, Turkey, the only predominantly Muslim member of NATO and an ally of Israel, is also an essential American friend: It granted access to its airspace and provided bases to American warplanes, and has promised to send troops to Afghanistan. If the United States attacks neighboring Iraq, Turkey will be even more vital, and the inherent tensions between its religion and its Western orientation will become more acute.
To many, Mr. Erdogan represents a threat to the rigid safeguards that have held religion in check and maintained Turkey's status as the most moderate and Western-oriented Muslim country.
But Mr. Erdogan is trying to shift his image. The religious rhetoric has been scrubbed away and his old opposition to NATO and the European Union set aside. That way he hopes to avoid any retribution by the generals, who could come back at him if he proves too religious for them. Elections are set for 2004; pollsters say his party would win handily if the vote was held now.
The country he may lead is complex. Western ways, embodied by television, films and tourism, are widely embraced. In Istanbul, short skirts are as common as religious head scarves, and alcohol flows freely.
"Turkey is not Iran," Meltem Eke, a stylish woman in her 30's, said at her bagel shop in the upscale Nisantasi district. "I am from a neighborhood that values the woman no less than the man."
But Turkey is at once modern and backward, democratic and repressive. The differences are sharp between the urban bustle and the sense that time stands still in the villages. There is a divide between the secular generals and business leaders, and those like Mr. Erdogan, who would like to see more religion in the mix of governing.
Within those contradictions lies a tension that is always just below the surface and always the object of careful monitoring by the generals. A further tightening of measures to control Islamic movements and businesses is now under review by the National Security Council.

The History
From Broad Tolerance To Rigid Secularism
Turkey's singular position among Muslim nations is rooted in history. 
The Ottoman sultans brought Islam to what is now Turkey by defeating the Byzantine emperor Constantine XI in 1453. In time, the Ottomans ruled an empire stretching from southern Europe to northern Africa and the Arabian peninsula.
The sultans were simultaneously political leaders and supreme rulers of the Muslim world. Rather than a strict religious government, however, they kept state and religion separate and demonstrated tolerance for other religions and customs.
"From the Ottoman period to today, our experience and traditions have made Turkish Islam more open to secular development than was the case in other Islamic societies," the foreign minister, Ismail Cem, said in an interview.
After the Ottoman empire shriveled in the late 19th and early 20th century, the sultans were followed by Ataturk, the general and determined secularist who founded the Turkish republic in 1923. For Ataturk, religion was the greatest threat to his dream of a European republic at the gateway to Asia.
Ataturk's insistence on secularism was ruthless. Control over education was taken away from religious leaders, Islamic courts were closed, equal rights for women were championed. The Islamic calendar was scrapped in favor of the Gregorian calendar used in the West; Arabic script was replaced by the Roman alphabet. 
Those who opposed Ataturk were hanged. 
His methods persist in moderated form. When the country's first pro-Islamic prime minister, Necmettin Erbakan, was deemed to have detoured too far from the secular path in 1997, generals directed his ouster.
Turkey practices its own brand of secularism: The government builds the mosques, employs those who preach in them and dictates sermons.
Still, political figures and parties have risen beneath an Islamic banner to challenge the militant secularism. Each time, they have fallen victim to laws that prohibit advocating alternatives to the secular state.

The Heartland
Exporting Rebellion To the Uneasy Cities
The resentments on which Mr. Erdogan builds his support are most evident in the heartland, where religious fervor lingers, polygamy is still practiced and illiteracy is high among women because families often do not send girls to school.
Konya is one of Anatolia's oldest cities, the place where Jalaluddin Rumi, the founder of the Islamic Sufi sect of Whirling Dervishes, gathered his disciples in the 13th century to preach his mystical message. His tomb rests inside the domed Mevlana Tekke, and every day dozens of women, their covered heads bowed, pray there.
But Konya is also a bustling city of nearly a million, with high-rise buildings and large agriculture businesses, many financed by devout bankers who observe the Koran's prohibition on interest.
"Traditions have been preserved here because there has not been much internal migration," said Osman Okka, an economics professor at Selcuk University in Konya. "Still, the Turkish people have lost a lot of their religious identity. We know God. We know the prophet. We know Ramadan. But we are illiterate beyond that because of the secular policies of the state." 
But a quiet rebellion against secularism has been brewing among business executives in places like Konya and their counterparts who migrated to Istanbul and other cities to form a new urban middle class during the past 15 years.
Its leader is Ali Bayramoglu, an industrialist who founded the Independent Industrialists' and Businessmen's Association to fight what he sees as government-backed discrimination against devout Muslims.
"We don't categorize a government as Islamic or secular," he said in the Istanbul office of the group, which represents 2,200 business owners and 10,000 businesses nationwide. "We have the idea that if we have a government with just and equal attitudes, that would be enough."
Mr. Erdogan wants to transform this disenchantment into a political mandate, but he must broaden his appeal beyond the devout, who have never mustered the political muscle to elect a national government. As a result, his speeches emphasize the economic failures and corruption of the current governing parties.
The message strikes home among the vast urban poor, particularly young men. Many arrived from rural areas during the past 20 years, bringing conservative values but few skills and little education.
One recent afternoon, several young men lounged outside a teahouse in Kasimpasa, a rough Istanbul neighborhood. None had a job, none supported the government.
"Maybe it's time for someone like Erdogan to shake things up," said Mehmet Osman, 22, who has never worked full time. "He knows what life is like for us."

The Islamist
A New Message Draws Skepticism
Mr. Erdogan grew up in Kasimpasa, selling lemonade and sesame bagels on the street to help support his family, which had migrated from the Black Sea region. He was so pious at a school for preachers that friends referred to him as hodja, or spiritual leader. He joined the Islamic political movement at 15 and got a degree in management at Marmara University.
He was elected mayor of Istanbul in 1994 on the ticket of the Islamic-oriented Welfare Party. Along with improving life in the city, Mr. Erdogan followed the tenets of political Islam. He banned alcohol in restaurants owned by the municipality, opposed the country's bid to join the European Union and advocated withdrawal from NATO. 
His language was blunt. In a 1995 speech, he said: "You cannot be secular and a Muslim at the same time. The world's 1.5 billion Muslims are waiting for the Turkish people to rise up. We will rise up. With Allah's permission, the rebellion will start."
Two years later, in an speech in Siirt, Mr. Erdogan recited a poem that included the line, "The mosques are our barracks, the minarets our bayonets, the domes our helmets and the believers soldiers."
That kind of talk gives the generals chills. Mr. Erdogan was arrested and convicted of "inciting public enmity and hatred." He was sentenced to 10 months in prison, stripped of his office and barred from politics for life.
He served four months in prison, and last year the political ban seemed to be lifted in a general amnesty. But prosecutors claim that the amnesty did not apply to him. A court decision is expected this month. 
Mr. Erdogan knows this is the time for moderation. In the interview, he exhibited none of the fire of earlier speeches. Those old words, he said, were misinterpreted. "This was not a statement in terms of war," he said, recounting his call for rebellion in 1995. "It is for modernizing the Muslim world."
He rejected the Taliban's brand of Islam, saying: "We never supported the Taliban rule. They represent blood and death."
When asked about the role of religion in government, he advocated freedom and tolerance, saying: "Islam is not an obstacle for democracy. Democracy includes Turks who are devout and those who are not."
It is impossible, say his secular-minded critics, to tell whether Mr. Erdogan has changed his mind or changed his message.

The Force of Islam
Articles in this series are examining growth in the influence of Islam. Previous articles have included Islam and women, the devout rulers of Saudi Arabia and Muslim influence in Indonesia, Russia and Nigeria. Later articles will examine the Taliban and the concept of jihad, or holy war. Articles in this series and related coverage are available on the Web:
nytimes.com/world

CORRECTION-DATE: March 8, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 8 about Turks' concerns that an Islamic political movement could undercut their long commitment to a secular government misstated the century in which the religion arrived. Islam began to spread in the 11th century in what is now Turkey -- not in 1453, when the Ottoman sultans conquered the area. A reader reported the error in January; this correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

HEADLINE: Isuzu and Hino Motors Plan To Merge Bus Units in 2003 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
Two of Japan's most troubled vehicle makers, Isuzu Motors and Hino Motors, said today that they had reached a deal to merge their bus-making operations next year, as they try to weather a steep sales decline across Asia.
 The companies, which have been negotiating the deal for two years, will begin joint production in October 2003. Together, they will be Japan's largest bus maker. The companies said they were also discussing a combination of their truck divisions. 
 Today's announcement is the latest move toward consolidation in a vehicle industry that analysts say has too many companies, factories and workers. With the Japanese economy floundering and the government slashing its public works budget, demand for trucks and buses has plummeted in Japan. Manufacturers built just 1.7 million of them last year, down 40 percent from 1990.
"Ensuring sustainable business is becoming harder than ever in the face of deteriorating profit," Isuzu and Hino said in a joint statement.
To compensate for the downturn at home and to take advantage of new markets and cheaper labor, Isuzu and other companies built assembly plants in Southeast Asia in the 1990's, but demand there dried up after the financial crisis of 1997. 
News of the consolidation buoyed the stock price of Isuzu; its shares rose 12.3 percent today. Forty-nine percent of Isuzu is owned by General Motors. But investors bid down shares of Hino, half-owned by Toyota Motor, by 3.3 percent.
Shares in both companies have been pummeled in recent months, with Isuzu touching a 31-year low. Isuzu, which also makes sport utility vehicles, expects to lose more than $200 million in the fiscal year ending March 31; its sales have fallen in seven of the last eight years.
Isuzu has already announced that it will shed one-third of its work force, close some factories and stop making Trooper sport utility vehicles in the United States. Still, investors remain skeptical that the company can cut costs fast enough.
General Motors appears to be among the skeptics. The G.M. executive in charge of operations in Asia and the Pacific, Rudy Schlais, said on Sunday that his company would make no more investments in Isuzu. The market value of G.M.'s stake has fallen by $900 million in a year.
"It's going to be a very tough road for Isuzu," said Chris Richter, a senior analyst at HSBC Securities in Tokyo.
The Japanese motor vehicle industry is increasingly being cleaved in two. A few companies, like Toyota and Honda Motor, can compete robustly around the world and have been able to expand their market share and pile up profits. 
The second-tier players -- without a strong overseas presence and often partly owned by foreign automakers -- are struggling to cut costs and shed assets to stanch losses at home. Examples include Mitsubishi Motors, partly owned by DaimlerChrysler, and Mazda Motor, controlled by Ford Motor. Over all, Japan's 11 sizable vehicle makers expect sales to contract by 0.7 percent in 2002, after a 0.9 percent decline in 2001.

HEADLINE: Lucent Finally Chooses a Chief Executive 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Lucent Technologies, the troubled telecommunications equipment giant, ended its long search for a chief executive yesterday by naming Patricia F. Russo, who was a top executive at the company before leaving 17 months ago.
 By rehiring Ms. Russo from Eastman Kodak, where she was president and chief operating officer, Lucent sent a clear message: the company does not plan a major departure from its current management policies as it tries to return to profitability. Lucent lost more than $16 billion and cut or spun off more than 70,000 jobs in the last year and a half. 
 The big question, analysts said, is whether the advantages Ms. Russo brings, as an executive who knows Lucent and its market, will override concerns that she is too closely associated with the business culture that led to Lucent's current problems.
"I would have liked for Lucent to move beyond its legacy management team," said Ed Oppedisano, a debt analyst at Deutsche Bank. "It's not clear whether an insider can help solve Lucent's complicated puzzle."
Ms. Russo, who is 49, assumed her responsibilities immediately yesterday, returning to the company where she worked for 19 years. She joined the company when it was still the communications equipment arm of AT&T and stayed after it was spun off as Lucent in 1996. 
Henry B. Schacht, who is 67, has relinquished his title of interim chief executive but plans to remain Lucent's chairman for about a year. Then Ms. Russo is expected to assume that post as well. 
Mr. Schacht was Lucent's first chief executive when it became independent from AT&T and left in 1997. He returned in October 2000 after the company's fortunes started to decline and the board ousted his protege, Richard A. McGinn. Lucent has been looking for a permanent replacement for Mr. McGinn since then.
But the search was tabled twice -- early last year, while Lucent unsuccessfully pursued a merger with the European equipment maker Alcatel, and later while Lucent fought off a debt and cash-flow crisis that raised liquidity fears.
That crisis has passed, but some analysts are skeptical about Mr. Schacht's forecast that Lucent can become profitable as soon as this year. 
Ms. Russo said in an interview yesterday that she intended to proceed with Mr. Schacht's efforts to repair the company. "I'm not naive about the work that needs to be done," she said, "but I would not have left Kodak for any offer but this one. I agree with the message that Lucent needs to perform more and talk less."
With Ms. Russo's appointment, Lucent will become the second-largest company in the United States to have a woman as chief executive. Hewlett-Packard, which is run by Carleton S. Fiorina, herself a former Lucent executive, is the largest. According to Catalyst, a nonprofit research organization that tracks women in business, the number of Fortune 500 companies with women as chief executives has grown to six from two in 2000.
During Mr. Schacht's first tenure at Lucent, Ms. Russo ran its business communications unit, later spun off as Avaya. She also oversaw business development and public relations as executive vice president for corporate operations. She left Lucent in August 2000, when she saw little room for further promotion under the chief executive at the time, Mr. McGinn.
When Mr. Schacht returned to Lucent in 2000, he helped arrange for Avaya to accept Ms. Russo as its nonexecutive chairman that December. Kodak lured her away a few months later. 
Ms. Russo returns to a company that has been hit hard by the recession in the telecommunications industry. Under Mr. Schacht, Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., shrank its work force to nearly 60,000 employees, from 150,000, by cutting jobs and spinning off and selling subsidiaries. Since mid-2000, its stock price has declined more than 80 percent.
Lucent shares fell 15 cents yesterday to close at $6.95.
Stymied by a wave of bankruptcies at small telecommunications companies and slower sales to large established customers, Lucent has had to revise its revenue and open its books to investigators from the Securities and Exchange Commission. During the company's liquidity crisis last year, a group of about two dozen banks agreed to lend Lucent money only if its assets were put up as collateral.
Mr. Schacht has vowed to return Lucent to profitability this year by cutting costs and focusing on selling gear to large telephone companies. But in light of Lucent's losses and the continued weakness in the telecommunications industry, some investors have called that goal unrealistic. 
Analysts and executives have also questioned Mr. Schacht's assessment that the telecommunications equipment industry will recover by 2003, allowing Lucent's business to grow at least 10 to 12 percent a year. They note the glut of communications network capacity created by entrepreneurial companies in the late 1990's, and they say that oversupply could curb equipment spending for another year or two. 
An executive at one of Lucent's largest customers, Verizon Communications, praised Ms. Russo's appointment yesterday. "Pat knows the customer base extremely well," said Lawrence T. Babbio Jr., Verizon's vice chairman. "As an insider, she brings knowledge of a very complex industry to the table."
But Mr. Babbio expressed caution about the state of the communications equipment industry, in which Lucent is the largest manufacturer. "At the end of the day, equipment purchases have to be driven by demand," Mr. Babbio said. "Right now we have too much inventory."
Mr. Schacht, for his part, defended Ms. Russo's appointment and Lucent's prospects yesterday. "She understands the industry and meets our criteria of having been a proven C.E.O. or C.O.O. of a multinational," he said. "Pat knows how to execute the plan that will put us on firm footing again." 
During its search, which was organized in part by the executive search firm Spencer Stuart, Lucent approached several high-powered executives, including Edward J. Zander, president of Sun Microsystems, and W. James McNerney Jr., the General Electric executive who became chief executive of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing last year.
But Lucent submitted a formal offer only to Ms. Russo, after the board met on Dec. 14. Mr. Schacht flew late last month to Boca Raton, Fla., where Ms. Russo has a vacation home, and the two discussed the offer over lunch on Dec. 29. 
According to a person close to the talks, Ms. Russo's annual base salary will be $1.2 million, or slightly more than Mr. Schacht's $1.1 million. Lucent said it would disclose Ms. Russo's other benefits in a filing with the S.E.C. in coming weeks.

HEADLINE: Bush Says He May Not Seek Balanced Budget This Year 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
President Bush said today for the first time that he might not propose a balanced budget this year. It would be the first time since 1997 that the government would spend more than it took in.
 Mr. Bush said the causes of the likely deficit were the war and the recession, not his $1.35 trillion tax cut, which increasingly aggressive Democrats have said was to blame in the opening days of this midterm election year. Democrats are hoping to use the economy against Republicans during the campaign. 
 Mr. Bush said he warned months ago that there might be deficits if the country were mired in a recession, a war or a national emergency.
"We're still in all three," the president said.
He then said that raising taxes would be a disaster, even though Democrats have not called for increases.
The president's comments, made at a White House meeting with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, within 90 minutes after Mr. Bush returned from 12 days at his Texas ranch, reflected his latest political moves linked to the languishing economy.
Mr. Bush also said he would include in his budget, to be submitted on Feb. 4, a stimulus plan to help unemployed workers. An earlier stimulus proposal died in fighting between the White House and Senate Democrats in December. Congress is to return to Washington on Jan. 23.
"I hope that when Congress comes back they will have listened to their constituents and that Congress will realize that America, like me, is tired of partisan bickering," Mr. Bush said at the meeting with Mr. Greenspan, which included Vice President Dick Cheney and Mr. Bush's senior economic and political advisers.
Moments after the president opened up what amounted to the day's political war, Democrats and Republicans began busily trading accusations and awakening the capital from a postholiday lethargy.
After the president's remarks, Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi and the minority leader, said on Oliver L. North's conservative radio talk show that Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota and the majority leader, was "Doctor No" and that he was blocking the president's economic agenda. Democrats, Mr. Lott added, "should lead, follow or get out of the way." 
Mr. Lott also accused the Democrats of hitching their hopes to a faltering economy. "I think they have concluded that a good economy is bad politics and a bad economy can work to their benefit," he said.
Democrats responded that Mr. Bush was falsely accusing them of calling for tax increases when they were not. Some Democrats, however, have asked Mr. Bush to rescind tax cuts that have not yet gone into effect.
"He's having a debate without an opposition here," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, who was commenting in the place of Mr. Daschle, who was in Hawaii. "He says he wants the partisan bickering to stop, and then he creates a straw man like this."
Mr. Dorgan, echoing other Democrats, also said the president should not include the economic stimulus package in his budget, which would not be passed until April 15 at the earliest. That would delay help for the unemployed for too long, he said.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, said in a statement that he had "not heard one Democrat say he or she wants to raise taxes."
"This is a partisan blame game," the statement said, "and it has no place in the debate about the future economic health of this country."
Officials in the White House Office of Management and Budget would not say today how far they expected the government's $2 trillion annual budget to end up in the red. But Mr. Bush's budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., has said he expects the deficits to be similar to projections by the Congressional Budget Office and those developed by analysts of both political parties. 
The Democratic staff of the House Budget Committee has estimated that the deficit would be at least $43 billion next year and probably $70 billion or more.
The Republican staff of the Senate Budget Committee has estimated that the government would have a $1 billion surplus next year, though Republicans have said that they assume the deficit would end up in the tens of billions of dollars after the near certainty that Congress approves more money for fighting the war.
The Pentagon is seeking a substantial increase, about $20 billion or more, for its 2003 budget, senior military officials have said. That would be about a 6 percent increase over the current $329 billion Pentagon budget. Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld is expected to argue that the Pentagon should stockpile laser- and satellite-guided weapons, which cost $20,000 to $1 million each.
"It makes sense to spend money necessary to win the war," Mr. Bush said. "It makes sense to spend money necessary to protect the homeland."
Mr. Daniels has said that some domestic programs, like the Women, Infants and Children Program that provides food to poor children and pregnant women, would get more money under the administration's budget.
But Congressional aides in both parties say that the administration intends to freeze or cut many other programs, including those run by the Smithsonian Institution.

Mr. Bush, who will unveil his budget on Feb. 4, sat between Vice President Dick Cheney and Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill. (Photographs by David Scull for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
President Acknowledges Budget Deficit Is Likely
President Bush said for the first time that he might not have a balanced budget this year, which would be the first time since 1997 that the United States government would spend more than it takes in.
 Mr. Bush attributed the likely deficit to the costs of fighting the war and on the recession, and not on his $1.35 trillion tax cut, as many Democrats have done. Page A16. 

Xerox to Fight S.E.C. on Accounting
Xerox served notice that it intended to fight the Securities and Exchange Commission, which the company said had concluded that the method that Xerox uses to account for leases was improper. C2.

Fight Over Hewlett Deal Intensifies
The proxy fight for the future of Hewlett-Packard became increasingly personal and acerbic as the company's board characterized as "inaccurate and inappropriate" recent statements by the dissident director Walter B. Hewlett. Mr. Hewlett, who is the leading the fight against Hewlett's planned acquisition of Compaq Computer, replied with a statement, dismissing the board's letter as "a careful construct of fine lines and half-truths." C4.

Stocks Drift Lower in Quiet Trading
The stock market drifted lower in quiet selling. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 62.69 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,197.05. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.62 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,164.89. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index lost 22.28 points, or 1.1 percent, to 2,037.10. C9.

Compaq Switches Forecast to Profit
Compaq Computer said that it would report stronger-than-expected sales for the fourth quarter and turn a profit instead of the narrow loss it had predicted. C4.

New Jersey Ford Plant May Close
The Ford pickup plant in Edison, N.J., might be shut down as part of the major reorganization plan that the automaker is set to announce Friday, a top Ford official said. C6.

Relaxation of Pollution Rules Urged
Federal regulators have recommended that the White House relax pollution rules affecting an array of industries and power plants, a move that environmental groups say would constitute the biggest rollback of the Clean Air Act since it was enacted 30 years ago. A1.

Carnival Seen Seeking Delay of Vote
Gearing up for its latest offensive in the battle for P&O Princess Cruises, Carnival plans this week to request the postponement of a shareholder vote as it seeks clarification of the cost of breaking up a rival deal with Royal Caribbean, people close to Carnival said. C6.

ImClone Shares Fall on F.D.A. Letter
Shares of ImClone Systems plunged more than 17 percent after a leaked letter from the Food and Drug Administration raised doubts both about whether the company can obtain approval for its cancer drug, Erbitux. The letter, sent by the F.D.A. to the company in December, explained why the agency had declined to review an application to market the drug. Shares of ImClone fell $7.66, to $35.83. C7.

Subpoena Issued for Pfizer Chief
Federal investigators have issued a subpoena to Pfizer's chief executive after the company refused to provide information about the prices of its prescription drugs. C9.

HEADLINE: THE INDIA-PAKISTAN TENSION: DIPLOMACY; 
Musharraf Sees Blair and Plans to Announce Steps Against Extremists

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
Urging restraint on India and Pakistan, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain flew here today from New Delhi and met with President Pervez Musharraf, who said Pakistan "rejects terrorism in all its forms and manifestations." 
 General Musharraf said he would spell out the steps Pakistan planned to take to fight violent extremists in a speech in the next few days. 
 Those steps, in addition to further restrictions on militant groups, may include bans on hate speech at Muslim schools and an end to open fund-raising for Islamic militants, officials said.
Western diplomats and Pakistani officials expressed hope that the speech, which could be delivered as early as Wednesday or Thursday, would provide a basis for scaling down the precarious buildup of military forces along the border and starting talks aimed at ending the crisis between the nuclear-armed rivals that began on Dec. 13 with an attack on India's Parliament. 
But even after the visit by Mr. Blair, India's government again rejected calls for dialogue, charging that Pakistan had not yet proved its sincerity in cracking down on the Islamic militant groups that India blamed for the attack.
"There's no question of any dialogue with Pakistan when there is no change in its attitude," India's foreign minister, Jaswant Singh, told reporters after a cabinet security meeting today attended by Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee.
Today the two sides continued shelling each other in divided Kashmir, the predominantly Muslim border region they both claim, and about 20 people were reported killed there in shootouts. Large numbers of troops remained on high alert along the entire 1,800-mile border.
Officials said General Musharraf would meet with senior political and military advisers beginning on Tuesday to agree on measures to be announced in his speech. 
The general will have to tread a delicate line between persuading foreign countries of his determination to curb Islamic militancy and not appearing to jettison the cause of Kashmir, which has been so vital to Pakistanis since the country's inception in 1947.
General Musharraf, who often speaks in English, is considering delivering the speech in Urdu, advisers said, underscoring his need to convince a restive public that curbing religious fanaticism is vital to Pakistan's future.
"We have a plan for checking extremism in our society," General Musharraf said tonight at a news conference with Mr. Blair, emphasizing that he had initiated measures to halt terrorists and slash the number of guns in the country even before the attacks on the United States on Sept. 11.
In the last year, the general started a campaign to collect illegal automatic weapons, which swamped the country during successive wars in neighboring Afghanistan, and in August he banned the military wings of two Muslim sectarian groups that were involved in growing violence and assassinations inside Pakistan.
In recent weeks, under the shadow of India's military buildup and at the urging of Western countries, General Musharraf has intensified that campaign, arresting the leaders of two groups dedicated to jihad, or Islamic holy war, in Kashmir and detaining several hundred followers of those and other militant religious organizations. 
Vans are no longer been permitted to drive through Pakistan's towns and cities openly seeking recruits to holy war.
Pakistani officials say they have been frustrated by India's vague, increasing demands and its refusal to acknowledge the genuine and politically difficult steps General Musharraf has already taken to rein in the militants.
India, taking a cue from Washington and its unyielding military campaign in Afghanistan, has used the specter of war to push for all the concessions it can get from Pakistan over an issue that strikes deep emotional chords in both countries.
Pakistani political experts warn, though, that an effort by India to humiliate General Musharraf may backfire. "No Pakistani government can be seen to be caving in to Indian dictates," said Pervais Iqbal Cheema, president of the Islamabad Policy Research Institute, an autonomous study center.
After Sept. 11 and the formation of an international coalition to destroy the Taliban and Al Qaeda, General Musharraf made a wrenching change in policy, ending years of Pakistani support for the Taliban and joining in the American-led campaign.
But two egregious acts on Indian territory -- a suicide bombing on Oct. 1 at the state legislature in Srinagar, in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, that killed 40 and the attack on the Parliament in New Delhi on Dec. 13, in which 14 people including the five attackers died -- threw the spotlight on fervent Muslim groups that have waged an increasingly violent struggle to end Indian rule in the southern part of Kashmir.
India charges, and Western diplomats agree, that Pakistan has aided such groups in the past. Pakistan makes the case, in turn, that India has been brutal and violated human rights in its effort to suppress a legitimate political movement.
In recent days, despite the evidence of a crackdown in Pakistan, Indian officials have said they are unconvinced. In part that is because Pakistani officials still talk about the struggle for liberation in Kashmir and in part because they have felt betrayed by General Musharraf in the past, when friendly meetings were followed by new attacks in the territory.
Indian officials also charge that Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence agency, which funneled support to the Taliban and to Kashmir fighters in the past, may not be fully within the general's control -- a charge that he firmly denies. 
General Musharraf has changed the director of the agency and quietly transferred many of its hard-liners to different jobs.
The Kashmir dispute has alarmed Washington and London, which fear a splintering of the global war on terror as well as the danger of a cataclysmic war.
Mr. Blair, after three days in India and a day in Pakistan, did not appear to have achieved any breakthrough. But he said tonight that he felt both sides understood that the crisis could abate only if two principles were followed: that Pakistan unequivocally renounce terrorist violence and that both sides pull back troops and engage in dialogue.
Mr. Blair, who later flew on to Afghanistan, noted the material benefits that Pakistan had gained by joining with the global coalition against the Taliban and Al Qaeda -- including debt rescheduling, trade concessions and promises of economic and military aid -- and praised General Musharraf for his vision.
The American ambassador here, Wendy J. Chamberlin, said the United States planned to support Pakistan's crackdown through aid in three areas: improving an education system that too often breeds religious extremism, improving the quality of the police and law enforcement and boosting trade and investment.
"I really believe that creating jobs in this country is a way to protect American lives," she said.

HEADLINE: Propelled by Drug and Hospital Costs, Health Spending Surged in 2000 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
National health spending shot up 6.9 percent to $1.3 trillion in 2000, the government said today. It was the largest one-year percentage increase since rising costs led President Bill Clinton to propose guarantee health insurance for all Americans in 1993.
 Hospital and drug costs were the main factors in the latest increase. The report also cited more spending on Medicare and resistance to the constraints of managed care. 
 Growth in health spending outpaced the 6.5 percent growth of the economy as a whole in 2000 (before adjusting for inflation), the figures show. Health care now accounts for 13.2 percent of the nation's total output, up from 13.1 percent in 1999 and 12 percent in 1990.
Numbers in the report help explain why health care is roaring back as a potent issue in this election year.
The report, from the Department of Health and Human Services, says health costs and spending are likely to climb faster even though the economy has been weak. As a result, it says, consumers will have to spend more of their own money on health care, and employers may be less inclined to offer health insurance to workers because health benefits have become more expensive.
"Increased job layoffs in the slowing economy will lead to a less competitive job market, reducing private employers' incentive to shoulder rising health care costs, potentially increasing the number of uninsured persons," said the report, published today in the journal Health Affairs. "Competition may force employers to shift a larger share of rising costs to workers, who may no longer be able to afford accelerating out-of-pocket costs. Fewer employers may offer health insurance, and the recently unemployed are often left without coverage."
Consumer groups and employers have sporadically issued reports documenting a rise in drug prices and insurance premiums. But today's report is the first authoritative, comprehensive government study that pulls together data for all parts of the health care industry.
"The new national health spending estimates may well mark the end of an era of reasonably affordable health care cost growth," said Katharine R. Levit, chief author of the report. Ms. Levit is director of the national health statistics group at the department's Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services.
The surge in health costs puts pressure on politicians to respond, but also makes them anxious about the cost of expanding public programs or offering large new subsidies for the purchase of insurance. President Bush and Congressional Democrats have offered rival proposals to provide health benefits to the unemployed and prescription drugs for the elderly.
The nation spent an average of $4,637 on health care for each person in the United States in 2000, up from $4,377 in 1999, $4,001 in 1997 and $2,966 in 1991. These numbers were not adjusted for inflation.
Ms. Levit predicted "a stronger increase in the health spending share of gross domestic product in the near future." Health care employment, prices and premiums all increased last year, she said.
The study identifies two main reasons for the surge in health spending: resistance to managed care by doctors, hospitals and consumers, and a decision by Congress to restore money cut from Medicare, the federal program for the elderly and disabled, which accounts for 17 percent of all health spending.
"Consumers increasingly choose less restrictive forms of managed care," which cost more than health maintenance organizations, the report said. In addition, it observed, "the consolidation of hospitals into networks and systems" has increased their bargaining power, so they can extract higher payments from H.M.O.'s and other insurers.
National health spending rose $83.9 billion in 2000, and hospital care and prescription drugs accounted for 45 percent of the increase.
Spending on hospital care rose by $19.9 billion, or 5.1 percent, to $412.1 billion, while drug spending grew $17.9 billion, or 17.3 percent, to $121.8 billion.
The figures for hospitals were significant because hospital spending had not risen more than 4 percent in any year since 1993. Outpatient hospital revenue is growing twice as fast as inpatient revenue. Hospitals say they need the money to cover rising labor costs. Weekly wages paid to workers in private hospitals rose 4.1 percent in 2000; in 1999, the figure was 2.3 percent, the report said.
Congress slowed the growth of Medicare when it passed the Balanced Budget Act of 1997. But an all-out lobbying campaign by hospitals and other health care providers persuaded lawmakers that the cuts had begun to harm patients. So Congress, in 1999 and 2000, passed laws increasing payments to providers.
"Medicare hospital spending made a comeback in 2000, similar to that in nursing homes and home health agencies," the report said.
The growth in prescription drug spending slowed a bit from 1999 to 2000, but drugs were still the fastest-growing category of health spending. Drug spending increased 19.2 percent in 1999 and 17.3 percent in 2000, the sixth consecutive year of double-digit growth. 
Total national spending on prescription drugs doubled in the five years from 1995 to 2000 and tripled in the decade from 1990 to 2000, according to government data.
The report cites several reasons for the rapid increase, including the effects of prescription drug advertising, wider availability of insurance to cover drug costs, an increase in the number of prescriptions written by doctors and a shift toward greater use of new, higher-price drugs. Some drugs can reduce health spending by reducing the need for hospital care, economists say, but that is not true of all drugs.
Hospitals accounted for 31.7 percent of all health spending in 2000, down from 42 percent in 1982. By contrast, prescription drugs accounted for 9.4 percent of the total in 2000, double their share in 1982.
The report also said that private health insurance premiums increased 8.4 percent in 2000, to a total of $444 billion, after rising less than 7 percent a year from 1996 to 1999. 
In addition, Medicare spending on home health care rose 0.8 percent in 2000, the first increase in four years. Medicare spending for home care had declined by more than 35 percent from 1996 to 1999, after growing for years at double-digit rates.
The report also said that spending for nursing homes bounced back in 2000, after growth slowed from 1995 to 1999. Spending rose 3.3 percent in 2000, to $92.2 billion.

HEADLINE: Deficit Politics Returns 

 BODY:
It did not take long after the New Year for President Bush and the Democrats to resume their squabbling over taxes and the federal budget. Unfortunately, their arguments have been covered with so much political padding that the country can hardly be expected to follow them.
 The tax cuts of 2001 have left the federal government ill equipped to deal with the demands of fighting both terrorism and a domestic recession. Congress scheduled most of the cuts to take place a few years from now. Projections by both the Democratic and Republican Congressional budget staffs suggest that unless at least some of them are derailed, the nation will plunge more deeply into debt or be forced to cut critical programs. 
 Mr. Bush has access to the same information everyone else does, but instead of making plans for a graceful retreat he seems determined to box himself into a hard-right scenario of continuing to cut taxes, mainly for the wealthy, at a time when more and more poor and middle-class Americans are finding themselves out of work.
Mr. Bush's behavior has been very much governed by his desire as chief executive to avoid the mistakes that cost his father a second term. The first President Bush, of course, vowed to oppose new taxes in his famous "read my lips" speech. Later, in a genuine act of bipartisanship, he went along with a compromise with Democrats to lower the deficit with a package of spending cuts and tax increases. The younger Mr. Bush has always drawn the wrong lesson from this story. He has told innumerable people that he will not make his father's mistake of provoking the wrath of the right wing. But the elder President Bush's mistake was not in agreeing to tax increases that helped set the stage for the big recovery of the 1990's -- it was making the reckless no-new-taxes promise in the first place. The public did not punish him for raising taxes but for breaking his word.
On the Democrats' side, the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, is on the attack himself, attempting to convince the country that last year's tax cuts were a prime cause of the current recession and budget deficit. Attentive listeners might presume that Mr. Daschle would want to see those destructive cuts repealed, but he has so far remained coyly silent. He is said by aides to be undertaking a slow path to an eventual confrontation with the currently popular president. That may make sense politically. But Mr. Daschle needs to start preparing the public for that moment by speaking out about the tough choices posed by the budget. 
Neither the president nor Congress has any easy solutions to these problems. Both sides only face some difficult choices. It would be best if they started talking about them candidly.

HEADLINE: The Quiet Man 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
On Sunday newspapers headlined George W. Bush's declaration that future tax cuts would be canceled "over my dead body." But the only news there was Mr. Bush's choice of words -- words he hasn't repeated, probably because his aides realized that they didn't sound very presidential, and were in poor taste in light of recent events.
 The interesting news story on economic policy, it seems to me, involves someone else -- and it involves his silence, not his words. Whatever happened to Alan Greenspan, the high priest of fiscal responsibility? 
 About Mr. Bush: Surely nobody expected him to give an inch, even though the surplus projections that were used to sell the tax cut have turned out to be nonsense. The Bush administration operates on the principle of "no enemies on the right"; it also operates on the principle that Mr. Bush is infallible. Whatever policies he may have proposed in the past, his aides always insist that they are perfectly suited to the present -- indeed, were devised with the present situation in mind. It's actually quite funny, though nobody dares say so.
 Last month, for example, Karl Rove explained that the tax cut, although originally proposed amid an economic boom, was designed to cope with the current recession. "All the signs were there in the second, if not the second, the third quarter of 2000," Mr. Rove said. When a questioner gently pointed out that Mr. Bush had laid out his tax plan way back in 1999, Mr. Rove brushed him aside. 
 And since Mr. Bush is infallible, why should he ever reconsider his decisions?
 But back to Alan Greenspan. A year ago Mr. Greenspan gave the new Bush administration decisive aid in its push for a large tax cut. Worrying that the national debt would be paid off too quickly, he urged Congress to cut taxes in order to put the budget on a "glide path" of gradually declining surpluses. 
 Some glide path; more like a nosedive. In 2000 America ran a record surplus; now, analysts from both parties agree that the federal budget will be in deficit for at least the next several years. They still project surpluses for late in the decade -- but if you believe those projections, I've got some Enron stock you might want to buy. 
 Mr. Greenspan ought to be upset. It's not just that during the Clinton years he became an icon of fiscal probity; the sudden plunge back into deficit undoes his own handiwork.
 You see, back in the early 1980's, before he became Fed chairman, Mr. Greenspan headed a commission that was supposed to secure the future of Social Security. The main result of that commission was an increase in payroll taxes, even as Ronald Reagan was cutting income taxes. The purpose of this regressive tax increase -- payroll taxes fall most heavily on low- and middle-income families -- was to generate a surplus that would, in turn, make it easier for the federal government to pay benefits to an aging population.
 But now, thanks to the disappearance of the budget surplus, the excess revenue collected by the payroll tax isn't being used to acquire assets, or even to pay down the federal debt; it's being used to cover deficits elsewhere in the budget. We're not talking small numbers here; only about 70 cents of each dollar in Social Security revenue is used to pay current benefits. In effect, the other 30 cents has now been expropriated for other uses -- mainly tax cuts for the richest few percent of the population. 
 Was this what Mr. Greenspan intended -- to raise taxes on the poor and the middle class, so that they could be cut for the rich? If not, why doesn't he say something? After all, a word from him could alter the landscape of economic debate, just as it did a year ago.
 It's true that to give that word Mr. Greenspan would have to admit, at least tacitly, that he was wrong last year. But he's not a politician up for re-election -- and if he's worried about his reputation, he should realize that if he continues to be silent history will not judge him kindly. Right now the provisional verdict is that he was a hypocrite: he sternly demanded fiscal responsibility while Democrats were in office, but had no complaints -- indeed, acted as an enabler -- as a Republican administration quickly squandered the fruits of all that austerity.
 That verdict doesn't have to stand. All it would take would be a few carefully chosen remarks. I'm all ears.

HEADLINE: Showing in Canada: The Mystery of the Falling Dollar 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
It's hard to say what they are, but Americans generally love them and Canadians hate them: the mysterious forces that have pushed the value of Canada's dollar relentlessly downward to new lows in recent weeks.
 The Canadian dollar -- nicknamed the loonie because of the loon depicted on dollar coins -- has been declining fairly steadily for three decades, a drop that has angered Canadians and puzzled the nation's leading economists. Experts are at a loss to explain why the exchange rate continues to erode even when the economy itself is fundamentally sound. 
 "Economists and others have run out of excuses to explain why the currency remains weak," said Alister Smith, deputy chief economist for the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in Toronto. "What's puzzling for a lot of Canadians is the fact that economists and others have said that once we improve the fiscal situation and stop running deficits, the currency will improve. Well, we've managed to do all that, but the exchange rate still hasn't improved." 
The deteriorating exchange rate has made Canada a bargain for American businesses, which have been buying Canadian companies in bunches, and for American tourists. 
At the same time, the weak Canadian dollar makes the United States and its products more expensive for Canadians, who have grown accustomed to buying American imports and taking vacations south of the border.
The value of the Canadian dollar has steadily declined since April 25, 1974, when it was worth $1.04. During trading on Dec. 24, 2001, it reached its lowest value so far, 62.3 American cents -- about 1.6 Canadian dollars to the United States dollar -- before recovering slightly. That capped a typically bad year in which the Canadian currency lost 6.25 percent of its value. It traded yesterday at 1.5988 to the dollar.
The deteriorating Canadian dollar is puzzling because it appears to defy positive indicators. For example, over the weekend the governor of the Bank of Canada, David A. Dodge, said the Canadian economy might actually have grown, however slightly, in the last quarter of 2001. If so, that would mean Canada has not technically entered a recession because it had only one previous quarter without growth in 2001. 
Despite that better-than-expected performance, the Canadian currency plummeted to new lows in the last quarter of 2001. Economists expect it to stay in that range for the rest of this year.
"Such things do cause people to scratch their heads," Mr. Smith said.
While unable to provide definitive answers for the question of what ails the Canadian dollar, economists have identified factors contributing to its plight. They say it has been undermined by a capital outflow as investors search for the most secure markets. That trend was worsened by a change in Canadian law that allowed a greater share of Canadians' individual retirement accounts to be invested in foreign securities -- 30 percent instead of 20 percent. 
Productivity may also be a factor. Much of the sophisticated equipment needed to improve productivity must be imported, and it is generally priced in ever more expensive American dollars. Companies in Canada usually find it easier, and cheaper, simply to add more workers and pay them in Canadian dollars instead of buying new equipment.
Some economists have argued that the declining currency makes a compelling argument for adopting a common North American currency with the United States and Mexico. But that would require Canada to surrender its ability to control interest rates, one of the most important tools in preserving the country's limited ability to steer its own economy. 
Of course, not every Canadian is unhappy about the nation's shrinking dollar. Some exporters like it because a weak currency gives Canadian exports a price advantage in foreign markets.
Dr. Sherry Cooper, chief economist at BMO Nesbitt Burns in Toronto, said some of Canada's political leaders also seemed to think that a weak currency was not particularly bad because of its positive effect on exports. But they should be more concerned, she said, because the weak Canadian dollar "amounts to a national pay cut."
Similarly, the Canadian economy's heavy reliance on commodity exports like oil, gas, timber, minerals and grain, which are usually priced in American dollars, ought to be generating bumper earnings in terms of the Canadian currency. But the global prices of most of those commodities are low now as the world economy sputters. 
Since 1970, Canada has had a floating exchange rate, which means that the market, not the government, determines the currency's value. As long as the market prefers other currencies, Dr. Cooper said, Canada's currency will continue to deteriorate.
"There's no magic potion," she said, "that will turn the Canadian dollar around."

HEADLINE: Soviet Hotel In Moscow To Be Razed 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
A hulking glass, stone and concrete 1970 eyesore in the heart of Moscow, the Intourist Hotel, shut its doors for good today and awaits demolition, as the city prepares to remove a major Soviet-era wart from its skyline for the first time since the fall of Communism.
 The hotel, owned by the Moscow city government and situated half a block from the Kremlin at 3 Tverskaya Street, is 22 stories if you include the karaoke Chinese restaurant in the basement. The city says it wants a more glamorous, smaller building -- 12 stories are planned -- to better fit the otherwise elegant block, which includes a theater and another hotel, built in 1903. 
 The demolition is purely cosmetic, authorities say, and not related to security concerns raised worldwide after the terrorist attacks on the United States in September. Moscow is in talks with Hilton, the international hotel chain, over the management of the new hotel. 
As Russia's economy expands and state-owned stores and restaurants are gradually replaced by private enterprises, hotels like the Intourist have become relics of the past.
Built for foreign visitors, who by Soviet rules were required to stay in special locations under supervision, the hotel was a strange combination of East meets West as guests rubbed up against traders looking to make an illegal buck.
The 434-room hotel was erected in 1970, at the end of an unfortunate building streak that led to the bulldozing of sections of this city's historic downtown district. 
The hotel served many noted -- and notorious -- guests over the last three decades, including French and Russian astronauts. Aristotle Onassis, according to the Russian daily Izvestiya, was rebuffed by the Soviet government in an attempt to build his own hotel on the spot. 
After the fall of the Soviet Union, one of the most powerful crime figures in Moscow, Otari Kvantrishvili, rented an office in the hotel before he was assassinated in 1994. Two years ago, a bomb ripped through the top two floors in what authorities believe was part of a business dispute. And in a moment fondly remembered by many of the hotel's employees, a leading actress in a Mexican soap opera that was highly popular in the 1990's, called "The Rich Also Cry," came for a brief stay.
Today, a white piano, locked up and benchless, was the only thing that remained in the hotel's first-floor atrium, where guests used to sit and sip tea. Tables were stacked, chairs gone, and the central fountain no longer spouted. A woman worker removed lacquered Russian dolls from a glass cabinet nearby. 
Up on the fourth floor, 64-year-old Zoya Timoshina, the hotel's main cashier for all of its 31 years, was shuffling through papers in her small office, preparing for her departure. The hotel's closing leaves approximately 450 employees without jobs, according to its management.
"It's sad to leave, but it is time," she said, looking wistfully around her small office. "I came here as a young beauty, and now am going away as a grandmother. We earned good money. I had a driver, and a heater in my room. It's a good building. They have these in America."
The hotel's management opposes the demolition, which so far does not have an official starting date and will be done piece by piece with cranes instead of explosives. They say the hotel was profitable and could have been upgraded for much less than the $130 million the city expects is needed to rebuild completely. And compared with prices in the hundreds of dollars at the prestigious five-star hotels nearby, the National and Metropole, the Intourist was a bargain.
"We charged $50 a night for a room in the center of Moscow -- what do you want?" said Alexander Kolesnikov, deputy director of the hotel, responding to criticism that the building is unsightly. "Tourists loved this place. We had almost a 100 percent occupancy rate. Every epoch has its buildings. Why do we need to destroy this one? What about the McDonald's nearby -- does that fit?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Intourist, a hotel near the Kremlin, was built in 1970. It is a reminder of the Soviet era in an area that seeks more modern elegance. (Paul Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Club Med Has First Loss in 4 Years and Closes 6 More Resorts 

BYLINE:  By KERRY SHAW 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
Reflecting the plunge in international travel since Sept. 11, the resort operator Club Mediterranee said today that it would close six more of its locations and eliminate its dividend.
 The company reported a loss of 70 million euros ($62.5 million) for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, its first loss in four years and a sharp reversal of fortune from the previous year. 
 Club Med, which operates more than 100 "villages" on beaches and ski mountains around the world, cited the chilling effects of the Sept. 11 attacks on travel and the gathering recession in the United States for the company's weak results. 
"We are flying blind; it's not very comfortable," the chairman of Club Med, Philippe Bourguignon, told Reuters.
The company said in a statement today that its overall bookings were 19 percent lower in December than in the previous winter season and that travelers were making reservations much later than before. Bookings at a few villages gained from the trend, notably those at European ski resorts, where late bookings pushed overall business up 13.1 percent.
The company has not yet sorted out what the long-term effects will be. 
"It is clear that since Sept. 11, reservation habits have changed," the company said. "In these exceptional circumstances it would be unreasonable to give any forecasts."
Analysts said they had been expecting rocky results from Club Med and were not surprised by the figures. The company's stock fell 1.58 euros, or 3.4 percent, to 45.47 euros ($40.58) a share.
But the results nonetheless undermined Mr. Bourguignon's standing in the eyes of some analysts, who cited earlier promises of 10 percent annual profit growth that Mr. Bourguignon, who was brought in to turn the company around in 1997, backed away from last year.
The company said that much of its loss for the year was attributable to the costs of reacting to Sept. 11. Measures announced in October included reorganizing some villages, temporarily closing 24 of them, and shedding 154 jobs at the Paris headquarters.
Revenue rose 5.1 percent for the year, to 1.99 billion euros ($1.77 billion), but not enough to overcome the company's relatively high fixed costs. Unlike many competitors, Club Med owns and operates all its villages, and does not use local franchisees.
The six villages to be closed, scattered from Greece to New Caledonia, bring the total shut in the last year to 15, an 8 percent cut in capacity.
Five more villages, aimed at North American tourists, were shut for the winter season, and analysts expressed concern that the next summer season would also be weak.
Beyond its core business, the company lost 5.6 million euros ($5 million) on its Club Med World Paris retail and entertainment development, and said it would hold off for now on plans to develop similar complexes elsewhere.
But performance was strong at the Gymnase Club chain of French health clubs, which the company acquired a year ago, and at Oyyo, a young-adult-oriented club in Tunisia.

HEADLINE: Philharmonic Moves Into a New Era 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN and ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
With its chairman describing it as "an institution in transition," the New York Philharmonic yesterday announced a host of user-friendly changes for next season including a 7:30 p.m. curtain time, music lectures before performances three times a week and twice-weekly preconcert chamber music programs. The Philharmonic season, scheduled to start on Sept. 18, will be the first under its new director, Lorin Maazel. Mr. Maazel will conduct 11 of the orchestra's 34 subscription weeks.
 The choice of Mr. Maazel was viewed by several music critics as a staid one for the orchestra. As if partly in answer to this charge, the Philharmonic program announced yesterday included 19 works that were world premieres, New York premieres or are to have their first Philharmonic performances. The 10 that have not been played by the orchestra before, however, include established works like a Berlioz opera and a Prokofiev overture and shorter works by Krzysztof Penderecki and William Bolcom. 
 The 125 concerts to be played by the Philharmonic include music by 54 composers, of whom 34 were born or wrote their major works after 1900. While many of those composers are in the mainstream canon, the lineup also features less frequently performed works by Carl Nielsen, Witold Lutoslawski, Charles Ives and Edgard Varese.
"I would say right now this is an institution in transition," Paul B. Guenther, chairman of the Philharmonic, said in an interview after a news conference announcing the season's offerings. Mr. Guenther mentioned the orchestra's educational programs and its parks concerts, neither of which is new, and collaborations with Jazz at Lincoln Center -- the most recent being "Nutcracker Swing," as evidence that Zarin Mehta, the Philharmonic's executive director, has been "wonderful about broadening audience participation." 
Although some critics have suggested that the Philharmonic's repertory should be more adventuresome, Mr. Maazel said he did not believe in doing new work just because it was new. "I don't think playing new work or premieres for the sake of doing so is the name of the game," he said.
"I'm careful to ask all the guest conductors not to perform anything they don't believe in," he added. "We ask them to suggest contemporary music in which they believe."
Similarly, Mr. Guenther said that the orchestra had to strike a balance between testing new waters and hewing to tradition. "It's easy to say we should have people in jeans like they do up at the Miller Theater," he said, referring to the stage at Columbia University. 
"Do you want to have an orchestra in New York City? You've got to maintain the financial integrity of the organization," Mr. Guenther continued. "That doesn't mean you prostitute yourself. But you have to have a cross section to satisfy the city."
According to the master plan for the ambitious $1.2 billion redevelopment of Lincoln Center, the Philharmonic's home, Avery Fisher Hall, has several hundred empty seats at most of its performances -- 61 percent of its productions have fewer than 2,400 seats filled in the 2,738-capacity theater. 
The master plan raises the possibility of eliminating 338 of the hall's seats, to reduce the capacity to 2,400.
Mr. Mehta disputed the master plan's attendance figures yesterday, saying that, with the exception of the weeks immediately after Sept. 11, the orchestra has for the last 10 years sold 88 to 90 percent of its tickets for each performance. "We just have to fight to keep it there," he said. "That's what the problem is." Mr. Guenther said the orchestra was "very stable," that contributions were coming in as scheduled and that there were no plans to cut back despite a tough economic climate for the city's cultural institutions. 
One pressing question concerning the redevelopment -- which calls for spending $325.8 million on Avery Fisher Hall -- is whether the stage should be renovated or razed and rebuilt. While Mr. Maazel would not say which option he favored -- and that the outcome depended on a cost analysis by officials other than himself -- he acknowledged yesterday that the hall is inadequate. "They used to say there are no bad acoustics, just bad conductors," he said. "Having said that, there are limits. And rather than struggle all the time, you are dealing with a hall that is just not up to snuff."
Mr. Maazel added that he was one of the first to conduct at Avery Fisher Hall; the piece was "La Marseillaise," the French national anthem. "I heard it twice," Mr. Maazel said to laughter. "Things were pretty bad. We've come a long way since then."
The Philharmonic has made adjustments to its hall's acoustics since Mr. Maazel's maiden voyage, but many musicians and critics are still dissatisfied with the results.
While Mr. Guenther said Mr. Maazel was not a custodial appointment -- holding his position until the orchestra finds another, long-term maestro -- Mr. Maazel, who is 71, has signed on only through the 2006 season. "If his commitment is for four years," Mr. Guenther said, "we can begin to think about who should be Lorin Maazel's successor."
The season's first world premiere, the details of which have not been announced, is to be performed with Beethoven's Ninth during the first subscription week (Sept. 18-24). The Philharmonic is offering the program as a memorial to the victims of the Sept. 11 attacks.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Corporate America's News Is Mixed, and So Are Shares

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Divergent signals on the state of business left investors cautious and prices mixed on Wall Street yesterday. 
 Optimistic comments from Microsoft and Tiffany encouraged the market, but disappointing statements from Gateway, Ciena and AOL Time Warner limited stocks' ability to advance. 
 Blue chips were weaker, falling back moderately after weeks of rallying, but technology shares managed modest gains. 
 As companies begin releasing fourth-quarter sales and earnings and some warn of weaker results, analysts expect a retreat, with investors cashing in profits from recent rallies.
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 46.50 points, or 0.5 percent, at 10,150.55, after falling 62.69 points Monday to halt a three-session 238-point winning streak.
 "We have earnings season upon us, and you are seeing some profit taking," said Richard A. Dickson, a technical analyst for Hilliard Lyons in Louisville, Ky. "But I don't think it is anything serious. The Dow hasn't shown any conviction on the downside," The Dow's decline yesterday was smaller than the 175 points it has gained so far in 2002. Additionally, the Dow has risen nearly 24 percent from its low after the Sept. 11 attacks.
 The broader market was mixed yesterday. The Nasdaq composite index rose 18.64 points, or 0.9 percent, to 2,055.74, but the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 4.18 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,160.71.
 Investors sold off the stocks of companies that reminded the market how tough business still was. Gateway slid 25 percent, down $2.56 at $7.69, on a fourth-quarter revenue warning.
 Ciena fell $1.05, or 6 percent, to $15.70, after the chief executive, Gary Smith, was quoted by the Dow Jones News Service saying that the company, along with other telecommunications equipment makers, will not rebound in the first quarter.
 "There is no clear sign of recovery," Mr. Smith said at a Salomon Smith Barney conference in Scottsdale, Ariz.
 AOL Time Warner, which reduced its 2002 earnings forecast on Monday, stumbled 68 cents, or 2 percent, to $32.
 While investors' increasing confidence in a healthier economy this year has bolstered stocks, analysts say the market's upside will be limited until there are concrete signs of a turnaround. 
 "Things are definitely looking better. But people are getting very excited, very quickly, and that's when things can pull back," said Gary Kaltbaum, market technician for Investors' Edge Partners.
 Still, positive news from several companies led to some buying. Tiffany climbed $1.95, or 6 percent, to $34.84, after saying its fourth-quarter earnings will be at the high end of previous estimates.
 Optimistic comments from the Microsoft chairman, Bill Gates, helped the technology sector shake off the disappointments from Gateway and Ciena. In a keynote speech late on Monday at the International Consumer Electronics show in Las Vegas, Mr. Gates said that Microsoft sold 1.5 million Xbox units during the holiday season and that it was the most successful game console introduction ever. Microsoft expects to sell six million consoles by the end of 2002.
 Microsoft rose 82 cents, or 1.2 percent, to $69.38, and its strength spread to other technology bellwethers. I.B.M. gained 65 cents, or 0.5 percent, to $124.70, and Intel rose 31 cents, or 0.9 percent, to $35.58.

HEADLINE: Port of Spain Journal; 
Failed Rebel's Boast: At Least He Rules the Street

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad 

 BODY:
Older and seemingly unrepentant, Yasin Abu Bakr, the spiritual leader of the Jamaat al-Muslimeen, has endured, even if its infamous attempt to remake Trinidad did not. 
 In 1990, Mr. Abu Bakr, now 60, and several dozen followers, angered over delays in resolving a land dispute with the government, staged a coup. For six days the radical Black Muslim group held the Parliament hostage and controlled a television station while 26 people died in the ensuing violence. 
 Although he surrendered after being promised amnesty and releasing his hostages, Mr. Abu Bakr and his supporters were arrested, tried and sentenced to death. But in a turn of events that some saw as bordering on theater of the absurd, they were set free after two years in prison when courts ruled that the government had reneged on its promise of immunity.
"Everything happens by the will of God, so if God had willed it not to happen, it would not have happened," Mr. Abu Bakr said of the coup attempt in a recent interview. "But what we can do is reflect on the past, and see how it can help to guide you in the future." 
The fact that his office wall featured -- among other items -- a bumper sticker that read "The Best Is Yet to Come" not too far from an organizational chart of Trinidad's government might still cause some to question his plans. 
Even today, whispers of terrorist links and drug dealing swirl about the Jamaat al-Muslimeen, or Society of Muslims, and government officials say they keep close tabs on it and advise foreign governments when Mr. Abu Bakr travels overseas.
But Mr. Abu Bakr, a former policeman, insisted that today he is interested only in providing spiritual care to thousands of poor and disaffected black Trinidadians who converted to Islam. Although 6 percent of the country is Muslim, a majority are of East Indian descent and do not relate culturally or politically to the Jamaat. 
As he spoke of the moral decline of politics, aides politely interrupted him at times to ask his advice on things like what kind of joiners should be used for a construction job or how long the cement should set for a schoolhouse being built by his group.
"These are not the hands of a cloth priest," Mr. Abu Bakr admitted as he extended his hands to reveal scarred palms and fingers. 
Earlier this year there was speculation over another possible coup when United States authorities arrested a man they said was linked to the Jamaat after he tried to buy assault rifles and automatic pistols in Florida. 
In October, Basdeo Panday, the prime minister at the time, lambasted the group when he said one of its members had called on able-bodied men to fight for Islam in Afghanistan. 
Privately, however, officials of the ruling United National Congress discounted the group's threat. "They are a bogeyman," said one high-ranking party official. "Panday brings them out to scare the children."
Mr. Abu Bakr, who denounced the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States, said the people quoted by the prime minister or arrested by American authorities were no longer associated with his group.
He added that he refused to attend an anti-American rally sponsored by one of them and insisted that he had no designs on political power or terrorist action. "How come nothing has happened to us?" he said. "How come I am not in jail?" 
Ever since they were released from prison and won close to $1 million from the government for wrongful destruction and occupation of their property, Mr. Abu Bakr and his adherents have planned to rebuild. But traces of past conflicts are scattered around the Jamaat's campus. 
For now, they have raised money by building and selling private homes, while building a two-story girls' school near the mosque. They also receive medical supplies from an Islamic charity based in Libya. The group's leaders said they now focused on providing counseling, health care and meals to the community. 
Although the group claims more than 10,000 members, others say the true number is about half that. The group's leaders say they still attract many youths who feel shunned by society. 
"I think that young people are fed up by the system as it exists," Mr. Abu Bakr said. 
One young member said he came to the group after he was stabbed at a party. Another said he grew tired of hanging out in bars and clubs. Others adopted the group after their parents left them to fend for themselves.
Mr. Abu Bakr said his ability to relate to some hard-bitten toughs in some neighborhoods helped his group broker the peace last month between warring gangs whose battles had claimed 37 lives. 
"We do what the government cannot," he said. "We rule the street."
But such closeness to the street, analysts and diplomats said, can come with an unpleasant price. There is widespread suspicion that members of his group have been involved with drug dealing or have hired themselves out as enforcers to collect bad debts. 
One diplomat said the group might no longer be as monolithic as it once appeared. He said that younger members felt that Mr. Abu Bakr was no longer the firebrand he once was and that he would rather tend to his family and business interests.
Maybe that was why the biggest splash Mr. Abu Bakr made in recent months was not about politics or international intrigue, but when he married his fourth wife. Still, there was a sort of international air to it.
"I have one wife who is mixed, an African wife, an Indian wife and one who is another mixture of Chinese and Indian," he said. "I now have the whole United Nations in my family."
