HEADLINE: Old Rules Gone, Argentines Brace for the Unknown 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
For more than a decade, Juan Carlos Meluso and his wife, Silvia Cataldo, awoke each morning knowing that one Argentine peso was worth one American dollar. Although the system was far from perfect, at least the rules were clear. 
 But when banks resume normal activities here Wednesday, after operating under emergency restrictions since before Christmas because of an economic crisis, the Melusos and millions of other middle-class Argentines will confront a brand new, uncertain world. After the peso was devalued by nearly 30 percent Sunday night, fears of a burst of inflation are growing, basic goods are in short supply and the economy remains prostrate. 
 "Nobody has the slightest idea what happens next or how things are actually going to function," Ms. Cataldo said. "It has taken us 10 years to get into this mess, and my biggest fear is that it will take us another 10 years to get out because this new system turns out not to work either."
When it was introduced early in 1991, the policy of pegging the peso to the dollar brought economic stability to Argentina by halting runaway inflation. But in recent years it had increasingly become a straitjacket, crimping economic activity by making imported foreign goods artificially cheap and driving Argentine businesses into ruin.
The Melusos said that back when they and the country were doing well, they earned as much as $2,500 a month between them. But since Argentina entered a recession nearly four years ago, that amount has fallen by more than half. Mr. Meluso, 57, once owned a construction supply business that he inherited from his family, but he had to sell it. Then he hauled all kinds of freight until the recession led to such a dropoff in business that he "couldn't even pay for the maintenance on my truck."
Ms. Cataldo, 45, worked for many years as a podiatrist "with a steady clientele that I worked very hard to build up." But as the recession deepened, people sacrificed what they considered luxuries. Her practice collapsed. "With the crisis, nobody wants to cut their nails, they only want to cut their costs," she said."The only time that people ever came to see me was when they could no longer walk." She has turned to making lamps at home and selling them at barter fairs around the city.
It is little consolation to the Melusos that other people they know are facing similar difficulties. One next-door neighbor who used to have a small plant that manufactured motors for washing machines has gone bankrupt, while the other has moved his leather goods business from a factory into his house because demand has fallen so much.
"The whole country depends on small businesses and commerce being healthy, not just me," Mr. Meluso said. "The president has said that he is going to support producers, but in all the changes that have been announced, I haven't yet heard anyone explain how they are going to get those sectors back on their feet so that people like me can begin to work again."
For younger couples, the situation is even more daunting. Leonardo Coll, a 36-year-old plumber, and Veronica Dimant, a 34-year-old mathematics professor, have been living together for three years in an apartment that is a family inheritance. They worry that prospects will not improve for a long time. "We'd like to have children someday, but it seems foolhardy to do that in the middle of a crisis as serious as this," Ms. Dimant said. "It's hard enough to support the two of us right now, let alone three."
Both Mr. Coll and Ms. Dimant became adults at a time of four-digit annual inflation. So when inflation dropped to less than 10 percent a year after the one dollar, one peso formula was instituted, they were impressed. The first years under that policy also brought other benefits, they recalled.
"We saw a lot of imported goods coming into the country that we had never seen before," Mr. Coll said. "And a lot of people who couldn't afford to buy on credit during the inflation of the 1980's were able to buy appliances."
But with the recession, Mr. Coll found himself competing with other plumbers, "who were always willing to do the job for cheaper than the next guy," and Ms. Dimant grappled with cuts in the education budget. The final blow came last month when, fearing the flight of money abroad, the government imposed a $250-a-week limit on cash withdrawals from bank accounts.
"My phone hasn't rung since, and I don't think it will until people can have access to their money again," Mr. Coll said. "They have got to lift those restrictions if they want to get the economy going again, but there is no sign they are going to do that."
To ease the devaluation's impact on the middle class, the government has ordered that all bank debts up to $100,000 be converted from dollars into pesos. But Mr. Meluso, who is still paying for his 1999 Renault, said that his financial situation was so bad that he would not benefit from the measure.
"It doesn't make a bit of difference whether my car loan is 350 dollars or 350 pesos a month," he said. "No matter how you calculate it, I can't afford to pay back what I owe and am going to have to sell that car."
The Melusos already own their home, and their two children, Federico and Florencia, have jobs and are able to support themselves. But the Melusos have been unable to pay their property taxes and have received letters from the municipal government threatening repossession if they fall further behind.
Ms. Dimant, meanwhile, has spent much of her summer vacation standing in line outside the bank holding her life's savings, along with thousands of other frustrated depositors.
"Nobody can save any money in a situation like this," she said. "I just want to get back the dollars that belong to me. Maybe I should stick them under the mattress, which still looks like the safest place for them in this ghastly situation."

HEADLINE: Surge in Bias Cases Punishes Insurers, And Premiums Rise 

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
Many companies, alarmed by the increasing size of payouts to resolve harassment or discrimination claims by employees, have bought insurance policies over the last decade to protect themselves.
 But insurers, who offered cheap premiums and low deductibles to encourage this new line of business, now find that they underestimated the number of small awards that companies make every year and did not anticipate the growing size of jury verdicts, one-fifth of which are now for $1 million or more. 
 Most are jacking up their rates -- some doubling or tripling them -- while a few have quit the business entirely.
"We are not making money on this coverage line and have not been for some time," said Michael J. Maloney, an executive with Chubb, one of the largest providers of what is called employment practices liability insurance, which covers bias, harassment and similar claims brought by employees. "If carriers don't change the behavior of the last few years, it won't be a viable product for the future." 
While it is difficult to generalize about just how much of an increase in prices companies should expect, premiums could double or triple at some large companies that already pay hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, Mr. Maloney said.
The problem can be traced to an abundance of cheap coverage when the market developed in the early 1990's, according to insurance industry analysts and consultants who specialize in helping companies address problems like sexual harassment. The premiums and deductibles were so low that some corporations thought that they did not have to take potential harassment or discrimination problems seriously, analysts and consultants said.
The companies that bought insurance were able to treat discrimination as "just a cost of doing business," said Freada Klein, a workplace-bias consultant in Cambridge, Mass. They viewed complaints of bias or harassment as outside their control, like a flood or other natural disaster, she said, rather than as something they could address.
With insurance becoming more costly and insurers more careful about which companies they cover, companies will probably have to start thinking hard about what steps they can take to reduce the likelihood of being sued. "There will probably be more attention paid over time," said Phil Norton, an executive with Arthur J. Gallagher & Company, an insurance broker in Itasca, Ill.
When it was introduced a decade ago, employment practices liability insurance seemed like the perfect response to changes in federal law that increased the risks for employers. Congress passed the Civil Rights Act of 1991, which, among other things, gave employees who sued for discrimination the right to demand a jury trial and to seek punitive damages.
Worried about the possibility of multimillion-dollar judgments, many companies sought coverage, although the policies typically do not cover punitive damages. In the last decade, insurers regularly tapped into that fear with aggressive sales pitches pegged to large settlements or jury verdicts in sexual harassment or discrimination cases, as when a jury in Ohio returned a $31 million verdict against Olsten Health Services for age discrimination in 2000 or CBS settled a sex-discrimination lawsuit for $8 million in that same year.
Roughly 30 percent of the companies surveyed in 1999 by the Society for Human Resource Management and Jackson Lewis, a law firm specializing in employment issues, had some sort of employment practices liability coverage.
Companies typically decline to discuss what insurance they have. They worry that acknowledging that they have insurance will either make them targets for suits or leave people with the impression that they have a systemic problem. But most of the very largest companies in the United States have some sort of insurance, according to Mr. Norton of Arthur J. Gallagher.
One large company decided to purchase a policy for the first time in recent weeks, according to Mr. Norton, even though the premiums were 50 percent higher than the ones quoted a year ago.
Some of the higher premiums are inevitable as insurers come to grips with their experience in offering coverage. Insurance companies were eager to offer inexpensive policies as a way to build their business in this new market, and they significantly underestimated their costs. "It was easy to see, as an observer, that they were underpricing," said David Sterling, an insurance broker in Woodbury, N.J.
In addition, many insurers were all too happy to cover companies without paying too much attention to whether the companies were at significant risk for lawsuits. "Controlling risk is very difficult," said Jeffrey M. Tanenbaum, a lawyer with Littler Mendelson, a firm that specializes in employment issues. But insurers, he said, "have done a horrendously bad job at risk."
Despite the greater attention that companies are paying to issues like discrimination and harassment, the costs associated with these complaints have continued to increase. As the number of claims made each year to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has remained steady at roughly 80,000, the awards made in settlements and mediation have increased by nearly two-thirds in the last few years, to nearly $250 million for the fiscal year that ended last September.
Jury awards for employment practices, including wrongful termination, have also increased sharply, according to Jury Verdict Research in Horsham, Pa. The median award rose to $218,000 in 2000 from $151,000 in 1999, and a fifth of all verdicts now top $1 million.
Layoffs caused by the economic downturn are likely to make employers even more vulnerable to lawsuits. "In bad economic times, we see more litigation," Mr. Tanenbaum said.
This flood of litigation has proved too costly for insurers. "Insurance companies cannot afford to underwrite this any more," said Wanda Dobrich, a psychologist with D&D Industrial Consultants in Montclair, N.J. D&D works with companies to educate employees about harassment and discrimination issues.
The problem is not so much the multimillion-dollar awards, although they can be expensive, but the sheer number of relatively small complaints, settlements or awards for tens of thousands each. These smaller amounts quickly add up to significant sums when deductibles are set too low. "You have the death by a thousand cuts," explained Mark Larsen, a consultant at Tillinghast-Towers Perrin, which advises companies on insurance and risk management.
As the overall industry has taken a turn for the worse, especially after Sept. 11, insurers are now raising prices as much as they can. With returns from their investments lower than in previous years and the wholesale insurance companies that typically help share the risk increasingly wary, retail insurers are doing what they can both to minimize their own risks and improve profits.
The problem, according to Mr. Norton of Arthur J. Gallagher, was that the combination of low deductibles and low premiums was a recipe for losses. A small company, for example, might pay just $12,000 for $1 million in coverage with a $5,000 deductible. But that company might easily rack up some $25,000 in claims in a single year, as would many others insured by the same carrier.
"It doesn't work," Mr. Norton said. Today, he added, the insurer is likely to charge the same small company $20,000 for coverage with a $25,000 deductible.
Insurers are likely to put into place even more increases, according to Mr. Norton. "You're going to see insurance carriers continue to wake up and realize that they are losing this money," he said.
What kind of overall increases companies may see is difficult to estimate because pricing depends on many factors. But many insurers are planning to raise premiums about 25 percent in 2002, after double-digit increases in the previous two years, according to Richard S. Betterley, the president of Betterley Risk Consultants in Sterling, Mass., which recently surveyed carriers. "It's now getting into real money," he said.
Employers will also have to absorb much more of the risk by paying significantly higher deductibles, Mr. Betterley added. Some insurers are also decreasing the amount of overall coverage they will offer. While some still say they will offer as much as $50 million in coverage, they may insure companies for only $10 million, he said.
Some insurers have even dropped out of the market. Alistar, a small insurer in California, is no longer writing new policies. General Electric's Employers Reinsurance, which said it was never a significant player in the industry, stopped writing new stand-alone policies in 1999.
What, if any, steps could be taken to prevent lawsuits is debated. Some defense lawyers and insurance brokers argue that companies can do little to prevent claims from unhappy employees. But many companies simply fail to put into practice common-sense policies that would improve their workplaces, according to consultants who work with companies to develop better procedures. The consultants argue that many companies have not addressed brewing problems in their workplaces because they have not had to do so.
While insurers and others have offered services to help companies address any problems they may have, companies have been reluctant to take advantage of this help. "All of the carriers, Chubb included, have come out with loss-prevention products," Mr. Maloney said, but the response has not been overwhelming.
While executives may address issues like the risk of having an executive embezzle money, many of them pay little attention to claims related to how employees are treated. "It's just not on the radar screen until it hits the lawsuit stage," said Robert Wellman, director of risk management for Risk International Services, a consulting firm in Houston.
But he predicts that such approaches will change as companies realize that they need to reduce their risks of being sued. "It's going to get there," Mr. Wellman said.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders and Consumer Borrowing Both Increase 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
Factory orders excluding military aircraft and other equipment rose in November for the second consecutive month, the first back-to-back increase in a year, the government reported today.
 A separate report from the Federal Reserve showed that consumer borrowing rose more in November than at any time in almost six decades as shoppers took advantage of incentives from automakers to buy cars with interest-free loans. 
 The 0.8 percent increase in factory orders came after a 2.9 percent rise in October, the Commerce Department said. A record decline in military aircraft bookings, which vary from month to month, helped push down the value of all factory orders by 3.3 percent, to $321.7 billion, after a 7 percent increase in October. 
The report mirrors the latest surveys on manufacturing from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and the Institute for Supply Management, and it supports comments by Fed officials that the economy is showing signs of recovering from the first recession in a decade.
"I think we are in fact building a foundation for a recovery," Anthony M. Santomero, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, said today. Recent statistics "indicate we are starting to see a better tone in the manufacturing world," he added.
Orders increased in November for computers, semiconductors and autos. Combined with a 10th consecutive decline in factory inventories, the report suggests increased production in coming months.
The Fed report showed that consumer debt increased $19.8 billion in November, or a 14.6 percent annual rate. That comes after a revised $11.2 billion increase in October, or a rate of 8.3 percent.
Low borrowing costs are helping underpin consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the economy. Nonrevolving credit, including auto loans, surged in November.
"Car sales were pretty strong, and most folks feel that there's going to be a recovery in the economy real soon," Mark Vitner, senior economist at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C., said before the report.
Even with a December unemployment rate at a six-and-a-half-year high of 5.8 percent, incentives are enticing buyers. Nonrevolving loans increased $14.4 billion in November after rising $14.7 billion in October.
The consumer credit report does not include loans like mortgages and home equity lines of credit. Refinancing surged to a record in November, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. That may have encouraged consumers to take on more debt for other purchases, like cars.
Credit card and other revolving debt rose $5.4 billion in November after falling $3.5 billion in October.
Still, since increasing at a 10.3 percent rate in the first quarter, borrowing has cooled. Consumer credit grew at a 1.3 percent annual rate in the third quarter after increasing at a 4.6 percent pace in the previous three months.

HEADLINE: Rates Remain High. Blame Bush Budget Or Big Expectations? 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Do budget deficits matter to the economy?
 Senator Tom Daschle, the highest-ranking Democrat in Washington, certainly thinks so. Last week, he blamed the Bush administration's fiscal policies for hampering an economic recovery. "The rapidly disappearing surplus is a key reason long-term interest rates have barely budged," Senator Daschle said. 
 But the economic evidence is not so clear. Though most economists agree that lower long-term rates would open the door to a new expansion, they do not all share the view that the government's worsening finances stopped rates from falling.
"There is just no evidence whatsoever that budget deficits by themselves have any influence on long-term rates," said John H. Cochrane, an economics professor at the University of Chicago. Professor Cochrane said that forecasts for an economic recovery played a much greater role in keeping rates high.
Peter Orszag, an economist at the Brookings Institution, disagrees. "The fact that long-term rates have not tracked the decline in short-term rates is consistent with the decline in the budget outlook," he said. He cited a range of models, including those used by the Federal Reserve and the Congressional Budget Office, that suggest that the Bush administration's budget changes will probably keep long-term interest rates a half to a whole percentage point higher than they would be without those changes.
Yet on Wall Street or in the ivory tower, Mr. Orszag might find himself in the minority. Though not all economists rule out the influence of the federal budget, most give it at best secondary importance.
For those who believe that the swing of the federal budget back into deficit explains why long-term rates have remained high despite cuts in short-term rates, the explanation goes as follows: because of new tax cuts and unanticipated spending, the Treasury Department will have to cancel plans to buy back hundreds of billions of dollars in debt to make up for the lost surpluses. To sell the extra debt to investors, supply-and-demand requires an extra reward -- higher interest rates.
Forecasts of the government's debts certainly have grown. Between May and August, the Congressional Budget Office lowered its estimates for federal surpluses over the next decade by almost $1.8 trillion, or about one-third, solely on account of legislative changes, mostly tax cuts. Economic and technical changes pulled down the surplus estimates by $461 billion more. And that was all before Sept. 11. Since then, Congress and the White House have circulated plans for hundreds of billions in new spending and tax cuts.
But Professor Cochrane was not impressed. "The kind of deficits we're talking about are just puny by international standards," he said. "The No. 1 thing you think about with long-term rates is inflation. If people think inflation's coming, then long-term rates go up."
His argument relies on forecasts about the economy. The sooner a recovery is expected, he explained, the sooner the Fed is likely to start pushing up interest rates to keep inflation under control. If it starts raising short-term rates, businesses will have little incentive to keep rolling over short-term debt rather than borrowing for the long term. For investors to be willing to hold more long-term debt, long-term interest rates would have to rise.
Alan Auerbach, director of the Burch Center for Tax Policy and Public Finance at the University of California at Berkeley, echoed that argument. The recent increase in long-term rates "has got to be attributed to the fact that there's more confidence in the recovery," he said. But the overall balance between the two, he added, is "more a matter of debate and religion at this point than hard evidence."
"There may be some background movement associated with the budget," he said, but "all the discussion of the Clinton period on salutary effects of deficit reduction -- it's just that, a discussion."
Giving the federal budget a smaller role also makes sense to James Goldberg, chief economist at Trust Company of the West in Los Angeles. "It's more expectations of recovery than the government's fiscal policy, although that is not a big plus," he said. "The change in the fiscal situation is just a little icing on the cake." 
At Credit Suisse First Boston's bond trading desks, each of the two theories garnered some credence. "Both are large issues in our market," said Brian Edmonds, co-head of treasury trading at the company.
He cited a big change in expectations about the scope of the government's indebtedness. Not long ago, many experts expected the debt to shrink to nothing. But the situation has turned around. Mr. Edmonds noted that the government issued $23 billion in two-year notes in December, up from only $10 billion in April.
He added, though, that these days, bond traders thinking about higher rates concentrate more on the prospects for an economic turnaround. "The real risk to the market, given where interest rates are right now," he said, "is that we see a much more robust recovery."
The two theories could also interact. "The recovery play itself rather takes away any big Treasury issuance scare," said John Ryding, chief market economist at Bear Stearns. A strong recovery, he reasoned, would generate enough tax revenue to remove the threat of more federal debt. "I don't think the fiscal picture is going to be a big issue," he said.
Mr. Ryding also doubted that the Fed would act quickly to tighten the supply of credit. "I think that the bond market is prematurely pricing in interest rate increases," he said. "I suspect that both short- and long-term interest rates will decline by the middle of this year."

HEADLINE: Europe Plan Would Give Bumped Fliers More Money 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
To the expected relief of bedraggled fliers, the European Commission has proposed a law to make airlines pay at least the equivalent of about $670 to every passenger bumped from a European flight.
 Few expect the measure to become law anytime soon. But the airlines moved quickly to protest the proposal as excessively harsh and menacing to a system of controlled overbooking that they say makes the reservation system flexible and helps bring down their fares. 
 The proposal was prompted in part by incidents like one last year in Madrid on the first day of Spanish schoolchildren's Easter holidays, when more than 300 passengers, including families with youngsters, were bumped off overbooked flights. 
Sensitive to such treatment of passengers, European airlines agreed last May to a kind of passenger bill of rights, similar to one adopted by American carriers in 1999, to stave off legislative action by the European Commission.
Among the airlines' commitments, which are to be enacted in mid-February, is a policy to reward passengers who give up a reservation on an overbooked flight.
So on Monday, the airlines were surprised when the commission's highest transport official, Loyola de Palacio, who happens to be from Spain, proposed a law to make the airlines pay 750 euros, about $670, to every passenger bumped from a flight of fewer than 2,100 miles, and to double the amount for passengers bumped from longer flights.
By contrast, current regulations in force since 1991 require that the airlines pay 150 euros for the shorter flights, and 300 euros for those longer than 2,100 miles.
"The overbooking situation has worsened," said Gilles Gantelet, the spokesman for Ms. de Palacio in Brussels. In 1999, he said, more than 250,000 passengers in Europe were bumped from overbooked flights. And while that represented only a little more than one-tenth of 1 percent of total passengers, he said, "there is no one who does not know someone who has been a victim."
The proposed law, he said, would also require the airlines, as American airlines do, to offer to pay volunteers 100 euros to take a later flight. 
The airlines, as expected, immediately cried foul.
"Unfriendly and untimely," was how Karl-Heinz Neumeister, secretary general of the European Airlines Association in Brussels, described the proposal. Untimely, above all, because European carriers are already suffering from a sharp falloff in air travel after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States. Moreover, he said, the association's passenger bill of rights, which will take effect next month, already contains an American-style proposal for a call for volunteers.
While few expect the proposal ever to become law, Mr. Neumeister said that if it did, it would mean that airlines would indeed have to stop overbooking.
In effect, the proposal is part of a struggle between the airlines and Ms. de Palacio, who came into office seeking to offset what she saw as an imbalance between benefits provided the airlines, like deregulation, and those for passengers.
Spurred by a swelling wave of passenger complaints, Ms. de Palacio began proposing new rules about two years ago that would require airlines to provide services like telling passengers which airline's plane they would be on if a flight was shared by more than one airline, and assuring free phone calls, meals and accommodations to passengers bumped off accidentally overbooked flights. At that time, she also proposed abolishing intentional overbooking.
"An airline ticket is a contract, and as in every contract, there are two parties," Mr. Gantelet said.
Mr. Neumeister said the airlines had argued that overbooking, "if done properly and responsibly, is good for the airlines, good for the economy, and good for low fares." Ms. de Palacio then withdrew the proposal.
Mr. Gantelet rejected the argument, put forth by the airlines, that passengers would opt for the larger statutory payments, saying that many passengers, including most business travelers, who had meetings to attend or appointments to be kept, would not volunteer for later flights.
Mr. Gantelet said that in any case the proposed legislation would require approval by the European Parliament as well as the Commission, the executive arm of the 15-nation European Community, before it would take effect. Such a procedure, he said, would mean the law could not be in effect before 2003 at the earliest.
If the airlines included a satisfactory compensation scheme for bumped passengers in their voluntary code of passenger rights, then the Commission would drop its proposal for legislation, he said.

PERSON: Gustav Rau 

HEADLINE: Gustav Rau, 79, Art Collector And Benefactor of Children 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
The art collector and philanthropist Gustav Rau, who amassed one of the world's major private art collections, died in Stuttgart last Thursday. He was 79.
 He died suddenly in a hospital, his Zurich lawyer, Dietrich Stettler, said. He had been recovering from pneumonia contracted a few months ago; no official cause of death was listed. 
 While working as a medical doctor in Africa, Dr. Rau regularly slipped away to Europe and the United States to indulge his passion for works by the old masters. Using the wealth he inherited from his family, who made money in auto accessories in Stuttgart, Dr. Rau bought hundreds of paintings and sculptures from five centuries, including works by Auguste Renoir, Claude Monet and Paul Cezanne.
Mr. Stettler represented Dr. Rau in his fight with former employees for control of the $600 million collection, which had been stored in a duty-free zone at Zurich airport. Dr. Rau, who never married or had children, willed the collection to the German branch of Unicef. The collection is second only in size to the Thyssen-Bronemisza collection in Madrid, his foundation said.
Dr. Rau "perhaps had a kind of naive attitude," Mr. Stettler said. "He didn't want to be a celebrity. He wanted to concentrate on carrying off his plans" for an investment that would significantly benefit children in the developing world, he added.
Although he prided himself on selecting and personally bidding on each piece, Dr. Rau parted company with most collectors and declined to surround himself with his choices. He had favorites, especially Jean Honore Fragonard's "Portrait of the Duke of Harcourt," but he did not hang art on his own walls. Instead, it was warehoused or on tour.
Dr. Rau, who used a wheelchair, made infrequent public appearances and refused most interviews. In recent months, he agreed to answer questions for The New York Times about his collection, explaining that he decided to invest his wealth in art because he was "wary of traditional investments" after seeing first-hand the economic turmoil in pre-World War II Germany.
He was drafted into the Nazi Wehrmacht at 19 but quickly deserted. At 40 he earned a medical degree, then sold the family business and moved to Africa. He worked first in Nigeria, then in the former Zaire, where he founded a hospital.
His return to Europe in 1997 set off a legal battle, mostly in Switzerland, over his art works. He medicated himself to offset the effects of a stroke and was found wandering the streets, disoriented, near his Monaco apartment. A guardianship ensued, and only after a series of rulings was his control restored last autumn over what he saw as his life's work.
Most of the paintings have already been moved to Germany, where they will be sold gradually to provide funds for vaccines, medical care and clean drinking water for children in the developing world, the German branch of Unicef announced.

HEADLINE: As the Governors Turn, Praise and Bipartisanship 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
Using his brief stint in the governor's office to praise his party's legacy, John O. Bennett, the State Senate president, was sworn in as acting governor this afternoon, and one hour later delivered a State of the State address proclaiming that a decade of Republican rule had left New Jersey a stronger and more prosperous place. 
 Mr. Bennett, who will serve as acting governor for only 84 hours, used his unusual moment in the spotlight to laud the record of Republicans who seized control of the Legislature during a tax revolt 10 years ago, but who lost their majorities during last November's elections. 
 He also noted the accomplishments of Christie Whitman, whose second term officially ends on Monday. Mrs. Whitman, who was elected in 1993 and left office to join the Bush administration last January, led state officials to cut taxes repeatedly during her tenure and also invested in rebuilding New Jersey's crumbling public schools and preserving one million acres of open space, Mr. Bennett said. 
"Christine Todd Whitman often said that we should strive to make New Jersey a better place in which to work, live and raise a family," Mr. Bennett said. "Thanks to her and the direction she set, New Jersey is that better place." 
Mr. Bennett's speech was part of a whirlwind week in the state capitol, where one legislative session will end, a new Legislature will be sworn in and four people will serve as governor over eight days. New Jersey has no lieutenant governor, and a quirk of the State Constitution allows the Senate president to complete the unfinished term of any governor. When Mrs. Whitman left to become administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco assumed the role of acting governor. 
But Mr. DiFrancesco dropped out of the governor's race and did not seek re-election to the Senate, so when his legislative term ended at 11:59 a.m. today, the role of acting governor was passed on to the incoming Senate president. To further complicate matters, last November's elections left the State Senate deadlocked at 20-20, so Mr. Bennett will share the title of Senate president with Richard J. Codey, a Democrat, and each man will serve as acting governor for half the week. James E. McGreevey, a Democrat, is scheduled to be sworn in on Monday to begin a four-year term.
Acknowledging the Republicans' diminished role in the new political landscape, Mr. Bennett also sounded a decidedly bipartisan tone through much of his address. He praised Mr. Codey and Mr. McGreevey, saying he was eager to work with Democrats to cut property taxes, strengthen antiterrorism efforts and improve education. 
But the very fact that Mr. Bennett delivered the address was a sign of the disarray of New Jersey Republicans in the post-Whitman era. Mr. DiFrancesco, who spent the last year in the dual role of senate president and acting governor, had asked to deliver the State of the State address as a kind of valedictory address. Mr. Bennett refused, to the dismay of many Republicans, but he included several complimentary references to Mr. DiFrancesco, calling him "my dear friend and predecessor." 
However awkward their send-off, Republicans said that they reduced taxes while trying to preserve open space and rebuild the schools. Like other states, New Jersey also saw impressive growth during the Whitman administration and cut its welfare roles. Still, analysts disagree whether those improvements were a result of state policies or the robust national economic boom of the 1990's. In keeping with their reputation as social moderates, New Jersey Republicans enacted relatively few restrictions on abortion rights, but pushed for tougher sentences against criminals, such as Megan's Law, which requires that residents be notified when a paroled sex offender moves to their neighborhood. 
"It's a respectable record," said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University. "When we look at education areas, like school construction, they were forced to take actions by the courts, so I don't think they'll ever get much credit for what they've done." 
Since his election, Mr. McGreevey has warned that the state faces a serious budget deficit. Less than an hour after the State of the State address ended today, as Mr. Bennett basked in the congratulations from his colleagues, friends and family, Mr. McGreevey released a terse letter urging both of this week's acting governors to refrain from any discretionary spending. 
"We have an obligation to the residents of the State of New Jersey to work collaboratively and not expend fiscal resources the state does not have," he wrote.

HEADLINE: Judge Overrules Decision Allowing Logging of Burned Trees 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
A federal judge in Montana has blocked a Bush administration decision, issued last month, that would have allowed logging on more than 40,000 acres of the Bitterroot National Forest.
 It was not immediately clear how the administration would respond. The ruling was a setback for the timber industry, which was hoping to begin a large-scale salvaging project immediately for the trees harmed by fires in 2000 before they rot and lose their value. 
 In his opinion, Donald W. Molloy, chief judge of Federal District Court in Missoula, halted the project and took the administration and the Forest Service to task for issuing their decision administratively and avoiding the customary 45-day public appeals process. The move, Judge Molloy said, looked like "an extralegal effort to circumvent the law." 
"It is presumptuous to believe that the agency's final decision has a perfection about it that would not be illuminated by interested comment, questioning or requests for justification of propositions asserted in it," he wrote.
Judge Molloy, who was appointed by President Bill Clinton, argued at some length that the Forest Service action strained credulity and said the idea that a signature by an administration official would carry enough weight to skirt the appeals process was "mystical legal prestidigitation."
The official is Mark Rey, under secretary for natural resources and environment in the Agriculture Department. He signed an administrative order on Dec. 16 that cleared the way for the sale of 176 million board feet of ponderosa pines that are dead or dying from the fires. The Forest Service estimated that the projects would create 4,000 jobs and pump more than $75 million into the local economy. The service also said some of the money from the timber sale would help replant trees and repair stream beds.
Mr. Rey, a former lobbyist for the timber industry, said at the time that the decision to bypass the appeals process was legal. He also said it was necessary because the timber needed to be salvaged quickly and because the environmental groups would sue anyway.
Mr. Rey said the judge's decision, issued late Monday night, was disappointing. He added that he would "work closely with the Department of Justice to determine what the next appropriate steps are." The administration could begin a public appeals process or it could appeal Judge Molloy's decision to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco.
Mr. Rey referred questions to Bill Mercer, United States attorney for the District of Montana, who issued a statement saying he would consult Mr. Rey and others before any appeal. 
Mr. Mercer's statement noted that the government had argued that the salvaging operation would cause no irreparable harm. He said that the environmental groups that had sought the decision would not eventually prevail on the merits of their case and that the public interest favored proceeding on the project, "given the environmental and economic benefits associated" with it.
Another Bush administration official said the decision was a Pandora's box because it could open to question other decisions made by the Clinton administration.
Spokesmen for the environmental groups that sought the court order based strictly on the lack of appeals and not on the merits of the logging operation said they did not oppose all logging in the Bitterroot.
Doug Honnold, a lawyer with EarthJustice, a law firm that represents the groups, said that Mr. Rey's initial action was an attempt to prop up a dying industry "under the guise of responding to a forest fire."
"It's an effort," Mr. Honnold said, "to reinstate a logging industry in a locale where it's hard to make a dime cutting trees because they're difficult to grow, you've got high elevations and a short growing season."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The ponderosa pines of Bitterroot National Forest, in Montana, bear the scars of fires that burned there in 2000. The timber industry had hoped to log the trees before they rot, but a federal judge has halted the project. (Jeremy Lurgio)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
White House Walks Away From Fuel Mileage Project
The Bush administration is walking away from a $1.5 billion, eight-year project to develop high-mileage gasoline-fueled vehicles. Instead it is throwing its support behind a plan to develop hydrogen-based fuel cells.
 Environmentalists and energy experts favor the research. But critics said that the new program, like its predecessor, would let Washington and Detroit focus on vague, long-term aims while avoiding the more difficult task of improving the gas mileage of cars and sport utility vehicles in the short term. Page A1. 

Motorola Told to Pay Iridium Lenders
A federal judge has ordered Motorola to pay $300 million to Chase Manhattan Bank and several other lenders to repay part of a loan to the company's troubled satellite-telephone venture, Iridium. Some investors and Wall Street analysts said the court decision could spell trouble for Motorola in four pending lawsuits, seeking billions of dollars in damages, brought by investors in Iridium. Shares of Motorola fell 37 cents, to $14.80. C9.

A Downside to AOL's Big Charge
While AOL Time Warner will be able to report far better earnings in the future because of its decision to take a big charge in the first quarter, it also becomes easier to compare AOL with other profitable companies. And by comparison, the stock may look very expensive, analysts warned. Market Place. C2.

Interest in Enron's Trading Unit
Several financial institutions and companies, including Citibank, UBS and BP, have indicated serious interest in buying Enron's energy-trading business, according to people involved in setting up an auction of the business. C4.

Enron executives met four times last year with the staff of Vice President Dick Cheney's energy task force to discuss energy policy, but they never talked about the company's finances, Mr. Cheney's counsel said. C4.

Sullivan. The building has sinuous terra-cotta vines, plump seed pods, spiky leaves, reedlike columns and glowering lion gargoyles. Commercial Real Estate. C6.

Deutsche Bank and Goldman, Sachs were unable to sell all of the 55 million shares of a Vivendi stock offering. C10.

The Treasury said that it wanted to shorten the time it takes to process the auctions of its securities to two minutes. C10.

The president of South Africa appointed a panel to examine the recent plunge in the country's currency. World Business, Section W.

Experts are at a loss to explain why the value of Canada's currency continues to erode even when the economy itself is fundamentally sound. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Pataki Confidant to Direct Rebuilding Effort 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Louis R. Tomson, a former top adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki, has been selected to run the day-to-day operations of the state corporation in charge of rebuilding Lower Manhattan, government officials and downtown executives said yesterday.
 Mr. Tomson, who was a troubleshooter for Governor Pataki, will be appointed executive director of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation within a week, they said. He is taking on the formidable and delicate task of organizing the reconstruction effort, which the executives said involves balancing real estate development and the public desire to create a significant memorial at the site of the World Trade Center. 
 On Monday, John C. Whitehead, chairman of the redevelopment corporation, said the corporation was reviewing a long list of candidates, which included Carl Weisbrod, head of the Alliance for Downtown New York, the business improvement district for Lower Manhattan; Rebecca Robertson, former president of the 42nd Street Development Project; and Richard A. Kahan, a former state official. But Mr. Tomson, who lives near Albany in Voorheesville, was Governor Pataki's first choice, according to people briefed on the appointment. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, Mr. Whitehead and directors of the redevelopment corporation approved the selection.
From 1995 to 1998, Mr. Tomson was deputy secretary and later first deputy secretary to Governor Pataki, with responsibility for policy development for the state's 60 public authorities, including the New York Power Authority, the Long Island Power Authority and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Until September, Mr. Tomson was also chairman of the State Thruway Authority. And he played a major role in advising the governor on dismantling the Long Island Lighting Company and creating the Long Island Power Authority.
"Whenever there was an impossible or contentious issue, the governor brought in Lou," said Robert D. Yaro, president of the Regional Plan Association. "He did an extraordinary job on a number of issues, including the J.F.K. air train, Long Island Power and dredging in New York harbor. He's accessible, and he's very close to the governor."
Mr. Tomson did not return calls requesting comment. And Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Governor Pataki, declined to comment. 
Mr. Pataki had to persuade Mr. Tomson to rejoin the public sector, which he left in 1999 to become senior vice president of corporate development at Plug Power, an upstate energy company that is developing an alternative electricity source called fuel cells. Mr. Tomson is expected to leave Plug Power.
In a lawsuit brought by shareholders, Mr. Tomson and two other company executives were accused of approving the release of positive public statements about the company in 2000 even after they learned about pending setbacks. The lawsuit claims that the executives profited from the sale of company stock just before the bad news became public and share prices dropped by 25 percent. Plug Power also received millions of dollars in loans and grants from the state.

HEADLINE: Terms Are Up, But They Land On Their Feet 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
The city's term limit laws managed to push four borough presidents and dozens of City Council members out of office. But in the week since their terms expired, many of the former borough presidents and council members have managed to avoid unemployment.
 Howard Golden, the former Brooklyn borough president, has taken a job as executive director of civic and governmental affairs in the office of Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney. Claire Shulman, the former Queens borough president, and Guy V. Molinari, the former Staten Island borough president, were named to the boards of divisions of the New York Community Bancorp, the holding company that owns a number of banks in the New York metropolitan region, including Richmond County Savings Bank and Queens County Savings Bank. 
 Mr. Golden, who was borough president from 1977 until Dec. 31, has been a longtime political confidant of Mr. Hynes. In his new job, he will be paid $125,000 a year, compared with the $135,000 salary for borough presidents.
"He is going to interface with community boards, community leaders and businesses," said Jerry Schmetterer, a spokesman for the district attorney's office. "We have programs that deal with alternative sentencing, recently released inmates and other law enforcement strategies," Mr. Schmetterer said. "He will be in charge of those programs. Mr. Hynes felt that Mr. Golden would be a tremendous asset in those areas."
Mr. Molinari and Ms. Shulman will be on the boards of the New York Community Bancorp divisions in their boroughs.
"We have 25 branches in Queens and 23 on Staten Island," said Ilene A. Angarola, a senior vice president of the company and corporate secretary. "And we have retained the local identity and our commitment to those communities." She said that the selection of Ms. Shulman and Mr. Molinari was intended to "provide advice, counsel and guidance in those areas."
Ms. Angarola said that, as directors, the former borough presidents are paid a fee, but she declined to disclose the amount. 
According to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, outside directors receive an annual retainer of $15,000 and a fee of $500 for attending each of the monthly board meetings. They also receive a retainer for committee service ranging from $1,000 to $8,000 depending on the committee and other fees for attending committee meetings.
Fernando Ferrer, the former Bronx borough president, said that he planned to lead a public policy institute and that he would elaborate on his plans in a later announcement.
"And I will be doing something in the private sector," Mr. Ferrer added. "I have a number of offers that have been made, and there are a number of conversations that are taking place. I'm not ready to announce anything yet."
Many council members affected by term limits have secured new positions in government. Karen Koslowitz, a former councilwoman from Queens, has taken a job as deputy borough president in the administration of Helen M. Marshall, the new borough president in Queens.
For a short time last year, Ms. Koslowitz and Ms. Marshall, then a councilwoman, were both candidates for Queens borough president.
Ms. Marshall was ultimately endorsed by the Queens Democratic Party organization after its chairman, Thomas Manton, persuaded Ms. Koslowitz to drop out of that race. Ms. Koslowitz will receive an annual salary of $134,000, compared with her Council salary of $90,000.
Another former council member, Guillermo Linares, was selected by Betsy Gotbaum, the newly elected public advocate, to be deputy public advocate at an annual salary of $90,000. Mr. Linares, a Democrat who represented Washington Heights in Manhattan, was first elected to the Council in 1991.
One former city councilman is serving in a particularly high-profile position: Victor L. Robles of Brooklyn, who was the Council's majority whip, was selected as city clerk by the Council, with a term that expires in 2006. Mr. Robles, who earns $141,000 a year, supervises the office that administers marriage licenses and is in charge of city documents.
Another of Mr. Robles's duties has been to swear in the newly elected members of the Council and to collect the fee, set by city law at 15 cents, to register them as members.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Bereft by Fire and Grandmother's Death

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Tristan Christy was awakened one morning last March by neighbors banging on his door to warn of a fire in the apartment above him. They were telling everyone in the building to get out.
 Tristan, now 14, lived there with his grandmother, and they both got out safely, though it meant he would have to go to school without a shower. He thought everything would be fine, so instead of waiting to see if there was any damage to the building, he got on the bus and went to school. 
 When he came home, Tristan, whom everyone calls Tiryese, noticed that only a window in the apartment above his had been broken. There were no fire trucks, no flames, no smoke.
He found plenty of evidence of the fire, though, when he walked into his apartment. His bedroom had taken the brunt of the damage. The ceiling had fallen in and the floor was covered in sheetrock and dust. Everything was charred or waterlogged, and destroyed. 
"All my stuff was gone," Tiryese recalled. "My TV, my dresser, my clothes." With no renters' insurance and little income, Tiryese's grandmother, Cherie Christy, 45, asked her godmother, Roberta Slaughter, 49, to pay for new winter clothes for Tiryese.
Later, for summer clothes, he turned to charity. For some years, Tiryese had been working with counselors at the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, which offers counseling and programs to teenagers at a community center in Midwood, Brooklyn. The board is a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
In April, Tiryese went on a bit of a shopping spree at a small store across the street from the community center with his counselor, Victor Fredericksen. They bought him underwear, socks, T-shirts, and dress shirts with about $400 from the fund.
Even before the fire, life had not been simple. Tiryese's parents are separated, and he is not in contact with his father. He said he speaks on the phone with his mother every few months.
The counseling sessions at the community center helped him overcome some behavior problems, Ms. Slaughter and Mr. Fredericksen said. "One time he was really hard to handle, with his grandmother," Ms. Slaughter said. "He gave her some rough times. After he started coming here, things got better." 
After the fire at his grandmother's apartment, Tiryese slept on a couch in the living room and then at Ms. Slaughter's apartment in Starrett City, the large housing complex in southeast Brooklyn.
His grandmother, who had cared for him since he was born, died of a heart attack in March. He learned the news from Ms. Slaughter when he came home from school that day. "We've been working on talking about the death of his grandmother," Mr. Fredericksen said. "I don't want to push it on Tiryese too much yet."
Tiryese said simply, "I've just been sad about it -- I've been keeping it to myself."
As a way of helping Tiryese deal with difficult emotions, gain self-confidence, learn discipline and stay busy after school, Mr. Fredericksen is enrolling him in a karate program. 
Ms. Slaughter has gained legal custody of Tiryese, and receives $63 every two weeks in welfare to care for him. She is an unemployed cosmetologist who is raising five foster children for whom she is paid stipends, and said her income is stretched thin.
To pay for the karate classes, Mr. Fredericksen will once again use money from the Neediest Cases Fund.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
AD MARKETER SAYS PROFIT WILL MEET REDUCED FORECAST

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The R. H. Donnelley Corporation, an advertising marketer, plans to cut 100 jobs and says 2001 profit was at the lower end of its reduced forecast. Profit for the year was $2.35 to $2.37 a share, excluding $30 million in pretax fourth-quarter costs, partly related to eliminating the 100 jobs, at its Raleigh, N.C., publishing plant, Donnelley said. 
In October, the company lowered its forecast for the year to $2.35 to $2.40 a share from $2.40. The company said it would report final results in mid-February. Donnelley's advertising sales have been hurt as companies have curtailed spending in a slowing economy. The company, based in Purchase, N.Y., named David Swanson its chief executive on Monday, He will start in May, succeeding Frank Noonan.

HEADLINE: Learning From Enron 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "The Enron Post-Mortem" (editorial, Jan. 4) correctly notes that Enron's collapse "was a shocking national calamity" and that it might lead to new federal regulations. 
But Enron's collapse was also shocking and calamitous in the developing world. 
 The best body to assess the behavior of multinationals is the World Trade Organization. The Enron case should inform the W.T.O.'s impending revised multilateral agreement on investment, which reduces rather than increases regulations of foreign companies.

ALICE H. AMSDEN
Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 4, 2002

The writer is a professor of political economy, Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: Somalia Is No Hideout for bin Laden 

BYLINE:  By Nuruddin Farah; Nuruddin Farah, a Somali novelist, is author, most recently, of the nonfiction book "Yesterday, Tomorrow: Voices from the Somali Diaspora."

DATELINE: CAPE TOWN 

 BODY:
As a child in the Somali Peninsula, I was brought up to believe that during Ramadan Satan is locked away in a place from where he can do no harm. I'm revisiting this myth, with a view to revising it, given the recent horrors with which the world has become familiar. In the word Satan, derived from the pre-Islamic Arabic root Shatana, I now find a secular meaning: "the one who spreads destruction" or "the one who opposes the will of the community." You can work out for yourself the Satan who will fit the world's present context, but he has been very much on the loose, visiting havoc on the world's innocent and choosing to reveal his wicked intentions in different guises, all of them unpalatable. No wonder everyone wants to know where Satan is headed next.
 The pundits predict that he will call at a Muslim country, and one of those often mentioned is Somalia. Apart from speculations, no one has the slightest idea what the spreaders of destruction and those in hot pursuit of them will do once Afghanistan has ostensibly rid herself of Osama bin Laden and his Qaeda associates. But the assumption is that in Somalia, a land of grief, these destructive forces would find a haven because there is no central authority to flush them out, hunt them down or bring them before a court. 
 The United States and its allies, having long remained impervious to the ruin of Somalia, must think hard now about firing a missile or mounting an invasion, and so bringing more pain to a land that has not enjoyed peace for over a decade. And if the aim is the eradication of terror, I would argue that Somalia is not even a promising target.
An American intrusion into Somalia would destabilize the fragile peace that has been achieved under a transitional authority with the mandate to establish a permanent, all-inclusive government. And for what purpose? According to America's own intelligence sources, the Qaeda cells in Somalia are far less active than those in Italy and Germany. Their lack of a strong structure is not the only reason Mr. bin Laden and his associates seem unlikely, to me, to seek refuge among Somalis. I see many barriers to his being hidden and shielded in Somalia.
The majority of Somalis would hardly welcome anyone likely to bring them destruction. We have so many problems of our own making that we would not be tempted to court the problems of folks from elsewhere -- especially if those problems include pursuit by the United States military.
And which warlord or warring group would Mr. bin Laden safely be able to choose as his host? He could hardly expect them to unite under his banner; their hatreds and rivalries go far too deep. And nobody carrying on his head a prize of $25 million, as Mr. bin Laden does, should be so foolish as to seek refuge in a land where treachery among the political elite has been greater than anywhere else in the known world. He had better find his peace elsewhere, in a land where loyalties are more permanent and where he would be less likely to be sold.
Simply staying out of sight would be difficult. A quarrelsome lot, we Somalis take delight in informing on or opposing one another. For the warlords and their loyalists, this translates into making it a primary business to discover who their enemies' friends are, what they are up to, with whom they are plotting, against whom and why. I cannot for the life of me imagine Mr. bin Laden or one of his associates finding a hiding place for even a single weekend in a land where everything is an open secret.
I doubt, too, that Al Qaeda could raise enough recruits among Somalia's unemployed to fight under its banner. Many a Somali might die willingly for his clan family or for financial gains, but not for an abstraction, which is what, in the final analysis, religion is to the barely literate. Moreover, I doubt there are more than a handful of my countrymen who are prepared to lay down their lives for Islam, well aware as they are that the Almighty has supplied the faith with many other volunteers, from other parts of the world, eager to do a martyr's work.
The West should not be fooled by the misinformation doled out by both the Ethiopian regime and its allies in Somalia and by the untrustworthy men now leading Somalia's murderous factions. They can be expected to point censorious fingers at their rivals, describing them as associates of Al Qaeda.
The attention that Somalia needs from the international community is not an invasion in the antiterror war, but meaningful support of the government's effort to regain sovereignty over the whole country. The warlords will lead us nowhere but to a dead end, where anarchy rules. This will be to the profit of neither ourselves, our neighbors nor the Western nations threatened by terror.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Luba Lukova)

HEADLINE: Thousands of Jobs Expected to Be Cut AtG.M. and Ford 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
The two largest American automakers are expected to announce the elimination of at least 15,000 jobs this week.
 General Motors plans to offer buyouts to about 5,000 white-collar workers as part of continuing belt-tightening in an automotive industry reckoning with recession. Later this week, analysts expect that Ford Motor will cut more than 10,000 jobs as part of a major restructuring plan. Ford officials declined to comment today on reports that as many as 20,000 jobs would be eliminated. 
 The prospect of cuts has somewhat overshadowed the North American International Auto Show here, where automakers from around the world are displaying new models for this year and concepts for the future.
G.M., the only one of the Big Three automakers that is expected to report a profit for 2001, appeared to be making the cuts less out of necessity than as a preventive measure. The company said today that it would offer buyouts to about 10 percent of its white-collar work force as part of an effort started in 2000 to trim its payroll.
"We can run leaner, and we should run leaner," said Rick Wagoner, the chief executive of G.M., who added that no plant closings were on the horizon for G.M. beyond the closing of a Canadian plant that was announced last year.
"The best companies work at competitiveness every day," he added. "When economics are tough, you've got a little bit of a sharper edge to it."
Though G.M. shares a number of concerns with the other members of the Big Three, including the weakness of the Japanese yen and the high price of sales incentives, analysts view it as the member of the Big Three with the most momentum. Today, Robert A. Lutz, G.M.'s new vice chairman who oversees products, led reporters on a tour to critique the competition's vehicles with a brashness that G.M. has long studiously avoided.
He even led a tour around the displays of Chrysler, where he served as president in the 90's, and offered his compliments to Dieter Zetsche, Chrysler's chief executive.
"No more sleepy Chrysler," Mr. Lutz said to Mr. Zetsche, adding that he would have preferred if the carmaker, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, was still sleepy and less competitive.
Other carmakers expressed surprise that G.M. was able to develop a concept car, the curvy two-seat roadster, the Pontiac Solstice, in the four months that Mr. Lutz has been at the company.
But most of the talk at the conference has focused on Ford and its financial health. Ford's cuts come as it tries to return to profitability after a miserable 2001 that brought a decline in its quality rankings, a sinking in the morale of its employees, a drop in its market share to 21.9 percent from 23 percent in 2000 and the removal of its chief executive.
The company, which is expected to report its first annual loss since 1992, is also expected to announce that some of its plants will be phased out, though Ford officials have said that no plant will be entirely shut down before the union contract ends in the middle of next year.
G.M., Chrysler and Ford all face similar obstacles this year. They will be challenged to increase sales during the recession and after drawing in customers by offering interest-free financing deals after Sept. 11. One side effect of the deals, which drove sales of new cars and light trucks to a record monthly level in October, is that the value of used cars declined. Falling residual values have hurt the outlook for the General Motors Acceptance Corporation because it affects the value of cars coming off leases.
"The biggest issue that GMAC faces from a financial side is residual values, and the worst of that seems to be behind us now," Mr. Wagoner said.
Referring to the job cuts, he said: "We've got to do what's right in our circumstances. I think at G.M. we have gone through some tremendous restructuring. There's not an activity at the company that hasn't been restructured. We had to do it because we had a very difficult performance in the late 80's and early 90's. We still have things we have to do."

HEADLINE: Wider Loss Forecast By Big Coal Supplier 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Shares of Massey Energy fell 19 percent today after the company, a large coal producer, warned that losses over the last two months of 2001 will more than triple earlier estimates, while projected earnings for 2002 will drop substantially.
Massey's stock fell $4.22, to $18 a share.. 
 Massey attributed the losses in part to having to add to a reserve fund in anticipation of a settlement with the state of West Virginia of a dispute over workers' compensation liabilities. Massey also added to a reserve fund in anticipation of losses from the bankruptcy of Enron, the failed energy trading company. 
 Results for the two-month period are scheduled to be released Jan. 30. Massey is switching its financial reporting from its fiscal year, which ends in October, to a calendar year. That led to the unusual report for two rather than three months.
Massey said that mild weather, lower steel demand and the general economic recession had led it to lower estimates of 2002 coal demand in central Appalachia, thereby lowering earnings forecasts.

HEADLINE: Focusing on Home Front, Bush Signs Education Bill 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
President Bush continued to emphasize domestic politics over war today as he signed into a law a major education bill that he reminded his listeners had been a central promise of his presidential campaign.
 "We're going to win the war overseas, and we need to win the war against illiteracy here at home as well," the president told a cheering crowd before signing the bill in the gymnasium of Hamilton High School in Hamilton, Ohio, the home district of Representative John A. Boehner, a leading Republican supporter of the bill. 
 "The story of children being just shuffled through the system is one of the saddest stories of America," Mr. Bush said. 
He promised that his bill would put American schools "on a new path of reform, and a new path of results." 
The bill, a bipartisan compromise reached even as Congress was consumed by the events of Sept. 11, is to greatly enlarge the federal role in public education, mandate annual testing of children in grades three to eight and provide tutoring for children in failing schools.
White House advisers today called the bill a triumph for Mr. Bush, even though he had to make major concessions for its passage, including giving up on a voucher program for private schools.
In what amounted to a victory lap and a political favor for the four main legislative supporters of the bill -- two Democrats and two Republicans -- Mr. Bush traveled from Washington to Ohio to New Hampshire and then to Massachusetts. It was his most extensive day of travel in the United States since Sept. 11, and marked a new emphasis on Mr. Bush's domestic agenda and the 2002 midterm elections. 
It may also have been one of the last displays of bipartisanship this year, as the president and Democrats wage war over the sputtering economy.
At Boston Latin, the nation's oldest public school, Mr. Bush appeared before a roaring crowd with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the main Democratic supporter of the bill in the Senate and typically a target of Republican attacks.
"I told the folks in the coffee shop in Crawford, Tex., that Ted Kennedy is all right," the president said, referring to a restaurant near his ranch where he had a cheeseburger last month. "They nearly fell out."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Kennedy, scions of the nation's two most famous and opposing political families with much to gain from the other, took time in each of their speeches at Boston Latin for extravagant compliments. 
"Now we remember the difference it has made this year with your leadership," Mr. Kennedy said at the school, the alma mater of his father and grandfather. The president, he added, "was there every step of the way making the difference on this legislation."
Mr. Bush, in turn, told the crowd that Mr. Kennedy had been with the first lady on Capitol Hill as they learned of the Sept. 11 attacks. "And I want to thank him publicly, in front of his home folks, for providing such comfort to Laura during an incredibly tough time," Mr. Bush said. He added, "So, Mr. Senator, not only are you a good senator, you're a good man."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Kennedy need each other politically this year for any deal on the patients' bill of rights, a major legislative goal for both men. 
In New Hampshire, the site of the nation's first primary, Mr. Bush attended his most political event since the attacks, a private reception for campaign donors in Durham. White House aides said it was not a fund-raiser, but a "thank you" for supporters. On Wednesday in Washington, Mr. Bush is to speak at a fund-raiser for his brother Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida.
Among the group in Durham was Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, the main Republican supporter of the education bill in the Senate and Mr. Bush's campaign manager during the 2000 New Hampshire primary. Mr. Bush lost the primary in a stunning upset to Senator John McCain of Arizona.
"I still invited him to come with me," Mr. Bush said of Mr. Gregg, to laughter.
Also along on the trip was Representative George Miller of California, the main Democratic supporter of the bill in the House. Mr. Bush traveled to California last Saturday.
Although Mr. Bush spoke in some detail about the provisions of the bill, he said in all three states that he had not looked at it closely.
"I wish you could have seen this piece of legislation," Mr. Bush said at Boston Latin. "It's really tall. And I admit, I haven't read it yet." As the crowd laughed, Mr. Bush added: "You'll be happy to hear I don't intend to. But I know the principles behind the bill."
One discordant note today came during Mr. Bush's remarks at the University of New Hampshire in Durham when a young man stood up in the crowd in the gymnasium and called out loud enough for the president to hear: "What about the dead Afghani children, Mr. Bush? What about the dead Afghani children?"
The unidentified heckler, who was evidently referring to civilians killed during the American bombing campaign in Afghanistan, was silenced by what appeared to be another member of the audience, an older man, who came up from behind him, firmly put a hand on what appeared to be the heckler's head or shoulder, and pushed him down. The president paused slightly, but continued with his speech.

HEADLINE: A Bush Event Signals All-Out Politics 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
After four months of steering clear of partisan political events, President Bush will appear on Wednesday at a fund-raising dinner here for his brother Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, the White House announced tonight.
 Mr. Bush had instructed his aides after Sept. 11 that it would be unseemly for him to engage in blatant politicking. Since then, his aides have debated about when he should resume political activities. 
 As the president returned to the road to pitch his economic prescriptions, he and his advisers decided it would be appropriate for him to appear on behalf of Jeb Bush, who is seeking re-election in November in one of the marquee contests of the year. Four Democrats, including former Attorney General Janet Reno, are competing to challenge Mr. Bush.
"There was some discussion in December about it," one of the president's advisers said of the conversations about whether the president should attend. "But there was a strong feeling that the president ought to do some political things and this was a good one to do."
In late October, Mr. Bush had been scheduled to be the big draw at a $1 million Republican fund-raising dinner to benefit the Republican Governors Association. But he sent Vice President Dick Cheney in his place.
Organizers of the event on Wednesday, at the Capital Hilton Hotel's presidential ballroom, only blocks from the White House, said it would be in two tiers: For $500 -- the maximum a donor can give directly to Jeb Bush's campaign -- participants can attend a reception featuring the president and the governor. Then there will be a small dinner to benefit the Florida Republican Party for about 50 couples, at $10,000 a couple. That high-dollar event will raise unregulated soft money, including corporate contributions.
The dinner had originally been scheduled for Nov. 28, but it was postponed because of the terrorist attacks and because Republican officials said they were having trouble raising money.
"Any time you have the president, it's an honor and a privilege," said Al Cardenas, the Republican chairman in Florida.
Donors had been told that the president "may or may not come," Mr. Cardenas said, but "they still want to be there to spend time with the governor."
The honorary chairs of the event are the president's and Jeb Bush's brother Marvin and his wife, Margaret, and their sister and her husband, Doro and Bobby Koch.
Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief political adviser, said in a recent interview that the president knew that sooner or later he would have to return to politics.
"He recognizes that there comes a time when he has that responsibility as leader of this party to do that," Mr. Rove said. "But particularly in the first three months, he's felt very uninclined to commit to political activity."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida will benefit from a fund-raiser. (Reuters)
