HEADLINE: Despite Uncertain Times, Parents See Private School as a Necessity 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
Ten parents showed up punctually at 8:30 a.m. yesterday at the Calhoun School on the Upper West Side for a tour of the private school where their 4-year-olds were applying.
 Julianna Ostrovsky had lost her job as an art designer for the Gap and Old Navy clothing stores as a result of the economic downturn after Sept. 11. Christopher Fisher, a massage therapist, and his wife, Cynthia Kolbowski, a counselor, had seen their businesses suffer, but like the rest of the parents, they considered it a must to send their children to a private school. 
 "Maybe the effects of the recession will be there next year," said one mother, unwilling to give her name because she had applied to 11 schools, "but most parents are still hanging in there." 
Indeed, despite the startling fluctuations in the stock markets, the slashing of year-end bonuses and the layoffs on Wall Street, affluent New Yorkers are still eager to send their children to the city's private schools, many of which charge more than $20,000 a year in tuition for a single child. 
"We are seeing a healthy flow this year," said Frederick C. Calder, executive director of the New York State Association of Independent Schools, which says half its members are in New York City. "The number of applications are similar to those of last year. People can do away with vacations, S.U.V.'s and other frills. It would take them a while to get to the point where they have to make cuts on their kids' education." 
Last year was a frantic time. Directors of admissions at schools like Brearley, Grace Church, Brooklyn Friends and Allen-Stevenson were inundated with applications, which reached record levels at most of the city's more than 70 independent schools. Parents lined up at doors, begging for spots for their children. There were simply too many applicants and too few spots. To many of the well-educated and handsomely paid parents, in the flush times of the last few years, nothing seemed to matter more than their children's admission into their first-choice school.
Times have changed. But "the phones are still ringing, people are still sending me letters and knocking on our door to ask for a spot," said Steven J. Nelson, headmaster of the Calhoun School, which has received 190 applications -- a quarter more than last year -- for 15 openings in its kindergarten.
Not that the well-off parents of New York have been immune to the effects of Sept. 11. The attack left some less able to afford the expense, but it also created an uncertain atmosphere that made the security and intimacy of private schools more attractive to parents.
"I think my child will feel safer at a private school at this time of uncertainty," said another mother touring Calhoun with Ms. Kolbowski. "My child will be more closely watched, and the teachers will know him better." Having applied to 19 schools for her son to ensure his admission to at least one, she insisted on anonymity.
She cringed even at the suggestion of sending her child to a public school. She has been following the news, and said that the education budget was being cut and that repairs would be approved only for the worst buildings. If her child went to Calhoun, she said, there would be one teacher for every six pupils.
"Many New York parents feel they don't have a viable alternative," said Mr. Calder, of the independent schools association. "If they lived in a suburb with good public schools, they might pull their children out of the private ones."
It is not unusual for applications to lag behind an economic downturn, he said. Even if parents are hurt by the recession, "they usually hope to ride it out."
The schools are also in a better financial position to help families who may lack the means to pay the full tuition. During the last decade, almost all of the city's private schools received big donations and increased their endowments.
"Most independent schools have deeper pockets for financial aid," said George Davison, headmaster of Grace Church School, where the number of applications is in line with last year's. "We are able to serve an economically diverse population."
The big changes wrought by Sept. 11 have affected the admissions process in intangible ways, said numerous admissions directors. 
"Parents are feeling a little less stress about getting their children into 'the' school," said Elizabeth Manley Murray, director of admissions at the Brearley School, where applications are at the same level as last year. "They are less anxious about the process."
Mr. Davison concurs. "People gained a little perspective that they didn't before on what's important in life," he said. "Fewer people believe that where their children go to school reflects on their own social statuses."

HEADLINE: Revisiting the Disabilities Act 

 BODY:
It is often said that bad cases make bad law. Tuesday's Supreme Court ruling narrowing the scope of the Americans With Disabilities Act shows that a well-intentioned but imprecise law can generate valid court decisions that nevertheless frustrate the spirit of the statute. There is little to fault in the unanimous decision. The problem lies in the law's language. Congress can and should find a way to eliminate the confusion it inadvertently sowed.
 The disabilities act was passed in 1990 with broad bipartisan support and much acclaim. It recognized that those with a range of physical and emotional limitations had been increasingly marginalized in American society both because of prejudice and failure to make simple modifications for them. Regarding the workplace, the idea was that if someone is qualified for a job but has a disability or develops one while working, an employer should make a reasonable accommodation. The law makes clear that bigger companies must accommodate more than smaller ones but no company should be unduly burdened. 
 The case of Ella Williams and Toyota that was reviewed by the Supreme Court fits the law's aims and requirements well. Shortly after starting work on a Toyota assembly line, Ms. Williams developed carpal tunnel syndrome, a painful repetitive stress injury, in her arms. Toyota shifted her job and she was fine for three years in her new post. Then the company added tasks that made her injury flare up anew. The two sides disagree on what happened next, but Ms. Williams ultimately stopped going to work and Toyota fired her. 
There is every reason to expect that Ella Williams should have the legal protection to keep her job. A Toyota plant has many tasks that would not aggravate her injury. Her situation was just what the law's framers had in mind -- a company should be expected to modify the conditions of someone's work within reasonable limits. Accommodating Ms. Williams would have been neither difficult nor expensive for Toyota.
Unfortunately, like previous cases on the same law, this case turned on the definition of "disability" enshrined in the law itself. The law defines a disability as an impairment that "substantially limits one or more of the major life activities." Stretching that slightly, the court ruled that for a workplace injury to qualify as a disability it must prevent or restrict someone "from performing tasks that are of central importance to most people's daily lives."
That seems reasonable enough. We don't want to classify half the nation as disabled. As Justice Antonin Scalia asked in oral argument last November, if someone can't extend her elbow, is that enough to bring her into the category of the handicapped? 
Of course not. But carpal tunnel syndrome is no trivial matter, and suffering from it should not make someone unemployable or turn her into a worker's compensation case. In a post-welfare world, the country should be pursuing policies that keep people employed. 
There are two streams of cases emerging in the federal courts on this law, and they pose a kind of Catch-22. One stream has made it increasingly difficult to declare an impairment to be a disability. But the other says that if you are not disabled, you are not protected from employment discrimination. This is not what was intended by the law's framers. 
Congress should either revisit the Americans With Disabilities Act and clarify its language or pass a new law that protects people like Ms. Williams. It should also bring the law down hard on unworthy disability lawsuits plaguing the courts and scaring employers. Most companies are trying to do the right thing by their employees. Congress should help them.

HEADLINE: A Very Different Council Ushers In New Leadership 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
On a day that City Hall took on the air of the beginning of a fall semester, the City Council formally elected its first new speaker in more than a decade, amended some of its operating rules, created an initial committee and named its minority leader.
 "The smooth democratic transition which we are witnessing today has proven the critics wrong and sends a strong message that the Council, as an institution, is stronger and more unified than ever," said Gifford Miller after being elected unanimously as speaker. Calling the Council "the people's voice," Mr. Miller praised the diversity of a body that now includes community activists, clergy members and educators. 
 The selection of Mr. Miller, 32, completes the near-wholesale change in the city's leadership brought about this year by term limits, including the mayor, more than two-thirds of the City Council, the city comptroller, the public advocate and four borough presidents.
Considered the second-most powerful position in the city, the speaker has broad powers to set the legislative agenda, as well as discretion over coveted committee chairmanships and leadership positions, each of which has traditionally carried an extra stipend, ranging from $2,500 to $29,000, above a council member's $90,000 a year salary. For his role, the former speaker, Peter F. Vallone, earned an extra $39,500.
In stark contrast to Mr. Vallone, who ran the Council for 15 years, Mr. Miller will serve for only 2, unless the term limits law is changed. Yesterday, he said it was premature to discuss whether he would work to have the law repealed, preferring to focus on the more immediate challenges facing the city like education, housing, public safety and the economy.
"The attacks and slowing economy have placed our city in a precarious situation," he told his colleagues. "We have lost thousands of jobs. We face the largest budget gaps since the crisis of the mid-1970's. And the problems confronting our city before Sept. 11 also continue to demand our attention."
Mr. Miller's selection as speaker had been all but certain since the weekend, when agreements were reached among the Democratic leaders in Queens and the Bronx, union officials and council members themselves. Now comes the tricky task of satisfying the competing desires of any number of officials, inside and out of the Council, who can all claim a role in Mr. Miller's success. In addition, there are advocates for special interests like labor, the environment and tenants who are lobbying members to lobby Mr. Miller for particular committee posts.
But yesterday, the public face of the Council was striking in its unanimity, the result of endless rounds of private meetings and negotiations about Mr. Miller's post as well as a package of rules changes proposed by a group called the Fresh Democracy Council. The amendments, passed by the newly named Committee on Rules, Privileges and Elections, were intended to make it more difficult for the speaker to bottle up bills or show favoritism to certain council members. That committee, with a Queens freshman and Miller supporter, Leroy G. Comrie, at its helm, will hash out the rest of the Council's leadership in the coming weeks.
The meeting itself, at which James S. Oddo of Staten Island was elected minority leader, at times lurched giddily along, with Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum laughing and struggling with her microphone and Councilman Bill Perkins chuckling in answering the opening roll call. But it was Charles Barron of Brooklyn, a former Black Panther, who perhaps proved the best harbinger of the more lively body that several council members promised would come.
Noting that the speaker and the mayor were white men from Manhattan, Mr. Barron, who has said he would seek legislation to line City Hall's walls with portraits of African-American and Latino historical figures, gave the new speaker a hammer and picture hooks so that he could start hanging portraits of the "brothers and sisters."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
An Online Financial Pioneer Acquires Bricks and Mortar

BYLINE:  By ANDRES MARTINEZ 

 BODY:
E*Trade was an amiable host to the late-90's Nasdaq trading bash. With its cheap commissions and consumer-friendly stock-trading Web site, the company was one of the online pioneers that empowered millions of Americans to take on Wall Street pros. Like few others, E*Trade's advertising campaigns captured tech investors' irrational exuberance. It was only two years ago that E*Trade aired Super Bowl spots starring a dancing chimpanzee ("Well, we just wasted two million bucks" was its punchline) and an emergency-room patient who had "money coming out the wazoo."
 Stock market investors have lost some $4.5 trillion since then, in the market's first two consecutive down years since the early 1970's, so it comes as no surprise to find E*Trade a bit chastened. The most prominent pitch on its Web site these days does not tout low commissions, real-time stock quotes or the notion that it's idiotic to consult a broker. Rather, it offers a 2.5 percent annual rate on a three-month certificate of deposit. Hangovers are dreary affairs, and financial ones are no exception. 
 For a nostalgic taste of the more frenzied aspirations of the dot-com bubble, visit the E*Trade Center on Madison Avenue. Though it did not open until last April, 13 months after the Nasdaq hit an all-time high that it is unlikely to revisit any time soon, the facility is a three-story chrome-and-glass shrine to the trading fever that overcame the country in the last months of the 20th Century. 
The E*Trade Center is as radical a departure from traditional brokerage offices as the now ubiquitous mega-bookstores were from traditional booksellers not long ago, and it too has a cafe inside. It is a place to hang out, grab a snack and pick up some MSFT or CSCO. Easy chairs and laptops are strewn about for your trading pleasure. Flat-panel screens are tuned into CNBC and its stock ticker, even in the bathroom.
A new Lexus is on display near the upstairs cafe, oddly enough. It's a promotional prize, reinforcing the space's sense of whimsy, reminiscent of the sportsbooks at Las Vegas casinos, the places where bettors make their sports wagers. Pick a team and watch the action onscreen.
But with the Nasdaq still 3,000 points, or 60 percent, below its peak, it was a rather quiet sportsbook when I dropped in recently during trading hours. In the nearly deserted basement reserved for hard-core day traders, two men argued over whether JDS Uniphase would soon take off again. It brought to mind those stories of Japanese soldiers still entrenched on remote South Pacific islands long after World War II had ended. 
E*Trade has moved on, even if some of its customers have not. It has become as much a bank as a brokerage. Kiosks and salesmen on the ground floor not only provide advice about investing in stocks, they also peddle prosaic banking offerings like mortgages and C.D.'s. Stodgy companies may have once been desperate to transform themselves into dot-coms, but now the opposite is happening. 
E*Trade's very presence in the physical world, in one of Manhattan's prime retail locations no less, would have been an act of heresy for an Internet pioneer such as itself a few years back. This revolution, after all, was about making brick-and-mortar businesses obsolete. 
Now E*Trade is mimicking the strategy of Charles Schwab and others that have blended online businesses with branch offices. Not only is the company opening showcases in major cities, it is also opening outlets in Target discount stores in places like Trussville, Ala. 
This strategy of becoming more than just an online trading floor for CNBC addicts accounts for E*Trade's relative financial health, surprising for a poster child of the dot-com bubble. The company's stock price actually rose in 2001 and it will once again sponsor this year's halftime Super Bowl show. It may be one of only two or three dot-com Super Bowl advertisers, down from 22 in 2000. 
E*Trade would have been doomed had it continued relying entirely on low-cost stock trades. In its earnings report issued last October, the company indicated that the number of its customers' brokerage transactions had fallen in the quarter that ended in September to 5.3 million from 9.4 million a year earlier. Customers' investment assets had shrunk to $36.3 billion from $61.3 billion a year earlier. E*Trade reports its latest quarterly earnings next Monday. 
To the extent that E*Trade's news is positive, it is largely because it has become a lot less reliant on trading commissions. Too bad not all of its customers were as willing to diversify in time.

HEADLINE: Kelly Plans to Cut Money For Overtime Police Patrols 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
Facing a budget crisis, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that he planned to significantly reduce the additional patrols that for two years have been financed by a $172 million overtime program in which officers worked on their days off.
 The department currently has $24 million to pay for the program from January to March. Mr. Kelly said he planned to stretch that money so that the program, known as Operation Condor, could continue into June, effectively halving the amount available for the patrols over the next six months. At its height, the program paid for an additional 1,000 officers on the street each day. 
 Operation Condor, which has been criticized for its cost and sometimes aggressive tactics, was credited by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani with maintaining record crime declines. It was instituted in early 2000 by Howard Safir, then the commissioner, and continued by his successor, Bernard B. Kerik.
But yesterday, Mr. Kelly, in a wide-ranging briefing with reporters, said he thought the department of 40,000 officers could keep crime down without the additional overtime spending for Operation Condor.
"I think the resources are adequate in the department to do the job," he said. Later, his spokesman, Michael O'Looney, said the department would try to maintain patrol strength through efficiency.
Even as he acknowledged the budgetary constraints, Mr. Kelly said there were some things that the department could not do without. Among them, he said, are increased counterterrorism training and new equipment, like protective suits and radiation detectors, which he expects will be paid for by the federal government, and an upgrade for the department's computer systems.
In focusing on the department's technology, Mr. Kelly noted that the 55,000-person agency had no systemwide e-mail. "I don't think you can find an organization in this country that size that doesn't have e-mail," he said.
Mr. Kelly said he hoped to draw on the expertise of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to improve the department's computer, communications and technology systems, areas in which solutions have long eluded department managers. Mr. Kelly said he would also try to solve some of those problems with outside contractors.
The commissioner also said he planned to hire an outside consultant to evaluate the department's response to the World Trade Center attack, to better prepare should the city suffer another terrorist attack.
"What lessons should we learn from Sept. 11?" he said. "What did we do that we don't want to do again?" He said he was seeking an objective examination to supplement department reports prepared after the attack.
That preparation and understanding will likely be invaluable in the future, Mr. Kelly said, as the city faces other challenges. 
Later this month, the city will play host to the World Economic Forum's annual meeting, normally held in Davos, Switzerland. Mr. Kelly said the meeting could draw radical protesters and would mean a major personnel commitment for the department.
The planned overtime reductions will hit officers, detectives and supervisors who have gone without a raise for years despite record crime declines, which the police unions say were hard won by their members.
Thomas Scotto, the president of the Detectives Endowment Association, said that most of his members understood that the city was facing a budget crisis and that overtime was often the first area to be reviewed. But he said the impact of the cuts remained to be seen. 
"Can the members keep the levels of arrests and reduction in crime at the same levels?" he asked. "That's the question." 
Last year, the department spent as much as $10 million a month on the Condor program, in which officers are assigned to work a sixth day in a week to bolster the police presence on city streets, officials said. For the next six months, the department will have only about $4 million a month to spend, so commanders will be able to assign far fewer officers to the additional patrols.
Mr. O'Looney said Commissioner Kelly had assigned Joseph J. Esposito, the chief of department, to examine how to make the most of the remaining Condor money and keep as many officers on patrol as possible.
Asked about past police administrations that spent far beyond their overtime budgets and kept returning to the City Council and City Hall to ask for additional money, Mr. Kelly pointed to the economic downturn that preceded Sept. 11.
"So they may have done that in the past, and, hey, God bless them, it was good they were able to do that," he said. "But it's just different now."

HEADLINE: Memories of Welfare Days Differ For Agency Head and Her Mother 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The city's new welfare commissioner, Verna Eggleston, learned about both work and welfare at her mother's knee. She was 9 months old when her father walked out on the family in the Bronx. Her mother, unable to pay rent and feed seven children on a housecleaner's wages, turned to public assistance. 
 In an interview yesterday, Ms. Eggleston proudly recalled how her mother, now retired, reacted to the news of her appointment by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to head the Human Resources Administration. 
 "She said, 'Oh, that's wonderful,' " Ms. Eggleston recalled. " 'I'm so glad that you're returning to the place that helped me to help you.' "
But how much and how long the family was helped by Aid to Families With Dependent Children, the federal program dismantled by the 1996 welfare overhaul, depends on whether the commissioner or her mother is telling the story. Ms. Eggleston, 45, who describes herself as an African-American Republican with conservative views, said her mother left welfare after "a short time." But her mother, Dorothy Eggleston, 76, said she received family assistance for 17 years, starting the year Verna was born.
The daughter said that the elder Ms. Eggleston's work ethic prompted her to demand training as a practical nurse and that she worked as many as four jobs at once to support the children and send them to college. 
The commissioner's mother, in a telephone interview from her home in Pineville, S.C., said that despite the city's compulsory work training programs and her housecleaning jobs, she continued to need the family aid to pay rent on the family's apartment in Clason Point Gardens, a public housing project in the Bronx. 
Not until 1973, she said, after "the government paid for me to go to nursing school," was she able to leave the rolls for good.
At heart, both accounts are about a valiant mother who did right by her children, four girls and three boys, all of whom became self-supporting. But these days, the details of such a family's life are charged with political meaning, as the city faces the first test of its welfare overhaul in a recession. 
By day's end yesterday, efforts to reconcile the two accounts culminated in a conference call arranged by the commissioner, in which she repeatedly interrupted her mother's replies with her own version of events.
"The department of public assistance did not subsidize my life to become commissioner," she said, after insisting that public aid during her childhood might have consisted mainly of surplus cheese.
Her mother quietly repeated that a check from the government covered the family's rent throughout. "I wasn't making enough to take care of my kids," she said. 
Ms. Eggleston, who most recently directed the Hetrick-Martin Institute in Manhattan, a social service agency serving gay young people, is almost unknown among veterans of the welfare overhaul debate. As an African-American Republican, she is also a bit of an enigma in the world of social services, even among some who knew her as a hands-on administrator of homeless shelters and group homes for foster children in the 1980's.
"Verna is smart as a whip, very savvy, forceful and viscerally familiar with those on the margins of society," said Poul Jensen, now president of Graham Windham, one of the city's oldest nonprofit foster care agencies, in an e-mail message. "She's fully capable of managing a behemoth like H.R.A., in my view."
Mr. Jensen, who was deputy commissioner of the city's Child Welfare Administration when Ms. Eggleston was in charge of group homes for foster children, said he did not know where Ms. Eggleston stood on various policy questions, but added, "My sense of her as a person and human service advocate prompts me to believe that she will likely move to extend and humanize legitimate efforts to decrease dependency, and when dependency is appropriate, move to secure it, humanize it and, if affordable, extend it."
Ms. Eggleston, who impressed Mr. Bloomberg after she left Hetrick-Martin to work as a paid consultant on his campaign, said her goals included continuing to reduce the welfare rolls. But she added that she did not want the successes of her administration to become the problems of the Department of Homeless Services and the foster care system. "I haven't forgotten where I came from," she said.
In her mother's account, the family was on the verge of homelessness when public assistance stepped in, housing the Egglestons in a public project within three months of her first application for help. 
But the commissioner does not recall feeling poor. She recalled that her mother hired people to help the children with their homework while she was cleaning other people's houses, which the mother verified.
"She strategically identified a set of godparents for each one of us," Ms. Eggleston said of her mother. All were middle-class black people, hers a runway model and an engineer who were deeply involved in her life. 
"Talk about a village raising a child." 
Ms. Eggleston went to the city's Performing Arts High School, but soon left, disenchanted, she said, by the limitations she experienced because of race. "The only play they would let me do was 'Raisin in the Sun,' " she said. "I wanted to do Bertolt Brecht."
She went on to Adlai Stevenson High School in the Bronx, during a period when most of the school's students were white and racial relations were tense, and later worked her way through college in the New York State system, in part with a federally sponsored job doing theater in state prisons. That work led to her career in human services.
One day, 21 years after her father's disappearance on Oct. 13, 1956, she was called by the authorities to claim his body. By then, she said, she was the only Eggleston in the telephone book in the Bronx. 
Her mother said her estranged husband was a World War II veteran who had good jobs as a store window display decorator in the 1950's. But the police told her he died homeless. Unknown to the family, she said, he had been sleeping in a Hunts Point junkyard, not far from the housing project where they lived. 
Ms. Eggleston asked that she not be stereotyped based on her childhood. "Don't put me in a box," the commissioner said. "Why can't I just be judged as an administrator?"

HEADLINE: Rise in Mortgage Applications Gains Force 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Applications for mortgage loans surged to a record last week, suggesting that the housing market showed few signs of stalling. 
 Home buyers taking advantage of 30-year fixed mortgage rates close to 7 percent led to a 27.9 percent increase in the Mortgage Bankers Association of America's purchase index, to a level of 375.9 in the week ended Friday. 
 If the total pace of 6.14 million new and existing homes sold from January through November was sustained in December, last year's sales will break the record 6.09 million in 1999.
"Housing is one of the saving graces of this recession," said Richard Yamarone of Argus Research in New York. 
Refinancing applications also increased. The refinancing index, which reached a record high in November, rose 32.6 percent, to 1,703.7 last week.
The increases in purchase and refinancing applications pushed the group's mortgage applications index up 29.9 percent, to 570.7 last week. It was the highest reading in a month.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Pataki's Speech: Pledges of Unity and Fiscal Responsibility 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Gov. George E. Pataki's annual address to the Legislature in Albany yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.
 Majority Leader Bruno, Speaker Silver, and to the members of this great Legislature, I thank you for the spirit of cooperation you have helped to foster. 
 Since Sept. 11, partisanship has given way to a new spirit of unity. That doesn't have to change and it shouldn't change, because New Yorkers need us to stay united. 
People want an end to partisan politics, and they deserve it. 
I pledge to work with you to keep that unified spirit alive for as long as I am governor. And in speaking of unity, I know we are all solidly united in our unwavering resolve to meet the challenges we now face.
The human cost of Sept. 11 was devastating. Only time's healing touch, and a continued outpouring of compassion and support, can ease the profound suffering that has been inflicted upon so many New Yorkers.
Addressing the other costs -- the economic fallout, the damage to our state's finances, and the security threat to the public -- will require more than that. It will take time. It will take perseverance. It will require courage. And it will require new laws to protect us from further acts of terrorism. . . .
Today, New York's war against crime is being fought, not just on our own streets, but on an international stage. . . .
Before I outline what I intend to do, let me tell you what we're not going to do.
We're not going to sell prisons to ourselves to balance the budget. We're not going to slash education funding in the middle of the school year. We're not going to use fiscal gimmicks to conceal reality.
In short, we are not going to resort to any of the irresponsible measures that were taken in prior years, when the circumstances were not nearly as grave as they are today.
And unlike 1989, unlike 1990, 1991, '92, '93 and 1994, we will not delay tax cuts.
Tony, it was great to see you standing on that side of the aisle Assemblyman Anthony Seminerio, a Democrat from Queens . Tax cuts will go forward. They must go forward, because we know that tax cuts create jobs.
This year, next year and beyond, we will cut taxes by hundreds of millions of dollars. It's what our economy needs, and what our people deserve.
It is these policies, guided by the principles of fiscal prudence and lower taxes, that have provided us with the economic momentum and fiscal discipline necessary to withstand the events of Sept. 11. . . .
Senator Bruno, Speaker Silver, my colleagues here in the Legislature, I applaud you for proposing no increase in spending for the Assembly and the Senate operations in the fiscal year that begins April 1.
Stop grumbling. It's the right thing to do. It is that kind of responsible nonpartisanship that New Yorkers want from us. And we're going to give it to them.
Later this month, I will submit a budget that reflects the challenges we face. It's a budget that, of necessity, not only holds the line on spending, but reduces general fund spending substantially.
We've made these decisions before, and they were the right decisions. We reduced spending in 1995, and it was the first step toward ending the crisis we inherited.
Now, the new challenges before us demand that we do it again so we can lead New York out of the financial crisis we face today.

HEADLINE: Dream Car: A Dressed-Up Skateboard 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
THE car of the future, according to General Motors, will have its engine encased in the floor and need no gasoline. It will also have a body and interior that can be replaced as moods change, electronically connected components instead of mechanical parts, and a power source that can serve your home from the driveway. 
 A mockup of the car is on display here this week at the North American International Auto Show. This concept vehicle, called the Autonomy, has few moving parts other than the wheels and is part of G.M.'s continuing research into cars powered by fuel cells, a source that holds the promise of emitting only water and heat by relying on hydrogen instead of gas. 
 Most automakers, including G.M., are putting a greater emphasis on ways to make fuel cells fit into conventional cars and trucks. An experimental pickup truck shown by G.M. in August had a fuel cell that took up a bit more than a third of its bed. But adapting it to cars will be costly.
"I think, by the end of the decade, we'll see hundreds of thousands of fuel cells on the road," said Lawrence D. Burns, G.M.'s vice president for research and development. Whatever the timetable, the emphasis is shared by the Bush administration, which chose the auto show as the occasion to offer a fuel-economy plan focusing on fuel-cell development. 
Aside from its effort to squeeze fuel cells into conventional cars, trucks and buses, G.M. had a separate team of engineers and designers envision a vehicle unfettered by the constraints of the automobile, which for a century has been designed around an internal combustion engine and mechanical parts.
The result is a vehicle that comes in two parts. The first is what G.M. engineers call the skateboard, a six-inch-thick platform encasing the engine and the car's computer system. The body, including the seats and interior, will perch on the platform, with features like braking, steering and acceleration controlled digitally by electrical impulses.
At a recent demonstration, G.M. engineers showed a mockup of the skateboard, which was almost 15 feet long and shaped like a flattened carafe, with Goodyear tires and several thin, parallel heating vents curving up each side. The second part, the body, looked like a sci-fi version of a Formula One racecar. 
G.M. envisions that the skateboard will last about 20 years, with the body popped off and replaced with a version customized to the owner's tastes far more often. "This is like a blank canvas, and you can paint whatever you want on top," said Adrian Chernoff, a program architect on the project, adding that the body could be switched "in the time it takes for an oil change."
Mr. Burns said that G.M. hoped to produce a working prototype of the Autonomy by the end of the year, but with an 11-inch-thick skateboard, to fit hydrogen tanks large enough for a trip of 100 to 150 miles.
Such a vehicle would drastically alter automobile assembly, raising questions like who would make the bottom and who would make the top. 
Of course, concept cars often resemble an era's vision of the future more than the actual future. G.M.'s Firebird concepts of the 1950's paid homage to a booming airline industry, with turbine engines and tail fins that made it seem as if the cars were made from spare parts of fighter jets. Other concepts featured cool gizmos that never made it into production, like the rear-view camera mounted on the back of the 1956 vision of the Buick Centurion.
As for the fuel cell, the major automakers tout it as a silver-bullet answer to many of the problems that now cause their industry to butt heads with environmental groups. In their ideal form, fuel cells would replace gasoline with hydrogen and emit only water and heat. The cells strip electrons from hydrogen atoms and use them as an electrical current, then reform the hydrogen atoms, combining them with oxygen to form water vapor. The technology could in principle be as useful in supplying power to homes and industry as in powering vehicles.
So far, however, the fuel cell has mainly served only as an argument against regulatory pressure to make short-term improvements in fuel economy. At a Senate commerce committee hearing in December, G.M.'s vice president for product development, Thomas J. Davis, cited fuel cell research as a reason that existing fuel economy standards should not be raised. 
The standards have not significantly changed for more than a decade, and fuel economy gains have been reversed in recent years as sales of trucks have overtaken sales of cars. To address the issue, the Clinton administration emphasized development of high-mileage gasoline-fueled vehicles, a goal on which the big three automakers have been spending $1 billion a year.
"We'd rather take those dollars and move to solutions like the fuel cell faster," Mr. Burns of G.M. said in an interview. And that, in essence, is the vision the Bush administration has now embraced.

HEADLINE: Bad News Keeps Coming For Japanese Economy 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Other major economies around the globe may be seeing signs of a soft landing or an incipient recovery, but in Japan, the recession is beginning to bite hard.
 A big psychological blow came with today's announcement of a radical paring of Merrill Lynch's brokerage operations in Japan, with 20 of 28 branches to be closed and 70 percent of jobs eliminated. Just three years ago, the country was hailing Merrill's expansion here as a sign that foreign investment would help lift the country out of its doldrums. 
 Since then, the Tokyo stock market has fallen by half, and Merrill's retreat spotlights the evaporation of short-term hope for recovery. Surrounding it are less prominent signs that the world's second-largest economy is faltering badly -- job cuts, new lows for the yen and warnings of a banking meltdown by spring. 
"By the end of March, we will have a financial crisis -- that is 100 percent true," one influential ruling-party legislator, Yoichi Masuzoe, said today. "All economic fundamentals have become much worse."
Depressed prices for stocks and real estate keep eating away at the frail balance sheets of Japanese banks. In Japan's eight largest cities, land prices last year fell 5.5 to 9.7 percent, according to a survey released today by the Misawa Real Estate and Development Corporation.
In addition, Japan's depressed economy appears to be turning loans bad at least as fast as banks can write them off. Japan's 15 largest banks have said they expect to lose $17 billion in the fiscal year ending March 31. And on April 1, the government will proceed with a plan to restrict deposit insurance to accounts with less than 10 million yen ($75,364), a move the banks fear will panic depositors.
"It's quite possible that financial institutions will fail," Masaru Hayami, governor of the Bank of Japan, warned last month. "If a chain reaction of withdrawals occurs, like sea waves, it is highly likely to shake the financial system."
The government is determined to go ahead anyway, Heizo Takenaka, Japan's economic and fiscal policy minister, said Tuesday in Washington. Mr. Takenaka met with top economic officials from the Bush administration, who urged aggressive write-offs and foreclosures on troubled loans. 
Just the opposite appeared to be happening in Tokyo today. Local newspapers reported that a consortium of banks was preparing to lend up to $1 billion to Daiei, the nation's second-largest department store chain, which is already tottering under the weight of $17.5 billion in debt.
As a group, Japanese banks have a negative net worth of $1 trillion, according to a study released last week by the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research. Bailing them out would swell Japan's public debt, already the world's largest, by 15 percent, and threaten to crush the country's currency and bond markets, the institute said.
"Japan's deflation and debt crisis now constitute systemic risk to the global economy," the report warned, echoing a view shared by many Bush administration officials.
Making the situation even worse, layoffs and job-sharing are starting to spread among manufacturers that for years had clung to the old norm of lifetime employment.
Fujitsu said today that it was asking about 5,000 employees to take time off this year at 60 percent of regular pay. Kansai Electric Power, the nation's second-largest utility, announced 3,000 job cuts over the next three years. Kotobukiya, a major supermarket chain, said it woulddismiss 3,500 workers and close one-third of its 134 outlets.
Last month, Hitachi, Toshiba and Sanyo Electric announced that they would carry out job-sharing programs this year, affecting tens of thousands of workers.
About 70 of a group of 100 Japanese business leaders surveyed by Kyodo News said they planned to cut workers' wages in 2002, and about half said they were cutting their work forces.
With interest rates near zero and the public debt at record levels, Japanese policy planners are now using the only macroeconomic tool left in their box, a cheaper yen. The currency briefly reached 133 to the dollar today, a 39-month low in value; it has fallen 6 percent since Dec. 1.
But many economists doubt that Japan can export its way back to economic health. A recent study by Morgan Stanley estimated that a 10 percent fall in the yen's value would lift exports by just 1 percent.
In another indication that the Japanese are retreating from their stock markets, the Tokyo Stock Exchange reported today that last year, for the first time, foreigners accounted for 51.8 percent of trading by value. Separately, financial statements were released on Monday for 120 members of the upper house of Parliament who faced election last July. The average member had 60 percent of personal assets in real estate, 36 percent in bank deposits, and only 4 percent in stocks.

HEADLINE: End of the Road For HomeStyle, Despite Remake 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI and ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
Four issues after a redesign and editorial overhaul, Home Style magazine closed yesterday, the latest in a string of consumer magazines to shut.
 HomeStyle, which was published monthly by Gruner & Jahr and had a circulation of about 900,000, is another casualty of a brutal environment for the magazine industry, which has had to weather rising postal rates and paper prices, consolidating wholesalers and shrinking newsstands. 
 What makes its demise notable is that HomeStyle was part of the shelter category, which includes magazines about interior design, home furnishings and architecture and has long been considered a safe harbor during a bad economy as Americans stay home and spend what money they have inside their homes rather than outside. 
Last year, in a bid to lure more upscale advertisers, Gruner & Jahr hired Suzanne Slesin, previously the executive editor of House & Garden, as editor in chief of Home Style, the low-brow cousin to Architectural Digest, House & Garden and Elle Decor.
Ms. Slesin's magazine was reader friendly but also esoteric, with cover photos that were not traditional shelter magazine fare, like the dimly lighted figure of a man with a dog, and a woman lounging in bed, alongside articles about the revival of knotty pine and plaid's nontraditional appeal. 
"I'm sad and disappointed that in spite of our successes, we're not able to continue," Ms. Slesin said yesterday.
HomeStyle will cease publication after the March issue, on newsstands on Feb. 12.
Daniel B. Brewster Jr., the chief executive of Gruner & Jahr, said in a statement that the new magazine's ad pages and revenue "exceeded our goals by 22 percent." But the expectations must have been low. Its ad pages dropped 27 percent, to 436 pages for the issues dated January through November 2001 from 596 pages for the corresponding period in 2000, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. For the November 2001 issue alone, Ms. Slesin's second, pages were down by 44 percent, to 35 from 62 for the November 2000 issue, and revenue was down 45 percent, to $2.1 million from $3.9 million.
For the first six months of 2001, its newsstand sales averaged 70,800 copies a month, down from 97,000 in the first half of 2000, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

HEADLINE: Bush White House Starts Own High-Mileage Car Program 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
As the Bush administration replaced one government-backed program to build high-mileage cars with another today, hardly anyone rushed to eulogize the old project. Environmentalists said too much had been spent and too little accomplished, while automakers said the effort's goals had been unrealistic in the first place.
 The Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles, started in 1993 and championed by Vice President Al Gore, spent more than $1.5 billion in federal money. The goal was for General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler, now a unit of DaimlerChrysler, to work together with auto suppliers, government laboratories and universities on a range of technologies aimed at making cars more fuel efficient. 
 The project involved a host of government agencies -- the Departments of Commerce, Defense, Energy and Transportation, as well as the Environmental Protection Agency and NASA. 
Less than half of 1 percent of the money set aside for the program went to the Big Three. This year, about half of the program's $127 million budget was earmarked for various national laboratories. The Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois, for instance, receives financing for fuel cell research, and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory near Knoxville, Tenn., researches aluminum materials. Suppliers are scheduled to receive about 30 percent of the financing and universities another 15 percent. 
The program did create some useful technologies that showed up in vehicles on the road. Lightweight aluminum was used in the 2000 Lincoln LS and in some Cadillacs. The Jeep Wrangler has a thermoplastic roof that uses technology from the program. And some of the research into diesel-electric hybrid vehicles can be used in the gasoline-electric hybrids to be sold by the Big Three starting next year. 
But in the end, the program's main goal, to produce concept cars that could get 80 miles a gallon by 2004 -- and could be mass-produced -- is far from reality. United States automakers say that producing vehicles that could leap to 80 miles a gallon is not possible this decade. In fact, they even argued at a Senate hearing recently that raising fuel economy standards to 40 miles a gallon over the next half-decade would be a crippling blow to their business.
By contrast, two Japanese companies, Toyota and Honda, are already selling gasoline-electric hybrid vehicles that get better than 40 miles to the gallon, though their total fleets get far less. This year, Honda plans to start selling a hybrid version of its popular Civic. 
Current corporate average fuel economy standards, also known as CAFE, which have not been changed significantly in more than a decade, require 20.7 miles a gallon for each company's average new light truck and 27.5 miles a gallon for the average new car.
"You can build 80 m.p.g. cars, but if they cost too much, nobody is going to buy them," said William Noack, a spokesman for G.M.
Environmentalists say the project was ultimately a failure because it was not accompanied by an increase in federal fuel-economy standards.
"Al Gore said this would make CAFE obsolete," said Daniel Becker, director of global warming for the Sierra Club. 
"What did it result in? Not a single, purchasable hybrid" from the Big Three.
Environmentalists are equally skeptical of the Bush plan. The announcement today came as the Senate prepared to debate its energy bill. Spencer Abraham, the energy secretary, said the project would be replaced by a program that would focus almost exclusively on one of the current project's furthest-off areas of research, the development of vehicles powered by fuel cells. 
Mr. Abraham said in an interview that he had supported the partnership when he was in Congress, "but when we came here we concluded that no one was going to produce these vehicles and no one would buy them."
Fuel cells draw power from hydrogen and ideally emit only water vapor and heat. All of the major automakers are working on fuel cell projects and say they represent the eventual end to the internal combustion engine. But most envision only a few hundred thousand such vehicles on the road by the end of the decade. Among the hurdles is outfitting service stations with hydrogen. 
"There is no requirement in either plan that the auto industry actually produce the vehicles for sale," said Mr. Becker of the Sierra Club. "If Congress is fooled into not raising CAFE standards because of this new smoke screen, the pressure will be off Detroit again." 
Secretary Abraham called his program a 21st-century approach that would eventually end the fuel economy debate, but added that it was far too early to set a timetable to require automakers actually to produce fuel cell vehicles. 
"You can't expect people to put vehicles on the road if you don't have the infrastructure to support it," he said. "This is Day 1."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Carl Levin, left, speaks at the auto show in Detroit yesterday. The Ford vehicle is an experimental model powered by fuel cells. (Associated Press)

 BODY:
U.S. to Form a Task Force For Investigation Into Enron
The Justice Department plans to form a special task force of prosecutors from across the country to conduct the criminal investigation into Enron and its eventual collapse, government officials said. The move widens the potential scope of the inquiry.
 Legal experts said that the decision to create such a task force on a white-collar case involving an individual company was virtually unprecedented, and signaled that the government had elevated this case to a level of significance usually afforded to investigations of entire industries. Page A1. 

Merrill to Take $2.2 Billion Charge
Merrill Lynch, the nation's biggest brokerage firm, said that it had cut 9,000 jobs since October, on top of the 6,000 eliminated earlier last year. All told, Merrill has eliminated more than 20 percent of its jobs in a year. The company said it would take its largest charge ever, $2.2 billion, in the fourth quarter. Shares of Merrill rose $1.55, to $57.99. A1.

Merrill's cutbacks include a retreat in Japan, the latest sign that the economy is faltering badly there. World Business, Section W.

Instant AOL Challenges for Parsons
Richard D. Parsons, AOL Time Warner's co-chief operating officer, will not become chief executive until May, but he is already acting as if he has the job. And it seems the job will be even harder than many would have expected when his promotion was announced barely more than a month ago. News Analysis. C2.

HEADLINE: Upbeat and Still Challenging Cuomo, in More Ways Than One 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Starting a year when he plans to run for a third term, Gov. George E. Pataki's theme today seemed to be back to the future.
 The governor's annual address to the Legislature included an inventory of his achievements, a long list of bills he has tried before and will try again, and repeated references to the failings of his predecessor, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. It offered little that was new, and few clues as to how he plans to solve the state's looming financial crisis. 
 Instead, Governor Pataki put an upbeat cast on every topic he touched, pledging "the same confidence, the same optimism" as in brighter times -- no surprise for an incumbent seeking re-election. Even when paying tribute to the victims and heroes of Sept. 11, his speech had the ring of a campaign rally, a string of encomiums to the good will and good prospects of New Yorkers.
"We responded to evil with good," he said. "We answered terror with strength. We met adversity with resolve. We will defeat hatred with tolerance."
The Republican governor has never really stopped campaigning against Mr. Cuomo, the Democrat he unseated in 1993. With the former governor's son, Andrew M. Cuomo, the former United States housing secretary, now running for the Democratic nomination, Mr. Pataki returned to that tactic repeatedly.
When he took office, he said, "Failed government policies left us with a $5 billion deficit, massive job losses, bloated government bureaucracy, an oppressive regulatory climate and the highest taxes in America."
Mr. Pataki vowed today, despite a multibillion-dollar budget deficit, that he would not postpone promised tax cuts, "unlike 1989, unlike 1990, '91, '92, '93 and '94," and that he would not repeat the fiscal low points of the Cuomo years.
"We're not going to sell prisons to ourselves," he said. "We're not going to slash education funding in the middle of the school year. We're not going to use fiscal gimmicks to conceal reality."
Andrew Cuomo, in a statement, criticized the governor for failing to address problems, like a "near-Depression upstate," and complained that Mr. Pataki had predicted a multibillion-dollar deficit in the coming budget, but "did not tell us -- not a word -- how he plans to balance it."
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, the other Democrat in the race, said, "This speech was a recital of promises, mostly promises that he's made and broken in the past."
But listeners of all political stripes called the speech strategically smart, saying that an optimistic rallying call works well for a popular incumbent appealing to a public still seeking solace after the World Trade Center attacks.
"It was very rah-rah," said Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the state Democratic Party chairman. "It had some good sound bites, so I guess it makes sense for him. Though on the substance of what we are going to do, it was very thin." 
Representative Thomas M. Reynolds, a Republican from western New York, said, "In an election year, you highlight what you've accomplished -- you dwell on the positive."
That was surely more palatable for Mr. Pataki than confronting head-on what 2002 holds for him: a potentially difficult campaign, with an economy and state finances rocked by recession and terrorism.
The governor made a few references to fiscal woes, warning that the general fund budget would shrink in the coming year. But he did not call for shared sacrifice, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg did in his inaugural address. As for solutions, Mr. Pataki left much of that for the release of his proposed budget this month.
The new proposals he made, like preserving a million acres of wild land and raising health care workers' salaries, will cost money that is suddenly scarce.
"He didn't lay much groundwork for sacrifice," said Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission. 
Rather, Governor Pataki offered a resume, dwelling more on the past than ever before in this annual ritual.
He recited his record of cutting taxes, increasing spending on education and the environment, inaugurating or expanding a raft of health care programs, and setting aside billions of dollars in reserve funds. He asked again for things the Legislature had rejected, like an initiative and referendum system, mayoral control of big-city schools, campaign finance reform, easing of the Rockefeller-era drug laws, and anti-terror laws. 
Even those failures can work to the governor's advantage. The ideas are popular, and he can always blame a recalcitrant Legislature for their defeat. 
Mr. Pataki remains no one's ideal as an orator. When punching a point, his already reedy voice drops into a sort of emphatic whisper. His anodyne aphorisms -- "there is no place for criminals in a society of heroes" -- often fall flat.
But his delivery has improved, and he no longer suffers from frequent, unflattering comparisons to his predecessor's speech-making. More important, Mr. Pataki's style is familiar and comfortable to New Yorkers.
"Obviously, it works for him," said Patricia Lynch, a former Democratic Assembly aide and now a lobbyist. "Strategically, for a guy facing a tough year, he handled it exactly right."

Gov. Mary O. Donohue; H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller; and Joseph L. Bruno, Senate majority leader. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Who Lost the Surplus? 

BYLINE:  By Bruce Bartlett; Bruce Bartlett is a senior fellow at the National Center for Policy Analysis.

DATELINE: GREAT FALLS, Va. 

 BODY:
On Feb. 4, the White House will send to Congress its proposed budget for 2003. There is no doubt that it will project a severe decline in surpluses from the estimates made last summer. The question of what caused this deterioration is likely to be a major topic of discussion from now until Election Day.
 Senate Majority Leader Tom Daschle, who fired the opening gun in this debate last Friday, says, in essence, that the change is due mainly to the $1.35 trillion tax cut enacted last year. Since much of this tax cut is being phased in over several years, Mr. Daschle believes that those provisions not yet in effect should be shelved. 
 President George W. Bush, on the other hand, argues that rescinding the tax cut constitutes a de facto tax increase and says he will veto it. His budget documents will surely say that the falloff in surpluses is due almost entirely to the economic slowdown and new spending required by the events of Sept. 11.
Substantively, Mr. Bush probably has the better of this argument. After all, the tax cut didn't suddenly get bigger in the last few months. Last summer's budget estimates (the most recent) of the Office of Management and Budget and the Congressional Budget Office, which projected large surpluses, had incorporated the effects of the tax cut. Thus, any deterioration in the surplus must necessarily be due to other factors.
Those other factors are principally macroeconomic. Since last summer's budget review, we have learned that the economy has been in recession since March. One can fault government economists for not incorporating this fact into their budget projections, but private-sector economists did no better. Of the 54 forecasters surveyed by The Wall Street Journal in July, only two predicted a recession in 2001.
Although policy makers often talk as if the budget drives the economy, it is really the other way around. Almost all of the budget is highly sensitive to assumptions about economic growth, inflation and interest rates. Because slower growth simultaneously raises spending on social programs and reduces revenues, the surplus will fall by about $12 billion for every 1 percent of expected growth that doesn't materialize. Even after growth returns to the expected trend, the surplus will be lower every year than it was projected to have been. Over the 10 years following just a single year in which growth was 1 percent less than expected, the surplus will shrink by a cumulative $463 billion.
But this is not the end of the story. When growth is overestimated over a longer period, the impact on the budget is staggering. If growth were 1 percent lower than expected not just for one year, but for 10 straight years, the cumulative reduction in the surplus would balloon to $2.6 trillion.
What this means is that very tiny changes in economic assumptions, when projected out over a 10-year budget window, can quickly add up to real money. It also means that a sharp falloff in expected growth, even if it lasts for a brief period, can have a major impact on the budget long after growth has rebounded. For these reasons, the recession gets the lion's share of the blame for lower surpluses. The surplus did not cause the economy to prosper, as Senator Daschle says, but instead was a consequence of high growth. Higher than expected growth will cause spending to be lower and revenues higher. The way to restore surpluses is simply to restore growth.
Of course, restoring growth is easier said than done. Fortunately for politicians, the private sector does most of the heavy lifting. Indeed, forecasters now believe that the worst of the recession is past and that the economy will be growing smartly by mid-2002 regardless of whether Congress passes a stimulus bill.
So the debate about the surplus is not really about the economy, but about the proper role of government. Senator Daschle clearly has a more expansive view on this matter than does President Bush. The former would like to see surpluses restored, perhaps not only because he believes they are inherently good for the economy, but because they make it easier to enact new spending programs. For the latter, tax cuts are not just about raising growth, but also about keeping the size of government under control. The budget is simply the arena in which this continuing philosophical battle is fought.

HEADLINE: MAKING BOOKS; 
Best-Seller Lists Get a New Job

BYLINE:  By Martin Arnold 

 BODY:
Can best-seller lists indicate the country's political leaning? That's a tricky question. I don't recall reading much about it anywhere or hearing talk about it among book publishers.
 I suppose it's not surprising that post-Clinton books by conservatives are doing well in the marketplace, but I was startled to learn that five books appealing to political conservatives, a third of the total, will be on the New York Times hardcover nonfiction best-seller list on Jan. 20 and that one of them will be No. 1. Certainly something is happening with books of the political right, and I don't think it started very recently. 
 It may simply be that conservatives are writing books of political thought and moderates and liberals aren't. It may be that conservatives are simply more interesting when they do write and talk, and get to an audience's belly in a way that liberals and moderates don't. Or it may simply be that if you are a publisher and want to make money, the conservative writers with their broadcasting celebrity will attract the readers, so that's where you put your chips.
Whatever the reason, the No. 1 book on the list is about an issue precious almost beyond any other to conservatives, the one that roils the blood at many dinner parties: the alleged leftness of the news media, in this case, television news. (It must be conceded that many nonconservatives also look upon the press as a collection of rogues.) The book is "Bias: A CBS Insider Exposes How the Media Distort the News" by Bernard Goldberg, a former CBS correspondent, and its climb to the top of the list is perhaps the most astonishing publishing event in the last 12 months.
It was published by Regnery, the country's leading publisher of conservative books and chief supplier of anti-Clinton titles, having published 10 since 1996, not all of which would be likely to pass muster at an assembly of scholars. Bill Clinton seems to be to Regnery what Mickey Mouse is to Disney. Barbara Olson's "Final Days" (Regnery), which discusses "the last, desperate abuses of power" of the Clinton White House, is No. 6. (Ms. Olson died on a hijacked airliner on Sept. 11.) Alfred S. Regnery, 59, publisher and son of the company's founder, said that "Bill Clinton sold a lot of books and was very kind to us, to our economy if not anyone else's" but that nonetheless "we do more books on issues than on people." The Goldberg book, which had been rejected by some mainstream publishers, had a first printing of 75,000 copies and now has 225,000 in print.
It was originally scheduled for publication in mid-October but was delayed after Sept. 11 because, Mr. Regnery said, there was "the feeling that the media becomes your friend after such a big event," and that chummy perception wouldn't help sell a lot of that particular book.
Regnery, which merged with the conservative Eagle Publishing Company in 1993, publishes 40 to 50 titles a year, many of them avoided by other publishers, often because of politics. "We do a lot of thoughtful books on health and finance issues, and biographies," Mr. Regnery said, adding that Benjamin Franklin was in the works, "and we know our market." Indeed he does. It's not uncommon for a Regnery author to be interviewed on 200 to 300 radio talk shows, he said. "We get writers who tell us their last publisher got them six to eight interviews."
"We do have the market more or less to ourselves, so we can promote our books again and again," he said. All this feeds a large network of conservative talk shows and, of course, Eagle's book clubs, the principal one called, quite naturally, the Conservative Book Club, with 104,000 members. Eagle also owns Human Events, an ultra-right weekly, and The Evans and Novak Political Report, a monthly newsletter.
Regnery's first best seller was by a young man named William F. Buckley Jr., and the book was "God and Man at Yale," which fell like a bomb on elite academia in 1951. It was followed shortly thereafter by Russell Kirk's "Conservative Mind" and a new edition of "Witness" by Whittaker Chambers. Where Regnery has the missionary zeal as well as the profit motive, mainstream houses publish books by conservatives (or nearly anyone) mostly for the profit, but they do publish them. For instance, No. 7 on the best-seller list will be Bill O'Reilly's "No Spin Zone" (Broadway); No. 10, "When Character Was King," reflections on Ronald Reagan by Peggy Noonan from Viking; and No. 11, Pat Buchanan's "Death of the West" (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's).
But there has been no mainstream publishing house since Erwin A. Glikes ran the Free Press, then a division of Macmillan but now owned by Simon & Schuster, that was devoted mostly to conservative books, publishing writers like Allan Bloom, George Will, Robert H. Bork and David Brock. Glikes was succeeded by Adam Bellow, son of the Nobel laureate Saul Bellow, when the Free Press became part of Simon & Schuster and Glikes resigned. Mr. Bellow maintained the conservative franchise for a while, but now there's new direction, and the Free Press publishes a mixture of voices.
Which basically leaves the lucrative conservative field to Regnery. There is, however, a small independent publishing house founded five years ago, Spence Publishing, that publishes books that, for instance, discuss weighty topics like what religious toleration means ("The Long Truce: How Toleration Made the World Safe for Power and Profit," by A. J. Conyers). Its publisher, Thomas Spence, said that among other things, "the book sees prayer in public schools as a way for the state to intrude on religion." Now that makes this year's conservatives seem almost red.
A nonfiction publishing list is a thunder gust of conflicting ideas and hopes in which single-issue books and tales of the shenanigans of politicians seldom do well. That's the conventional wisdom. But what seems true for now at least is that if they are coming from the right, the author is apt to get rich.

HEADLINE: Boldface Names 

BYLINE:  By James Barron 

 BODY:
Secretary General Bloomberg?
 During the campaign, MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG said only four jobs could tempt him away from his communications conglomerate: president of the United States, secretary general of the United Nations, president of the World Bank and mayor of New York. 
 Having won one of those jobs, he had dinner at the Lotos Club Tuesday with KOFI ANNAN, the United Nations secretary general. "I know them both, and I knew they knew each other," said WILLIAM H. LUERS, president of the United Nations Association of the United States, who organized the dinner. 
Of the mayor, Mr. Luers said: "I think he was very open about the importance of the U.N. to the city, but it was basically ambience. There were no decisions made, no negotations undertaken." Among the others Mr. Luers invited were JOHN C. WHITEHEAD, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation; DEPUTY MAYOR PATRICIA HARRIS; and the mayor's sister, MARJORIE TIVEN.

No, but I Read the Book Jacket
There are advantages to being a best-selling author other than, say, megabuck advances: Airport security workers will accept your book-jacket photograph as identification.
"I used it on the Delta shuttle," said BRAD MELTZER, who was carrying his new page turner, "The Millionaires," when he rushed from the WNYW-TV early-morning program "Good Day New York" to La Guardia Airport. "The woman taking the tickets said, 'I saw him on TV,' " Mr. Meltzer reported.
He pointed out, nicely, that the resemblance between his face and the one in the photograph was no coincidence. "Then she said, 'I need some identification.' I said, 'Can I use this?' " Mr. Meltzer made the plane.

F. Scott Plimpton
GEORGE PLIMPTON is having an if-it's-Tuesday-this-must-be-Belgium kind of week. He has a date at the 92nd Street Y tonight for "Zelda, Scott and Ernest." In this adaptation of letters from the 1920's and 1930's, Mr. Plimpton plays F. Scott Fitzgerald; NORMAN MAILER plays Hemingway; and Mr. Mailer's wife, NORRIS CHURCH MAILER, plays Zelda Fitzgerald.
Mr. Plimpton had to fly to Toronto on Tuesday for the cable-television series "Nero Wolfe" (he plays Wolfe's lawyer). Worried about missing his plane home, he called Mr. Mailer about potential fill-ins.
"I suggested PAUL NEWMAN," Mr. Plimpton said. "Norman thought I was serious. He said, 'I know Paul very well. He's very fastidious. I don't think I could get him to do it that quickly.' "

Replicating Cosell's Comb-Over
So there was a screening of the made-for-television movie "Monday Night Mayhem." On Tuesday night.
One scene in the TNT film about the rise of ABC's "Monday Night Football" shows Howard Cosell, played by JOHN TURTURRO, taking off his toupee and revealing a comb-over. Mr. Turturro said that to duplicate Cosell's hairline, he had to shave his head for months, but only around the edges.
"So what," he said. "It's only hair." 
And that scene in which ROONE ARLEDGE, who went on to be chairman of ABC News, joins DICK EBERSOL, now the president of NBC Sports, in a hot tub, surrounded by women? "It never happened, or not like that," Mr. Ebersol said. "The producers decided they had too many scenes set in hotel rooms. And then they decided the hot tub scene looked too empty, so they added the girls."

Marc Anthony Wins in Court
A copyright infringement suit that accused MARC ANTHONY of stealing words and music for his biggest hit -- "I Need to Know," which won a Latin Grammy Award in 2000 -- has been dismissed. The songwriter DANIEL AGREN sued Mr. Anthony and his producer, CORY ROONEY, last year, citing a 1989 song of the same name.
"Our song was unique and original and that's what we were able to establish in persuading them to drop the case," Mr. Anthony's lawyer, ORIN SNYDER of the Manhattan firm of Parcher, Hayes & Snyder, said after JUDGE DENNY CHIN of federal court in Manhattan signed an order ending the case. A lawyer for Mr. Agren, DAVID JAROSLAWICZ, did not return a call for comment.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AMNESTY; 
7 Taliban Officials Surrender to a Governor and Go Free

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Seven high-ranking officials of the vanquished Taliban government, including the justice minister who played a leading role in the Taliban's repressive laws and the destruction of the Buddha statues at Bamian, surrendered to a provincial leader and were allowed to go free on Monday, a spokesman for Afghanistan's new government said today.
 The move raises fresh questions about whether the interim government in Kabul will be able to exert control over this land of feuding fiefs and warlords. 
 Officials here said they had not been consulted on the decision by the governor of Kandahar Province to grant amnesty. They said they had been informed a day later. 
"We're in the process of finding out whether these people qualify as war criminals," said Omar Samad, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry. "If that is the case, the interim administration will have to investigate."
Mr. Samad said the government was most concerned about the release of Mullah Nooruddin Turabi, the former justice minister, and Abdul Haq, the former chief of security for the western city of Herat.
As the ranking legal official of the Taliban, Mr. Turabi could be held to account for acts like the public executions of people in the Kabul sports stadium and the destruction of the giant statues last year.
Mr. Turabi, who has only one eye, was considered extreme in a regime of extremists.
Mr. Samad did not identify the other five officials who had surrendered, though he said one or two were Taliban elders, who had not taken an active role in governing the country. He said two people rumored to have turned themselves in, the former defense minister, Mullah Ubaidullah, and the former minister of mines, Mullah Saadudin, were not among those whose names had been supplied to the government.
Mr. Samad said the government was determined to bring to justice any Taliban leaders found to have committed crimes against the Afghan people or to have been accomplices of the terrorist network Al Qaeda.
To do that, though, it must confront independent-minded bosses like Gul Agha, the governor of Kandahar. After negotiations that were shrouded in secrecy, he agreed to free the Taliban officials if they handed over their weapons and vehicles and returned to their villages.
Kandahar, in southern Afghanistan, is the spiritual heartland of the Taliban. That means the freed men are likely to be welcomed back into village society. It also means they could slip across the border into Pakistan.
That ability to disappear is what worries United States officials, who continue to search for Osama bin Laden, the head of Al Qaeda, and Mullah Muhammad Omar, the spiritual leader of the Taliban.
Mullah Omar remains at large, despite reports that he was cornered in the Bagram district.
Mr. Samad said he was not aware of a request by the United States to gain custody of Mullah Turabi or Mr. Abdul Haq. An American military spokesman, speaking to reporters earlier today in Kandahar, did not sound overly alarmed by the reports of the release of the Taliban officials.
"We're not in the business of determining who should and should not be in custody right now," said Lt. James Jarvis of the Marine Corps.
Disputes over the surrender of Taliban leaders have erupted before, each time dramatizing the fractured nature of Afghanistan. The fall of Kunduz, in the north, was delayed while forces led by ethnic Uzbeks and Tajiks bickered over who should accept the white flag of the Taliban military commander.
Even though Afghanistan's provincial governors have nominally pledged allegiance to the new government, Mr. Samad acknowledged that keeping those power brokers in line would be extremely difficult.
"The interim administration is in control to the extent possible," he said. "We still have terrorists running around this country. We still have Taliban fighters running around the country. We still have threats to stability."
Even as the government was struggling with its unruly provinces, it sought to impose order in the capital.
The Interior Ministry ordered soldiers and paramilitary troops in Kabul to turn in their weapons or report to their barracks within 72 hours. Mr. Samad said the move was in accordance with the agreement reached in Bonn that created the temporary government.
The order drew praise from officials of the United Nations, which brokered the agreement. "If you choose to become a civilian, you have no need for your weapon," said Ahmed Fawzi, a spokesman for the United Nations here.
Disarming the soldiers, security guards, militia members and regular citizens who carry guns will pose a host of challenge. One is how to extract weapons from people who cannot imagine living without them.
Another is what to do with many of the soldiers who wish to remain in the army.
An estimated 700,000 people in Afghanistan carry guns. A spokesman for the Defense Ministry said in an interview today that Afghanistan did not need an army of more than 200,000. That means it will have to turn away many of its volunteers, disarming them in the process.
"For those people who refuse to give up their weapons, we will compel them," said the spokesman, Col. Salhe Registani. "When we start disarming them, their commanders will be less likely to challenge the government."
In an address on television -- a medium banned by his Taliban predecessors -- Hamid Karzai, the head of the interim Afghan government, laid out a brief blueprint for restoring economic and political stability.
"Let us join together and make a national army," he said, speaking in Dari, the Persian language used in northern Afghanistan. He said he would control inflation, encourage manufacturing of Afghan products, try to create jobs and foster a market economy.
Mr. Karzai also said his government would stop printing unsupported Afghani notes. Several different groups have printed Afghan currency in recent years, leading to a proliferation of bills not backed by the government.
