HEADLINE: Bloomberg's School Plan Gets Support in Albany 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared today to get a warm reception to his ideas for revamping the management of New York's public schools. 
 In his first mayoral trip to the state capital, where he came to watch Gov. George E. Pataki deliver his annual address, Mr. Bloomberg got greetings from legislators of both parties and open support from the governor for his idea of turning the Board of Education into a mayoral agency, a sentiment that appears to be gaining more support among members of the State Assembly. 
 In his inaugural address last week, Mr. Bloomberg said that "the public, through the mayor, must control the school system." Today, Mr. Pataki said: "Mayor, you are right. Real education reform means giving the mayors of our big cities that control. I will fight to give you that power this year." Mr. Pataki had also expressed support for mayoral control of city schools in past years. 
While only a few Democrats joined the state's Republicans in standing and clapping when Mr. Pataki made his remarks, the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said at a news conference later that he would keep an "open mind" about Mr. Bloomberg's idea, something he declined to do when Rudolph W. Giuliani was in office.
"I've ruled nothing out," Mr. Silver said, adding that a task force that he appointed to study the issue would look at several possibilities, including turning the board over to Mr. Bloomberg. 
Assemblyman Steven Sanders, the Manhattan Democrat who heads the Assembly Education Committee, said last week that abolishing the Board of Education was "highly unlikely" as an option for the task force to consider and the Assembly to approve.
However, since then, Mr. Bloomberg and his deputy mayor for policy, Dennis M. Walcott, have met with Mr. Sanders, and he has apparently softened his stance. "I expect there will be significant reforms," to the board, Mr. Sanders said today. "The mayor has a lot of ideas and we look forward to working with him. Mayor Giuliani was not interested in compromise. I think the new mayor will not limit his conversation to narrow topics and that kind of attitude will hold him in good stead around here."
Other possibilities include expanding the board but allowing the mayor to appoint most of the members rather than the two he now appoints (the borough presidents pick the five others), a method supported by the teachers' union. Another option is to make the Board of Education financially independent, with its own taxing authority. Mr. Silver said he would like to see any changes happen before the next school year began.
There were already signs that Mr. Bloomberg would get a better audience in Albany if he made the issue a priority, as his aides have suggested he would. Today, Mr. Silver invited the mayor into his Democratic conference, something Mr. Giuliani was never asked to do, and when he entered the conference room, Mr. Bloomberg got thunderous applause. 
Some people close to the speaker surmised that he and his staff would be much more open to negotiating with Mr. Bloomberg than Mr. Giuliani, who was often disdainful of the Assembly members and attacked Mr. Silver after Sept. 11.
J. Michael Boxley, counsel to Mr. Silver, watching Mr. Bloomberg leave the speaker's office today, whispered to another staff member: "It's going to be a lot better. It really is. You'll see."
That is not to say that Mr. Bloomberg, who hopped from a meeting with Senate Republicans to a brunch with Assembly Democrats to the speech and a private meeting with the governor here today, kept the mayoral stage to himself.
Mr. Giuliani, who once again hinted today that his career in politics was not over, sat in the same row as the new mayor during the governor's speech, and Mr. Pataki praised him openly during his remarks, which led to a standing ovation for Mr. Giuliani. 
When asked how he enjoyed being in Albany once again, Mr. Giuliani said, "I felt great, I felt sort of liberated to just feel the experience and say what I wanted to say and I didn't feel the pressure of having to worry about, you know, what's Albany going to do to us this year, are they going to help us, are they going to hurt us."
Indeed it is Mr. Bloomberg who must be concerned about what Albany plans to do this year, and his needs are great. With a roughly $4 billion hole expected in next year's budget, he will be looking to Albany for financial aid, particularly on economic development projects that he will need to convince the state that its battered budget can benefit from as well.
Mr. Bloomberg praised the legislators he met with today, and said he would return to Albany frequently. "New York City is a very big part of New York State," he said. "The health of the state is something that we care about. New York City and New York State, their relationships are inseparable."
As a parting gift, State Senator Serphin R. Maltese introduced legislation that would permit Mr. Bloomberg's daughter and his sister to work in his administration as volunteers.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Take me out to the ballgame, but don't make taxpayers build the ballpark. The high cost and low benefit of sports subsidies.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
IN his last week as mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a deal to issue tax-exempt municipal bonds to subsidize half the $1.6 billion cost of building new stadiums for the Yankees and Mets on the sites of the existing stadiums. The state would also throw in $150 million to improve parking and transportation. In return, the teams would sign 35-year leases, with no escape clauses. 
 Why spend nearly $1 billion of public money to subsidize facilities for a private industry in which billionaire owners pay multimillion-dollar salaries to average players? Mr. Giuliani justified it on economic grounds, saying, "This is something that would be very, very good for the economic development of the city." 
 He later boasted, "You can't underestimate the effect on civic pride and the economy of the city." 
Yet economists who study the sports industry say the only way to underestimate the economic value of subsidizing stadium construction is to use negative numbers. Experience suggests that subsidies for stadiums yield negligible economic benefits and expand the gap between the superrich and everyone else.
New York is not unique. Ever since 1953, when Milwaukee offered the Braves a $5 million stadium to lure the team from Boston, more than $20 billion of public money (in current dollars) has been allocated for stadium construction. The government has pitched in more than two and a half times what team owners have contributed. 
Economists argue that premier sports leagues exploit their monopoly position by pitting one city against another to extract income from taxpayers, usually in the form of stadium subsidies. If team location were not restricted by league monopolies, cities like New York would have more than two baseball teams, and competitive balance would be improved. In Japan, for example, 6 of the 12 professional baseball teams are in Tokyo or neighboring cities.
The extra money generated by subsidized stadiums accrues to owners and ballplayers. Ticket prices rise because of the new amenities. A reason athletes' salaries have soared in recent years is that leagues have grown better at playing hardball with host cities. 
A good overview of the economics literature is provided by John Siegfried of Vanderbilt and Andrew Zimbalist of Smith College in "The Economics of Sports Facilities and Their Communities," published in the summer 2000 issue of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. 
They argue convincingly that there is little reason to suspect that a new sports stadium will generate sufficient revenue to justify its cost. In the first place, if a team's revenue would rise enough to offset the cost of new construction, the owners would be willing to make the investments themselves; they're not. 
So for subsidies to make economic sense, enough additional economic activity must be generated to the rest of the city to offset the remaining costs. This is unlikely. Although a new stadium may entice more fans to come to the ballpark, the extra money they spend there is typically offset because they spend less elsewhere -- they attend fewer movies or concerts, play less golf or dine out less frequently. The total budget devoted to leisure activities is fairly inflexible, so the rest of the city suffers. 
To be sure, team owners have hired consultants who argue that there are large economic gains from stadium construction. But such promotional studies frequently ignore the substitution that takes place among leisure activities. By and large, academic studies that look at the actual experience of cities that build stadiums find no effect on the local economy, or a negative effect. 
Robert Baade of Lake Forest College and Allen Sanderson of the University of Chicago found that adding new stadiums had no systematic positive or negative effect on employment relative to trend levels in 10 cities from 1958 to 1993, and even in the positive cases the effects were quite small. Other work suggests that per capita income might decline in cities that subsidize sports stadiums because much of the income garnered by players and owners is spent outside the host city. Only 29 percent of professional basketball players, for example, have permanent homes near where they play, Mr. Zimbalist said.
Further corroboration of negligible economic effects of sports franchises comes from strikes. During the 1994 baseball strike, for example, "the relationship between a city's economic performance before and during the strike essentially was no different for cities that hosted teams and those that did not," according to a study by John Zipp of the University of Akron.
The money promised to the Yankees and Mets is enough to increase school spending in New York City by $1,000 a student or cover the fire department's entire budget for a year. Is the (probably trivial) economic payoff to the city from tearing down two historic stadiums to build domed ones in their place worth the cost when the money could be used to improve education and public safety? 
Even longtime fans are becoming fed up. Steve Warren, 69, a longtime fan of the New York Giants and then the Mets, said: "Devoted baseball fans like me have finally begun to realize that there is something inherently wrong with this beautiful game when owners pay obscene salaries to athletes and claim 'poverty' when it comes to improving facilities for fans, and instead seek public funds to build private stadiums. We are dunces if we continue to support them while they pull the wool over our eyes." 
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has the final say on Mr. Giuliani's pledge to subsidize stadiums, has been lukewarm to the idea, but still promised to give the teams $50 million to continue planning over the next five years. "The issue is really, 'Can we afford them?' " he said recently. "I will have to take a look down the road as the economy develops."
The real issue should not be whether we can afford them, but whether the benefits of subsidizing stadiums outweigh the costs, especially compared with the high economic and social payoff from competing uses of public financing. On this question, economists offer a resounding no. 
Moreover, Mr. Siegfried notes that even if the Yankees and Mets should move out, New York is unlikely to be without baseball -- the Twins and the Expos could move in. "Let's see baseball try to block that franchise move," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani supported plans to subsidize ballparks partly on the ground that they were good for development in New York. But many economists say the effects of such subsidies are negative. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Governor as Confectioner 

 BODY:
New York's governor, George Pataki, managed yesterday to seem upbeat about a state financial predicament that even he had to admit is a "fiscal crisis." What would have most state leaders preaching gloom and preparing the public for sacrifice had Mr. Pataki remembering the heroes of Sept. 11, recalling the Battle of Saratoga and offering up suggestions for additional, albeit modest, spending programs. 
 The governor was kicking off his own re-election campaign as much as a new season of the State Legislature. For a budgetary villain he resuscitated the era of former Gov. Mario Cuomo, who has been out of office for seven years. Mr. Pataki compared today's yawning state deficit, courtesy of Osama bin Laden and the recession, to the budget gaps left by Governor Cuomo in 1995. Unfair as that is, it is certainly a signal that it's election time again for Mr. Pataki. 
 In his eighth State of the State address, Mr. Pataki returned to many of his regular themes, and the fact that some of them, like reforming the drug laws and campaign finance rules, have been on his agenda before does not make them less worthwhile. 
Other old favorites included reforming and simplifying school aid formulas, a proposal that will work only if it is accompanied by a fairer allocation of state funds among the urban, rural and suburban school systems. With Mayor Michael Bloomberg in the packed Assembly chamber, Mr. Pataki also backed more mayoral control of and responsibility for city schools, a good idea that will not make it through the Assembly unless the governor adds significant political pressure to his support.
Given the perilous condition of the state's finances, Mr. Pataki had very little to say about specific sacrifices that will be needed to balance the budget. He promised to control state spending but he also refused to rule out any delays of tax cuts that could add to his substantial deficit, costing an additional $300 million next year. Mr. Pataki's call for bipartisanship and holding the line apparently rules out any sacrifices for his own pet programs. 
Perhaps he was saving the bad news for his budget address later this month. One hint of trouble to come was the governor's announcement that he would be sending the Legislature a proposal on health care in the next few days. According to a report in The Times earlier this week, the governor is planning to use funds from an increased cigarette tax and a payment of about $1 billion to the state from Empire Blue Cross-Blue Shield to boost salaries for state health workers. Blue Cross would make the payment if the state allows it to become a for-profit company, and the governor would be using this one-time payment to underwrite expenses that will recur every year. The package could also disrupt New York City's labor negotiations at a precarious financial time. While rewarding the politically powerful health care workers makes good sense for a re-election campaign, it may not be financially wise.
By the end of his speech, Mr. Pataki suggested that the Legislature could honor the nation's heros by "our unity." Judging from the applause by Republicans and the occasional groans among Democrats, New York State's Legislature will have to find another way. The 2002 election season started yesterday in Albany, and Mr. Pataki rang the opening bell.

HEADLINE: Pataki Vows to Limit Spending And to Avoid Delaying Tax Cuts 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Basking in the patriotic spirit in New York since Sept. 11, Gov. George E. Pataki promised in his annual address today to hold the line on spending without postponing tax cuts and urged lawmakers to rise above partisanship.
 The governor, a Republican who is preparing to run for a third term this fall, used much of his hourlong address to extol the heroics of the firefighters, rescue workers and police officers who died in the attack on the World Trade Center. He also publicly applauded his one-time rival and political nemesis, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose popularity has soared since the attack. 
 Mr. Pataki then asked the Assembly members and senators to abandon the partisan bickering that has paralyzed budget talks and negotiations over major bills for the last year. "Since Sept. 11, partisanship has given way to a new spirit of unity," the governor declared. "People want an end to partisan politics, and they deserve it." Excerpts, Page B4. 
The speech included few new proposals, but did lay out some goals that, if the Legislature agrees, will help him appeal to voters he needs to woo next fall. He called again for lessening the state's harsh mandatory sentences for drug crimes, a hot issue among minority voters.
He also asked lawmakers to pass a law making it illegal to discriminate against homosexuals, a group whose support he would like. In a nod to environmentalists, he pledged to add a million new acres of parkland over the next 10 years. He also pledged to improve the delivery of care to women with cervical or breast cancer, a promise sure to help his image among women.
Mr. Pataki, mindful of the poor showing of Republican candidates in upstate communities in the last election, also said he would introduce a raft of proposals for spurring the faltering economy in places like Buffalo, Syracuse and Rochester. He provided few details.
On the state budget, Mr. Pataki asserted that the terrorist attacks had crimped tax collections and predicted that "revenue losses will reach into the billions."
"We will lose more in revenue than many states collect," he said.
Yet Mr. Pataki did not lay out how he would close the gap. Sounding what is likely to become a campaign theme, the governor vowed not to go back to what he called the fiscal gimmicks Gov. Mario M. Cuomo employed in the last administration, like selling the prisons to the Dormitory Authority to raise cash for expenses. 
He also vowed that he would not repeat Mr. Cuomo's tactic of postponing tax cuts already enacted. There are about $300 million worth of tax cuts scheduled to take effect this year. "Tax cuts will go forward," he said, as the Republicans rose to give him the longest ovation of the speech and Democrats sat glumly.
"They must go forward, because we know that tax cuts create jobs," he said. "This year, next year and beyond, we will cut taxes by hundreds of millions of dollars."
The governor then congratulated the lawmakers for not proposing an increase in their own budgets this year. Some lawmakers grimaced. "Stop grumbling," the governor chided. "It's the right thing to do."
Mr. Pataki left his budget plans vague, saying only that he would hold the line on spending and would decrease spending from the general fund. That is a relatively meaningless promise, Democrats said. Governors have long manipulated what programs are paid for from the general fund and from other revenues to make it appear that they are restraining spending.
The governor said he would soon send the lawmakers a bill that would pay for salary increases for hospital workers and nurses in health care institutions across the state. The proposal would pay for the raises with a bigger tax on cigarettes and a $1 billion windfall the state should receive from the conversion of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to a for-profit insurer. The proposal also depends on Congress's agreeing to shoulder a slightly bigger share of Medicaid costs.
Some Democratic lawmakers have called the proposal a fiscal gimmick of the kind Mr. Pataki lambasted in his speech, because it would, in essence, spend a one-time windfall on salary increases. The bill would also pay for several other health programs, among them drug subsidies and walk-in clinics, through new sources of revenue, taking them out of the general fund.
"It's the way you do the books that counts," said the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat.
The speech was studded with other promises and requests. Mr. Pataki called on the Legislature to amend the State Constitution to allow residents to put referendums on the ballot through petitions. 
As he has in the past, the governor called for abolishing parole for all felons and he asked the Legislature to make the legal definition of drunkenness more strict. He said the state needed to pass campaign-finance reform. He pleaded with the Legislature to lift the statute of limitations for rape. He again asked the Legislature to streamline the cumbersome formulas for allotting aid to schools.
He also repeated his call for New York City schools to be placed under the mayor's control.
Despite his call for bipartisan cooperation, most or Mr. Pataki's proposals were applauded by only one side of the aisle or the other. Most Democrats were silent when he talked about ending parole. Most Republicans were quiet when he called for equal rights for homosexuals.
After the speech, the party lines were quickly drawn. H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and a Democratic candidate for governor, dismissed the address as a string of meaningless pledges. "The real issue is: are we going to see any of these promises fulfilled," he said. "What we heard is a long list of promises we have heard before."
The leader of the Republican majority in the Senate, Senator Joseph L. Bruno, said his conference would embrace the governor's call for more money to spur economic development outside New York City. Despite the state's gloomy finances, the governor said he would propose $250 million for biotechnology research and $100 million in low-interest loans for small businesses upstate.
Mr. Pataki wrote the speech himself, with some help from his chief speechwriter, John Wolfe, aides said. This being an election year, many in the audience viewed it as the beginning of Mr. Pataki's campaign. The governor tried to tie himself to the heroic deeds of Sept. 11. He waxed poetic about the dead, saying they watched the audience from heaven.
"Let us, through our unity, continue to make them proud," he said. "And let us do so full in the faith that they are still watching us, full in the faith that on that fateful morning, from the fury of violence the souls of thousands rose, up from the cloud of dust, and above freedom's harbor, they traveled through the sky toward God, and left the vivid air signed with their honor."
But when the applause ended, the business of politics began in the marble halls of the Capitol. The budget to be unveiled on Jan. 22, many said, would erase the warmth of Mr. Pataki's speech, as the battle over money in an election year begins.
"The budget will come to this as a cold shower after a steam bath," said a Democratic assemblyman, Richard L. Brodsky.

A front-page article yesterday about Gov. George E. Pataki's annual address to the New York Legislature misstated the name of the state agency to which the Cuomo administration sold two prisons in the early 1990's to close a gap. It was the Urban Development Corporation, not the Dormitory Authority.

HEADLINE: Bush Plan Seeks to Restore Food Stamps for Noncitizens 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
The Bush administration proposed today to restore food stamps to many legal immigrants, whose eligibility for benefits was severely restricted by the 1996 welfare law.
 The White House said that at least 363,000 people -- legal immigrants who have not become citizens -- would qualify for food stamps under the plan, to be included in the budget President Bush sends Congress in early February. The proposal would cost the federal government $2.1 billion over 10 years, the administration said. In October, 18.4 million people were receiving food stamps. 
 Mr. Bush's plan, or something like it, has an excellent chance of becoming law. The Senate is considering such changes as part of a far-reaching bill to reauthorize farm and nutrition programs. Under the proposal, the White House said, noncitizens with low incomes could qualify for food stamps after living here legally for five years. A similar test already applies to legal immigrants seeking Medicaid or cash assistance.
The welfare bill passed by Congress and signed by President Bill Clinton in 1996 made noncitizens ineligible for food stamps and many other types of assistance financed with federal money. Supporters of the ban, mostly Republicans, argued that federal benefits drew immigrants to the United States and then discouraged them from working.
Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, expressed the intent of Congress in 1996 when he said, "Immigrants should come to the U.S. with their sleeves rolled up, ready to work, not with their hands out, ready to go on welfare."
But today, amid a recession that is hurting many immigrants, and with the government waging a war on terrorism that has targeted some immigrants, Mr. Bush is eager to show his commitment to them. He is also eager to address domestic problems -- a transition his father failed to make effectively a decade ago after the Persian Gulf war. 
Many of those who could benefit from the food stamp proposal are Hispanic. The White House has been ardently courting Hispanic voters.
In an interview today, Newt Gingrich, the House speaker in 1996, said: "I strongly support the president's initiative. In a law that has reduced welfare by more than 50 percent, this is one of the provisions that went too far. In retrospect, it was wrong. President Bush's instincts are exactly right."
Mr. Bush is selectively disclosing parts of his budget in advance -- specifically, those proposals likely to win political support -- as Mr. Clinton often did.
Antihunger groups and Hispanic groups praised the Bush plan. "This is an enormous step forward, for which the president should be congratulated," said Cecilia Munoz, vice president of the National Council of La Raza, a Latino civil rights group. "Mr. Bush did not speak out on this in the presidential campaign, and he had not done so since he assumed office."
As governor of Texas and as president, Mr. Bush has taken pride in his good relations with Hispanic Americans. Karl Rove, the president's senior political adviser, said last year that capturing a bigger share of the Hispanic vote was "our mission and our goal" and would require assiduous work by "all of us in every way."
But the Republican Party is split, and some Republicans have alienated Hispanic voters by espousing a restrictionist immigration policy.
Representative Tom Tancredo, Republican of Colorado, said he would fight the president's food stamp proposal because it would "entice people to come to the United States to be on welfare."
Mr. Tancredo, chairman of the Immigration Reform Caucus, with 55 members in the House, said: "The president has chosen to steal a page out of the Democrats' playbook. The Democrats have been enormously successful in buying votes through welfare. That's all this is, a sop to a Democrat-leaning voter bloc, an attempt to expand our political base by including the Hispanic vote."
Since the Sept. 11 attacks, the government has detained more than 1,100 noncitizens for questioning and has stepped up enforcement of immigration laws. Mr. Bush insists he is waging war on terrorists, not immigrants, and his food stamp proposal can be cited to support that claim.
James D. Weill, president of the Food Research and Action Center, an antihunger group, said, "It's really positive that the administration wants to extend food stamp benefits to this group of legal immigrants." He said his group had been supporting a broader restoration of food stamps, as proposed by Senators Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, and Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa. But Mr. Weill said, "Everybody is moving in the same direction, and we are delighted to see that."
The economy is worse now than in 1996, when Mr. Clinton signed the welfare bill. "Immigrants have been hit hard by the economic downturn," Ms. Munoz said, "and there's no safety net for those who arrived after 1996."
Welfare and food stamp rolls have plummeted since 1996, and members of Congress express much less concern now about being overwhelmed with the programs' cost, even though budget surpluses have evaporated.
In general, food stamps are available to people with gross incomes up to 30 percent above the poverty level. A three-person household can qualify if its gross income does not exceed $1,585 a month.
Federal officials said Mr. Bush's proposal would make it much easier for state and local employees to determine whether an immigrant was eligible for food stamps. The immigrants are generally ineligible now, but there are some exceptions based on a person's age, work history and date of entry into the United States.
About 800,000 immigrants were removed from food stamp rolls in 1996, according to the Agriculture Department, which runs the program. Two years later, benefits were restored to about 175,000 immigrants, mostly children and older people who were in the country before the legislation was signed in August 1996.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
A War of Loose Ends

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
America's goals in Central Asia were easily explained as Kabul and Kandahar fell, when daily Pentagon videos showed bombs homing in on caves in Tora Bora and when there was a reasonable prospect that Osama bin Laden, Mullah Muhammad Omar and their top aides would soon fall into American hands.
 But that was last month. And while President Bush was taking a New Year's break on his ranch, and then returned here to focus on the economy and education, his war against terrorism entered a murkier, messier moment. While the president insists that his goals are unchanged -- a broad war against all terrorists with a global reach -- events have forced a more diffuse, complex strategy. 
 Today, officials raised alarms about Iranian meddling in the lawless western reaches of Afghanistan and an American transport plane crashed, for still-unexplained reasons, in Pakistan. American troops were engaged in a search of the border between Pakistan and Afghanistan for hundreds of Taliban and Al Qaeda leaders still at large, and what just weeks ago looked like a ruthlessly effective war from the air today looks more like police work in a bad neighborhood.
The new complexities are evident from the way Mr. Bush and his top aides speak about their challenges these days -- and what they have suddenly chosen not to talk about.
"We're in a dangerous phase," the president volunteered on Saturday during a swing through the West Coast. He was speaking of the cave-to-cave searches in Afghanistan and the death on Friday of Sgt. First Class Nathan R. Chapman, of the Army Special Forces, killed in a firefight that now appears to have been an ambush. But he could just as easily have been talking about everything else that has cropped up while he was cutting new trails across his 1,600-acre ranch.
Once Mr. Bush talked about the hunt for Mr. bin Laden and Mullah Omar regularly, without prompting. Now he rarely does, beyond a cursory repetition, in every speech, that sooner or later, somewhere, the United States will bring "the evil ones" to justice.
His aides insist that there was no decision made to depersonalize Mr. Bush's language, even though they acknowledge that when he uttered the words "dead or alive" about Mr. bin Laden, even Laura Bush warned him that he was sounding a little overzealous. But as one senior administration official close to Mr. Bush said last week, "There's not a lot be gained by talking about them," especially when they appear to have escaped.
So at the Pentagon this week, officials announced that they are no longer going to provide regular updates on the manhunt.
Moreover mopping up in Afghanistan is only one of several worries confronting the administration. The prospect of war between India and Pakistan now consumes more of the attention of Mr. Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. Senior administration officials, are still engaged in an internal debate over whether to open a second front -- and, if so, where. If the time is not ripe to take on Saddam Hussein, should the United States set its sights on Somalia and Southeast Asia? 
But even as those debates continue, Mr. bin Laden remains unaccounted for. The search of the burned-out caves in Tora Bora produced evidence that Mr. bin Laden, an ineffective fighter, was perhaps a more successful fugitive. (He had recently been in residence.) But that only raised new suspicions about whether the surrogate ground force the United States had used for the campaign in the caves had, through incompetence or corruption, let him slip away.
Mr. Bush's aides focus instead on what has gone right in Afghanistan. The new government is taking power more smoothly than many anticipated, they note. British peacekeepers have arrived, women are lining up to get into Kabul's shattered university and the cleanup of mines and Al Qaeda hideouts continues. Two senior Al Qaeda fighters were seized earlier this week, and intelligence agents are sorting through a trove of computers, old notebooks and maps seized from Al Qaeda safe houses. Hundreds of prisoners, assessing their sudden change of fortune, have begun to talk -- except those who are suicidal and bent on taking their captors with them.
Mr. Bush uses these events to argue that Washington pundits who declare the war has bogged down are as wrong today as they were in early October, before the fall of the Taliban.
"We're making steady progress -- and I use the word 'steady' because sometimes it seems like there is a certain impatience in the airwaves," Mr. Bush said during a talk on Saturday to a cheering crowd of students and their parents at Parkrose High School on the outskirts of Portland, Ore.
He suggested that the public understands the difficulties ahead, perhaps better than the experts and commentators. "I don't believe that there's an impatience amongst the American people," he said. Tomorrow, Mr. Bush will appear at the Pentagon to sign a bill providing a large increase in military spending, in part in the expectation that the mission in Afghanistan will be long and costly.
Still, the White House seems not to have many ready answers about its own next moves.
At his daily briefing today, Mr. Bush's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, largely deflected questions about how long the growing ranks of prisoners in Afghanistan will be detained, whether they are truly "prisoners of war," or what kind of discussions are under way about how to try the midlevel members of Al Qaeda now in custody. He made it clear that Mr. Bush is less interested in the legal niceties than the practical necessity of letting peace take hold.
"If the alternative is to let them roam Afghanistan free again to commit more crimes and to engage in war, that's clearly not an option," he said.
Officials caution that the campaign in Afghanistan, which has experienced periods of intense activity followed by periods of halting progress, is likely to continue in this way. The end of the war on terrorism, they say, is nowhere in sight.
Yet while it continues, there is at least one urgent new front to address. Inside in the offices of the National Security Council, Afghanistan seems far less a priority than assuring that India and Pakistan do not trip into war -- or that Pakistan's radical Islamic minority does not seize the moment to confront President Pervez Musharaff, Mr. Bush's new ally. The State Department announced today that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell would travel to India and Pakistan next week.
"Afghanistan is now a cleanup operation, and cleanup operations are by their nature less focused than active combat," argued one of Mr. Bush's senior advisers last weekend. "But the bigger risk right now isn't that Afghanistan is going to implode -- that's actually going better than we expected -- it's that the rest of the neighborhood will go up in flames."

HEADLINE: Ex-Labor Secretary Outlines Race to Lead Massachusetts 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 9 

 BODY:
Bursting late into a crowded field, Robert B. Reich, the former secretary of labor, announced today that he would be a Democratic candidate for governor of Massachusetts.
 Mr. Reich, a professor of social and economic policy at Brandeis University who speaks and writes broadly on those subjects, said he would make the state's sagging economy a priority. 
 In his announcement at a Back Bay hotel, Mr. Reich called Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift, a Republican who is seeking re-election, "something of an embarrassment." 
But before Mr. Reich (pronounced rysch) can campaign against Ms. Swift, he will have to compete for the Democratic nomination against five other candidates. That could be quite difficult under the party's nominating rules. To qualify for the primary election, a candidate must get 15 percent of the vote at the state Democratic convention, on June 1. 
The other candidates -- State Treasurer Shannon P. O'Brien; former State Senator Warren Tolman; Steve Grossman, a businessman; Secretary of State William Francis Galvin; and Thomas F. Birmingham, the State Senate president -- have had significant head starts in campaigning and fund-raising.
"I don't have any illusions how difficult it is for me to even get on the ballot in Massachusetts," Mr. Reich said today.
But he said he entered the race because he believed he had "something extra" to offer.
Mr. Reich, 56, made it clear he intended to use his experience as secretary of labor during the first four years of the Clinton administration as a drawing card. 
"I was a member of an administration that presided over the longest period of expansion and economic growth in American history," he said. 
People close to Mr. Clinton said they could not imagine that the former president would support Mr. Reich's campaign. After Mr. Reich left the administration, he was not bashful about criticizing the president. A former Clinton White House official put it this way, "It will be interesting to see how former Secretary Reich will explain a number of very negative comments in the last several years about President Clinton to Democratic primary voters in Massachusetts."
Mr. Reich said he talked with Mr. Clinton and had not been discouraged from running. Mr. Grossman, who was chairman of the Massachusetts Democratic Party and then the national party, has said he has Mr. Clinton's support.
Mr. Reich is one of four Clinton cabinet officials running for governor in their states. The others are Andrew M. Cuomo, the former housing secretary, in New York; Janet Reno, the former attorney general, in Florida; and Bill Richardson, the former energy secretary, in New Mexico. 
Mr. Reich said he planned to lay out specific plans for improving the economy in speeches in the coming weeks. In previous interviews, he has not ruled out the possibility of seeking an increase in the state capital gains tax, something none of his Democratic opponents have touched. 
Today, he said, he would "do everything in my power not to raise taxes, but I am not going to make any read-my-lips promises or say over my dead body. That would be irresponsible."
In his speeches, Mr. Reich often jokes about his short stature. In his closing punch line today, he said, "I am not a big man. But it is not the size of the dog in the fight. It is the size of the fight in the dog."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, with his wife, Clare Dalton, yesterday in announcing his candidacy for Massachusetts governor. (Jared Leeds for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES; 
Kung-fu Brave Vs. Gallic Beast

BYLINE:  By Dave Kehr

 BODY:
Born in Hawaii and raised in Germany, the martial-arts champion Mark Dacascos plays an American Indian in the French film "Brotherhood of the Wolf."
 That's one working definition of globalization, but Mr. Dacascos, who lives in Los Angeles with his wife and year-old son, is a modest man who sees nothing very strange in his resume. 
 "My mother and father are both kung-fu teachers," Mr. Dacascos said, "and most of my free time was spent at their kung-fu school, either training or doing my homework in one of the back rooms. When I was 9, we moved to Hamburg, Germany, and I lived there until I was 18. However, when I was 17, I did spend 6 months in Taiwan." 
"My mother is half-Irish and half-Japanese, and my father is Spanish-Chinese-Filipino," he added, by way of explaining his global dimensions. "When I was going to school in Hawaii almost 30 years ago, I looked very different from everyone else. I was really a fish out of water. I wanted to be like all the other kids, but there was no way I could. I was searching for an identity, and I think I found it at my dad's martial-arts school, where I took on more of my Chinese heritage."
"Brotherhood of the Wolf," which opens today (review, page 30), is a period adventure film, set during the reign of Louis XV when a mysterious beast was terrorizing southern France. It was a huge hit in France last year, and opens stateside today, in the hope of joining "The Closet," "Amelie" and "The Crimson Rivers" in what has become an unexpected surge of French films finding mainstream acceptance in the United States.
Mr. Dacascos plays Mani, an Iroquois warrior brought back from the New World by Gregoire de Fronsac (Samuel Le Bihan), a naturalist assigned by the king to track down the rampaging beast. The resourceful Mani befriends the wolves of the forest, who lead him to the beast's lair.
"I'm not Native American," Mr. Dacascos said. "However, I feel the belief systems of the Native Americans are very similar to the people from Hawaii, in that we really respect nature. Just having those senses definitely helped me. And I worked with a Mohawk cultural teacher, Alex Rice, who tried to explain the values of her people to me.
"Of course, we wanted to make Mani a person of flesh and blood, too -- not just this noble sage guy walking around with a straight face," Mr. Dacascos said. "I wanted to find a sense of humor and give him some flaws. He's very highly evolved, but in spite of that, he can still get drunk and go to a brothel and have a good time."

Pasadena Scribbler
"I didn't grow up in Orange County, but all of my family lives there," said Mike White, the screenwriter of the engaging teenage comedy "Orange County," which opens nationally today (review, page 32). "I grew up in Pasadena, which is just splitting hairs. I was a young scribbler, and for some reason I always wanted to be a writer, but I grew up in a world where that didn't seem like an option. I had idealized fantasies of higher education, the idea that somewhere outside my homeland there'd be a place that would take me where I wanted to go."
The main character in "Orange County," Shaun Brumder (played by Colin Hanks, son of Tom Hanks), is a scribbler, too, and he has placed his hopes on going to Stanford, where his favorite novelist (Kevin Kline) is on the faculty. But when an incompetent high school counselor sends someone else's transcripts to the university, Shaun finds himself rejected. With the help of his girlfriend (Schuyler Fisk, daughter of Sissy Spacek) and his stoner brother (Jack Black), he sets out to correct this gross injustice, only to create further problems along the way.
The film was produced by the theatrical division of MTV, and for Mr. White, "the fun of the movie was making an MTV movie that in some lighthearted way subverted the MTV childhood that I had."
Mr. White's scribblings went on to include several scripts for the popular television series "Dawson's Creek" and the independent film "Chuck and Buck," in which Mr. White played one of the title characters, a sweetly eccentric young man who has been harboring a secret crush on his best friend from grade school for 20 years. He also plays a small but telling role in "Orange County," as an English teacher with an uncertain understanding of Shakespeare. "The acting thing is just kind of a whim," Mr. White said. "It's not really my focus; it's just fun. What's frustrating is when you write stuff and then you hand it off, and you're not a part of the production side of it. Acting has been a way of being part of the production of the movie, even if I'm not directing it."
Directing is definitely on the horizon for Mr. White, who last year had a television series of his own devising, "Pasadena," on the air. "It was the first time I had creative control, and now I'm feeling like it would be cool to direct," he said. "There comes a time when you're tired of being a backseat driver, and you're ready to succeed or fail on your own terms."

Japan Noir
The winter film series at the Japan Society (333 East 47th Street, Manhattan) is called "Dark Visions: Japanese Film Noir and Neo-Noir." Though it concludes with a couple of well-known films by Akira Kurosawa -- the 1948 "Drunken Angel" (March 19) and the 1963 "High and Low" (March 22) -- most of the movies in the series won't be familiar to western audiences: they include work by less celebrated masters like Yoshitaro Nomura ("The Chase," Jan. 25), Kiyoshi Kurosawa ("The Guard From Underground," Feb. 1) and Sogo Ishii ("Labyrinth of Dreams," Feb. 8).
For Daisuke Miyao, a film historian and doctoral candidate at New York University who will introduce the series with a lecture next Friday at 6:30 p.m., the significant difference between American and Japanese film noir is one of time frame: at their height in the late 1940's and early 50's, the Hollywood noirs expressed the despair and disillusionment of a generation returning from war, while the Japanese noirs were a phenomenon of the late 50's through the 60's, when, Mr. Miyao said, "people were losing faith in the new economic and political systems, and looking for other values."
For Mr. Miyao, one quintessential Japanese film noir is the movie that will be shown after his lecture, at 7:30: Seijun Suzuki's "Branded to Kill" (1967). "Its use of a complicated narrative and complicated points of view, its use of the femme fatale figure and its very nihilistic, cynical, thematic motifs make it a classic of the golden period," he said.
Information: (212) 752-3015.

HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

* ARTS ON THE HIGH WIRE, Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Manhattan, (212) 485-1534. Between the Sept. 11 attacks and the recession, contributions to nonprofit arts organizations slumped seriously in 2001. Artists working in the World Trade Center area also suffered damage to studios, artworks and spirits. This benefit concert will raise immediate money for the New York Arts Recovery Fund along with recognizing that the arts need support. The lineup, featuring musicians with downtown sensibilities, includes the songwriters Joe Jackson and Suzanne Vega, the performance artist Laurie Anderson, the clarinetist and composer Don Byron, the turntablist quartet the X-ecutioners and the composer and improviser John Zorn, along with dancers (Elizabeth Streb), cartoonists (Jules Feiffer, Ben Katchor, Art Speigelman), authors (Paul Auster, Roy Blount Jr.), the clown Bill Irwin and, yes, a tightrope walker: none other than Philippe Petit, who once walked a wire strung between the tops of the World Trade Center towers. Tonight at 8; tickets are $15 to $25 (Jon Pareles).

ANDY BISKIN, DREW GRESS, DAVE BALLOU, Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 989-9318. Mr. Biskin, the clarinetist -- a builder of melodically coherent, ear-pleasing jazz miniatures -- is an idea person. You can hear in his music the particular assignment he was giving himself. In the past he has worked with a New Orleans-style frontline, and with the songs of Stephen Foster, among other things; now he's trying out a trio with clarinet, bass and trumpet. The lack of a drummer leads to openness; it can be a fertile valley to explore. Tomorrow night at 9; cover charge is $10 and there is a $6 minimum. (Ben Ratliff).

GEORGE COLEMAN OCTET, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, Manhattan, (212) 864-6662. Here is the great Memphis tenor saxophonist, a perennially underrated musician and a serious harmonic improviser, in a rare grouping, getting away from his usual quartet. Included in the band are some of the musicians who have become regulars at this uptown club, like the trumpeter Jim Rotondi and the bassist John Webber, and others like Gary Smulyan, the Carnegie Hall Jazz Band's baritone saxophonist. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9, 11 and 12:30; cover charge is $18 (Ratliff).

EKOOSTIK HOOKAH, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. The lyrics to Ekoostik Hookah's songs often long for refuges where the good times roll, and the music takes the jam-band route to get there, putting pushy blues guitar and shifty meters into the Grateful Dead format. After 10 years on the circuit, the band has a dedicated following. Tomorrow night at 9:30, with an opening set by Brothers Past; tickets are $10 in advance, $12 tomorrow (Pareles).

* GIGI, KARSH KALE, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778. Gigi comes from Ethiopia, where funk, African melodies and Arabic inflections added up to music full of unexpected angles and modal curves. The longing in her songs is communicated without translation by her plaintive but determined voice. In the United States, the producer Bill Laswell hooked up her music with jazz and electronics on her impressive debut album, "Gigi" (Palm Pictures); for these shows, she will have acoustic backup. Tonight at 9; admission is $15. Tomorrow night at 6:30 she shares a bill with Karsh Kale, a tabla player and disc jockey whose far-reaching band fuses Indian traditions and electronica; admission is $20 (Pareles).

* JIM HALL TRIO, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-3080. There's probably no more self-effacing player at Jim Hall's level in jazz; he plays as if he could ditch it all tomorrow and never think about it again. His own compositions are sweet, oddball, sectional, played against lithe, swinging accompaniment. (This weekend it's Scott Colley on bass and Terry Clarke on drums.) Even at their most unconventional, Mr. Hall's tunes sometimes run the risk of sounding dinky, using light blues and country phrases in original, circuitous song forms that aren't their natural element. But he is true to himself. He is not razzing popular music or pulling anybody's leg, and his trail of accomplishments speak for themselves: his late-50's stint in Jimmy Giuffre's trio, his playing with Sonny Rollins ("The Bridge") and Art Farmer ("Live at the Half Note") and a recent, late-blooming explosion as a composer and arranger. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11; cover charge is $30 and there is a $10 minimum (Ratliff).

HOOBASTANK, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111. The eternal adolescent identity crisis takes shape in Hoobastank's tuneful, vigorously strummed songs, which sound something like the Dave Matthews Band playing tributes to Tool and Rage Against the Machine. Tonight at 9. Tickets, $10; the performance is sold out, but returns may be available (Pareles).

INTERPOL, Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. Miss the 1980's heyday of Depeche Mode and New Order? Interpol sets out to revive the moody propulsion of vintage mope-rock. Tomorrow night at 11:30, with the Astrojet at 9:30 and Sea Ray at 10:30; admission is $10 (Pareles).

IRISH MUSIC GALA, Blarney Star, 43 Murray Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 732-2873. The traditional Irish music series at the Blarney Star resumes with an all-star lineup that's also a preview of its coming season: Brian Conway on fiddle, Jerry O'Sullivan on uilleann pipes, Dermot Grogan on flute, John Dillon on guitar and no fewer than four button accordionists: James Keane, Patty Furlong, Joey Mullen and Tom Dunne. Tonight at 9; admission is $12 (Pareles).

D. D. JACKSON, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778. This Canadian jazz pianist is concerned with the evolution of jazz, and he's getting there through hybrid forms, having added dashes of a classical sensibility, of Latin music, of electric fusion and other things. He has a new record, "Sigame," on the Justin Time label, for which he has been prolific. Tonight at 7; cover charge is $20 (Ratliff).

* BAABA MAAL, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8778. Every so often, the Senegalese singer and songwriter Baaba Maal takes a break from leading his explosive band to play acoustic guitar. With his mentor and longtime duet partner Mansour Seck on vocals and Kaouding Cissoko on acoustic guitar, this is a chance to hear Mr. Maal's fusion of griot music and Western pop in its most intimate form. Tomorrow through Monday night at 9:30; admission is $30 (Pareles).

LES McCANN, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-8592. A Southern pianist who made his name in the 1960's with some ingeniously contemporary-sounding music -- particularly the "Swiss Movement" album with Eddie Harris, which yielded the song "Compared to What" -- Les McCann is a gray eminence of jazz-funk. Tonight through Sunday night at 8 and 10:30; cover charge at the tables is $30 and a $5 minimum; at the bar, $20 and a one-drink minimum (Ratliff).

ROGER McGUINN, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 502-3471. One of folk-rock's founding fathers as the leader of the Byrds, Roger McGuinn plugged in an electric 12-string guitar for songs by Bob Dylan and Pete Seeger, and the Top 40 was never the same; then he turned to country-rock. He's bound to riffle through his back pages onstage; expect "Mr. Tambourine Man" and "Chestnut Mare." Tonight at 8; admission is $30 (Pareles).

RENE McLEAN, Sista's Place, 456 Nostrand Avenue, at Jefferson Avenue, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, (718) 398-1766. Son of the alto saxophonist Jackie McLean, this tenor saxophonist has made some distinguished music himself, especially an album made in South Africa in the early 90's. He is not often seen in New York. Tomorrow night at 9 and 10:30; admission is $10 (Ratliff).

BRAD MEHLDAU AND DIANNE REEVES, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. A double bill, in which Mr. Mehldau's trio and Ms. Reeves's own group will play independent short sets. It's an interesting pairing of an inward-looking and harmony-rich pianist and a forthright, straight-out virtuosic singer whose talent still hasn't quite been captured on record but who always gives rewarding performances. Sunday night at 8 and 10; cover charge is $30 with a $10 minimum. (Ratliff).

MISSION OF BURMA, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. The blunt noise of punk and glimmers of the complexity of progressive rock were merged in Mission of Burma, a Boston band that lasted from 1979 to 1983 and influenced the likes of R.E.M., which has played the band's "Academy Fight Song"; Blur; and Moby, who remade "That's When I Reach for My Revolver." It played so loud that its guitarist, Roger Miller, has suffered from severe tinnitis ever since, but its founding trio has briefly reunited for two shows in New York and two in Boston. Tomorrow's show at 9 p.m. is sold out; Sunday night at 9 tickets are $25 in advance and $30 on day of show (Pareles).

MOLDY PEACHES, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111. Adam Green and Kimya Dawson, who lead the Moldy Peaches, can be crude, earnest, funny, folky and punky. They volley lines back and forth or sometimes sing two lyrics at once, and although they have song titles like "Who's Got the Crack," easy laughs aren't all they offer: "We like to contradict ourselves, that's our act," Mr. Green raps. The Realistics and Scrappy Hamilton are opening acts. Tomorrow night at 9; admission is $10 (Pareles).

MARIO PAVONE QUARTET, Knitting Factory, Old Office, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Mr. Pavone's band plays simple tunes, built of vamps and strong melodies, with energy and taste. In the last decade he has branched out quite a bit, playing with a lot of different bands, and this weekend's band tends toward the raucous side. It includes the saxophonist Tony Malaby, the trumpeter Steven Bernstein (both of whom can roar) and the drummer Michael Sarin. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and 10; admission is $12, with a one-drink minimum (Ratliff).

JEAN-MICHEL PILC TRIO, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, below Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063. This French pianist is a splashy stunner at the piano keyboard, sharing a line that runs from Errol Garner to Don Pullen, and he loves running Monk (as well as his own melodies) through mazelike chord substitutions. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 10:30; cover charge is $12 (Ratliff).

* MONICA SALMASO WITH CYRO BAPTISTA, Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street, at Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, (212) 772-4448 or (212) 545-7536. Monica Salmaso, a singer from Brazil making her New York City debut with these concerts, carries on all the best aspects of Brazilian pop: the melodies, the genuinely poetic Portuguese lyrics, the understatement that makes sophisticated music seductive. The ever-inventive percussionist Cyro Baptista sits in. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $30, $15 for students, $26 for members (Pareles).

SINGERS OVER MANHATTAN: ANDY BEY AND BARBARA CARROLL, Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse, 10th floor, Rose Building, Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street, Manhattan, (212) 721-6500. A singer with great range and sensitivity -- his enormous voice centers on a bass-baritone but shoots into falsetto range -- Mr. Bey has been having a slow but steady career revival in the last five years. Barbara Carroll has a Carlyle Hotel audience (she appears there every year) and a past in New York bebop. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $45; both shows are sold out, but returns may be available (Ratliff).

SMOKEY AND MIHO, LOUIE AUSTEN, Northsix, 66 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-5103; Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7503. Miho Hatori sings and writes songs for the funk-rap-lounge band Cibo Matto; Smokey Hormel has played guitar with Tom Waits and Beck. Leading a band, they promise to delve into -- what else? -- Brazilian music. Tonight at Northsix, they share the bill with Louie Austen, who has been crooning love songs in hotel bars for two decades, has lately hooked up with some synthesizer-loving techno producers and is about to release his first album. Tonight at 9, with the jazz drummer Ben Perowsky and his band opening; admission is $10. Tomorrow, Smokey and Miho play the 8 p.m. set at Tonic, followed by Vinicius Cantuaria at 10 and midnight. Mr. Cantuaria is steeped in the bossa nova: its gently brushed guitar chords, its quietly elaborate melodies, its shades of sensuality and melancholy. He knows it well enough to stretch the form without losing its essence. Admission at Tonic is $10 for Smokey and Miho, $12 for Mr. Cantuaria, or $16 for both (Pareles).

* KOKO TAYLOR, SON SEALS, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42d Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. Koko Taylor's big, raspy voice blasts through her blues tunes like a sandstorm. She's fond of tunes full of male braggadocio, like "Wang Dang Doodle," and she's as tough as anyone who has ever sung them. This double bill pairs her with a bluesman as untamed as she is: Son Seals, who plays Chicago blues with the classic alchemy of despair, ferocity and joy. His voice growls while his guitar solos taunt and sear, ratcheting up the tension within his plaints and accusations. Tonight at 8; tickets are $35; 10 minimum. (Pareles).

VICE, CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 982-4052.. Corey Glover, whose recent shows with the reunited Living Colour have reminded fans that he's an exemplary hard-rock belter, leads his own band, Vice. Tonight at 8, with Vial and Wild Nine as opening acts; admission is $10 (Pareles).

BUSTER WILLIAMS, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037. A liquid-toned, agile bassist and a heavyweight from the middle-aged generation of players who were coming up amid the fusion years, Mr. Williams has kept strong small bands for years; this one includes the saxophonist Javon Jackson, the pianist Eric Reed and the drummer Lenny White. Tonight through Sunday night at 9:30 and 11:30, with a 1 a.m. set tomorrow; cover charge is $20 tonight and tomorrow and $15 on Sunday, and there is a $10 minimum all nights (Ratliff).

* WORLD MUSIC SHOWCASE, Makor, 35 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 601-1000. With the Association of Performing Arts Presenters meeting in New York City, this bill gives music from five continents a public audition. Fantcha sings mornas, the lilting, wistful, piquantly mournful songs from the Cape Verde Islands off the coast of Senegal. Monica Salmaso sings Brazilian pop. Spaccanapoli turns Italian tarantellas and pro-labor sentiments into rousing rock songs. Lo'Jo, led by a gravel-voiced French singer, sounds like an itinerant cabaret band that has wandered a long way from the boulevards, hearing griot tunes and tangos and Tom Waits. Les Yeux Noirs, another French group, plays gypsy and klezmer tunes. The Israeli jazz bassist Avishai Cohen leads his International Vamp Band, which leans toward Latin rhythms; Silk Road plays Chinese folk music, and the steel drummer Andy Narell plays easygoing Caribbean-tinged jazz. Sunday at 6 p.m.; admission is $15 (Pareles).

KEVIN YOST, Centro-Fly, 45 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 627-7770. Kevin Yost, a drummer turned disc jockey, plays sets of house music that mix his own tracks with others he loves, full of buoyant keyboard chords, utopian vocals and more than a trace of jazz. Tomorrow night at 10; admission is $20 (Pareles).

HEADLINE: Bracing for Soft Sales, Carmakers Stake Out High Ground 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
WITH economic gloom casting shadows like winter snow clouds over the North American International Auto Show, the luxury market appears to be giving off a glimmer of light. 
 Even as auto companies are bracing for softer sales, after the torrid pace of the last three years, they are rolling out high-ticket vehicles in all sizes and configurations. 
 Almost every manufacturer in the $30,000 and up market, from domestic stalwarts like Cadillac and Lincoln, to Japanese challengers like Lexus and Infiniti, to European makers like BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Volvo, has something new on display here, either as models set for production or as concept vehicles, which are designs that often reach the market with some modifications for the sake of practicality. 
The interest in luxury is easy to explain. The high-end market is one of the few profitable sectors left as competition cuts into profit margins on mass-market cars and on mainstream trucks and sport utilities. Luxury sales continue to grow with segments still left to explore. 
During media previews of the auto show, which opens tomorrow, Denny Clements, the general manager of Lexus, a division of Toyota, said he expected industry sales of luxury trucks would rise 45 percent, to 440,000 a year, by the end of next year. Just a few feet away stood the GX 470, Lexus's third sport utility vehicle. It will go on sale in about a year at roughly $45,000, priced between the hulking LX 470 and the midsize RX 300. 
Lexus sales reached a record 222,000 last year, of which about 30 percent, or about 66,600 vehicles, were trucks. Industrywide, trucks, including sport utilities, pickups and minivans, outsold cars for the first time, accounting for 51 percent of vehicle sales in America. 
Mr. Clements cited demographics to back up his optimism. "Someone is turning 50 every eight seconds," he said, and buyers from ages 45 to 62 dominate the luxury market. He also pointed to what he calls the "democratization of affluence." By 2005, he said, 11 percent of households will have incomes of more than $100,000 a year.
Moreover, Mr. Clements said, attitudes have changed since Sept. 11. "There is not quite the stigma of, 'Who are you to buy this car?' " he said. 
"People are falling in love with cars again," he said, "and they are saying, 'I deserve to have this car now.' "
Executives at BMW, which sold a record 213,000 vehicles in the United States last year, behind Lexus and ahead of Mercedes-Benz, sense the same change of attitude. 
"If this is what life is about, I want to enjoy it more," Thomas Purves, chief executive of BMW's operations in the Americas, said of the attitudes of consumers.
BMW has several new vehicles on sale or in the works. On display here is a new version of the company's 7-Series sedan, which will sell for at least $70,000. The car has been criticized by some BMW purists for its curvy rear styling and its electronic operating menus, which are controlled by a joystick. 
"I just don't know what they were thinking," said Jeremy P. Anwyl, chief executive of Edmunds.com, a Web site that provides information to car buyers. 
Mr. Purves said he thought the car would sell well when it goes on sale in a couple months. "Americans are much more open to new things," he said. "This car really grows on you."
Still to come from BMW is a compact sport utility, the X3, plus new 1-Series and 6-Series cars. 
Mr. Purves said the four new lines should help the company reach its goal of selling 300,000 vehicles a year in America.
While BMW is predicting stronger American sales for 2002, Mr. Purves said he thought it was dangerous for manufacturers to consider the luxury market immune from an economic slowdown. BMW was among the automakers whose sales were hurt in the industry's last big recession, from 1990 to 1992. Mr. Purves said he expected the first six months would be "quite tough" because of the slow economy and because potential buyers might have already been swept into the market by special financing offers last fall.
The automakers based in Detroit have their own flood of new luxury vehicles, as Cadillac and Lincoln try to establish new images and new looks. 
Lincoln is showing a redesigned Navigator sport utility, as well as a conceptual design for a Continental that recalls the clean, understated Lincolns of the 1960's. 
Cadillac displayed the production version of its two-seat XLR roadster a slightly revised version of a previous concept car called the Evoq which is about a year away from reaching the market. 
Cadillac has even taken a swipe at Ferrari, displaying a low, sharp-edged concept for a high-performance, V-12 sports car. Called the Cien, the car shows how Cadillac's faceted "art and science" design could be applied to models in the six-figure range, about twice as much as the most expensive Cadillacs currently offered.
Smaller European companies are also eager to join the market. Volvo rolled out its XC90, a sport wagon with S.U.V. features, and the Land Rover unit of the Ford Motor Company displayed a new Range Rover, which is more refined and plush than its predecessors. 
Maserati, which is owned by Ferrari, is returning to the American market after 10 years. At the show, it displayed a coupe as a companion for the convertible that goes on sale this year. The Maseratis will be priced from $77,000 to $87,000.
A pair of concept wagons also attracted attention. The Audi Avantissimo sport wagon, first shown at the Frankfurt Motor Show last fall, is a design study for a large, spacious wagon based on the A8 sedan. Mercedes showed a sleeker but somewhat similar wagon it calls the GST, for Grand Sports Tourer, a departure from the company's existing lineup of clearly defined sedans, roadsters and sport utilities.
Mercedes led the American luxury market in 1999 but has fallen to third place. S. Paul Halata, chief executive of Mercedes-Benz U.S.A., said the company had several products on the way, beginning with a new version of the SL luxury roadster, on display here, which would go on sale in the spring.
Next fall, there will be a new midsize E-Class sedan, which will keep its distinct round head lamps. Next year, Mercedes will introduce an ultra-luxury sedan, the Maybach, which will join an increasingly crowded field of cars selling from $100,000 to $500,000.
Mr. Halata said he was not concerned that a softer economy would hurt his company's plans. 
"We've been very fortunate in the past not to have felt the impact" of recessions, he said. Besides, he said, Mercedes's century-old heritage is a selling tool that newer brands, presumably including the 13-year-old Lexus, can only wish for. 
"A lot of manufacturers would pay for our heritage," he said. 
Mr. Anwyl of Edmunds.com said that he was impressed by efforts to attract luxury buyers, but he cautioned that competition would be fierce. 
"It all comes down to quality," he said. "This is an unforgiving market and it should be."

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
Chronicling a Bubble Called Kozmo.com

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT

 BODY:
Though shot in digital video and accompanied by a sprightly techno score, "E-Dreams," Wonsuk Chin's documentary about the rise and fall of Kozmo.com has the artifactual feel of an old newsreel. The movie is a window into an era that feels curiously remote. Listening to the buoyant young C.E.O.'s and market analysts talk about their I.P.O.'s and market caps, you may feel a vague stirring of nostalgia, accompanied by mild disbelief. Did people really talk that way back then? Did they really believe that a business devoted to delivering videocassettes and pints of Ben and Jerry's to lazy urbanites could merit hundreds of millions of dollars in venture capital?
 Back then, of course, was around two years ago, in the giddy days of the dot-com boom. Residents of New York and a handful of other cities may remember Kozmo delivery folk with their orange bags zipping through intersections. Compulsive CNBC watchers will recognize Joseph Park, the affable, energetic 20-something who, along with his buddy Yong Kang, left jobs in investment banking to pursue what they, without irony or embarrassment, call their "vision." Mr. Park was one of the Internet boom's media darlings, and in "E-Dreams" he spends a lot of time at photo shoots and in talk-show green rooms, and even more on his cellphone with journalists. 
 If you have seen "Startup.com," Chris Hegedus and Jehane Noujaim's chronicle of the short life of govworks.com, "E-Dreams" will feel familiar. In "Startup," the company's reversals of fortune were mirrored in the deteriorating friendship of its founders, Kaleil Tuzman and Tom Herman, and Mr. Chin's film, lacking the dimension of personal drama, is thinner and more distant from its subjects. Though the director incorporates some nice street-level shots of Kozmo messengers in motion, and some glimpses of the chaos in the company's warehouses, the movie is a little claustrophobic -- a marathon of conference calls, frenzied pointing and clicking, and office pep talks.
Happily for Mr. Chin -- though unhappily for his subjects -- the invisible hand of the marketplace wrote a script that no human screenwriter could have hoped to match. In 1998, Kozmo arrived in New York with a few employees, many of whom slept in the company's basement offices and showered at nearby health clubs. By early 1999, Kozmo had raised $28 million in financing and by Christmas of that year it had secured an additional $120 million.
With nearly 4,000 employees (everyone, in Mr. Park's view, an imminent millionaire), a $150 million "strategic" deal with Starbucks (to allow consumers to buy a latte and return a video in one location) and a wildly disproportionate sense of its prospects (Mr. Park dreams of being as big as Amazon, Federal Express or IBM), Kozmo prepares for that late-90's rite of passage, the initial public offering (I.P.O.).
In February of 2000, we see Mr. Park brandishing a cigar at an Oscar party and predicting an even bigger blowout once Kozmo goes public. (At another point he somewhat abashedly calculates that, if the stock trades at $20 a share, he would be worth around $150 million.)
The I.P.O. never took place, and the party ended with the Nasdaq crash of April 14, 2000 -- at which point "E-Dreams" discloses that Kozmo had been losing roughly 10 times its revenue. Suddenly, the picayune matter of profitability became a big deal, and Kozmo's brilliant business model, which had thought of just about everything else, began to unravel.
By July, Mr. Park had been ousted by the company's board, and we are left wondering which is more astonishing: a 27-year-old C.E.O. of a multimillion-dollar company or a 28-year-old former C.E.O. He is too young to be tragic, too lucky to be heroic; his story is like a Dreiser novel redone as an Archie comic, or a pilot for the WB network.
Once upon a time, Mr. Park and his partner were objects of envy and admiration -- rock stars, in his own immodest formulation. Then, as their stock options turned out to be play money, they were regarded with smug schadenfreude. "E-Dreams," which opens today at the Quad, invites a more objective and sympathetic point of view.
Mr. Park comes across as amiable and energetic, and in a scene with his parents -- immigrants from South Korea who run a dry-cleaning business in Philadelphia -- we understand that he is harnessing the new economy in pursuit of a very old dream. His pluck is accompanied by folly amounting almost to hubris, but this is the kind of sin that capitalism ultimately forgives.

E-DREAMS

Directed, edited and produced by Wonsuk Chin; director of photography, Joia Speciale; released by Seventh Art Releasing. At the Quad Cinema, 34 West 13th Street, Greenwich Village. Running time: 94 minutes. This film is not rated.

WITH: Joseph Park and Yong Kang.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joseph Park with Kozmo.com messengers in the company's heyday. (Seventh Art Releasing)

HEADLINE: Vodafone Shares Cooling With Slower Growth in America 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 10 

 BODY:
The Vodafone Group, a wireless favorite among investors, has lost a bit of its luster of late.
 Today, its shares fell nearly 4 percent, adding to a 12 percent slide this week, as analysts expressed concerns about disappointing growth of subscribers in the United States and the uncertain introduction of new wireless services in Europe. 
 Vodafone shares have now given back nearly all the gains accrued in a rally that began last fall. The shares closed today in London down 3.7 percent, at 164.5 pence. On the New York Stock Exchange, its American depository receipts -- each representing 10 shares of the British company -- closed at $23.65, down 10 cents. 
Shares of other European telecommunications companies also fell today.
The intention of a large Vodafone shareholder to sell its stake contributed to the rapid deterioration of the share price this week, analysts said. Banco Santander Central Hispano, which owns 1.1 billion Vodafone shares, is looking to sell the stock to raise money to cover losses related to the devaluation of the Argentine peso.
Banco Santander, Spain's largest bank, has estimated that it stands to lose nearly $3 billion almost immediately from the devaluation.
Executives from Banco Santander were not immediately available. A spokesman for Vodafone declined to comment.
Other worries weighed on Vodafone shares today, analysts said, including a disappointing report from Verizon Wireless, a cellphone operator in the United States. Vodafone owns 45 percent of the venture; Verizon Communications owns the rest. Verizon Wireless said it added 750,000 subscribers in the fourth quarter of 2001, or nearly 200,000 fewer than some analysts had expected.
In addition, some retailers have reported disappointing sales of mobile phone handsets during the important Christmas selling period. 
And NTT DoCoMo, the large Japanese phone company, said this week that it would fall short of previously set targets for subscribers to its new wireless service that offers customers a continuous connection to the Internet.
"Vodafone is the leader, and it is one of the first stocks people go to if they want to take money out of the sector," said Richard Lewis of New Star Asset Management, which owns some Vodafone shares.
The subscriber numbers reported by Verizon Wireless were especially disappointing against expectations that people in the United States would begin using mobile phones more frequently after the events of Sept. 11. 
"Some had factored in the events of Sept. 11 and expected people to buy mobile phones for security reasons," said John Tysoe, an analyst with WestLB Panmure in London. "That did not happen to the extent that people had expected."
The United States presents another challenge for Vodafone in that it is one of the few markets in which the company does not have a controlling stake.
