HEADLINE: Wilderness Above, a Mine Below and a Furor 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: NOXON, Mont., Jan. 10 

 BODY:
On the banks of Rock Creek here in the Cabinet Mountains of northwestern Montana, the only sound breaking the silence is the flow of the icy water. But that could change.
 Last month federal and state regulators granted a permit for a giant silver and copper mine that would burrow a length of three miles under a federal wilderness area, 900 feet below the snowy ridges and the lodgepole pine. The result would be one of the largest underground mines in North America and make this the first time the government had permitted large-scale mining beneath a wilderness area. 
 The regulators, citing an 1872 federal mining law, say the company involved is acting on a properly filed claim allowing it to mine on public land. 
"A lot of people have been contacting me and saying, 'Just vote no,' " said Jan P. Sensibaugh, director of the Montana Department of Environmental Quality. But "the agency can't just decide that we can't go forward with the project just because the public doesn't want it." 
Ms. Sensibaugh's department and the United States Forest Service, the two agencies that granted the permit, have both said in response to opposition that in order to forge ahead, the company will have to abide by strict environmental regulations. Nevertheless, environmental groups vow to mount a strenuous legal challenge, saying the project imperils waterways and an isolated population of grizzly bears.
The project has also angered officials in northern Idaho, which increasingly depends on tourists drawn to its clear rivers. Treated waste water from the mine would drain into the trout-filled Clark Fork River and across the Idaho border into Lake Pend Oreille. 
At the core of the fight is a question that has never been tested on so large a scale since Congress authorized creation of national wilderness areas 38 years ago: Should mines be allowed to extend underneath federally designated wilderness zones, which by statute are to be "untrammeled by man"? 
The company that wants to build the mine, the Sterling Mining Company, based in Spokane, Wash., says the Cabinet Mountains Wilderness Area would be untrammeled on the surface. The opening to the mine would be not in the wilderness area itself but on adjacent federal land. Hikers, campers and fishermen in the wilderness zone, the companysays, would be unaware of the activity hundreds of feet below, except perhaps for occasional explosions needed to open shafts and reach deposits that Sterling believes total 935 million pounds of copper and 115 million ounces of silver.
Opponents, though, say that the project would be far more intrusive and that it offers a vivid argument for revising the 1872 mining act.
Intended to encourage Western development, the law grants mining companies nearly automatic rights to mine on federal land for a few dollars an acre. Critics of the law, including Clinton administration officials who tried to overhaul it, argue that it has long outlived its intent and amounts to a lucrative giveaway to corporate interests. 
"It's an absurdity, it's a crazy law," Cesar Hernandez, a field representative with the Montana Wilderness Association, said during a walk by snowshoe in the Cabinet Mountains area the other day. "If the Sistine Chapel was in this country, you could exercise a right to mine under it." 
The proposed mine has plenty of supporters in western Montana, especially here in tiny, economically depressed Noxon, the closest town, which drew brief notice after the Oklahoma City bombing as a militia hotbed.
With logging and mining in decline, the town has tried, though without much success, to transform itself into a tourist destination, adopting the slogan "You can spell Noxon backwards, forwards or sideways, and it's still Noxon." 
Drinking coffee at the Noxon Cafe, Nick Schmidt, a 73-year-old retired pipeline mechanic, said the town could use a boost from the project, which officials say would employ about 350 people in addition to providing property taxes for a struggling school district. Asked what Noxon's primary industry was, Mr. Schmidt replied: "Nothing, anymore. That's why we need something like this." 
But the mine has fierce opponents, too, both in Montana and in neighboring Idaho, who say it will cause serious environmental problems. The mine would discharge up to three million gallons of waste water a day into the Clark Fork River. Over its 30-year lifetime, it would also be expected to throw off 100 million tons of crushed rock, or tailings, which would have to be buried in fields near here. 
While both those activities would take place adjacent to the wilderness area per se, environmentalists say they can also foresee air pollution within the zone and damage to its watershed. The suits they are planning mean that mining operations are at least a couple of years off.
Or another kind of law might stop the project: the law of economics. Sterling already owns a smaller mine, known as the Troy Mine, in a neighboring county. Operations were suspended there in 1993 because of low silver and copper prices.
The Troy Mine is a ghost town these days, in the words of Bruce Clark, its manager, one of only five full-time employees who maintain the big crushers and other mothballed equipment that the company hopes to restart once metals prices recover sufficiently. The same hopes prevail for the Rock Creek Mine, which has bigger deposits and so would be more economical to operate.
Mr. Clark, a jovial man with a large mustache who has worked at the Troy Mine since 1980, said he was frustrated by public perceptions. Environmental regulations and improvements in technology, he said, mean that treatment of the Rock Creek Mine's waste water would bring it well within clean-water standards. 
"We can do it right -- we can absolutely do it right," Mr. Clark said during a tour of the Troy Mine that wound past a sign saying it had been built by "Montana miners and the free enterprise system." 
"A lot of people, you're not going to convince them that a mine is a good thing," Mr. Clark said ruefully. "You might as well be beating your head against that wall," he said, pointing to a massive face of copper-laced rock. 
But environmentalists say mining companies have always claimed to have the technology to prevent damage, and have often been proved wrong. The Clark Fork River, which winds through rocky canyons and grassy meadows here, has been affected by mines before. Cadmium, arsenic and other toxic elements from more than a century of mining have polluted it and other rivers in the area, including the Blackfoot, which empties into the Clark Fork and was immortalized in Norman Maclean's "A River Runs Through It."
The Clark Fork has been the object of a longstanding cleanup campaign, one that the Rock Creek Mine's opponents, including the Clark Fork Coalition and the Rock Creek Alliance, say makes the idea of introducing new mining waste to the area profoundly objectionable. 
The opponents plan to wage a legal battle over the scope and intent of the Wilderness Act of 1964, which authorized the wilderness areas. Among the issues is whether that statute trumps the 1872 act, which decreed that mining be considered the best use of public lands.
No roads, construction or motor vehicles are ordinarily permitted in wilderness areas. The Wilderness Act allowed existing mining "patents" -- claims to the minerals in a given location -- to be exercised in a few wilderness areas. But most of those existing patents involved very small-scale operations.
The claims at Rock Creek, on the other hand, were filed afterward, and the courts will probably be asked to determine whether so large an operation is permitted within the meaning of the Wilderness Act. 
"The Bush administration and the State of Montana are acting as if there is an absolute right to construct this mine," said Roger Flynn, director and managing attorney for the Colorado-based Western Mining Action Project, which is representing a coalition of conservation groups planning to challenge approval of the mine. "That's simply not the case at all under federal law." 
But Frank Duval, Sterling's president, said the company's patent gave it the right to take the silver and copper that lie buried beneath the wilderness area. 
"The opponents say we'll kill all the bears and poison the fish," Mr. Duval said. "That's just ridiculous. This thing has been studied and studied and studied, and the fact is the mine can operate and follow all the proper guidelines."

HEADLINE: Mr. T., Mr. G And Mr. H. 

BYLINE:  By Bill Keller; E-mail: billkeller@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Whenever a truly dreadful person dies or retires and the chorus of polite, speak-no-ill-of-the-departed accolades begins, I think of the nasty bee-sting E. E. Cummings bestowed on the editor and poet Louis Untermeyer. Untermeyer's influential 1919 anthology, "Modern American Poetry," omitted some of the great poetic innovators of the time, but included three poems by Untermeyer himself and one by his wife. Cummings gutted him in four lines.
mr u will not be missed
who as an anthologist
sold the many on the few 
not excluding mr u
 The epigram was mean-spirited (later Untermeyer editions included the overlooked poets, and plenty of Cummings), but it was a memorable kick against the collective deference that accumulates around powerful people. 
 In that dyspeptic spirit I'd like to begin the new year by bidding farewell to three men whose departure will raise the median decency of the United States Senate. In their remaining, lame-duck months, Jesse Helms, Strom Thurmond and Phil Gramm will enjoy the ritual tributes of colleagues and the sanitized adieus of home-state editorialists. Let's be frank. They will leave behind an institution they have helped appreciably to debase.
Senators Helms, Gramm and Thurmond have in common the fact that they harnessed their collective century of seniority to the Taliban wing of the American right. Point to an act of cultural division, bullying unilateralism or anti-government populism committed in the Senate during their decades there and you will usually find these three men among the sponsors. But there are others in the Senate who have voted for egregious causes, right and left, and still others who have never stood for much of anything. What sets these three apart is that each has made his own special contribution to the cynicism of our public life.
It is tempting to excuse them, in their twilight, for at least having made the place more colorful. Mr. Helms affected a theatrically courtly demeanor, sirring and ma'aming witnesses he regarded as infidels. (His manners were selective; it was the courtly Mr. Helms who once remarked that if President Clinton visited North Carolina he'd "better have a bodyguard.") Mr. Gramm pokes witty fun at his own orneriness. "People say I don't have a heart," he once joked. "I do. I keep it in a quart jar on my desk." As David Plotz wrote in Slate, Senator Gramm is a mean, bitter pessimist, but "he has benefited from one of the strangest prejudices of politics: that meanness is a synonym for integrity." Mr. Thurmond benefits from another prejudice, our instinctive American admiration for those who correct themselves. He abandoned his ardent segregationist views when the demographics of his state made that expedient, and even hired actual black people to work on his Senate staff, a fact sometimes reported with such awe that you'd think he'd marched with Dr. King in Selma.
I wish I could summon up tributes to these men, if only for the contrarian pleasure of defying the liberal tradition of these pages. But alas, it has to be said that each of them has impoverished our precious political culture.
Mr. Thurmond's contribution is that he helped make Congress ridiculous. I can't think of a more cringe-making spectacle in public life than watching Mr. Thurmond, age 99, being shoveled into his seat at some committee he is only dimly aware of attending, and listening as he struggles to read a text prepared for him by an aide, losing his place at the end of each line. The Senate has never been a youth center, but Mr. Thurmond has deteriorated like Dorian Gray's picture while his constituents acquiesced and his colleagues averted their eyes. His embarrassing political shtick includes a self-conscious virility, manifested in his ability to produce children into his 70's and in his famously cute habit of leering at female interns, groping female senators and acclaiming the beauty of female witnesses before his various committees. Senator Thurmond did not invent the role of Washington lecher, but he helped cultivate the men's-club chauvinism in which Bob Packwood and Bill Clinton and Gary Condit operated.
Please understand, Mr. Thurmond's sin is not that he grew old; it is that growing old was the sum of his career. The message of his nearly half-century in the Senate is that success is to be measured not by tangible accomplishments -- Mr. Thurmond has none, unless you count getting post offices and schools named for himself, and wangling an appointment for his 29-year-old son and namesake as the top federal attorney for South Carolina -- but by political longevity. What Mr. Thurmond represents is the transformation of senators into self-perpetuating instruments of incumbency. For years, "Senator Thurmond" has been a shell inhabited by party leaders, campaign donors and staff who operate behind his Oz-like seniority, the way Communist Party apparatchiks ruled in the name of the sickly Leonid Brezhnev. I don't believe in term limits, on the principle that voters are entitled to make their own mistakes, but Mr. Thurmond makes me less certain of my conviction.
Mr. Gramm should be remembered for perfecting one of the more duplicitous roles in politics -- the anti-government welfare queen. He has run his every campaign as a scourge of government spending and a champion of the beleaguered little taxpayer. At the same time he has built a great money sluice from Washington to his home state and pandered to the energy, banking and insurance lobbies that underwrite his political ambitions. His politics could be called hypocrisy, but only in a language that places a huge premium on understatement.
Contrast Mr. Gramm with Representative Dick Armey, another Texan with a mean streak, a Ph.D. in economics and a professed distaste for government spending. Mr. Armey, who is also retiring after this Congress, had the intellectual integrity to fight federal farm subsidies and to engineer the closing of unneeded military bases, including one serving his home district. Not so Mr. Gramm, who once boasted, "I'm carrying so much pork, I'm beginning to get trichinosis."
One of Senator Gramm's most generous benefactors was Enron, which lavished money on his campaigns and paid his wife handsomely as a corporate director. Senator Gramm, in turn, had a hand in legislation that exempted Enron's explosive energy derivatives business from government regulation and oversight. How big a hand, and whether that legislation enabled the secret funny business that led to the company's collapse, may emerge in one of the many investigations under way. Enron's business was built on the premise that just about anything could be turned into a commodity and bought and sold. The beleaguered little taxpayers who lost their jobs and pensions in the Enron fiasco will be interested to know whether that included their senator. 
Mr. Helms leaves behind at least a double legacy. He helped perfect fear-mongering as a form of fund-raising, using his own and allied political action committees to raise many millions by appealing to the crudest bigotries of voters. The technique is now pervasive across the political spectrum, but Mr. Helms helped pioneer those alarming boldface solicitations that warn: "Your tax dollars are being used to pay for grade school classes that teach our children that CANNIBALISM, WIFE-SWAPPING and the MURDER of infants and the elderly are acceptable behavior." (Yes, that's an actual letter that went out over his signature.)
Mr. Helms has also diminished American stature abroad by using senatorial obstruction and intimidation to undermine our diplomatic service and pre-empt our foreign policy. As the senior Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for the past 15 years, and as the mentor of a right-wing mafia within the Republican Party, he has been an author of much of what makes the world resentful of America: our stingy foreign aid, our lordly attitude toward any multilateral organization, our disdain for treaties, our support of despotic regimes from apartheid-era South Africa to the juntas of Latin America.
Mr. Helms will not be missed;
Unrelenting jingoist,
He sold us bullies of their realms,
Not excluding Mr. Helms.

ORGANIZATION: CONGRESS (US) 

PERSON: PHIL GRAMM (89%); BILL CLINTON (52%) KELLER, BILL; HELMS, JESSE (SEN); THURMOND, STROM (SEN); GRAMM, PHIL (SEN)

HEADLINE: FORD PLANS TO CUT 35,000 EMPLOYEES AND SHUT 5 PLANTS 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich. Jan. 11

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company announced its most sweeping cutbacks in two decades today, terminating 35,000 workers, closing five plants and dropping four models.
 No longer will the company make Lincoln Continentals or Ford Escorts, as it cuts North American capacity by nearly a million cars and trucks a year. 
 William Clay Ford Jr., who took over as chief executive 10 weeks ago, said the company had underestimated its competitors and the effects of the recession. Ford, which owns Hertz and started several Internet ventures, also had reached too far beyond the business of making cars and trucks, he said. "We strayed from what got us to the top of the mountain, and it cost us greatly," he said. 
Ford will close 5 of its 44 North American plants by the middle of the decade, including plants in Edison, N.J.; Cleveland; Ontario; Michigan; and Hazelwood, Mo., near St. Louis. The Edison plant, 53 years old, will close by 2004, costing 1,600 jobs. Page B1. 
Two more plants, in Avon Lake, Ohio, and in Mexico, with no new products scheduled, are vulnerable, and 20 more plants face cutbacks. 
The company said it would step up job cuts begun early last year that, when finished by the middle of the decade, would reduce its worldwide staff of about 350,000 by 10 percent, including 21,500 workers in North America.
In cutting North American production capacity to 4.8 million vehicles annually from 5.7 million, Ford also will retire the Mercury Cougar and the Mercury Villager.
Analysts were divided over whether the cutbacks would be enough to restore Ford's competitiveness. In North America, the cuts are smaller than the reduction of 26,000 workers that Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, announced last year. They are also smaller, over all, than the huge cutbacks by General Motors in the early 1990's that led to the closing of more than 20 plants. 
Ford's North American reductions include 15,000 hourly workers, 5,000 salaried workers and 1,500 contract workers. Having terminated about 8,000 of these jobs last year, Ford now plans to cut about 13,500 more.
Mr. Ford's tone in explaining the cutbacks was humble. "For most of the last decade, Ford Motor Company was on a roll," he said. "The great success that we enjoyed may have caused us to underestimate the growing strength of our competitors. Our success may have also caused us to underestimate the effect of the economic downturn."
Analysts had mixed reviews. Stephen Girsky of Morgan Stanley called the plan credible while Brett Hoselton of McDonald Investments said the cuts had not gone far enough beyond those made recently by G.M. and Chrysler.
Ford intends to become so much more efficient that it can offer more new models while saving $9 billion annually. But analysts noted that Chrysler said this week that it would also increase the number of new models it develops while cutting billions from development costs. 
Mark Oline, the managing director who oversees auto industry credit ratings for Fitch, said that labor agreements would delay Ford's savings. Ford, he said, "is hamstrung from the costs they can take out because of union contracts." 
"The real open question is what will happen under the new union contract." 
Ford will take a $4.1 billion after-tax charge in the fourth quarter to pay for the cutbacks, which will put its projected 2001 loss at $5.4 billion, its first annual loss since 1992. Under the plan, the company aims to break even this year and earn about $2 a share by about 2005. 
Fitch and other ratings agencies all reacted negatively. Standard & Poor's, which downgraded Ford and Ford Credit two notches last year, put Ford on a negative credit watch, raising the possibility of a further downgrade. Moody's Investors Service said it would re-evaluate Ford to see if further downgrades were warranted. Fitch downgraded Ford today. Such downgrades drive up Ford's borrowing costs.
Ford said it would raise additional funds through a $3 billion offering of bonds that are convertible into stock under certain terms. The company also plans to trim its dividend to 40 cents from 60 cents. The dividend had been $1.20 a year ago. 
The plan's financial projections assume that Ford, excluding its premium brands like Jaguar, Volvo and Land Rover, will be able to hold its market share steady for the next five years. Given the increasing incursions of Asian automakers in the profitable market for light trucks, analysts say it will be hard for Ford to reverse its market share decline. 
"Stable Ford share is, I think, somewhat unrealistic," said Saul Rubin, an analyst at UBS Warburg. "I think we're going to have to go through a further phase of restructuring." 
Labor officials have not yet agreed to the plan, and the current contract with the United Automobile Workers, which prevents Ford from closing plants, defers much of the cost-cutting. The current contract expires in September of next year. Labor officials will have to be courted aggressively, especially because one of Ford's biggest problems is the declining quality of the cars and trucks coming from its plants.
As Mr. Ford and his new management team presented the plan to analysts today, they offered it as a rejection of the strategies of Ford's previous chief executive, Jacques A. Nasser, even if his name was unspoken. 
Mr. Ford pitched the plan as a "back to basics" approach in which the company would focus again on building reliable cars and trucks. Nicholas V. Scheele, Ford's chief operating officer, said the company aimed to receive $1 billion this year by shedding peripheral businesses acquired during Mr. Nasser's expansive tenure.
Kwik-Fit, a British chain of auto repair shops, could be sold, the company said, and it plans to continue to retreat from Mr. Nasser's online ventures. Hertz is another subsidiary that analysts say is on the block. 
Martin Inglis, Ford's chief financial officer, said the company's troubled financing unit, Ford Credit, would tighten up its credit standards and pull back from loans to customers buying cars from other companies. The moves are aimed at reducing the need for Ford to keep pumping capital into Ford Credit as its loans have ballooned. Ford said it would provide $700 million for Ford Credit today.
Ultimately, Ford's turnaround must be driven by developing cars and trucks that people want and will buy, Mr. Ford said. 
At 44, he is the first Ford family member to run the company since his uncle, Henry Ford II, stepped down in 1979. Today he said he would forgo his salary and bonus this year, and take only stock options as compensation. 
Mr. Ford said this act was a symbol of his confidence in his turnaround plan and his company. 
"If we do get it right, I'll get paid very well on these stock options," he said. "If we don't, I won't get paid. That's a risk I'm willing to take."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
More Loans Between Owners Bring More Denials of Conflicts of Interest

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Bank loans continued to plague Major League Baseball and its contraction plan yesterday, but the commissioner and the owners continued to deny any impropriety. The upshot of the outbreak of loan disclosures may very well be that the owners will change the rule that has created controversy.
 The latest transactions that have come to light are a series of loans made by a financial firm owned by Carl Pohlad, owner of the Minnesota Twins, to a business owned by Jerry McMorris, managing partner of the Colorado Rockies, and a series of loans made to the St. Louis Cardinals by a bank whose largest shareholder is Carl Lindner, managing partner of the Cincinnati Reds. 
 The newest disclosures create questions because of Major League Rule 20 (c), which, under the heading "Conflicting Interests," says that no one from one team may lend money, directly or indirectly, to a member of another team without the loan being disclosed to and approved by the commissioner and the other owners.
"This is a loan we certainly knew about," Commissioner Bud Selig said about the McMorris loan by telephone from Milwaukee. "It was a loan between individuals. None of the Rockies' assets are at all involved." Selig spoke before the loans to the Cardinals surfaced.
Bob DuPuy, baseball's chief lawyer, said he did not see a problem with the McMorris loan either. "It has nothing to do with baseball operations," he said, also speaking without knowledge of the Cardinals' loans.
Selig borrowed $3 million for the Milwaukee Brewers in 1995, when he was president of the team, from a financial company owned by Pohlad.
The commissioner and the other owners might have known about all or some of these loans, but no votes were taken on them. Critics of the practice have not questioned the legitimacy of the loans but the fact that the owners did not vote on them even if they knew about them.
The owners have obviously ignored 20 (c). No one has acknowledged ever having voted on a relevant loan. Several owners have suggested in recent days that it has become increasingly difficult for teams or owners to borrow sizable sums of money from an institution that does not have another owner as an owner.
"The more centralization, the fewer places you can go," one said.
McMorris said, "We may have some rules that need to be refreshed." 
The loan Selig secured from Pohlad instantly created cries of conflict of interest because it has been no secret that the Twins are one of the teams targeted for contraction, and Pohlad would stand to receive more for his team from baseball than he would if he were to sell it.
Selig has labeled the conflict charge as preposterous because, he said, contraction was not his idea initially and it comes more than six years after the loan. But the McMorris loan, which was first reported yesterday in The Star Tribune of Minneapolis, added fuel to the conflict firestorm because McMorris is considered the father of contraction. Selig has said that McMorris was the first owner to propose the idea in 1999.
"He told me I was crazy," McMorris said yesterday by telephone from Denver. "I said, 'If you have a business that's not going well, you can't keep pouring money into it.' I brought it up in the blue-ribbon committee, and Paul Volcker said it's a valid economic theory." Volcker was Alan Greenspan's predecessor as chairman of the Federal Reserve.
McMorris, who owns 11 percent of the Rockies, acknowledged having taken the loans from Pohlad's Builders Mortgage Company for Timnath Farms, his agriculture and land business, one of many businesses besides the Rockies that he owns. 
"It was on the private business side," McMorris said, refusing to divulge the amounts of the loans. "It was arm's length. With an abundance of caution, I cleared it with the commissioner's office. The Colorado Rockies aren't doing any business with Mr. Pohlad. It didn't have anything to do with contraction and it didn't have anything to do with the Minnesota Twins. Mr Pohlad is in that business. He's a banker."
Telephone efforts to reach the principals in the loans to the Cardinals were unsuccessful. Documents on file with the Missouri secretary of state show that Lindner's Provident Bank of Cincinnati made unspecified loans to the Cardinals from 1996 into last year. Lindner, who had been a limited partner in the Reds' ownership, became the chief executive Oct. 1, 1999.
The loans continued to attract attention from Congress yesterday. Representative Betty McCollum, a Democrat from Minnesota, called for a congressional investigation of baseball's business practices.
In a letter to the leaders of the House Judiciary Committee, McCollum said, "Despite M.L.B.'s assurances to play fair with our national pastime, it is clear that the shady and self-serving practices of some owners have clearly run afoul of the expectations of fans and, now, Congress."
John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the ranking Democrat on the committee, called for Selig to step down as commissioner earlier in the week, then altered his position by saying he would be satisfied if Selig dropped contraction for the coming season.
Conyers said yesterday that he planned to meet with one of Selig's lawyers, presumably DuPuy, next week. Conyers also said he wanted the committee to have a second day of hearings. 
"I had no intentions of calling another one, but Selig was not forthcoming," he said. "He's a great witness. He's very verbose, articulate. He knows a lot, maybe not as much as he thinks he knows, but he's a great witness. He's got lots of answers for everybody, not always to the questions you ask him."

HEADLINE: With Suicide, an Admiral Keeps Command Until the End 

BYLINE:  By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Throughout the fall and winter, Chester Nimitz's daughters kept asking him if he was certain that he was ready to carry out his plan and end his life.
 "I said, 'Are you really going ahead with this?' " said the youngest of his three daughters, Sarah Smith, recalling a family discussion on Christmas Day at her parents' retirement community outside Boston. " 'Why do you have to do it now?' " 
 Her sister Betsy Van Dorn asked her father if he was depressed. "I said, 'You know there are medications like Prozac that can help you with your mood,' " she said. "He said, 'Nah, I'm not depressed.' " 
Chester W. Nimitz Jr., the son of the World War II Pacific fleet admiral, was 86. His wife, Joan, was 89.
His intelligence, decisiveness, confidence and organizational and planning skills had enabled him to rise through the Navy ranks and ultimately to become an admiral, as his father was. He was used to being in charge, aboard the submarines he commanded during World War II, at the technology company where he became chief executive or leading family boating excursions during summers on Cape Cod.
"Nothing was left to chance," said Ms. Smith, 53, who lives in Milton, a Boston suburb. "He made sure everything worked the way he wanted."
The admiral had made it clear to his family for more than a decade that when the time came, he and Joan intended to take charge of their own deaths. "They didn't want to think in any way that their final days would be controlled by some whippersnapper internist at the hospital," said Mr. Nimitz's sister Nancy Nimitz, 82, a retired economist who lives in Topanga, Calif.
As recently as three years ago, her brother was still golfing, gardening with his wife, reading four books at one time, listening to opera, socializing and generally living life so fully that he decided to have quintuple-bypass surgery. 
But in the past year, the couple's growing medical infirmities had begun to control their lives. The admiral, who during World War II had sunk a Japanese destroyer by aiming three torpedoes at its bow as it charged his submarine, was becoming less and less in charge.
He got top medical care, his daughters said, but still he continued to fail. He suffered from congestive heart failure. He had lost 30 pounds because of chronic gastrointestinal problems. He had constant back pain. He kept falling. He was losing his vision. No longer able to drive, he was losing his independence.
Mrs. Nimitz, who had been trained as a dentist in her native England and had spent years raising her daughters alone while her husband was at sea, suffered from osteoporosis so severe that her bones were breaking. She had a painful condition in her feet called neuropathy. She had gone blind, and could no longer enjoy one of her last remaining pleasures, reading.
"She was fed up, and she said it all the time," Ms. Van Dorn said. "When I made her a doctor's appointment for Jan. 13, she said sotto voce, 'I'm not going to be there.' "
Ms. Smith said: "Perhaps some people find strength in spiritual misery. Not them." 
Her father worried that his heart would give out within months, his daughters said, and that his wife would not be able to commit suicide on her own. Ms. Smith said her mother had worried aloud that without her husband's help, she would not be able to take the pills to end her life.
"He said, 'That's the one last thing I have to do for your mother,' " said Ms. Van Dorn, who is 55 and lives in Boston.
And so on Jan. 2, her parents canceled their nighttime nurse and committed suicide with what their daughters said was an overdose of sleeping pills.
In a note commanding that they not be resuscitated, the admiral wrote: "Our decision was made over a considerable period of time and was not carried out in acute desperation. Nor is it the expression of a mental illness. We have consciously, rationally, deliberately, and of our own free will taken measures to end our lives today because of the physical limitations on our quality of life placed upon us by age, failing vision, osteoporosis, back pain and painful orthopedic problems."
Experts on aging suggest that the Nimitz case is unusual. Most suicides among the elderly are driven by factors like disease, depression, social isolation and poverty, said Thomas R. Cole, a Houston gerontologist and medical humanist. With the proper help, he said, such suicides can be avoided.
Dr. Sherwin B. Nuland, a professor at Yale and the author of "How We Die," said "In something like five out of six cases, if a physician is able to sit down and ask people why they really want to die, they can solve their problems with modern medicine or psychological help."
The admiral, though, had planned his last act down to the smallest detail. He had waited until after the New Year so that he could write tax-exempt checks to his children, their husbands and grandchildren dated Jan. 2, Ms. Smith said. He had left meticulous records in a file labeled "When CWN Dies."
During a family get-together on New Year's Day at her parents' apartment, Ms. Smith said, there was no explicit mention of what was to happen, and no formal goodbyes.
"We hugged them and gave them kisses," Ms. Smith said. "Betsy said something like, 'You've been wonderful parents.' They didn't want emotion. They were of a generation that didn't obsess and discuss issues."
Ms. Smith and Ms. Van Dorn had visited their parents several times a week. A third daughter, Frances, 60, who lives in Virginia, was in frequent contact. Their parents never asked their help in ending their lives, Ms. Van Dorn said. And the daughters knew better than to try to dissuade them. "They did what they wanted to do," Ms. Van Dorn said. 
The daughters are understanding and even admiring of the decision. "I think it was very unselfish of my parents to do what they did," Ms. Van Dorn said.
Mrs. Nimitz had discussed her plans to take control of her own death years ago with her sister, Barbara Beard. "I said, 'I wish I could get the pills,' " Mrs. Beard, who is 82 and lives in England, said in a telephone interview.
The Nimitzes did not believe in any afterlife or God, and embraced no religion. But one of Mr. Nimitz's three surviving sisters, Mary Aquinas, 70, is a Catholic nun with a Dominican order in California. Sister Mary said that she could not condone her brother's decision to end his life, but that she still felt sympathetic.
"If you cannot see any value to suffering for yourself or others," she said, 'then maybe it does make sense to end your life.'

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE INVESTIGATION; 
Man Charged With Lying About Radio Device in Room

BYLINE:  By JANE FRITSCH 

 BODY:
An Egyptian student who was staying in a hotel room with a view of the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 was charged yesterday with lying to federal investigators about an aviation radio that was found in the room's safe.
 The student, Abdallah Higazy, 30, was arrested on Dec. 17 after he returned to the Millenium Hilton Hotel to collect his belongings, investigators said. The hotel, across the street from the trade center site, has been closed since the attack. 
 After a brief hearing, Mr. Higazy was ordered held without bail by United States Magistrate Judge Frank Maas of Manhattan. In denying bail, Judge Maas said that the government appears to have a "very strong case" against Mr. Higazy, and that he has "a substantial incentive to flee a community he doesn't have substantial ties with." 
Mr. Higazy, the son of a former Egyptian diplomat in Washington, was educated largely in the United States, according to his court-appointed lawyer, Robert S. Dunn. At least 20 people have come forward to testify on Mr. Higazy's behalf since his arrest, Mr. Dunn said. His parents now live in Egypt, and a brother lives in Ithaca, N.Y., he said.
Mr. Dunn said his client never lied to federal agents and does not know how the aviation radio -- which can be used for air-to-air and air-to-ground communications -- got into the safe in his hotel room.
Mr. Higazy arrived in the United States on Aug. 27 with a student visa arranged through the Institute for International Education, in conjunction with the United States Agency for International Development, Mr. Dunn said. The institute had arranged for Mr. Higazy to stay at the Millenium for a month while he looked for housing and began his studies at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, Mr. Dunn said.
The hotel was evacuated shortly after the planes hit the twin towers, and has remained closed. Security officers began removing personal property from the rooms, and in early October, an officer entered Room 5101, the corner room with the view of the World Trade Center where Mr. Higazy had been staying, according to documents filed in court by prosecutors.
In the locked security safe, the officer found an air-band transceiver on top of a number of other items, including Mr. Higazy's passport and an Arabic book, the documents said. The transceiver was described as a hand-held radio marketed for use by pilots.
Mr. Higazy was arrested on Dec. 17 when he returned to the hotel. F.B.I. agents showed him the transceiver, according to the court filings, and he said it was not his. He also said that he had never seen it before, he could not even guess what it was, and it could not have been found in his room, according to the filing.
Agents arrested him as a material witness and took him to the F.B.I. office in Lower Manhattan, where he told agents that he had repaired radios for the Egyptian Air Corps that were used by pilots to communicate with people on the ground, the court documents said.
Mr. Higazy, who has been in custody since Dec. 17, said little in court yesterday, except to answer the judge with a clear "Yes, Sir," when asked whether he had accurately filled out a form claiming that he had no money to pay a lawyer.
In arguing for bail, Mr. Dunn said that his client had "a long, stable relationship with the United States" and many friends in the country and no criminal background. The government's case is circumstantial, Mr. Dunn said, and suggested that things were so chaotic at the Millenium Hotel after Sept. 11 that someone else could have entered Mr. Higazy's room and placed the radio device in the safe.
Dan Himmelfarb, an assistant United States attorney, argued that Mr. Higazy lied about the radio in three separate interviews with federal agents and attempted to obstruct an investigation of "the most serious crime in the nation's history."
An aviation radio on the 51st floor of a building across that street from the World Trade Center, Mr. Himmelfarb said, "is potentially a quite significant part of that investigation."
A spokesman for Polytechnic University confirmed that Mr. Higazy had enrolled at the school in a master's degree program in computer engineering. The Institute for International Education did not return telephone calls about Mr. Higazy. According to its Web site, it administers over 250 programs for the State Department, the agency for International Development, private companies and aid organizations.
Mr. Higazy is to appear in Manhattan federal court for a preliminary hearing on Jan. 28.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Enron Official Sought Help From Government Last Fall
The president of the Enron Corporation repeatedly called a senior Treasury Department official last fall and sought help arranging bank loans for the energy company as it scrambled to avoid collapse, the Bush administration said.
 The official, Peter R. Fisher, the under secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance, spoke six or eight times during late October and early November with Greg Whalley, Enron's president, a Treasury Department spokeswoman said. Page A1. 

Ford Motor Plans to Restructure
Ford announced its most sweeping cutbacks in two decades, cutting 35,000 workers, closing five plants and dropping four models. A1.

Ford's plan to eliminate 15,000 hourly jobs in the United States and Canada may revive an old partnership between the unions and Ford to compete with foreign rivals. C3.

The four vehicles being dropped by Ford include some storied names, but none of them have sold well lately. They are the Lincoln Continental, the Ford Escort, the Mercury Villager minivan and the Mercury Cougar. C3.

Kmart's Credit Rating Is Cut Again
Moody's Investors Service downgraded Kmart's credit rating for the second time in less than a month, citing concerns about the operating performance of the retailer and uncertainty about the success of its business strategy. C2.

Stocks Dip After Greenspan Talk
The major stock indexes dropped after Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan warned that the economy still faced some significant risks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 10.95 points, or 1 percent, to 1,145.60; the Nasdaq composite index lost 24.78 points, or 1.2 percent, to 2,022.46; and the Dow Jones industrial average declined 80.33 points, or 0.8 percent, to 9,987.53. C6.

Japan's Leader Visits His Neighbors
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, who winds up a tour of Southeast Asia on Monday, is finding that Japan is no longer greeted as a leader. Mr. Koizumi had hoped to promote regional cooperation and trade liberalization, but instead has been confronted with questions about Japan's attempts to contain its troubles by letting the yen fall in value. C2.

Wholesale Prices Fell in December

HEADLINE: ENRON'S COLLAPSE: THE POLITICS; 
Parties Weigh Political Price Of Enron's Fall

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
Concern that the escalating Enron inquiry could ensnare the White House has rattled some Republicans in Congress, who said they were not yet willing to defend the administration while so many facts were still unknown but who warned Democrats against trying to use the case for partisan advantage.
 In interviews, many Republicans said they were hopeful that the investigations would conclude that administration officials had done nothing wrong. But they were approaching the matter warily because so many questions remained unanswered. 
 "The danger here is if somebody acted in a capacity for the administration and the administration cut them a special favor," said Representative Thomas M. Davis III of Virginia, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee. "Then you have an issue. So far, there's no evidence of that. But we have a responsibility to take a look." 
Representative Mark Foley, Republican of Florida, said that while he would be surprised if there was a finding of wrongdoing by the White House: "I don't think this goes away. We have to go to where this leads us. It doesn't matter if it's a cabinet secretary or a line worker in the White House."
Mr. Foley added, "When the front page described a presidential link, it's not helpful."
Already, the publicity over Enron has unnerved Republican politicians as Mr. Bush tries to keep the public rallied behind the war and his plans for the economy, and his party is gearing up for midterm elections. With the prospect of Congressional hearings, the distraction is likely to continue for some time.
"This is counterproductive to us keeping focused on what we need to keep focused on," said Mike McDaniel, chairman of the Republican Party in Indiana. "We still have men and women out there putting their lives on the line. But the Democrats are ramping it up to make it an issue in the campaign."
Indeed, Democrats are savoring what some describe as the biggest opening they have had to portray Mr. Bush and his party as pawns of special interests. Several party leaders said their strategy was to not appear crassly political by attacking the White House. Instead, they intend to sit back quietly, expressing sympathy for workers and investors hurt by Enron's collapse as Republicans face a cascade of questions.
"The strategy is going to be to let the investigation take its course and not to dial it up politically," said one Democratic Party official. "If your enemy is shooting themselves in the foot, you let them."
Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic Party chairman, followed just that course in an interview, saying, "This issue does not need any fuel from Terry McAuliffe. It has enough on its own. So I'm going to stay right out of it."
The Democrats also could be restrained by the disclosure today that Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury secretary under President Bill Clinton and now a top executive at Citigroup, had called a senior Treasury official to ask whether he would consider asking a bond-rating firm to hold off on downgrading Enron's debt, a move that could cost Citigroup millions of dollars. The Treasury official, Peter Fisher, a Democrat, said he would not intercede.
Another reason Democrats said they were treading carefully is that Enron was also a generous donor to Democrats, including Senators Charles E. Schumer of New York, Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico and John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan. In fact, Republicans plan to portray the Enron collapse as a bipartisan disaster.
"It's a little difficult for the Democrats to point their fingers," said former Representative Bill Paxon, a New York Republican who is close to the White House.
Tad Devine, a top strategist for Al Gore in the 2000 presidential campaign, conceded: "Our party has to be careful in the way we pursue it. The Republicans demonstrated in the 90's that if you are overzealous in political persecution, you'll pay a price."
But Mr. Devine asserted that Enron's donations to Democrats would not deter his party from making it a campaign issue. "Sure, Democrats received money from Enron," Mr. Devine said. "But the locus of support Bush had, with Enron being out of his home state, could make this a very big problem for him."
The White House is clearly on the defensive. Today, for perhaps the first time in her tenure as Vice President Dick Cheney's counselor, Mary Matalin was in full political tilt. She and other Republicans invoked Clinton scandals -- including his affair with a White House intern -- as they defended their own president.
Appearing this morning on the Don Imus radio program, Ms. Matalin said critics "act like there's some billing records or some cattle scam or some fired travel aides or some blue dress."
The president himself has also been on the defensive, putting some distance between himself and Kenneth L. Lay, the chairman of Enron, by saying that Mr. Lay had supported Ann Richards, the former Democratic governor of Texas, over him in the 1994 campaign.
Besides trying to stoke questions about the Democrats, the White House approach is to make the point that the president has nothing to hide.
"If anybody else wants to focus on politics, that's their prerogative," said Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary. "But the president's focus is on getting to the bottom of this fully" by supporting a thorough criminal investigation and policy review.
Asked if the Enron affair and the resulting investigations could dog the president throughout the year, Mr. Fleischer said: "This dog won't hunt. That's a reference to the politics of it."
Yet the unfolding Enron case has already set off a frenzy of finger-pointing among Republicans, some of whom have raised questions about the role of Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, and Donald L. Evans, the Commerce secretary.
One senior adviser to the White House said: "The administration wanted this to be the week of the president's bipartisan education bill and continued success in the war in Afghanistan and beginning of a pivot to the State of the Union. I don't think the Sunday shows are going to spend a lot of time talking about the education bill. Do you? It's all Enron all the time now."
Another adviser to the White House said that while the accusations from some Democrats were overheated, he feared that "nothing is going to keep people from frothing about this, and it gets the president off message and makes him reactive."
Some Democrats who worked in the Clinton administration and endured years of scandals were privately celebrating the latest turn for Mr. Bush.
Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster, said the Enron case could be beneficial as his party's candidates make the case this fall that Republicans are a party of special interests and big business.
"This is a story about a powerful and well-connected corporation hurting average people and it goes to the heart of how voters see the differences between Republicans and Democrats," Mr. Garin said. He conducted a nationwide poll last week, he said, which found that "already over 60 percent of the electorate know about the Enron situation."
An element of the Democrats' strategy is to depict the Democrats as the only party willing to pass laws to protect workers at companies like Enron.
Gov. Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire, a Democrat, framed it as an economic matter. "It's a potentially big issue," she said. "Everyone who has watched what's happened to the employees of Enron who have lost all their retirement savings while management cashed out is very concerned."
Tom Cole, a former chief of staff for the Republican Party, put forth his concern: "The real question is, was there something given to Enron that was inappropriate? I don't have the answer to that."
But, Mr. Cole added, "If Whitewater didn't help us, I don't think Enron's going to help them. The politics of scandal have not been successful in tipping the partisan balance of power in Washington during the Clinton administration And particularly in the wake of Sept. 11, this stuff seems pretty trivial."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
With Losing Week, This Year's Gains Are Largely Gone

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, completing their first losing week in three, after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said there were "significant risks" that an economic recovery would fail to take hold.
 Tyco International Ltd., Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Citigroup Inc. helped lead the decline as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index erased its year-to-date gain. 
 "Stocks were on a tenuous footing to begin with," said Jack Ablin, chief investment officer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank. "This new guarded view of the economy may push investors toward bonds" and out of stocks. 
 The S.& P. 500 fell 10.95 points, or 1 percent, to 1,145.60. The Nasdaq composite index lost 24.78 points, or 1.2 percent, to 2,022.46. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 80.33 points, or 0.8 percent, to 9,987.53.
 For the week, the S.& P. 500 dropped 2.3 percent and the Dow fell 2.7 percent, also wiping out its gain for the year. Year-to-date, the S.& P. 500 has lost 0.2 percent and the Dow 0.3 percent.
 The Nasdaq shed 1.8 percent this week, paring its gain for 2002 to 3.7 percent.
 Stocks, which bounced between gains and losses much of the day, dropped after Mr. Greenspan said in a speech to the Bay Area Council Conference in San Francisco that "it is still premature to conclude that the forces restraining economic activity here and abroad have abated enough to allow a steady recovery to take hold."
 Treasuries surged as the comments increased speculation the Fed might cut interest rates a 12th time in 13 months. The 10-year Treasury note rose 26/32, to a price of 101 1/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.86 percent from 4.97 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 22/32, to 100 3/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.37 percent from 5.41 percent on Thursday.
Companies that have benefited most from the Nasdaq's 44 percent rally since September dropped, including Cisco Systems and the Nvidia Corporation.
 "We are worried that all this money flowed into the group," said Adam Friedman, a manager of the $700 million Armada Large Cap Value fund. "Valuations were getting high, and we have made quite a bit of money in them. We still like tech, but it's more prudent to take chips off the table."
 About 70 percent of 50 technology stocks studied are too expensive given their earnings prospects, an analyst for Merrill Lynch, Steve Milunovich, wrote in a report.
 Microsoft would have to increase profit 94 percent to justify its price, Mr. Milunovich said. Analysts expect 16 percent growth. Comverse Technology and Maxim Integrated Products would have to increase earnings 57 percent and 98 percent, he calculated. Wall Street's consensus calls for their profit to decline 11 percent and 36 percent, respectively.
 Cisco, the largest maker of networking equipment, fell 79 cents, to $20.21. The stock had soared 73 percent since Sept. 21. Business Week quoted a Harvard Business School professor in its Jan. 21 issue as saying the company's accounting practices obscure how much Cisco actually made in the 1990's.
 Nvidia, the maker of computer graphics chips, lost $2.92, to $63.07. It has rallied 145 percent since mid-September and was the top-performing stock in the S.& P. 500 and the Nasdaq 100 last year.
 Tyco, a diversified manufacturing company that is the biggest maker of electronic controls, dropped $2.72, to $52.20; Wal-Mart, lost $1.20 to $55.80; and Citigroup, the financial services company, fell 78 cents, to $49.07.
 The Kmart Corporation plummeted for a third day, losing 90 cents, to $3.30, on concern the company, the third-largest discount chain, lacks the money to carry out turnaround plans and fend off Wal-Mart.
 Microsoft fell 67 cents, to $68.61, giving up a 1.5 percent gain, after a federal district judge rejected its offer to give schools in poor neighborhoods $1 billion worth of computers to settle class-action lawsuits claiming it overcharged customers.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sounds Note Of Caution On Economy 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said yesterday that the economy was not yet out of danger, injecting a powerful voice of caution into a growing consensus on Wall Street that a recovery is imminent or already under way.
 Mr. Greenspan's comments suggested that the Fed could cut its main short-term interest rate once again early this year and that rates might remain low for longer than many investors had expected. Stocks fell and bond prices rose after his remarks. 
 "I would emphasize that we continue to face significant risks in the near term," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech to a civic group in San Francisco. Corporate profits and investment remain weak, unemployment could continue rising for some time, and household spending will be slowed by a number of factors, he said.
"It is still premature," he said, "to conclude that the forces restraining economic activity here and abroad have abated enough to allow a steady recovery to take hold."
But Mr. Greenspan also noted that the nation's economic condition had improved somewhat in recent months, as the pace of job losses dropped off and companies made considerable progress in working off bloated inventories of goods and supplies. He also emphasized his confidence that technological advances had fundamentally improved the economy's productivity, allowing growth over the longer term to be faster than it was in the past. 
"There are sound reasons for concluding that the long-run picture remains bright, and even recent signals about the current course of the economy have turned from unremittingly negative through the late fall of last year to a far more mixed set of signals," Mr. Greenspan said.
Over all, Mr. Greenspan provided a relatively downbeat assessment of the economy's immediate prospects. In doing so, he appeared to signal his intention to support at least one more rate cut to cap off a yearlong campaign of aggressive monetary easing. Since last January, the Fed has lowered its benchmark federal funds target rate -- which directly affects many small-business, credit card and automobile loans -- by 4.75 percentage points, to 1.75 percent.
The Fed next meets at the end of this month and then again in March. After the speech, investors switched course and began betting in the futures market that another quarter-point rate cut was now more likely than not.
But Mr. Greenspan, and the handful of other Fed officials who spoke publicly this week, may have a second motive, too: trying to talk down long-term bond rates. 
Those rates, which guide interest rates on mortgages and many other business and consumer loans, have shot up in recent months on the assumption that the economy would rebound strongly this year and the Fed would soon begin jacking up the short-term rates it controls.
"It seems as if they decided the market needed new guidance," said David Orr, the chief economist at Wachovia Securities. "They're trying to walk the fine line between saying, 'the recession has probably ended' and 'the recovery is probably not going to be as strong as the consensus thinks.' "
For more than a month, many Fed officials have said that they expect this year's recovery to be more modest than most investors and Wall Street economists do, and the spate of recent speeches generally reinforced that message.
"The real question is whether the consumer will stay the course long enough to revive business investment," Cathy Minehan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, said during a speech yesterday in East Hartford, Conn. "And here one can reasonably have doubts."
Ms. Minehan said she was skeptical that household spending would rise as much as it normally did in the wake of a recession, given how much money consumers have spent in recent months on homes, cars and other big-ticket items. The rise in mortgage rates last year caused refinancings to decline recently.
Without a jump in consumer spending, Mr. Greenspan said, companies would not begin to rebuild the inventories they have reduced in the last year and would refrain from investing heavily in new equipment.
If the Fed officials were in fact trying to push down long-term rates, they succeeded, at least initially. After Mr. Greenspan's speech, the yield on 10-year Treasury bonds dropped to 4.86 percent from 4.97 percent. 
But Mr. Greenspan's cautionary remarks also seemed to give investors reason to worry that corporate profits were not on the verge of a recovery. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 80.33 points to close at 9,987.53, falling below 10,000 for the first time since Dec. 20.
Investors and economists have become increasingly confident that the recession that began last March is nearly over, a view reflected in a 24.6 percent rise in the Dow average from its recent low on Sept. 21 to its latest peak on Jan. 4. This week, Goldman, Sachs, which had one of the more pessimistic forecasts on Wall Street, reversed its view, predicting the economy would grow at an annual rate of 2 percent this quarter rather than shrinking at a 1 percent rate.
Despite his cautious short-term outlook, Mr. Greenspan continued to express optimism about the economy's long-term prospects. He again said that new technology had given companies better information about their businesses and had made the economy more efficient. This in turn has allowed the country to produce more with less and to grow more quickly than it once did without generating inflation.
"The implicit message," Mr. Orr of Wachovia Securities said, "is that in 2002, despite a recovery, we won't see upwards inflation pressure that would require sharp tightening by the Fed."
Many economists remain uncertain of how large and how permanent the improvement in productivity will prove to be. Last year, the government significantly reduced earlier estimates of productivity growth in the late 1990's, giving weight to the skeptical argument that much of the improvement was a result of a financial bubble and, ultimately, unsustainable.
But Mr. Greenspan, if anything, seems to have become more certain that his view is correct.
"Until last year, the hypothesis of an accelerated productivity trend had not been tested in the contracting phase of a business cycle," he said yesterday. "Recent developments have provided that test, and the early returns certainly look favorable to the hypothesis."
Despite the recession, productivity growth has been higher in recent months that it was for much of the 1980's and early 1990's.
Mr. Greenspan also said the economy should get a boost this year from increased government spending and the tax cuts that will kick in as part of the tax legislation President Bush signed last year. But he also seemed to warn the administration and Congress not to overdo it with additional spending or new tax cuts.

HEADLINE: Russian Court Orders Dissolution of Independent TV Network 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
For much of last year, Russia's popular independent NTV television network wasted away in an endless legal battle, victim of what was variously called a Kremlin crusade to snuff out a free press, a corporate blood feud and an utterly impenetrable intrigue. 
 As if Russians needed proof, a Moscow court made it clear today that the TV-6 television network, the scrawny heir to NTV's legacy and some of its most famous journalists, was riding a gurney down the same path. 
 The Moscow Higher Arbitration Court ordered the network's owners to start immediately liquidating the company, overturning a two-week-old court ruling that had annulled an earlier liquidation order in this latest, seemingly endless legal war. 
Today's ruling was a major defeat for Boris Berezovsky, the financier and onetime Kremlin insider who controls the network from self-imposed exile in London. Mr. Berezovsky, a vociferous critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, has long been under federal investigation for his dealings during the wild early days of Russian capitalism. 
TV-6 lawyers and managers assailed the decision, which not only was unexpected and swift, but was based on a law that had expired with the new year. They said they would appeal the ruling to Russia's Constitutional Court, the nation's supreme legal authority, and perhaps to the European Court on Human Rights. 
While TV-6 officially has six months to complete its liquidation -- and therefore to carry on its legal fight -- many experts, and the journalists themselves, said the network's fate was preordained, and bleak. Civil liberties groups expressed fear that the decision signaled an erosion of the news media's freedom in a nation where two of the three major television networks are state-run, and the third is owned by a state-controlled monopoly. 
"These strange seesaw decisions are similar to a controlled nuclear chain reaction, whereby the eventual outcome is absolutely clear," Aleksei Simonov, a human rights advocate and president of the Foundation for the Protection of Glasnost, told a Moscow radio station today. "The only thing that matters is when." 
The State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said the United States took "a very dim view" of today's court ruling. "It adds to the already strong appearance of political pressure in the judicial process against Russia's independent media," he said. "We continue to believe that the development and protection of an independent media are essential for Russia's political and economic development, and that freedom of the press and promotion of the rule of law are best served by allowing TV-6 to remain on the air." 
Mr. Berezovsky, interviewed from London today on the Moscow radio station Echo Moscow, called the ruling part of a concerted Kremlin attempt to take control of the national media. "The authorities are fighting for their survival, for their existence, and those who disagree with the authorities are fighting against them," he said. 
Mr. Berezovsky broadly suggested that the struggles over both TV-6 and NTV were part of a state-directed plot to control the flow of information, and to suppress independent reporting on crimes committed by Russia's special services. 
As he has before, Mr. Berezovsky threatened to release what he said was a cache of documents proving that government agents plotted and carried out the 1999 bombings of apartment houses in Moscow and Volgodonsk, killing more than 300 people. 
The bombings, which have been attributed to terrorists from the separatist province of Chechnya, rallied public support for a war against guerrillas there that continues to this day. 
But Mr. Berezovsky has yet to offer any evidence to back such claims. Other experts say that even if the battle over TV-6 is politically tinged, the fight may center less on press freedom than on whether corporate forces with insider connections can seize control of the channel's potentially lucrative broadcast license. 
The Kremlin declined to comment on the court decision. 
The travails of TV-6 uncannily resemble those of NTV, which until last summer was controlled by another sharp Kremlin critic, Vladimir Gusinsky, who is also under criminal investigation and also lives in self-imposed exile, in Spain. 
Both networks were attacked under the same obscure law, now expired, that essentially permits shareholders to demand dissolution of companies that do not turn a profit based on a complex formula pegged to their stock value. Legal experts say the law has not been applied in any other case of note. 
Mr. Gusinsky's nemesis was Gazprom, the vast state-controlled natural gas company that had financedmuch of his news media empire and eventually took it over. Mr. Berezovsky's is Lukoil, Russia's largest oil company, a political force in its own right and a minority shareholder in TV-6. 
While Mr. Gusinsky's empire was mired in debt, however, the managers of TV-6 contend that the company has begun churning out a profit since some of Mr. Gusinsky's managers and journalists fled to the channel after losing control of NTV.
The network's lawyer, Geralina Lyubarskaya, said in an interview today that the courts have refused to consider the network's current balance sheet, relying instead on the company's finances at the time the court battle began. 
The latest ruling is all the more curious, she said, because the law was changed on Jan. 1 as part of a larger overhaul of the financial code. Because the previous liquidation order had been annulled on Dec. 29, two days before the new year, the entire case became moot when the old law lapsed, she argued.
Today's ruling was handed down in an unscheduled session of the Higher Arbitration Court one day after the court's deputy chairman protested the Dec. 29 decision. Ms. Lyubarsakaya said that such reviews usually required months to process. 
"From a professional standpoint, as a lawyer, I am someone who cannot work without respect for the judicial system," she said. "But I have lost this respect, and for me, it is a professional drama."

HEADLINE: Eisenhower in Kabul 

BYLINE:  By Douglas Brinkley; Douglas Brinkley is director of the Eisenhower Center for American Studies and professor of history at the University of New Orleans.

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
There is speculation now about whether President Bush will visit Afghanistan once the American bombing campaign ceases and the new government is established in Kabul. If he does go, he will not be the first American president to make the journey. On Dec. 9, 1959, Dwight D. Eisenhower, while on a goodwill mission to Central Asia and the Middle East, made a pilgrimage to Kabul. There, he met with the eager, 45-year-old Afghan king, Mohammad Zahir Shah -- the same king many now would like to see return from exile to reclaim the throne in Kabul. 
 Eisenhower had long been eager to visit that strange and forbidding land. "It was a boyhood dream of his to see the Khyber Pass and size up how tough their soldiers were," Gen. Andrew Goodpaster, who served as Eisenhower's assistant on that trip, recently recalled. On the morning of Dec. 9, Eisenhower, who had been in Karachi to discuss Pakistan's troublesome relationship with India with President Mohammad Ayub Khan, flew from Pakistan to Bagram Airport, 38 miles from Kabul. The flight, as reported by Russell Baker in The Times, was harrowing: as the president's jet swooped across the snow-capped peaks dividing Pakistan from Afghanistan and prepared to land, "six Soviet MIG-17's flown by Afghan pilots streaked out to escort it in." This was no accident: Soviet aid had been pouring into the country since 1955, when Nikita Khrushchev had visited. The Kremlin was eager to give Ike a little reminder that it was in charge in this supposedly neutral nation. This was just the beginning of one of the most curious days of Eisenhower's presidency. 
 Winter had set in on this landlocked nation of 12 million and the temperature was near freezing, yet tens of thousands of villagers lined the route from the airport to Kabul. Zahir Shah, looking like a boyish stand-in for Charles de Gaulle, escorted him down the route (now paved by the Soviets) that had been traveled by Alexander the Great, the Persians and Genghis Khan. Many of the tribesmen cheering at the roadside had been waiting for hours, warming themselves over small bonfires. "Faces were weather-beaten, often hidden by full beards and turbans, more than faintly similar to biblical pictures of the time of Abraham," Eisenhower later wrote in his memoir, "Waging Peace." "Few, if any, women were present." 
Once at Chilstoon Palace, Eisenhower and the king talked for five hours, with Eisenhower raising concerns over the Afghan monarchy accepting so much Soviet aid and the king asking for more than the $145 million in economic assistance that the United States had already promised him for building roads, a new airport in Kandahar and dams, and for training teachers.
Besides making a plea for more money, the king also hoped that Eisenhower could intervene with two difficult problems: improving Afghanistan's relationship with Pakistan and helping to solve a prickly water dispute between Afghanistan and Iran. According to the declassified report on the Eisenhower-Zahir Shah meeting, the president told the king that "nothing was easy these days" and that he was "not a mediator" but would "do what he could." 
General Goodpaster remembers talking to Ike as the president's plane finally left Afghan soil. The president liked Zahir Shah but his mind was not on cold war politics or economic aid. (The joint communique issued by the two leaders said little of substance, mainly noting that the trip "had strengthened the already warm and friendly relations between the two countries.") Instead, Eisenhower was most interested in the chanting tribesmen he had seen and the desolate majesty of the Hindu Kush. As General Goodpaster recalls, Ike considered the Afghans "the most determined lot he had ever encountered."

HEADLINE: German Right Backs Bavarian to Run Against Schroder 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Jan. 11 

 BODY:
The populist and experienced governor of Bavaria, Edmund Stoiber, will lead the conservative opposition parties in their effort to defeat Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's Social Democrats in elections in September.
 Mr. Stoiber's rival, Angela Merkel, the leader of the larger Christian Democratic Union, bowed to the inevitable today and announced that she was withdrawing from the race. 
 Her own party's leaders urged her privately to concede, arguing that Mr. Stoiber, 60, had a better chance to unseat Mr. Schroder and that further infighting would only damage the opposition's chances and her own prospects. 
Mr. Stoiber, fiercely conservative, is considered an excellent economic manager of the country's most prosperous state at a time when Germany is sinking into recession and the number of unemployed is close to four million.
The stagnant economy makes Mr. Schroder, a shrewd politician and an excellent television campaigner, vulnerable, but the campaign is expected to be bruising.
Ms. Merkel, 47, the first woman and first easterner to lead a major party, was gracious in defeat. She met Mr. Stoiber, the leader of the Bavarian-based Christian Social Union, for breakfast, then spent much of the day telling confidants that she would pull back.
"I have always said the chancellor candidate of the conservatives should be the person who has the greatest chance of victory," she said at a nationally televised news conference in Magdeburg, in eastern Germany, during a meeting of her Christian Democrats.
"Together with Edmund Stoiber," she said, "I will do my part so that these chances of victory are not just a possibility but also a reality, and I shall do this with passion and deep conviction."
Ms. Merkel appeals strongly to moderates, women and voters in the east, constituencies with whom Mr. Stoiber is relatively weak. But she was never able to put her stamp on her own party, which is still suffering from a slush fund scandal that broke two years ago and tainted the reputation of her mentor, the former chancellor, Helmut Kohl.
Mr. Stoiber will have to fight not only Mr. Schroder, but the received political wisdom here. Bavarians are regarded with envy and suspicion as successful provincials, rather like Texans in America. And there has been a traditional cultural divide between the mostly Protestant north and Catholic south, which includes Bavaria.
The only Bavarian leader to run for the chancellorship until now, Franz-Josef Strauss, lost to Helmut Schmidt in 1980 and was considered a kind of sacrifice to an inevitable victory by a coalition of the Social Democrats and Free Democrats.
But this time Mr. Schroder is allied with the Greens, who have been losing popularity and may not even win the 5 percent of the vote required to get into Parliament.
Recent opinion surveys have shown Mr. Schroder losing ground, with the Social Democrats and the conservatives each polling 39 percent, according to the Electoral Research Group for ZDF television.
"The conservatives' standing has improved considerably," said Dieter Roth, of the polling firm. Mr. Schroder's party had held a four-point lead for the last six months or so.
Head-to-head, Mr. Schroder, 57, is more popular than Mr. Stoiber. But while an American style of personal campaigning is becoming more widespread, voters still cast their ballots for parties, not people.
Now that the conservatives have chosen their standard-bearer, the race will get more serious. This evening Mr. Stoiber issued a statement in Munich attacking Mr. Schroder for failing to produce the kind of economic reforms required to end the current slump, especially in the formerly Communist eastern states, where unemployment is high.
"Because we can only have prosperity, social and internal security together in Germany, I will do all I can to make sure that the new states are no longer uncoupled but can catch up," Mr. Stoiber said.
He plans to focus on widespread perceptions of rising crime and uncontrolled immigration as well. Mr. Stoiber has also emphasized a tougher stance on internal security since it was discovered that the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States were planned by Arabs living in Hamburg.
The sudden rise of a law-and-order party in Hamburg state elections earlier this autumn shocked German politicians. The leader of the party, a local judge named Ronald Schill, threatened to run nationwide unless Mr. Stoiber was the conservative candidate, an important argument used quietly against Ms. Merkel.
The conservatives are bound to attack Mr. Schroder for allowing his party in Berlin to go into coalition with the Party of Democratic Socialism, the direct descendant of the East German Communist Party, which built the Berlin Wall.
Mr. Schroder's efforts to move his own party to the center, where most elections are won, has allowed some room on his left that the former Communists are trying to fill behind their witty leader, Gregor Gysi. But Mr. Schroder is likely to paint Mr. Stoiber as a kind of provincial preacher, inexperienced internationally and with dangerous ideas.
Mr. Stoiber, who was Mr. Strauss's campaign manager in 1980, has toughness and political skill. He is known in the popular press as "the blond hatchet" or "the Bavarian pit bull," and is considered more a stiff Prussian than a fun-loving Bavarian.
He studied law before joining the Bavarian Ministry of Development and Environment in 1971 and has worked in the government ever since.
Mr. Stoiber "is like a crocodile that appears to lie listless in the mud and then, when his prey is within reach, strikes like lightning and without mercy," wrote the liberal Bavarian daily Suddeutsche Zeitung. "In questions of power, Stoiber has an infallible sense for the right timing and a brutality with which he always catches unaware even friends within the party."
Mr. Stoiber's best endorsement will be the economic performance of Bavaria, where unemployment is at 5 percent, half the national average, and where a prosperous lifestyle is matched with a crime rate that is second-lowest in the country.
Bavaria was a poor agricultural state at the end of World War II, but the Christian Social Union has built a business-friendly state with some of the best schools in Germany and has used billions in privatization proceeds to finance new businesses and "clusters" for new industries.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Angela Merkel has withdrawn from the race to lead the conservative opposition parties and has endorsed Edmund Stoiber as the candidate. (Reuters)
