HEADLINE: Bonjour, Teacher. Guten Tag, Too. 

BYLINE:  By ADAM BOWLES 

 BODY:
WHEN the International School at Dundee opened in Greenwich more than a year ago, the founders of the magnet school insisted that foreign language be treated equally with other, more traditional elementary subjects, such as math and English. 
 Now, the district wants to extend a similar language program to all its elementary schools, insuring that all its approximately 4,400 students learn a language other than English. 
 "Research suggests that children who learn a second language early on are apt to become multilingual, become more proficient in their native language and score better in their achievement tests," said Douglas Fainelli, the principal of Dundee. "We feel very strongly that this is not enrichment, this is important learning that all children should have."
Since at least 1993, there has been a steady but significant increase in foreign -- now more commonly called world -- language programs across the state, particularly in elementary schools. 
And, it appears the Sept. 11 attacks will lead to an even greater surge in these programs as educators insist on closing the gap between what students learn and what they know about other cultures and languages. 
A regional vocational high school in Bridgeport is teaching Mandarin Chinese for the first time this year. A state association of business executives has started a pilot program this year in which members visit Connecticut students to promote interest in learning other languages. And at least a handful of schools, including Canterbury, have recently reinstated world language programs that were cut from their budgets several years ago.
Mary Ann Hansen, a world language consultant at the Connecticut Department of Education, said she has been getting about five calls a week from school districts who are interested in starting a world language program. Typically, she gets only two such calls a month. 
Ms. Hansen said the terrorist attacks revealed a high level of ignorance among students toward Arabs and the rest of the world.
"It made people think seriously about how we've missed the opportunity to train our children in languages," Ms. Hansen said. "It showed us we're too isolated. We don't understand the cultures of the world. Education is a nonmilitary response to Sept. 11."
Christine Brown, director of foreign languages at Glastonbury Public Schools, said there are parallels between when the Russians launched Sputnik in 1957 and the events of Sept. 11.
"We didn't know about Sputnik because we didn't have experts in the country to speak Russian to monitor their scientific progress," Ms. Brown said. "We still don't understand how people think and you can't get that through English. Many people didn't understand the linguistic complexities and the 50 different languages spoken near the border of Afghanistan and Pakistan. This is not a new message, but the difference is people may be listening because of the events that have occurred in the last two months."
Soon after Sputnik, the National Defense Education Act was enacted and Glastonbury received a $1 million federal grant to create new learning methodologies using the latest technology, namely the tape recorder. 
Now, as president-elect of the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Languages, Ms. Brown is among the nation's leaders who are calling for more language programs to keep up with the rest of the world. But even before the attacks there were significant enrollment increases in world language classes in Connecticut. 
From 1993 to 2001, high school enrollment in this subject increased 21 percent to 84,104 students. During that same time, the number of schools that provided world language to students before grade 8 jumped to 271, up from 98, and the number of districts with such a program nearly doubled from 75 to 143. There are 169 school districts in Connecticut.
But the largest percentage increase took place among younger students. In 2001, there were 31 districts and 60 schools that taught world language before fourth grade, compared with just six districts and 14 schools in 1993.
Nationally, about one in five elementary schools reported teaching foreign languages in 1987, according to a survey by the Center for Applied Linguistics in Washington. In 1997, about one in three elementary schools reported teaching foreign languages.
Nancy Rhodes, one of the authors of the study, said while the increase in foreign language elementary programs is positive, it still is not adequate.
"We only have 32 percent of elementary schools offering foreign language programs," she said. "When you look at the whole scheme of things there needs to be much more."
Ms. Rhodes added that while many high school students may be bilingual, most foreign students are multilingual, with some learning up to four languages.
Still, technological upgrades have enabled schools here to link with students in other countries, particularly through e-mail pen pal programs and video conferences. Also, recent research showed that the younger a child is exposed to a different language, the easier it is to learn it and the easier it becomes to master complex languages in college.
State curriculum guidelines in 1998 urged schools to incorporate the proficiency of another language and knowledge of other cultures into the core of their curriculums.
The Connecticut Department of Education has added cultural ignorance to its list of top concerns that already include achievement gaps and teacher shortages, a priority noted in the back-to-school speech of Theodore S. Sergi, the education commissioner. 
"Do we believe that American 10-year-olds know as much about China as their Chinese counterparts know about America? No, and in this respect, we may be far behind much of the rest of the world," he said. 
"Have we sufficiently studied other countries, languages, cultures, their history and arts, their governments and economics, their geography and resources, and their strengths and needs? No. and we are missing a great opportunity for learning," he added.
Enrollment is increasing despite the state not requiring it for high school graduation. Some districts offer optional courses on the subject; others make it mandatory. 
Spanish, with an enrollment in the year 2000 of more than 54,700 students, is easily the most common world language taught in Connecticut schools. French (16,419), Latin (5,517), Italian (2,932) and German (1,296) rounded out the top five. 
There were more than 320,000 Hispanics living in Connecticut, according to the 2000 census, or a 50 percent increase from 1990.
"We have a larger number of Hispanic people in this country," Ms. Rhodes said. "Within the U.S., it is a useful language."
But schools also teach less traditional languages such as Russian and Portuguese. A few schools even teach Chinese.
John Curtis, principal/supervisor of the Bridgeport Regional Vocational Aquaculture School, said the high school introduced classes in Mandarin Chinese for the first time this year. The aquaculture school, which focuses on marine science and marine technology, has a student exchange and distance learning program with counterparts in China, where there is a strong fisheries industry. Ten students are enrolled in the optional program. Mr. Curtis said fluency in the language will give his students an edge in their careers.
"China is a major supplier of aquacultural products throughout the world," he said. "Kids are responding to this very favorably. They are conversant already." 
The biggest obstacle to further enrollment expansion is the lack of certified world language teachers, not finances, Ms. Hansen said. She estimated that there is a demand for about 60 teachers statewide, which would allow about 6,000 more students to learn another language. Another 60 teachers have only temporary permits and are not fully qualified. 
"The shortages are increasing," Ms. Hansen said. "Some districts are not considering starting programs because there are no teachers."
State partnerships with education government ministries in Italy and Spain have provided more teachers to Connecticut and has helped eased the shortage. The partnership with Spain, for instance, has allowed 55 education students in Spain to teach in schools here, including three teachers in Montville. 
Also, recent changes to the state's Alternate Route to Certification summer program means 60 additional teachers, not just 30, will be made available to schools every year to teach a world language.
The state has asked colleges to provide more world language teaching programs and has encouraged elementary school teachers, whose native tongue is other than English, to become certified world language teachers.
Richard Kusland of New Haven and a member of the International Executives Resource Group, started a pilot program this year in which business leaders from his association visit Connecticut schools to talk about the importance of understanding other cultures and learning other languages.
"There is a disconnect between the business world and education as it relates to international relations," said Mr. Kusland, who speaks Mandarin Chinese, Japanese and French. "International relations, not just language, are extremely important if we are going to be able to function in a world that we are a part of and not to be isolationists. With only one language you only think about the world in a certain way."
Canterbury recently reinstated a world language program. Budget cuts several years ago forced the school to drop Spanish. Now it is taught in grades 5-8. The older students take Spanish four times a week; the younger ones take it once a week.
"They absolutely love it," the principal, Kathleen Boyhan-Mauf, said. "The community itself recognizes the importance of the students understanding diverse cultures. I've had several parents excited about it."
Donna Way is one of them. She said she was expecting good things for her son Kyle, a sixth-grader, now that he is taking Spanish classes and believed it is especially important because of the increase in Spanish-speaking residents in the state. She regretted that her oldest child was never taught a world language in elementary or middle school. 
"I think it's going to be a great advantage for Kyle," she said. "It will help him to mix in with other kids and will help him in the job force." 
Ms. Brown in Glastonbury said parents move to her district just so their children can enroll in its foreign language program, which includes Spanish, French, Russian, and Latin beginning in ninth grade.
Recently, a parent from Virginia called for more information about these classes. Ms. Brown added that several graduates have gone on to begin careers in Russia and land key jobs in the defense and humanitarian sectors because of their knowledge of the Russian language and culture.
Fields Memorial School in Bozrah is one of the more than 100 elementary schools that still do not have a world language program. David Easterly, the superintendent, said that every year during budget talks people advocate for such a program.
But it would cost the district more than $40,000 to pay for a first-year teacher's salary, benefits and curriculum materials. So far, the school board hasn't approved money for the program.
The debate will pick up again during the new budget season, and when it does, Mr. Easterly said, it would be painful to have to decide against a world language program simply because of financial limits.
"From my perspective it is extremely important that students learn more about the languages and cultures of other nations," he said. "Hopefully, we will see our way clear on this."

HEADLINE: A Walk Along the Water Is Not a Simple Matter 

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: POINT PLEASANT BEACH 

 BODY:
GIOVANNI DA VERRAZANO didn't need the public trust doctrine when he became the first European to visit the Jersey Shore in 1524.
 But in the half-millennium since then -- particularly over the past decade -- development of private enclaves along New Jersey's beaches and riverbanks has repeatedly forced advocates of free access to the waterfront to invoke the 1,500-year-old public trust doctrine to force property owners to open their shores. 
 Even now, as chill winds keep beaches and walkways empty of all but the heartiest romantics, fisherman and a smattering of bundled up young mothers with strollers, there are negotiations playing out that will help determine who can use New Jersey's hallowed shores and golden coasts, and even whether they have to stand waist-deep in the water to do that.
For Bill Neyenhouse -- the Hudson River waterfront coordinator for the State Department of Environmental Protection and the man leading New Jersey's effort to line the 18.5 miles of Hudson River and New York Bay shoreline with a walkway from the Bayonne to the George Washington Bridge -- March 20, 2001, was a day he is not likely to forget. 
It was on that blustery morning that Mr. Neyenhouse went to the river armed with a court order he had obtained after the state's victory in a lawsuit against Shelter Bay -- an exclusive enclave of celebrities and other privacy seekers with breathtaking views of Manhattan -- to physically remove a section of chain link fence.
It was a full decade earlier, in 1991, that Shelter Bay had first been ordered by the department to remove the fence. 
"That was a particular case where I'd been involved from the beginning," recalled Mr. Neyenhouse, who had spent his summers as a youth at the Jersey Shore. "So it was a good feeling not only to be there, but to take wrench in hand and unbolt the sections of fence."
Without the public trust doctrine, which has its roots in ancient Rome, much of the Western world's coastline might be entirely off limits to the public. Indeed, the public trust doctrine is the fundamental legal principle implicit in state laws guaranteeing access to beaches and riverfronts, even if they are privately owned.
According to the modern oracle of waterfont wisdom and law -- the Web site of the federal Environmental Protection Agency -- the Roman Emperor Justinian asked his legal scholars in A.D. 530 to put all of the laws of the empire in writing. The result was the Institutes of Justinian, which included the provision that "by the law of nature these things are common to all mankind; the air, running water, the sea and consequently the shores of the sea." Thus was public trust was born. 
Rome, of course, fell. But like the pounding of the surf, the public trust doctrine has reverberated through the ages. It was absorbed into the legal systems of many European nations, including England, which passed it on to the American colonies.
Today, nearly every state, including New Jersey, has incorporated the doctrine into its laws.
In one of the most prominent ongoing cases, residents of Point Pleasant Beach could further define what public access means when it comes to private property above and below the water line. At its core, the case pits the privacy interests of property owners against the public's access to the waterfront.
Farther north, on the west bank of the Hudson, state regulations that went into effect in 1988 requiring developers to build and maintain public walkways along the 18.5-mile stretch between Bayonne and Fort Lee have angered some waterfront property owners, including those at Shelter Bay.
For a year before Mr. Neyenhouse of the state environmental agency removed the gate, Shelter Bay had actually been unlocking it to allow public access to the walkway during the same hours Veterans Park was open, 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. said Ray Gonzalez, president of the RPM Group, the company that manages Shelter Bay.
But Mr. Neyenhouse said the gate and guardhouse that Shelter Bay had installed effectively deterred the public, though Mr. Gonzalez said that for a year before the gate was removed and since then, there had been no incidents reported involving intrusion on residents' privacy or safety.
"It wasn't like we put up a neon sign that said, 'Come, we're open,' " Mr. Gonzalez said. "That walkway was always open to the public. What the state objected to was the appearance of the closure."
In Jersey City, a newly formed tenants organization at the mushrooming Newport development are pressing city officials and the developer, the Lefrak Organization, to build a waterfront park on an abandoned pier. But the LeFrak family, a major contributor to the Guggenheim Museum, wants to build a cultural center there.
Just as the cases involving Point Pleasant Beach, Newport and Shelter Bay fall under the same legal principal, the public trust doctrine, they have come to a head for essentially the same reason: burgeoning growth. As the state's economy boomed in the 1990's, developers scrambled to make the most of the increased demand for beachfront homes and riverfront condominiums, sometimes at the expense of public access.
In New Jersey, the public trust doctrine is implicit in the Waterfront Development Act, a statute dating from 1916, which is now concerned mainly with regulating the Hudson River and New York Harbor waterfronts. A federal law, the Coastal Area Facilities Review Act, better known by the acronym Cafra, regulates coastlines, which in the Garden State means the shores of the Raritan Bay, the Atlantic coast and the Delaware Bay. 
There is also the federal Coastal Zone Management Act, which requires states to assess the status of coastal issues -- including public access -- every three years. In August, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection's Office of Coastal Planning issued its most recent status report, which is required for federal financing of state projects. The report cites the public trust doctrine as the main tool in gaining or protecting public access.
Moreover, the report said, "The demand for access would increase proportionately as the coastal population increased. A review of the 2000 census confirms that. The population of New Jersey rose to 8,414,350 from 7,730,188 in 1990, an increase of 8.9 percent. In addition, the more urban areas along the Hudson, the Delaware and the Raritan, the demand for public access is likely to increase as water quality continues to improve and as the areas are redeveloped."
The report continues: "The public trust doctrine, which was enunciated by the New Jersey Supreme Court in several decisions, requires that tidal water bodies be accessible to the public for navigation, fishing and recreation. The court also recognized the 'increasing demand for our state's beaches and the dynamic nature of the public trust doctrine' and found that the public must have access to and use of privately owned dry sand areas as reasonably necessary to use the tidal water bodies."
The extent of the public's access -- or lack of it -- to the waterfront is difficult to gauge, the report found. While the state routinely demands that the public have access to the waterfront before it grants any developer permission to build, over time those points of access become obscured because signs are replaced or even removed -- sometimes deliberately.
But according to the latest report, the state environmental agency "lacks current accurate information regarding the location and extent of public access areas and lacks long-term monitoring of conditions at these locations."
To try to remedy the situation, the state will begin to compile an inventory of waterfront public access sites beginning in October.
The public's access to dry sand is especially relevant in Point Pleasant Beach, where negotiations are now taking place among property owners, borough and state officials and advocates of public access to determine just how public some privately owned beachfront should be.
Advocates for both private property and public access agree that the point where property owners have the right to exclude the public is mean high tide, or high water mark. Essentially, this is the spot farthest inland reached by the water at high tide. In theory, this dividing line between public and exclusive use gives anyone the right to walk, sit, fish or engage in any other proper use on sand that is, at most, dampened by the lapping of the waves. 
The problem is that the mean high tide mark tends to shift because of tidal changes as well as the narrowing of beaches because of erosion. As a result, the legal mean high water mark can be different from nature's. In Point Pleasant Beach in recent years, this has meant the legal mean high tide mark is somewhere waste deep in the ocean, a situation that advocates for beach access say is absurd. 
Ann Alexander, executive director of the Environmental Law Clinic at Rutgers University, who is representing an organization called Citizens' for the Right to Access Beaches, or CRAB, in the negotiations, believes the court's reference to dry sand provides a basis to assert the public's right to use the beach above the mean high-tide mark. The state has proposed a distance of 10 feet above.
The controversy in Point Pleasant Beach swelled after members of the citizens' group complained to the state that they were being denied access to beaches that at one time had been privately owned, but by companies that permitted access to the beach for a fee.
The problem, the organization said, was that the borough rezoned the property several years ago to allow single-family homes to be built, and that the homeowners were not willing to provide access to the public -- even for a fee.
Since then, the organization says, borough police have routinely told non-homeowners to leave the beach.
Bill Hiering Jr., the borough attorney, said that after a hotel proposal for the site fell through, leaving the site's previous owner bankrupt, single-family homes were the only way to develop the property.
"I think the borough was just trying to see something viable there," Mr. Hiering said of the zoning change.
Last May, the state wrote letters to the borough and to homeowners asserting they were violating terms of waterfront development permits. One problem, lawyers said, was that the terms of public access were never precisely defined.
On a recent Saturday, a dozen members of thye citizens' group gathered on the sandy shoulder of Ocean Avenue in Point Pleasant Beach between the Paradise Beach and Bay Point Dunes subdivisions. Large, newly constructed homes are wedged together on narrow lots, straddling a similarly narrow, slightly winding development road, Beacon Lane, named after the beach it parallels.
One specific provision of the waterfront permit issued by the state to the two subdivisions was that access to the ocean would be through a 10-foot-wide sandy ally between houses. At the Ocean Avenue entrance to the ally, barely visible to traffic, is a small sign reading, "Beach Access, Open to the Public," illustrated by a stick figure marching into a set of minimalist waves as gulls fly overhead.
"I've been enjoying this stretch of beach since the 1960's, surfing, swimming, fishing," said Ralph Cipolla, 49, a member of the citizens' group and longtime shore resident. "I've surfed up and down the East Coast, the West Coast, the Caribbean, Hawaii, and it's the only place I've been pulled out of the water by a security guard and told the ocean is private property."
"The surfers call this sewer beach," said Ed Sirchio, the organization's president. 
Raymond D. Bogan, a lawyer who represents the Bay Point Dunes Homeowners Association in the negotiations, said the public has the right to walk down to below the mean high-water mark within the 10-foot access corridor, then head into the waves or turn right or left and move up and down the beach. 
"My position is, they certainly have the right to stroll, to fish, do whatever they want beyond the watermark," Mr. Bogan said. "On the other hand, do they have the right to utilize the upland property? My position is that no, they don't. They have the right to get over that property."
But Ms. Alexander cited a 1984 New Jersey Supreme decision that involved a suit by non-residents against a homeowners association that had limited the sale of beach badges to Bay Head residents only. Ms. Alexander said the court found that the public should indeed be able to remain on dry sand above the mean high-water mark.
Referring to Mr. Bogan's position, she said, "I think to the extent that he's saying the public has no right to any of the dry sand area, he's simply wrong."
John Ely, president of the Paradise Beach Association, another group involved in the talks, said he had no problem with the notion of the public enjoying the ocean near his house. But as a practical matter, Mr. Ely said, visitors leave garbage strewn on the sand and even demand to use the rest rooms of homeowners.
If the state wants the public to have access to this beach, Mr. Ely believes, it should condemn it and compensate him, and then hire lifeguards and litter patrols. Otherwise, he said, the state has no right to impose that responsibility on homeowners.
"We own this property," said Mr. Ely, 61, a contractor who lives in New Brunswick. "This is America. Who can tell you people can go on your property?"
While citizen activists are often critical of state agencies -- often accusing them of being in league with industrial polluters or other commercial interests -- waterfront access seems to be one area in which official efforts are roundly praised by activists.
In August 1999, when the dispute over Shelter Bay was raging, the state also prevailed in a related suit filed in federal court against the Department of Environmental Protection by the New Jersey Builders Association and its national affiliate. The builders argued that the walkway requirement amounted to an unconstitutional taking of private property. But in what Ms. Alexander and others termed a landmark decision, Judge Garrett E. Brown of United States District Court in Newark rejected the builders' arguments. 
Citing the public trust doctrine, Judge Brown found that 15.4 miles of the 18.5-mile waterfront walkway was fill that had once been underwater, and therefore reserved for the public's use. For the 3.1 miles of waterfront that had historically been dry land, Judge Brown found that the walkway rules were well within the state's authority to regulate land use.
Patrick O'Keefe, chief executive of the New Jersey Builders Association, said he was discouraged by the recent court decisions and feared that property rights were being eroded like so much New Jersey beachfront.
"I think the direction of the law places a cloud over the ownership of all the shorefront property in New Jersey," Mr. OKeefe said.
Mr. O'Keefe warned that carrying the public trust doctrine to its extreme, particularly as applied by Judge Brown, the principle could be invoked to strip property owners of their rights on barrier islands from Bay Head to Beach Haven.
A common complaint among property rights advocates in the waterfront access debate is that the state has been unwilling to put its money where its mouth is. While the state is eager to force owners to provide the public with access to their waterfront property, it has been reluctant to publicly finance waterfront access projects, including purchasing waterfront property from private owners.
The result of that reluctance, Mr. O'Keefe and others said, was that property owners were unfairly penalized for living along the beach, and the walkway has evolved in a peacemeal fashion -- still incomplete after 13 years -- as the state waits for the waterfront to be privately developed. 
But the state has developed its own stretches of walkway. Perhaps the most notable example is the one at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, with its stunning views of New York Bay, Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty. 
In Hoboken -- where the classic "On the Waterfront" was filmed -- walkways and waterfront parks opposite Manhattan are on property owned by private developers, the state, the city and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. It is a model of public planning enthusiastically endorsed by the crowds that flock to the waterfront there, and envied by residents of nearby communities.
But there are also stretches of waterfront that even the most optimistic advocates concede may not be accessible to the public in the foreseeable future. These are typically occupied by businesses -- a Hess oil depot in Edgewater, for example -- that have continuously operated since before 1988, and therefore are exempt from the walkway requirement. Fortunately, Mr. Neyenhouse pointed out, these remaining, inaccessible stretches will be subject to walkway rules if they are converted to new uses.
One location about to add a new stretch of walkway is the Newport complex in Jersey City. Some residents of the 600-acre development saw the request for additional office space on the site's last remaining 31 acres as an opportunity to persuade the developer to turn a six-ace peninsula into a waterfront park.
In the end, the residents and city officials who intervened on their behalf failed to win the park concession from the developer, the LeFrak organization. But they did exact something else: a 2005 deadline for completion of Newport's stretch of the walkway. 
"I think thats a good thing," Ms. Coe said.
The deadline is significant, in that it goes beyond the state's 1988 regulations, which only require that developers build a walkway at the time they develop their property.
"Were trying to nudge things along," said Stan Eason, a spokesman for Mayor Glenn Cunningham of Jersey City, referring to the 2005 deadline. "The mayor stepped in and said, hold on, youve got a whole lot of people who live down there who want to have some input."
The walkway also runs through Weehawken, West New York, North Bergen and Fort Lee, and other citizens groups are fighting similar battles to make their waterfronts more accessible.
Richard LeFrak, president of the Lefrak Organization, said his company had already provided 3,200 feet of walkway at Newport at a cost of $9 million.
"Do I think its a nice amenity, yes, I think its a nice amenity," Mr. LeFrak said. "Not only for my tenants, I think everybody in the community has enjoyed the walkway."
Regarding the peninsula, Mr. LeFrak said, the entire perimeter would be ringed by the walkway, plus a 1.4-acre pier jutting from the peninsula will be made into a park.
But there always comes a point when property owners assert their rights, which Mr.k O'Keefe pointed out are established under the Fifth Amendment, providing for just compensation when land is taken for public use. Making the public pay for public amenities, including waterfront access, is the whole point of the condemnation process, said Mr. LeFrak, who warned against trying to push developers and other waterfront property owners too far.
"There is a limited amount of public infrastructure that can be extracted from the development community," Mr. LeFrak said. "The state always has the option of condemning property and paying for a park. The last time I looked my name wasn't the State of New Jersey."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 
Big Loco, Shy Girl and Friends: A Debate About Stereotypes

BYLINE:  By ADRIAN BRUNE 

 BODY:
When children in most New York neighborhoods plug a coin into a gum-ball machine, a toy car or tiny space alien is likely to roll down the slot into the waiting hands below.
 But in largely black and Latino neighborhoods like the South Bronx, especially at the local chain supermarkets like C-Town, the most coveted prizes are miniature plastic figures wearing baggy jeans, knit caps and bandannas, otherwise known as the Homies. 
 Homies are an offshoot of a comic strip of the same name created by David Gonzalez, a California graphic artist, that first appeared in the mid-90's in Lowrider Magazine. In 1998 they made their way East as two-inch gum-ball machine miniatures. 
As their tale has unfolded in the comic strip, the Homies are a group of tightly knit Chicano buddies raised in the bleakness of the Mexican-American barrio of East Los Angeles. Their culture involves cruising around in low-riding cars, rapping at local hangouts and picking up scantily clad women. Fellows like Pelon, Smiley, Eightball, Mr. Raza, Droopy and Big Loco hang out at the local taco stand and trade provocative remarks with Babydoll, CatEyes, Bouncy and Shy Girl.
Ask a random sampling of people on the streets of the South Bronx if the Homies accurately represent them and their neighbors, and they will mostly answer no. At the Point, for example, a community development center, many young people in the after-school program are outfitted not in gangster garb but in Abercrombie & Fitch or the Gap. 
"They depict people from the West Coast," said Wilfredo Feliciano, a member of the graffiti collective Tats Cru, who nonetheless contributes to the collection of Homies in the collective's office on Garrison Avenue.
"We know the guy that makes these," added Mr. Feliciano, who was wearing work boots, jeans and a yellow T-shirt. "They are funny because each one represents what many of our friends look like."
But despite their appeal, the Homies do not win universal praise; a Latino supermarket chain in Los Angeles County pulled the toys from its gum-ball machines in 1999 after the police and prosecutors complained.
"I would not let my daughter play with a woman figurine that is dressed like a slut or something," said Tanisha Thompson, a 23-year-old mother from the South Bronx. "It's bad enough that there is already such a negative interpretation of this neighborhood."
Others, however, see the Homies simply as yet another art form, like rap and graffiti, that is unique to the urban community. 
"I don't see anything negative about them," said Cinderella Martin, an administrator at the Point. "The way they dress is just the way they are." 
Gesturing toward one of the little figures, she added: "This guy right here looks like most of the artists who come to the Point. What's negative about that?" ADRIAN BRUNE

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Fortunoff Is Set to Begin Major White Plains Project

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
FORTUNOFF, the Long-Island based jewelry and home furnishings retailer, is about to start work on a 180,000-square-foot store in White Plains on the site of a closed Saks Fifth Avenue store. The change will bring the first full-size Fortunoff store to Westchester County, while marking the departure of Saks from the county after almost 50 years. 
 The company, which also has a store on Fifth Avenue in New York City and four other suburban stores, will build an additional 80,000 square feet in its building for other tenants, possibly including a restaurant. Saks, whose store at the site was 128,000 square feet. announced its plan to close its Westchester store in June, saying its interests would best be met by "concentrating our resources on our other locations in the surrounding area." 
 The department store's closest outlets are in Stamford and Greenwich in Connecticut and in Manhattan. The shuttering of the White Plains store is one of several Saks Fifth Avenue closings within the past two years. In all, Saks Inc. operates 61 Saks Fifth Avenue stores.
The old department store building in White Plains, which contains pockets of encapsulated asbestos, according to city officials, is to be razed.
The opening of the new Fortunoff is part of a larger redevelopment effort in downtown White Plains, according to Teri Waivada, executive director of the county's Industrial Development Agency.Officials and merchants hope that new retail development in the city -- particularly Cappelli Development's construction of a $300 million retail, entertainment and residential complex on a former Macy's department store site at Mamaroneck Avenue and Main Street -- will inject new life in the downtown area, which, outside of several retail malls, has been struggling in recent years.
White Plains, often called the City of 1,000 Stores in the 1940's and 1950's, has experienced a high vacancy rate in its downtown retail area in the past decade, with the smaller stores on Mamaroneck Avenue and the side streets languishing in the shadow of the malls.
Several blocks away from the small stores along Mamaroneck Avenue, Saks has stood by itself for much of the past decade, across the street from and in competition with The Westchester, a million-square-foot mall, built in the early 1990's and anchored by Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom. In 1998, Saks considered a $65 million project involving 155,000 square feet of small shops next to a renovated Saks. But the project never proceeded.
ALTHOUGH Fortunoff will also stand apart from the city's two major retail malls -- the Galleria Mall and The Westchester -- its planners expect it to fare better than Saks. "Fortunoff is a separate destination in its own right, offering a very large selection of housewares and jewelry and not competing with anyone else," Ms. Waivada said.
Fortunoff, a privately held company, is predicting $90 million in sales for its first year of operation in White Plains, and this would translate to $2.4 million in city sales taxes annually, said Paul S. Wood, coordinator of economic development for White Plains. Saks generated $18 million in sales in 2000 and about $600,000 in tax revenues for the city.
The new Fortunoff is expected to have 600 full- and part-time workers. In June, Saks said it employed about 100 people at the White Plains site.
Mr. Wood said the city had been courting Fortunoff for several years and was pleased when the Saks site at 100 Bloomingdale Avenue -- the street also has a longstanding Bloomingdale's store -- became available.
Fortunoff paid $14 million for the Saks Fifth Avenue building and six acres of land on which it is located, said Louis Fortunoff, the retailer's vice president. 
Mr. Fortunoff, who is the grandson of the Max and Clara Fortunoff, who opened the doors of their first store in Brooklyn in 1922, said demographic studies indicated a move to Westchester would be propitious. In addition to its Fifth Avenue store, the chain has suburban stores in Westbury on Long Island and in Wayne, Woodbridge and Paramus in New Jersey.
Mr. Fortunoff said the retailer locates in areas where there are 200,000 households with an average household income of $75,000 or more within a 15-mile radius. "When we get that, we're pretty happy," he said, adding that Fortunoff tested out Westchester with an outdoor-furniture store in Scarsdale that it first opened in 2000. "That store did well," Mr. Fortunoff said. "It was the confirmation we needed." The Scarsdale store is open only during the warm months.
He also presented material to the city citing statistics from the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics showing that Westchester residents annually spend $114 million on jewelry, $959 million on home furnishings and $506 million on housewares, appliances and tabletop items like china, crystal and silverware.
After considering other sites in White Plains, Fortunoff decided on the Saks site, opposite The Westchester, which attracts many well-to-do customers. Because it is not practical to construct a bridge between the mall and the new Fortunoff site, the city will spend $2 million to improve pedestrian access between the two sites, Mr. Wood said. The money will cover curb, water main and sidewalk work; traffic signals; and underground wiring.
White Plains was designed with an emphasis on its roads -- to facilitate the efficient movement of vehicles transporting workers in the city's office buildings, especially during rush hours. "Now we're hoping to encourage more pedestrian traffic," Mr. Wood said. "We're looking to make White Plains more of a 24-hour city."
Last month, the White Plains Common Council approved plans for Fortunoff's retail center after the company made several changes to allay neighbors' concerns. Initially, neighbors objected to the proposal, saying it would further disrupt life in their quiet neighborhood of one- and two-family homes.
Residents were worried about noise, exhaust fumes and other pollution; increased traffic; and cars parking on side streets in front of their houses.
IN response to their concerns, Fortunoff has agreed to enclose its loading dock, which is near a private backyard, and move a proposed service road to make room for a planted buffer zone. In addition, asbestos removal will be carefully monitored when Saks is demolished, and construction workers will be instructed to park on site or in specially designated areas. 
While the city of White Plains is offering no specific financial incentives to Fortunoff, the county will issue $90 million to $110 million in taxable bonds, Ms. Waivada said. The proceeds from the sale of the bonds will be dispersed to Fortunoff to pay construction costs, and the interest and principal on the bonds will be repaid by the company, which has made a commitment to have the store in operation by December 2003. The bonds are typically purchased by corporations or banks looking for short-term liquid investments.
The developer is also receiving state and local sales tax breaks on construction and equipment.
"We're helping Fortunoff because projects like these create jobs and help the tax base," Ms. Waivada said. "We're looking forward to this next step for White Plains."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Maya MacGuineas, Robin Brooks

 BODY:
Maya Carol MacGuineas and Robin Jermyn Brooks were married yesterday at their home in Washington. Judge Emmet G. Sullivan of Federal District Court in Washington.
 Ms. MacGuineas, 33, is keeping her name. She is a senior fellow specializing in fiscal policy at the New America Foundation, a public policy research institute in Washington. She is also on the boards of Common Cause, the government watchdog organization, and Third Millennium, an organization specializing in public policy issues for people born in the 1960's and 1970's. She graduated from Northwestern and received a master's degree in public policy from Harvard. 
 She is the daughter of D. Biard MacGuineas of Washington and the late Carol Kalish MacGuineas, and is the stepdaughter of Peggy Miller. The bride's father is a partner in the Washington office of Dykema Gossett, a Detroit law firm. Her mother was a freelance writer.
Mr. Brooks, 31, is an economist in the research department at the International Monetary Fund in Washington, where he is working on the impact of globalization on financial markets. He graduated from the London School of Economics and received Master of Arts and Master of Philosophy degrees in economics from Yale, where he also received a Ph.D. in that subject.
He is the son of Val and Jermyn Brooks of Friedrichsdorf, Germany. His father retired as the senior partner for Europe of PricewaterhouseCoopers L.L.P., in London, and is now an executive director of Transparency International, an organization in Berlin that seeks to increase governmental accountability and uncover corruption. His mother teaches drama at the Phillip-Reiss-Schule, a high school in Friedrichsdorf.
The couple met at the Brookings Institution in 1997, where Mr. Brooks occupied a cubicle outside of Ms. MacGuineas's office when she was a senior research analyst and he was a research fellow. Mr. Brooks said it took several months for him to make it clear that, despite appearances, he was not her personal secretary and did not take memos. Despite the confusion, he said they became fast friends and soon were inseparable as a couple.

HEADLINE: Insurance Bills Provoke Sticker Shock 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
BUILDING owners and residents are doing double-takes these days as they look at their insurance bills and see premiums that have jumped sharply -- even, in a few cases, doubling. 
 With a significant chunk of insurers' assets suddenly dissipated by payouts set aside after the World Trade Center attack -- about $50 billion in claims out of about $140 billion in available capital -- the insurance companies and their network of financial backstops, the reinsurance companies, have taken steps to restuff that cushion against possible future losses. 
 Landlords, co-op shareholders, condominium owners, market-rate renters and even, eventually, rent-regulated tenants will pay the price. Premiums have been increasing by about 30 percent nationwide, and far more for many New York buildings -- 66 percent according to one landlord group's survey.
For now, industry analysts say, owners of private homes, particularly in more suburban environs, will not be hit as hard, though circumstances other than the events of Sept. 11 are expected to also raise premiums on homeowner policies. 
Paul Brensilber is president of Jordan Cooper & Associates, managers of 40 residential buildings with about 6,000 apartments -- most in "core Manhattan," he said, "but not downtown at all."
Last month, when insurance policies for 30 of those buildings were renewed, "the increases averaged 60 percent," Mr. Brensilber said. "And we have another package of properties, luxury buildings, where we've experienced an 87 percent increase."
One of the smaller buildings that Mr. Brensilber's company manages, a 58-unit co-op on the Upper West Side, saw its premium increase from $18,000 to $30,000 a year -- a 66 percent jump. "The owners will get a 75 cent per-share increase, or an average of $207," he said. "It's significant, it hurts."
Daniel Benedict is president of Benedict Properties, which owns 40 buildings with 2,000 apartments, most of them rent-regulated six-story structures in Queens and the Bronx. "My insurance policy expired Oct. 29, just in time for the new rates to come into play," Mr. Benedict said. "The rates increased between 40 and 100 percent. In past jumps, it's been 10 to 12 percent."
"I've seen cycles before," Mr. Benedict said, "but nothing like this."
There have never, of course, been circumstances like this. 
"First of all, the impact will be greatest on multiunit structures that are dense with people," said Robert P. Hartwig, vice president and chief economist for the Insurance Information Institute, a trade association. Besides office buildings and other businesses, those structures include co-op, condominium and rental apartment buildings, all of which must carry commercial insurance because they are operated as businesses, usually organized as corporations.
"Now, post-Sept. 11," Mr. Hartwig said, "any building like this could be viewed as a possible target that is attractive to terrorists -- either the structure itself being the target or the structure suffering collateral damage because of proximity to another attractive target." Citing Battery Park City as an example, he said, "It was not the target itself, but nevertheless suffered severe damage."
And while those risks are, as Mr. Hartwig put it, "considerably diminished in places like suburban Yonkers and Dutchess County, or the more rural parts of the metropolitan area," clusters of multifamily buildings and even single-family homes in proximity to less obvious potential targets could also eventually be affected. Those targets could include, according to industry officials, airports, corporate complexes, military bases, port facilities, a stadium, a chemical factory, a power plant.
SOME real estate executives wonder, however, whether the insurance industry is stretching to its own advantage. "Things are so out of control," said Joseph Strasburg, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, the largest landlord group in New York City. "Post-9/11, in some respects, gave insurance companies an excuse to really jack up these rates."
"Several companies, both U.S.-based and international," Mr. Strasburg said, "have ceased writing for residential, which reduces competition and further increases pricing."
Mr. Hartwig confirmed that assertion, saying: "It is true that some insurers and reinsurers have stepped back from some lines of insurance in order to limit their potentially catastrophic loss-exposure from terrorist acts. It's not limited to residential."
Mr. Brensilber, whose buildings are facing sizable premium increases even though they are not downtown, said: "What we're being told is that the insurance companies are just considering them high-risk. I can understand high risk -- like my office is right by St. Patrick's Cathedral and Rockefeller Center. But the Upper East Side or West Side? I don't imagine that would be first and foremost for terrorist activity. I don't understand it."
It has been, to be sure, a course-changing year for the industry. Insurance companies have experienced, as have all others, a drop in the value of the stocks and bonds in which they invest. They have begun to turn away from their decade-old practice of using homeowner insurance -- the policies by which individual home and apartment owners insure their possessions -- as a loss leader; that is, as a discounted lure in a package with other types of more profitable personal policies, like automobile insurance. At the same time, after Sept. 11, many businesses that were underinsured are now clamoring for increased coverage. So there is a squeeze.
Then, on Dec. 20, Congress rejected legislative efforts to create a federal backstop for the industry by which the government would have shared some of the losses in the event of future terrorist attacks.
And so, with the unprecedented "global decrease" in the capital available to pay claims after Sept. 11, Mr. Hartwig of the insurance institute said, there has been upward pressure on premiums. That pressure has also been caused, he said, "by the fact that reinsurers have indicated that they will no longer, in many cases, be willing to provide coverage for terrorist acts."
Reinsurance is, in effect, insurance for the primary insurance companies -- a way of reducing their exposure. And in some instances, particularly for large buildings, the primary insurance company will take out policies with several reinsurers, thereby further spreading the risk.
"You're left with a situation," Mr. Hartwig said, "where fewer primary insurers are holding all the risk for acts of terrorism with no way to spread it out around the globe. For many insurers, this represents an unacceptably high level of risk."
To cover that risk, insurance companies have taken steps other than simply raising rates. While in the past they had offered their good customers credits (discounts on the premium), some companies have reduced or eliminated those credits. Some companies have reclassified policyholders from a "superpreferred" tier to a preferred or standard tier -- classifications based on the age and condition of the building. And in some cases, companies have decided to eliminate coverage in the basic comprehensive policy for certain risks -- like terrorist attacks or the presence of lead -- requiring customers to buy a rider at an additional expense.
But the primary method of raising premiums, other than through the rate, is to increase the valuation on a building. "Typically, when you bought a policy in the past," said Dan Margulies, executive director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, a group representing about 2,500 landlords in the five boroughs, "you worked with your broker to establish an agreed-upon value for replacement of the building, and the policy premium would be based on that agreed-upon value. Now the insurers are saying they don't agree, essentially saying, 'The building is worth more and we're going to charge you more.' "
Based on several surveys, Mr. Hartwig, the industry representative, estimated that premiums for commercial policies are rising by about 30 percent as they come up for renewal across the country. "So the cost of insuring apartment complexes will rise, nationally, somewhere in that 30 percent range," he said. 
But John Schule, vice president of Smyth, Sanford & Gerard, the chief insurance broker for the Rent Stabilization Association, said that a recent survey of 400 building owners showed that the average rate increase has been 66 percent. "It's for five-unit apartment buildings in the five boroughs on up to 300-unit owners," Mr. Schule said. "The sticker shock has hit them."
And Mr. Margulies of the Community Housing Improvement Association said, "We're seeing typical renewal increases in the 40 to 60 percent range and, in some cases, double." 
With many of his members owning rent-stabilized buildings, Mr. Margulies wondered how the city's Rent Guidelines Board would calculate insurance increases in its annual Price Index of Operating Costs and deliberations over possible raises in regulated rents. "We have a big concern that they won't take full account of the increases," he said. "It's never a straight pass-through, because they look at all the costs -- taxes, oil, labor, supplies, water, legal, insurance -- and then they flip a coin." Officials of the Rent Guidelines Board declined to comment.
Doing some quick calculating, Stuart Saft, chairman of the 2,200-member Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums, said, "According to the agents I've spoken to, the cost for insuring most buildings is currently 8.5 cents per square foot."
"So let's say you have a building that's 200 feet by 200 feet; that's a footprint of 40,000 square feet," Mr. Saft continued. "If it's 15 stories, the building has 600,000 square feet. If the insurance is 8.5 cents per square foot, the premium would now be $51,000." But last year, he said, "the rate would have been about half of that, so the premium would have been about $25,000."
If the building has 300 apartments, meaning the apartments average 2,000 square feet, "the insurance cost doubles to $170 per apartment," Mr. Saft said, "and that will show up in the maintenance."
Citing an actual renewal, Mr. Saft said a recently constructed building on the Upper East Side that paid $31,035 for insurance last year will pay $49,128 this year -- a 63 percent increase "in a brand new, fully sprinklered building with no loss history."
"There are 76 units," he said, "so the average insurance cost per apartment is going from $408 to $646."
Asked about increases of 50 to 100 percent for buildings in New York, compared with the national average of about 30 percent, Mr. Hartwig said: "Yes, that will happen for some properties. One thing we've learned from Sept. 11 is that terrorists are intent on not only destroying property, but also destroying lives. So a residential structure itself could be targeted."
"I should stress," he added, "that prior to Sept. 11 rates were rising in the 10 to 15 percent range anyway."
Three primary cost-drivers were at work, nationally, before Sept. 11, and still are, Mr. Hartwig said: record losses from natural catastrophes over the last decade, rising rebuilding costs and a slimy black substance called Stachybotrys chartarum -- mold.
The latter, he said, "is a completely new category of suit, and it's having a dramatic impact on the cost of insuring homes and, in some areas, apartment complexes and office buildings."
Last month, 500 tenants and the landlord of Henry Phipps Plaza, an apartment complex in the Kips Bay section along the East River in Manhattan, reached a $1.17 million settlement of a lawsuit over mold that the tenants contended had caused health problems ranging from respiratory disease to hastened deaths. The original suit had sought $12 billion.
BUT even before mold joined the list of cost-drivers, premiums were already rising, particularly because of an increase in natural disasters. In 2001 alone, Mr. Hartwig said, there were 14 named storms across the country, "which is well above average."
"Fortunately, none came up this way," he said. "But 2002 could change all that. In the metro area, there are many homes that are considered at great risk for damage from windstorms, including hurricanes, because they are close to the shore." At the same time, there has been an acceleration in the cost of home repairs, Mr. Hartwig said, caused by, among other things, higher material costs and a shortage of skilled labor.
All of that, he said, raised the cost of homeowners insurance by 6 percent in 2001, and is expected to do the same this year -- after a 1.5 percent increase in 2000.
Stephen Batkin, president of Lampe-Batkin Associates, an independent insurance agency in White Plains, said that while premiums have been inching up, he has not yet seen much change, "from the suburban homeowner's point of view," after Sept. 11. That is true, in part, because state insurance departments review and sometimes trim rate increases for homeowner policies. 
The World Trade Center attack has, however, "caused people to review their policies to see if their coverage is adequate," Mr. Batkin said. "That we've seen a lot of. People finally realized that it is possible to have total losses, and they want to be sure their policy will protect them."
Pointing out that the global tremors from Sept. 11 -- particularly "the uncertainty about reinsurance" -- have yet to ripple through the more tranquil lanes and cul-de-sacs of suburbia, Mr. Batkin said: "We're just waiting to see what will happen. All signs point to a change."
Mr. Benedict, the landlord with many buildings in Queens and the Bronx, was befuddled by it all. "It has nothing to do with claims histories!" he said.
And in Manhattan, Mr. Strasburg of the Rent Stabilization Association, the large landlord group, was both troubled -- about "the double whammy of rate increases and valuation increases" -- and philosophical.
"We believe it's cyclical," he said, "and things will ease off in two years."

HEADLINE: CENSUS; 
A Welcome Mat for Immigrants

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: CAMDEN 

 BODY:
LIKE many other Cuban families, Felipe Gorostiza's found northern New Jersey warm and accommodating.
 "The Cuban population when I was in North Jersey was big in a few towns," said Dr. Gorostiza, who is now the executive director of Walter Rand Institute for Public Affairs at Rutgers University here. "Then they became the typical American immigrant experience and moved to the suburbs. Cubans went everywhere, and I guess I am one." 
 The latest census information shows that New Jersey still embraces immigrants searching for the American dream. While the state lost nearly 40,000 people to other states from April 2000 to July 2001, that was more than made up for by over 60,000 immigrants who came to New Jersey from other countries during that same period.
Since 1790, the Census Bureau has made complete counts of the nation's population, but it now has a mandate from the federal government to update those statistics regularly, especially those relating to race, ethnic origin and immigration.
Indeed, the latest population estimates show that New Jersey, while ranked only 24th among the states in overall population growth, is adding people faster than any other state in the Northeast -- primarily because of the increase in the number of immigrants coming to the state.
"It is the continuation of a trend that started back in the 1970's," said Sen Yuan-Wu, the chief demographer for the New Jersey Department of Labor. "Immigration policy changed in the late 1960's, putting fewer restrictions on non-European immigrants. Since then, New Jersey has been a welcoming place for immigrants from, particularly, Asia and Latin America."
Current statistics back this up. Overall, New Jersey's population rose by 70,081, to 8,484,431. Nearly 50,000 of that was because of the state's internal birthrate. But a loss of 39,215 people to other states was more than offset by the 63,361 immigrants who decided to call New Jersey home during the same period. That disproportionate population shift placed New Jersey sixth among the states in net immigration.
"I would think one of the biggest reasons immigrants come to New Jersey is that they don't have that preconceived notion that New Yorkers and Philadelphians have about New Jersey being somehow undesirable," said Dr. Gorostiza.
He said immigrants today are not looking to be those huddling masses of lore.
"They don't turn up their noses and move to Brooklyn just because it isn't New Jersey," he said. "They see it is a good place to live, convenient to working in the cities, safe and cheaper than cramming into some apartment in the city."
Most of the people leaving New Jersey, according to the census data, move to either New York and Pennsylvania (presumably those native-born New Jersey naysayers Dr. Gorostiza talked about) or to Florida (primarily retirees).
But those immigrating come from an increasingly wide range of countries. The large Cuban immigration of the previous 30 years slowed in the last decade. In 1990, for instance, there were about 80,000 Cuban-born New Jersey residents; in 2000, there were 72,000.
On the other hand, there was a boom in Mexican immigration to the state -- a 258 percent increase from 1990 to 2000. And though the increase was statewide, the largest increase was was centered in Cumberland County, where the Mexican population rose sixfold in 10 years.
Dr. Gorostiza attributed the large in increase in Cumberland County, in South Jersey, to a change in agricultural patterns in the areas around Vineland and Bridgeton.
"Things have changed from food growing to nurseries," said Dr. Gorostiza. "It is now not a migrant community, but a year-round one. The migrants used to come from Puerto Rico and then go back home, but the Mexicans who replaced them work from spring to Christmas in the nurseries and greenhouses."
However, he noted that the Mexicans came to the area in the first place because there was a Spanish-speaking infrastructure already in place from the Puerto Rican community.
"If you come to a place where your language is spoken, where it is easier to get the food or other items you are used to, where people are used to having people somewhat like you, you are more likely to build a community there," he said.
Similarly, he said, Central American immigrants have resettled in the urban neighborhoods of North Jersey that 10 or 15 years ago were primarily Cuban.
Conversely, what seemed to be a burgeoning Japanese immigrant community, especially in Bergen County, has dwindled somewhat in recent years. The census figures show that there are 15 percent fewer Japanese-born New Jersey residents than there were in 1990.
"The Japanese economy has taken a nose dive, so the people who were sent to work in New York and who lived in Fort Lee for three years are just not there anymore," said Dr. Gorostiza. "They would naturally move to that area, since there was a great place to shop, the Japanese mall in Edgewater, and much larger apartments than they were used to in Japan."
According to Dr. Wu, the state demographer, the major age groups that New Jersey is losing to other states are the over-60's and those in their teens and early 20's.
"The first is not hard to figure out," he said. "It's retirees who are moving to the Sun Belt. This is a national trend, and I'm afraid even New Jersey will not escape it.
"But it is more distressing among the young people," he added. "That is mostly because we send so many people to college in other states. Rutgers is nowhere as big, for instance, as Ohio State, so we have a hard time keeping young people here for college. That can be a disturbing population trend for the future."
In the near future, New Jersey may also lose its foothold among the 10 most populous states. It is currently ninth, but census figures show that at their current rates of growth, Georgia and North Carolina are poised to overtake New Jersey in population. Georgia is almost certain to do so by 2005, and North Carolina will probably overtake New Jersey by the end of the decade.
Nonetheless, New Jersey is still the most densely populated state, with about 1,200 people per square mile as against the rest of the country, where the average is about 77 people per square mile.
"We are growing more than any other state in the Northeast, but I am afraid that isn't enough with the trends of population moving South and West," said Dr. Wu. "But as long as the economy here stays strong, immigration will continue and we will continue to prosper as a state no matter how many people we have."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A street in Jersey City. Many new state residents are Latin American. (Nancy Wegard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS AND GOVERNMENT; 
A McGreevey Cabinet Takes Shape

BYLINE:  By SARAH RUBENSTEIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
AS New Jersey's fiscal outlook wors ened considerably with its budget shortfall growing by a billion dollars to $2.4 billion since the last accounting only five weeks ago -- Governor-elect James E. McGreevey last week pressed ahead to fill out his nascent cabinet.
 Mr. McGreevey, who is poised to take the oath of office on Tuesday, has so far cobbled together a cabinet that includes, on the one hand, political allies, and on the other, figures who have accumulated years of experience in their fields without becoming too embroiled in the state's political system. 
 "These are qualified individuals who do not raise any eyebrows," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School at Rutgers University.
Among those whom Mr. McGreevey has named to fill some of the most powerful positions in the state's first Democratic administration in more than 10 years are a Trenton outsider, a lawyer who has worked on both sides of the political aisle and a fellow Woodbridge insider. 
In the aftermath of a campaign -- both truncated and at the same time dominated by such issues as terrorism, a yawning budget shortfall and educating the state's 1.3 million public school students -- Mr. McGreevey's choices of William L. Librera as education commissioner, David Samson as attorney general and John E. McCormac as treasurer have drawn the most attention.
As Mr. Librera, a former schools superintendent in Montclair, admitted in an interview last week, he is hardly a Trenton insider. After meeting with Edithe Fulton, president of the New Jersey Education Association, for the first time last week, he said he doubted that people had guessed that Mr. McGreevey would choose him for the post.
Still, he vowed to use his more than 30 years of experience to address many of the issues that Mr. McGreevey has emphasized. He said he would focus on early childhood literacy while also working to implement reforms that require the state to provide more aid for some of the poorest districts. 
In addition, Mr. Librera said he would work to reorganize the Department of Education, a body whose leadership role has drawn criticism in recent years.
The 55-year-old Mr. Librera, currently an associate professor in the educational leadership department at New Jersey City University who also runs Educational Nexus, an educational consulting firm, was superintendent in the Montclair public schools from 1992 to 1997 before becoming superintendent in Allamuchy, a much smaller district.
Those who worked with Mr. Librera, who served Montclair -- always a highly politicized district -- at a particularly fractious time said he devised innovative solutions to some of the district's problems.
Herman White, who was board of education president in Montclair during Mr. Librera's tenure, said he was one of the first educators to analyze and to begin to address an achievement gap between black and white students. He also addressed the district's growing space crunch by opening a new middle school and making a controversial decision to allow the town to take over the prekindergarten program.
Yet many said that the superintendent's position in Montclair -- always an exhausting one -- eventually tired Mr. Librera, who left the district, with a student body of 6,200, to run the schools in Allamuchy, a district with 350 students in kindergarten through eighth grade, all in one school.
"In a town this diverse, wrestling with so many important issues, you're not going to make everybody happy," Mr. White said. "It wears on you, and I think it wore upon him."
While Mr. Librera is a Trenton outsider, David Samson -- a lawyer from Roseland whom Mr. McGreevey has selected as attorney general -- has worked for Republicans and Democrats alike. Having allies on both sides of the aisle could well benefit Mr. Samson, who takes over an office that has been enmeshed in the battle over racial profiling and an array of demands on law enforcement because of the Sept. 11 attacks.
A senior partner at Wolff & Samson, a firm with 85 lawyers working out of offices in Roseland and Hackensack, Mr. Samson has overseen the firm's managerial and budgetary responsibilities. In addition, he was appointed by former Gov. Thomas H. Kean as chairman of the Governor's Task Force on the Laws Governing the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, and by former Gov. Jim Florio to the Governor's Commission on Health Care Costs.
"The very fact that he's not a Democratic partisan tells you that he wasn't selected for that purpose, and I think that's a nice statement to make," Mr. Florio said in a telephone interview. "That should send out a message that you're interested in evenhanded law enforcement that hasn't got anything to do with any overtly partisan philosophy."
Indeed, Mr. Samson represented Chuck Haytaian, the Assembly speaker and chairman of the State Republican Party during former Gov. Christie Whitman's administration, in a sexual harassment case that was eventually settled. Later, he and employees of his firm donated more than $50,000 to Mr. McGreevey's 1997 and 2001 gubernatorial campaigns.
For his part, Daniel Waldman, president of the New Jersey State Bar Association, said Mr. McGreevey made a "brilliant" move in his selection of a lawyer who has been involved in civil, rather than criminal, litigation.
Because Mr. Samson is not known as a defender or prosecutor, it would he difficult to accuse him of choosing sides on racial profiling or the prosecution of potential terrorists, Mr. Waldman said.
"He comes with no baggage in that regard," he said.
But no baggage also means no clear reputation on the divisive issue of racial profiling, something that Frank Askin, a professor at Rutgers Law School, said could be a problem unless Mr. Samson takes immediate action.
"I would certainly feel more confident if the attorney general had a track record," Mr. Askin said. "There's no particular reason the minority community should have confidence that he's going to jump in and do the job."
However, those who know the 62-year-old Mr. Samson said he would bring strong managerial skills and extensive experience to the office. And Peter C. Harvey, a Morristown attorney whom Mr. McGreevey chose to be first assistant attorney general, will be the first black to hold the position.
To handle one of the new administration's most daunting challenges -- a budget shortfall projected at $2.4 billion -- Mr. McGreevey turned to Woodbridge's acting business administrator and chief financial officer, John E. McCormac, whom he credited with helping to bring the city out of a "fiscal abyss."
"Programs and services and funding will have to be cut, but I think we can do it," Mr. McCormac said in an interview last week, adding that in Woodbridge, he "dug in" and fixed the budget, one section at a time.
Filling out some of the other 18 cabinet positions, Mr. McGreevey designated Albert G. Kroll, a West Orange lawyer who has represented numerous labor organizations, to lead the state Department of Labor, and Ida L. Castro, who headed the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in the Clinton administration, to lead the Department of Personnel.
In addition, Dr. Clifton R. Lacy, senior vice president for medical affairs and chief of staff at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, was Mr. McGreevey's choice to lead the Department of Health and Senior Services, and Mayor Susan Bass Levin of Cherry Hill was designated to lead the Department of Community Affairs.
Mr. McGreevey chose Bradley M. Campbell, a regional administrator for the federal Environmental Protection Agency in the Clinton administration, to head the state's Environmental Protection Department, and Rev. Dr. William D. Watley, senior pastor of St. James African Methodist Episcopal Church in Newark, to head the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission.
Holly Bakke, who has worked in the insurance industry, was chosen to lead the Department of Banking and Insurance, and Col. Glenn K. Rieth, director of the State Army Aviation Office for the New Jersey Army National Guard, was designated to head the Department of Military and Veterans Affairs.
So far, said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University, Mr. McGreevey's team reflected an emphasis on diversity and expertise.
Mr. Rebovich said the extent to which Mr. McGreevey actively involved his commissioners in the policy-making process remained to be seen, though he emphasized that Mr. Samson and Ms. Levin were two people "who will not tolerate being in the background."

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
In Other Cities, the Grass Is Browner

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON; This column about the local economy will appear every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THERE are worse places to be right now, economically, than in New York City.
 That may seem unlikely. After all, in the past four months the city has lost 3,000 lives and perhaps as many as 100,000 jobs. According to the most recent government statistics, in the aftermath of Sept. 11 New York City suffered the biggest 12-month job loss of any metropolitan area in the country. 
 Those who live in and around the city have been bruised, battered and bereaved -- physically, emotionally and financially.
But there are plenty of cities across the country where economic life is at least as lousy. Small cities, like Yuma, Ariz., where the unemployment rate has been hovering around 20 percent -- except during the summer, when it shoots up to about 30 percent (in New York, the rate is under 7 percent).
Big cities, like Los Angeles, where the unemployment rate is not bad, but corporate hiring, as measured by help wanted ads, has plunged by more than 60 percent in the past year (making New York's 40 percent drop look less dire).
Extremely unfortunate cities, like Danville, Va., where the big products used to be textiles, tires and tobacco. In the 12 months ended in November, Danville's unemployment rate soared to 9 percent, and the number of jobs shrank by 4.8 percent. (If that had happened here, the job count would be down by almost 210,000 through November, rather than by the 82,500 reported by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.)
Of course, the existence of misery elsewhere is no consolation for the people here who are out of work.
And New Yorkers can only hope it won't be any justification for the federal government's failing to pony up all the money it has promised to this wounded city. The folks in Washington aren't exactly sharing the rest of the country's economic pain; our nation's capital has added more jobs in the past year than any other metropolitan area.
But trying to figure out where New York fits into the national recession may help provide some perspective, even (dare one say it?) a little optimism.
For one thing, the fact that so much of the region's economic pain stems directly from the terrorist attack suggests that some of the job losses may be temporary, says Jason Bram, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Even if they do come to goggle at ground zero, some tourists will also eat at Tavern on the Green and put waiters back to work. Some of those Wall Street firms that fled to Jersey City will find it more convenient to move some of their staff back to Manhattan. And, eventually, construction workers will build whatever it is that will coexist with a memorial at the trade center site, assuming the entire project does not turn into this decade's version of Westway.
Across the country, most of the really devastating job losses have been in industries involved in making things, like cars and computers and couches (this has not been a happy time to be living in Detroit or San Jose, Calif., or Hickory, N.C.). In New York State, this explains why the unemployment rate has risen more sharply in Binghamton and Elmira than downstate.
The only thing New York City makes much of is money. The bad news is that Wall Street continues to lay people off, as Merrill Lynch proved last week. The good news is that the stock market, a leading indicator, started rebounding in late September.
Things are likely to get worse here before they get better. But when the national economy does turn around, which many economists are hopeful will happen later this year, so will New York's.
How much and how fast is a matter of some debate. In the optimistic camp is Mr. Bram, who says, "I find it hard to believe we would do worse than the nation, even with this disaster." Less cheery is Ken Goldstein, an economist at the Conference Board, who says that New York City will not snap back as much as other places, because it will not lose as much as other places (which doesn't sound so bad).
A decade ago, New York's poor economic prospects helped prompt people to move to areas with sunnier outlooks. Today, employment hot spots are hard to find, except in a few places not exactly known for their bright lights (Fayetteville, Ark., say, or Fargo, N.D.). For ambitious young people, Mr. Goldstein said, "the Big Apple is still the big lure."
And as long as that is the case, there will be plenty of worse places to be, economically, than New York City.
