HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
The NewM.B.A. Vogue: A Job at a Blue Chip

BYLINE:  By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU 

 BODY:
HIS father worked as a manager at Bristol-Myers Squibb for 22 years, but Brandon Thomas, a student at the McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas at Austin, had no intention of following in his footsteps. The staid culture of a Fortune 500 company just wasn't for him.
 Not until the dot-com meltdown and the recession came along, that is. Suddenly, the prospect of a steady paycheck and a steady climb up the corporate ladder looks pretty good to Mr. Thomas, now 25, who plans to receive his degree next year. 
 "I'm working on getting an internship right now with larger, well-known companies in D.C. and New York," he said. "It will help me evaluate how well I can morph into the corporate culture."
Just a few years ago, many M.B.A.'s fresh out of school would rather sell dog bones than take a job with a stodgy corporation that made Buicks or macaroni and cheese. The allure of the dot-com world, with its freewheeling culture and promise of stock-option riches, made the traditional office seem banal.
But on business school campuses across the country, students who watched the technology bubble burst or who worked at start-ups that never really started are rediscovering the virtues of stability and a healthy balance sheet. "Before, it was sexy to take the risk for 1 percent in the company," said Jonathan McBride, co-founder of Jungle Interactive Media in New York, publisher of MBA Jungle, a magazine for M.B.A.'s and young business executives. "Now it's a status symbol to have a job."
At least 75 percent of M.B.A. students at the Kogod School of Business at American University in Washington are looking for jobs at larger, more stable companies, compared with fewer than 50 percent a year or two ago, said August Schomburg, director of graduate programs. He said many M.B.A.'s were focused on industries like pharmaceuticals, energy and consumer products.
Frank A. Beck, director of human resources for the marketing unit at R. J. Reynolds Tobacco in Winston-Salem, N.C., said: "It's night and day. Over the past three to five years, with all the interest in e-commerce, telecommunications and consulting, the pool of M.B.A.'s concentrating on marketing more traditional consumer packaged goods was drained. Now the pendulum has swung. We've probably been receiving two to three times more resumes since early fall."
For new M.B.A.'s, the most popular safe harbors just a year ago were consulting and banking, but jobs are now scarce in those areas. At high-tech start-ups, workplace specialists say, they are almost nonexistent.
"Those companies no longer come to campus or place jobs with career centers," said Andy Chan, director of the Career Management Center at the Stanford Graduate School of Business. "Students are saying, 'I need work.' "
Garrett Wilson, a student at the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota, had a recent fling with small business, but he now thinks bigger companies are better. Mr. Wilson, 31, held a summer internship last year at a medical-device maker that was seeking Food and Drug Administration approval for a potentially lucrative product. If the product had gone to market, he figured at the time, he would have had a good shot at a full-time job. "There would have been a huge upside to getting in on the ground floor of that," he said. But the F.D.A. rejected the application, and the company failed.
NOW Mr. Wilson is shopping for a position at a medium-size to large corporation, preferably in consumer products, that will give him a chance to move up through the ranks. "C.E.O? Maybe someday," he said, half-joking. "But I'd settle for head of marketing."
That kind of attitude means that names like General Motors and R. J. Reynolds are back in vogue among the estimated 100,000 students who graduate from the nation's business schools every year. It has also created a much larger, and potentially cheaper, pool of talent from which hiring managers can choose.
At General Motors, M.B.A.'s who left the company to join dot-coms or start their own companies are returning, according to Thomas Thivierge, director for talent acquisition at G.M.'s North America unit. "They say, 'Please, can I come back?' because they know we'll be here 100 years from now," he said.
Mr. Thivierge says a big benefit for him is the new glut of M.B.A. holders with experience as senior information technology executives at smaller companies. His annual recruiting turned up two or three such prizes in 1998, he said, but a choice of 10 candidates last year.
Because of the economic slowdown, Mr. Thivierge has cut back slightly on his hiring and on internships for M.B.A. students. But he said, "We are excited about getting the latest and greatest talent." 
Other companies are more aggressive about offering jobs to business school graduates, according to Mr. Chan, at Stanford. "Businesses have high expectations that these people will do something big in their companies," he said. Now companies are in the driver's seat. "They may pay less than they had to," he said, "or give them lower titles, but the M.B.A.'s are gaining security and getting into a company that may start their careers off on the right foot."
Stephen F. Johansson, associate dean for corporate relations at Vanderbilt University's Owen Graduate School of Management in Nashville, estimated that starting salaries were down as much as 10 percent this year from those of recent years, though recent graduates of the top business schools could still expect to earn $60,000 to $100,000 a year.
That creates a golden opportunity for big corporations to stack their middle-management ranks with M.B.A. holders, headhunters say.
"Companies are facing the realities of, Do they have the right people in the right jobs?" said Jeffrey Heath, president of the Landstone Group, a recruiting firm in New York. "They are re-evaluating everything they've done over the past five years, correcting what they did wrong in hiring."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA; 
Preservationists Fear a Rush to Judgment Downtown

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
New York has a problem: Much should not be forgotten, but much must be remade.
 In TriBeCa, this issue has gained urgency since Sept. 11, with Community Board 1, the Historic Districts Council and others seeking a new historic district in the southern part of the neighborhood. 
 The real estate boom of the late 90's brought a few boxy penthouses to that area. But most of its 19-century dry goods and textile warehouses, and a few stretches of sandstone buildings, are intact. 
"The idea is to save the rest," said Madelyn Wils, the chairwoman of the community board. 
The concern stems from some residents' fear that the push to revitalize downtown will wreck what the boom passed over. "Developers are seeing this as an opportunity to get development through quickly," said Roger Byrom, co-chairman of the landmarks committee of the community board.
Furthermore, small businesses in the area, which was blocked off for two months after Sept. 11, are struggling. Some fear a wave of closings could precipitate widespread development. "Vacant buildings could be delivered to developers," said Simeon Bankoff, executive director of the Historic Districts Council.
Sherida E. Paulsen, the chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, seemed to understand the worry. 
"The landmarks law doesn't take into account some of these other pressures sometimes," she said. "We are taking the time to really look at this right now because we do understand the community has real concern."
In 1991 and 1992, the commission designated four historic districts that encompass about half of TriBeCa. The southern area now under discussion had been included in the community's original landmark proposal, but lay outside the final district boundaries. However, at that time, the commission considered 17 buildings in the currently proposed district as possible individual landmarks. To date, it has voted on one.
Ms. Paulsen said her staff had identified an area, containing 12 of the 17 buildings, as a potential extension to the southernmost TriBeCa historic district. "The community proposed something that was much larger," she said, adding that the commission would decide next month if it scheduled a hearing on the matter.
But Ms. Wils, who is also on the Lower Manhattan Redevelopment Corporation, an agency to rebuild downtown, said some fear was misplaced. "We have millions of square feet of empty office space, so there is not any need to rush or forgo any process for rebuilding," she said. ERIKA KINETZ

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Why It Takes Psychology To Make People Save

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to saving for retirement, Americans are not rational. They know they do not put away enough, surveys show. But ask them to save more in their 401(k) plans and they balk. A buck in hand is irresistibly spent. Try a different approach. Ask them to commit now to increasing their savings in the future, make the increase coincide with the next raise, and they cheerfully sign up.
 Various quirks embedded in human nature come into play. Saving more in the future seems much less of a sacrifice. When the future arrives, opting out succumbs to inertia. And timing the increase to coincide with a raise, so that one cancels out the other, is much more palatable than a cut in take-home pay. In the human psyche, giving up a raise not yet in hand is easier for people to accept emotionally than a loss, even the illusion of a loss. After all, the money "lost" is still there, in one's savings account. 
 Standard economics allows for none of these quirks. Over a lifetime, people rationally save an optimal amount, mainstream economics holds. Confronted with the reality that people do not save enough, the mainstream has no solution, except to reiterate that people are rational, so whatever they save must be enough. No wonder behavioral economics is making such a splash, becoming the "in" specialty of young economists from the best graduate schools.
"You have to force savings and take the money away before people have it and can't resist spending it," said Richard H. Thaler, a University of Chicago economist.
Mr. Thaler is a pioneer in the development of behavioral economics over the last 25 years, and now he is a leader in finally applying the insights to daily life. So far the application focuses on persuading people to save more in 401(k) plans. But there are other potential uses. Fiscal policy is one. Allowing for human quirks, what is the most effective way to spend public money to promote jobs and economic growth? "If we invested six months in designing a stimulus package using insights from behavioral economics, there is good reason to think it might work," Mr. Thaler said.
That is still off in the future. Medicine offers an immediate application. Some dentists, for example, are beginning to ask behavioral economists how to get patients to return every six months for teeth cleaning. Reminder postcards don't often work. People put them in a drawer and procrastinate -- another human quirk that messes up mainstream theory, with its faith in rationally taking good care of teeth. Most people delay, unless the dentist extracts a commitment, by persuading a patient, when he or she comes in for a cleaning, to make an appointment on the spot for the next cleaning, six months hence.
"The postcard system only facilitates procrastination," said David I. Laibson, a behavioral economist at Harvard, who gets calls from dentists.
THE most promising application so far is retirement savings. At a time when workers must save for their own retirement, they are in danger of inadequate income in old age unless they contribute 10 percent of their pay to 401(k) plans, pension experts say. And that does not count losses in 401(k) money invested in high-technology stocks or in the Enron Corporation.
Such hearty contributions are certainly in the interest of the Vanguard Group, which administers 401(k) plans for companies like Philips Electronics North America, a unit of Royal Philips Electronics. Philips also has a stake: under federal law, top executives cannot have retirement savings too out of line with those of ordinary employees.
So Vanguard and Philips turned to Mr. Thaler and to Shlomo Benartzi, at the University of California at Los Angeles. Executives had read a paper they wrote, entitled "Save More Tomorrow," reporting on the results at a Midwestern company where 162 employees, more than half the staff, had agreed in advance to annual increases in their 401(k) contributions, each increase coinciding with a raise. Over three years, the contributions rose to 11.6 percent of income from 3.5 percent.
Most of the 16,000 Philips employees enrolled in 401(k) plans save 6 percent or less. So Philips is experimenting. With Vanguard administering the test and Mr. Thaler and Mr. Benartzi giving advice, the company will ask 2,000 workers next month to commit to annual increases in 401(k) contributions of one, two or three percentage points. The first increase would be in April, when Philips gives annual raises, although this year, in a recession, a raise is not a sure thing, says Lisa Pyne, Philips's benefits director.
Still, she is counting on inertia to keep people from opting out -- even the 3 percenters who, absent a raise, might notice the slight decline in take-home pay. "Behavioral economics seems to work," Ms. Pyne said.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
In Recession Talk, Economists Shift to the Past Tense

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
JUST before the new year, James E. Glassman and his associates at J. P. Morgan made a big change in their economic outlook, updating their growth forecast for the first quarter to zero from a decline, at an annual rate, of 2 percent.
 A zero may not seem like much. But for economists, it means that the recession is not going to end in the spring, as they had predicted. It's over now. 
 Other forecasters have joined in. At Goldman, Sachs, the first-quarter forecast has shifted even more radically, from minus 1 percent to plus 2 percent. At Morgan Stanley, the shift was more modest, to plus 0.1 percent from minus 0.6 percent. But the effect would be the same: the recession would end this quarter.
"When I see people changing their minds so quickly, it makes me think they were not prepared for the economy to be so resilient," said Mr. Glassman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan, including himself in his criticism. "Economists need to be humble. We have always misjudged the turn."
The sudden speed-up means that Federal Reserve officials, meeting at the end of this month, may decide that there is no need to cut their benchmark short-term interest rate by another quarter-point, to 1.5 percent. Many analysts are still betting on another rate cut, but more positive news in the next few weeks could change that view.
The shift in outlook also suggests that the sharp jump in long-term interest rates at the end of 2001 -- in anticipation of a nice recovery soon -- was more reasonable than many analysts thought at the time. The same may be true for the surge in the stock market, which, like the bond market, is supposed to be forward-looking.
Mr. Glassman also says the early end to the recession may mean that the subsequent recovery will be stronger than the mild rebound that many economists have forecast. "The fact that the bottom is coming early makes me feel better about the outlook," he said. So it is possible that long-term interest rates, already at relatively high levels, could move even higher.
The new forecasts are a result of the persistent strength in consumer spending even as businesses reduced their orders sharply. "Right now, the level of production is significantly below final demand," said Jan Hatzius, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs.
A result is that product inventories fell sharply in the fourth quarter, a decline now estimated at $100 billion to $120 billion at an annual rate. (Fourth-quarter data on the gross domestic product will not be released until Jan. 30.)
Because of that steep drop, economists expect the inventory drain to slow greatly in the current quarter, maybe to around $40 billion. But in the calculation of G.D.P. numbers, this slowdown in the rate of decline becomes a positive.
Also contributing to the changing outlook is new strength in manufacturing. The manufacturing index of the Institute of Supply Management rose to 48.2 in December -- still in recession territory but close to breaking through 50 into recovery. In addition, the index for new orders, considered a good predictor of future manufacturing activity, shot up to 54.9, its highest point in 20 months.
An increase of 2.3 percent in chain-store sales in December showed that many retailers had a better Christmas than expected.
"There is something you can hang your hat on if you want to claim that the economy is at an inflection point," said Louis Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson Associates, referring to an end of the recession.
So what are Federal Reserve officials thinking, after all this new data? Several regional bank presidents said last week that the recovery would come later in the year. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, agreed with these comments in a speech on Friday. He warned that "despite a number of encouraging signs of stabilization, it is still premature to conclude that the forces restraining economic activity here and abroad have abated enough to allow a steady recovery to take hold."
Private economists must react quickly to new data. (Ahead of his colleagues, Ian Shepherdson of High Frequency Economics predicted in October that there would be recovery signs before the end of the year.)
Fed officials must be more cautious. Still, one wonders if they are just trying too hard to talk down stubbornly high long-term interest rates while locking themselves into one more rate cut on Jan. 30. If they continue with this cautious view, a decision not to cut rates will be a big surprise.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/W. George Greig; 
William Blair International Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
WITH all the world outside the United States to choose from, W. George Greig, who runs the $425 million William Blair International Growth fund, says he is emphasizing more investments in the emerging markets of Asia.
 The youthful population of many countries there and "the important transformation of Asian economies from producer-driven to consumer-driven" make the region attractive, said Mr. Greig, who works in Chicago. He said stock markets in China and other countries that export heavily to the United States had begun to respond positively to the Federal Reserve's monetary stimulus. 
 The fund returned 14 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with a loss of 3 percent for its peer group of foreign stock funds, according to Morningstar Inc. In the last 12 months, it lost 11.9 percent, versus a loss of 20.7 percent for its group. 
Mr. Greig, 49, looks for what he calls "the best-managed companies with the best growth prospects and the strongest balance sheets." While most of the fund's money is invested in Europe, he has put almost one-third of it into Asia and Australia. He has made a relatively big bet on Asian emerging markets, at 12 percent of assets, versus 5 percent for his benchmark, which is technically called the Morgan Stanley Capital International All Country World Index Free Ex-U.S.A.. (Translated, that means an index of all world markets outside the United States that are easily accessible to outside investors.)
The portfolio, which contains 120 or so stocks, is broadly diversified among industries and market capitalizations. He typically holds a 15 percent stake in emerging markets worldwide; that has crept up to 18 percent, just below his policy limit of 20 percent. "When leading economic indicators turn up," he said, "the emerging markets, and Asia in particular, tend to do well."
He screens companies periodically, seeking above-average three-year earnings and revenue growth. Earnings growth of the portfolio averages 18 percent a year, roughly double the benchmark's rate.
His valuation analysis uses multiple variables, including multiples of price to earnings, price to book and price to cash flow. That "helps us to overcome gaps and inconsistencies across different industries, different countries and different accounting systems," he said. If interest rates are low in a particular country, like Japan, P/E ratios may be very high, he said, so he may put more emphasis on other multiples.
He also compares a company's current P/E ratio with its historical multiples and those of its rivals.
In Asia, Mr. Greig likes Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, a big maker of chips for American companies and for local markets. He originally bought shares in March at a split-adjusted price of 56.85 Taiwan dollars, then worth $1.69. They now trade at 87.50 Taiwan dollars, or $2.50. "To be successful, a foundry must be very efficient and very versatile," Mr. Greig said. "This company can shift quickly among products and has money to invest in advanced technology." 
He said analysts expect the company's earnings growth to be 28.3 percent a year, on average, for the next three years.
Mr. Grieg has added to his investment in Ryanair Holdings, which runs the discount Irish airline. He originally bought American depository receipts of Ryanair in March 1999 at $18.76, adjusted for splits; the A.D.R.'s now trade at $30.25.
"Ryanair operates extremely efficiently at a very low cost," Mr. Greig said, and has much opportunity to grow because discount air travel is not as entrenched in Europe as in the United States. He said analysts expect earnings to grow 14 percent a year for the next three years.
He also likes BHP Billiton, the mining conglomerate based in Melbourne, Australia. "What makes this company interesting is that it's a great growth company in a low-growth business," Mr. Greig said. Management is equally skilled at exploration, prospecting, mining, controlling costs and arranging acquisitions and joint ventures, he said. 
Earnings are expected to grow 20 percent a year, on average, over three years. He originally bought shares in September 2000 on the London market at a split-adjusted price of $:3.14, then worth $4.48; they now trade at $:3.75, or $5.42.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Taking After Father; 
A Frozen Sperm Riddle

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
IN the ethical quagmire of assisted reproduction, many of the toughest questions eventually land in court: Who has the right to frozen embryos, frozen eggs, frozen sperm? Whose name should appear on the birth certificate, the genetic mother, who provided the egg, or the carrier, in whose womb the baby grew?
 And now comes this one: What are the inheritance rights of children conceived posthumously, with frozen sperm, years after their father's death? 
 "It's another in the long string of examples of the law struggling to come to terms with new reproductive technologies that raise questions that traditionally did not have to be faced," said Sally Goldfarb, who teaches family law at Rutgers Law School in Camden, N.J. "It used to be that a child born more than a year after a man's death was conclusively presumed not to be his child. We can't say that anymore. There's a vacuum in terms of legislation on the issue, so the courts deal with it, case by case." 
The highest court in Massachusetts ruled this month that twin girls born two years after their father's 1993 death from leukemia should have normal inheritance rights, if both the man's consent to the conception and his genetic relationship with the children could be proven.
"Posthumously conceived children may not come into the world the way the majority of children do," said Chief Justice Margaret H. Marshall of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court. "But they are children nonetheless. We may assume that the Legislature intended that such children be 'entitled,' insofar as possible 'to the same rights and protections of the law' as children conceived before death."
Her decision acknowledges that granting inheritance rights to posthumously conceived babies may complicate life for earlier-born heirs. "In an era in which serial marriages, serial families, and blended families are not uncommon, according succession rights under our intestacy laws to posthumously conceived children may, in a given case, have the potential to pit child against child and family against family," she said, since the later child's share of the inheritance would reduce the amount available to any older children.
And in the expanding universe of assisted reproduction, she said, there are many possible parent-figures whose benefits or estates may be claimed: egg donors, sperm donors, gestational carriers, and others with no biological connection who arranged the conception and intended to raise the child.
As a practical matter, there is the vexing question of how long an estate might have to be held open for an afterborn heir -- or whether heirs who already received bequests might have to give back part of their inheritance.
The Massachusetts case, and a similar one still pending in New Jersey, are relatively simple ones, each involving twin girls conceived posthumously with frozen sperm from a young husband who died of leukemia, without a substantial estate or other children. And in both cases, the twins' mothers sought benefits for the children paid for by taxpayers, in the form of Social Security, not a portion of a contested estate. 
In Massachusetts, the Social Security Administration told Lauren Woodward, who had applied for benefits for her twins, Mackenzie and Michayla, that the girls could not be treated as Warren Woodward's heirs, because they were conceived after his death. Years ago, a family court judge deemed Mr. Woodward the girls' legal father, and ordered their birth certificates amended to include his name. But the federal government would not pay benefits, so Ms. Woodward sued in federal court -- and because Social Security benefits are paid according to state inheritance laws, a federal judge asked the state's Supreme Judicial Court to rule on the issue.
The New Jersey case is following a similar path. Like Ms. Woodward, Mariantonia Kolacy was denied Social Security benefits for her twins, Amanda and Elyse, born in 1996, nearly two years after their father's death. Last year, a state judge ruled that the girls should be deemed legitimate heirs. But the Social Security Administration still refused benefits because the ruling was not from New Jersey's highest court. In July, the Kolacys' lawyer, Robert Kerekes, took the case to federal court.
ULTIMATELY, legal experts said, state legislatures may provide guidance on the rights of posthumously conceived children. So far, only Louisiana has passed legislation allowing posthumously conceived children to inherit -- but only if the dead spouse authorized, in writing, such use of the frozen gametes, and only if the child was born within two years to the surviving spouse. The law grew out of a long campaign by Nancy Hart, who was refused Social Security benefits for her posthumously conceived daughter, but won an out-of-court settlement in 1996.
According to Mr. Kerekes, there are a handful of other posthumously conceived children, scattered through the United States, receiving Social Security benefits. But the Woodward case is the first in which a state's highest court faced the issue.
"The Massachusetts court almost pleads for legislation in the field, saying the issues 'cry out for lengthy, careful examination outside the adversary process,' " said Carol Sanger, who teaches family law at Columbia University's law school. "Still, because this was one of the easier situations, the court could afford to be philosophical, saying without having to decide that there very well could be time limits set, but that, on the other hand, psychologically, time limits might push a woman still grieving her husband's death into bearing a child before she was ready. And, as the court said, conceiving a baby with frozen sperm can take many tries over many months." 
Professor Sanger noted, moreover, that the Massachusetts ruling addressed a relatively narrow question. "The Massachusetts case was explicitly about married men and women, and even in that case, the court wanted proof that the child came into being with the sperm donor's consent, and said that the fact that he'd frozen his sperm wasn't enough to show consent," she said. "You can imagine some guy passing out 15 vials of frozen sperm to 15 different women, each with a little note saying, 'Go for it.' And that's really not what Social Security was intended for."

HEADLINE: A Haven For Women Is No Longer Quite Home 

BYLINE:  By NANCY HASS 

 BODY:
FOR decades, the halls of Linda Brady's co-op on East 18th Street were redolent with a comforting mix of old-fashioned smells: L'Air du Temps perfume, takeout Chinese food, fabric softener.
 That was because her 1960's-era building, like scores of other white glazed-brick high-rises that are ubiquitous on the East Side of Manhattan, had a large number of occupants who were women like herself -- single, well employed and now over 50. Such buildings, mostly made up of studios and one-bedroom apartments, had a reputation for dowdiness and were considered architectural eyesores by purists, but Ms. Brady loved hers, and the women who were her neighbors. 
 "We all knew each other," she said. "A lot of the people had been here since the 1960's and 70's. Back then we threw parties, we shared houses together in the Hamptons." As her friends in the building grew older, she said, they would all look in on each other. "It had a family feel to it." 
But then one day the scents that Ms. Brady, 51, a corporate architect, once associated with home seemed to evaporate. The halls now smell of aromatherapy candles, Dolce & Gabbana perfume and occasionally marijuana. The recyling room, where old Redbook magazines and Loehmann's boxes were once stacked, holds empty imported-lager bottles, Prada shopping bags and discarded brokerage statements from Chase.
And Ms. Brady's building is bustling not with her friends, many of whom had modest incomes as public-school teachers, secretaries and department store buyers, but instead with bond traders and public relations executives, nearly all under 35.
"They work until late at night; then they go to the gym; then they go out," said Carol Chesler, 60, a freelance copy editor who is among the dwindling number of longtime tenants."They seem to have a plan. We never had a plan. We just went along and saw what would happen."
The transformation of Ms. Brady's and Ms. Chesler's co-op is being repeated in similar white-brick buildings all over town. Because of an unusual combination of sociological trends and the history of Manhattan real estate development, the buildings -- largely built in the 1960's -- became havens for many middle-class single women. But since the mid-90's, these longtime residents have been vacating their apartments, retiring and moving to sunnier climes. The buildings, once shunned as "white whales," have grown fashionable with young professionals who are moving in and changing what was once a Manhattan version of "The Golden Girls" into a Wallpaper magazine layout -- people like Terence Riley, chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, and Marcy Swingle, an editor at Daily Candy, a Web site aimed at young fashion-conscious shoppers.
"You can make a 60's apartment really kitschy and modern," said Ms. Swingle, who is in her early 30's and bought her 60's Village apartment a couple of years ago from an elderly occupant.
In an informal survey, doormen and superintendents at 20 white-brick co-ops around Manhattan all echoed the observations of Spiros Pappas, the super at the Mayfair, 207 East 74th Street: "This place used to be filled with them -- these ladies who are here living alone forever. Now there are not very many left. My favorite one has the walls padded to keep out the noise. In the past couple of years, there's been a complete change. It's young people with good jobs, great clothes." The metamorphosis of an entire class of buildings is, like many tales of the city, a matter of being in the right place at the right time. White-brick buildings, nearly all of which are east of Lexington Avenue, with others scattered throughout the Upper West Side and Greenwich Village, were built as rentals primarily between 1960 and 1968, following a decade when, as a result of the postwar obsession with the suburbs, there was little residential construction in Manhattan. The specially glazed brick, which architects hoped would reflect light to the street in an increasingly crowded, dark metropolis, was first used in 1950 by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill at Manhattan House, on East 65th Street between Second and Third Avenues. But the white-brick boom didn't really begin until the late 50's, and it lasted only a decade.
Unlike the sumptuous prewar residential buildings lining Park and Fifth Avenues, white-brick buildings were pared down in scale and detail -- mainly because that made them cheaper to build. Most apartments were small, designed to attract the single people developers expected to opt for city life in an increasingly suburbanized society. Unlike tenements, the only other type of building widely available to people who weren't rich, 60's-era apartment houses had elevators and doormen. At a time when single women were starting careers in unprecedented numbers, the buildings offered a haven. They were safe, clean and affordable. (Ms. Chesler's rent in the mid-70's, when she moved into her ground-floor studio, which has a small patio, was only about $300, and she bought it for $25,000 in 1983.)
"This was the era of 'The Best of Everything' -- all those melodramas about young girls coming to New York to have a career and then to wrench their guts out about whether to get married instead," said Ann Douglas, a historian who writes frequently about New York City.
The buildings were meant to be transitional. "The way it was supposed to work was that single people would live in these small apartments in these buildings until they got married," said Emanuel Tobier, an emeritus professor of economics and planning at New York University. "Then they would move to the suburbs, and new ones would take their place,"
But it was mostly the men who seemed to move on. About the same number of men and women moved into the buildings in the first decade or so, according to managing agencies, residents and superintendents. But by the early 90's, many more longtime residents were single women than single men, according to data from the annual New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey analyzed for The New York Times by Andrew Beveridge and Susan Weber, demographers at Queens College. The figures show that of the people who moved into buildings built between 1960 and 1969, nearly 40 percent were women living alone in 1991. Less than 2 percent were men living alone. The rest were a mix of couples, and men and women with roommates. (A great majority of apartment houses built in the 1960's were the white-brick variety.)
Why did more men than women leave? For the same reason, apparently, that has often drawn complaints from single women in the city: the greater proportion of straight women than straight men in the local population. "By the 1960's New York had become the nation's most competitive marriage market," Mr. Tobier said. "Most of the men got married and moved away. But many of the women never did."
Longtime residents and building managers said that white-brick buildings were also a magnet for women, some of them divorced, who were seeking an independent life. "I had plenty of chances to be married back in the 60's," said Emily Weiss, a retired teacher who is in her early 60's and has lived in a one-bedroom apartment painted robin's-egg blue in a white-brick building in the East 70's since she was 27. "But I never found anyone who was interesting or creative enough. They just wanted me to move to Scarsdale or Riverdale or somewhere and be a house mouse. I never found a good enough reason to leave this nice place."
Thousands of women like Ms. Weiss were in the right place at the right time. Their rents were protected under rent-stabilization laws, and in the 1980's, when most of the buildings went co-op, the residents either stayed on as renters or bought their apartments at insider prices. As real estate prices soared in the 80's and 90's, they were sitting pretty. As one of the few remaining groups of middle-class Manhattanites, they helped support a wide variety of low-key local businesses, especially along First, Second and Third Avenues. "By accident, this whole generation of women hit upon a time when it was possible to live a decent life alone in Manhattan," Mr. Tobier said.
But that is changing. In recent years, many of the women have reached their 60's or 70's, and with the market for small apartments retreating from its highs of the late 90's, they are selling. Some are moving to be closer to their families. Others have died. "Within about a year and a half everyone I know, all my friends, have either died or moved away -- poof!" said Ms. Brady, the retired architect on East 18th Street.
In their place has come a generation of buyers who covet the 60's buildings for entirely different reasons. Because it has been years since prewar buildings with doormen were within reach of most young people, balustrades and crown moldings no longer cast so long a shadow. Even lofts are too expensive for just about anyone.
When Jennifer Star, 32, an executive recruiter, was shopping last year for an apartment on the Upper East Side, she never considered a prewar building. She eventually found a 1,000-square-foot one-bedroom place with an alcove in a white-brick building for $350,000; the seller was a rabbi who had inherited the place from an older unmarried woman in his congregation who had lived there since the 60's. "Who thinks of a prewar anymore?" Ms. Star said. "You adjust your tastes completely. This apartment was totally a mess when I first saw it. I wound up gutting it completely. But the minute I walked through the door that first day, I thought, this is fabulous."
Arguably, the duckling-to-swan transformation of the white-brick buildings has as much to do with aesthetics as price. In the past few years, midcentury furniture and design have had a renaissance. This has given a sheen to the angular 60's buildings, most of which have eight-foot ceilings, boxy rooms and little detail. "More and more people are accepting the world in a horizontal vernacular," said Jeffrey Bilhuber, who has decorated homes for clients like Anna Wintour and David Bowie in prewar buildings, but has many friends who have moved into white-brick co-ops. "Modern furniture profiles much lower to the floor, which looks fantastic in a 60's-era space."
That attraction was felt by Mr. Riley, of the Museum of Modern Art. He said there was "no question" that he wanted a minimalist 60's building when he went apartment shopping. "I can't tell you how long I looked for an eight-foot ceiling," said Mr. Riley, who lives on West 12th Street in an apartment that is a paean to Modernist furniture. "There were all those 80's buildings where they shaved feet off the floor plan and then jacked the ceiling up. And all the yuppies who had lived there before had put ceiling fans in every room. It felt like you were in a Cuisinart."
Ms. Brady and Ms. Chesler are glad to see that the buildings they have always loved are now being appreciated by others. But they fret that their way of life is rapidly receding. "You don't want to feel like it's in with the fabulous new kids and out with women like us," Ms. Chesler said. "We're an important part of the life here. Maybe we aren't as driven as the new crop, but we brought a down-to-earth quality to the place. You want to think that that's worth something."

HEADLINE: Rebuilding New York; 
The Possibilities of Lincoln Center

 BODY:
The combined effects of the terrorist attacks and the recession have left many Manhattan institutions reeling -- including Lincoln Center, the city's premier performing arts complex. Sept. 11 caught its resident companies in the midst of protracted wrangling over an ambitious 10-year, $1.2 billion redevelopment plan that will depend, in part, on an infusion of city money. Not long after his inauguration, Mayor Michael Bloomberg made it clear that a harsh new fiscal reality might mean, at the very least, postponing that plan. Now Lincoln Center must adjust to this new reality while finding a way to perform seriously needed repairs. It must also find leadership with the ability and vision to continue planning for the future.
 At the moment, Lincoln Center lacks a president. Its chairwoman, Beverly Sills, who has done her very best to keep the peace at Lincoln Center, is 72 and has said she would like to retire when a new president is hired, something she planned to do several years ago. This might look like the brink of crisis, but it may well be an enormous opportunity instead, a chance to embrace a generational transition in leadership and bring new dynamism and openness to the center itself. 
 The building of Lincoln Center transformed the Upper West Side, but as the neighborhood has grown up around it, Lincoln Center has come to seem less and less like the vital heart of a community and more and more like a moated bastion of the status quo. Its patrons still enjoy some of the greatest music, dance and theater on the planet, but those audiences are increasingly homogeneous. The shared spaces of the center, including Damrosch Park, often have a barren stillness that reflects the sometimes chilly relations among the resident companies.
Lincoln Center may be the largest performing arts center in the world, but other arts centers around the world have done a far better job of being destinations in themselves, of belonging to the public at large and to the next-door neighbors as well.
As economic conditions and the fund-raising climate begin to improve, it will take forceful new leadership to overcome the entrenched personality conflicts at Lincoln Center and, eventually, to move redevelopment forward on a scale suited to the center's magnitude. Lincoln Center's plans for renovation should be as ambitious as the plan for building it in the first place. But the time, and the cast, will have to be right for doing so.
The real question facing Lincoln Center is whether it can find a strong and permanent new leadership to recreate the sense of a common good, which has fractured under the strain of the last few years. There is a risk of making weak appointments simply to preserve the status quo, the balance of psychological power among the quarreling artistic companies. That is exactly what Lincoln Center cannot afford to preserve.
The generational shift at Lincoln Center is imminent, and nowhere more so than at the New York Philharmonic. Even as critics embrace the possibilities of Lorin Maazel's first season as conductor -- a season containing an abundance of contemporary and newly commissioned music -- they are looking over the horizon of 2006, when his contract expires. By hiring Mr. Maazel to replace Kurt Masur, the Philharmonic brought in 71-year-old new blood. No one doubts Mr. Maazel's vigor or his desire to enliven the Philharmonic's schedule, but the clamor for a younger conductor -- a young American conductor -- will only grow as time passes.
Of all the problems facing Lincoln Center, the knottiest has been what to do with the New York City Opera. It needs a theater of its own, but, for separate reasons, neither the New York City Ballet nor the Metropolitan Opera wants it to have one, at least not on the Lincoln Center campus. The question for City Opera was always where to go if it left the West Side. In the wave of redevelopment that will begin downtown around the World Trade Center site, the opera management might look at the possibility of building a theater there.
Nothing would be better suited to the larger purposes of restoring Lower Manhattan or to City Opera itself. What a gift it would be to bring music to the neighborhood of that site, to make it a place for rejoicing as well as mourning.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Argentina's Crisis: It's Not Just Money

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES 

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT Argentina's long, slow-motion slide into bankruptcy, default and devaluation, Wall Street and Washington worried mainly about what came to be called "contagion," the fear that the economic crisis here would infect neighboring countries. Now that the collapse has occurred, the larger, more immediate danger may prove to be the spread of an old and eternally appealing political idea: resentment-based populism.
 Four South American countries will be having presidential elections over the next 10 months: Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Brazil. In each, the disintegration of the Argentine economy after a decade-long experiment with free-market policies provides ammunition for candidates who reject the notion, propagated by the United States, that there is an unbreakable link between democracy and the North American model of an open economy, a combination Latin Americans call neoliberal. 
 "The idea that the neoliberal model of the Washington consensus is dead is something heard not just in Argentina, but being repeated throughout Latin America," said Felipe Noguera, a political consultant and analyst here. "There are a lot of people out there right now who are looking for an alternative and have concluded that Argentina offers one."
The new president who took office here on Jan. 1, Eduardo Duhalde, is the product of an electoral machine founded by Argentina's original 20th-century populist, Juan Peron. For more than 50 years it has had a top-down view of politics, preferring to organize society into "sectors" like labor unions and employer associations, rather than appeal to voters primarily as individuals. In return for their loyalty, Argentine companies and workers were allowed to flourish behind protective tariff walls, at least until a decade ago.
Combined with Hugo Chavez, the former paratrooper and perpetual critic of "savage neoliberalism" who has served as president of Venezuela since 1999, that gives advocates of populism beachheads at both ends of the continent. And in Brazil, where anxious voters have been monitoring both the Venezuelan and the Argentine experiments, Luiz Inacio "Lula" da Silva of the Workers' Party, an admirer of Mr. Chavez and an opponent of free market policies, continues to lead the polls as he makes his fourth run at the presidency.
Until recently, the traditional solution to a crisis like Argentina's would have been a military coup. But the armed forces are discredited nearly everywhere in Latin America, and in the few places where they are not, like Venezuela, officers are extremely reluctant either to tarnish their image by intervening in politics, or to take over a mess they can't clean up.
"Populism implies that you have money to spend, and these days the money just isn't there," said Michael Shifter, a senior fellow at Inter-American Dialogue, a policy analysis group in Washington. "What you're seeing in country after country is that they've simply run out of options."
Indeed, South America's most worrisome problem may be that nothing seems to work anymore. In Venezuela, even Mr. Chavez is not immune. These days, his popularity is falling even faster than the price of oil. The result is a radicalization of his "Bolivarian Revolution," with incitations to class warfare and the rare spectacle of a successful national strike called jointly by labor unions and employer groups to protest what they see as the president's growing authoritarian tendencies.
General Peron, an archetypal Latin American caudillo, or strongman, has always been one of Mr. Chavez's idols. The Venezuelan leader has also been counseled by Norberto Ceresole, a neo-Peronist Argentine sociologist who preaches a "postdemocratic" ideology based on the idea that a charismatic leader can forge a mystical bond with the masses, thereby eliminating the need for political parties. Critics of the ideology like to point out that Europe's early fascists had a similar skepticism about classic democracy; Mr. Peron, in fact, modeled his government after Mussolini's.
In the column that he writes for leading Latin American newspapers, the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa noted last week that "the sound and the fury of a popular mobilization against the political class" here in Argentina last month was very much like "that which preceded the meteoric political career of Comandante Hugo Chavez in Venezuela and began the erosion of its democratic system."
With traditional political leaders and parties increasingly discredited, a space has opened for leaders who present themselves as outsiders and emphasize their distance from the system. In Mr. Vargas Llosa's own country, that kind of voter rage and disgust has already produced both Alberto Fujimori and, after a traumatic decade of authoritarianism, the current president, Alejandro Toledo, without an accompanying reinvigoration of the political system.
IN urging countries around the world to embrace free markets and free trade alongside free elections, the United States has held out the hope that rapid economic progress, benefiting all segments of society, will follow. But with their economies wobbly or worse, critics in Latin America are increasingly skeptical, and their attention is now focusing on the political side of the formula as well as the economic one.
"When you pursue the economic logic, you tend to shortchange the political logic," said Eduardo Gamarra, director of the Latin American and Caribbean Center at Florida International University in Miami. The United States, he said, "urged policies that dismantled traditional ties, between labor and the Peronists, for example, but didn't construct anything in its place. Now the problem is how to construct those when there is an absolute rejection of political parties and the political system."
After having largely ignored Latin America since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the White House seems to be awakening to the danger of instability in its own hemisphere and moving to demonstrate American interest. President Bush is expected to visit the country he knows best, Mexico, in March, and a trip to South America is being contemplated for later in the year.
But that late recognition is a far cry from Mr. Bush's initial promise of a foreign policy focused on spreading prosperity and democracy throughout the hemisphere. And it does not offer a solution to the threat implicit in a piece of graffiti sprayed on a sidewalk across from the Casa Rosada, the presidential palace that has been the focus of violent antigovernment protests here: "We are going to keep on coming. Signed, the People."

GRAPHIC: Photo: During a 24-hour general strike last month, only a cat could be seen at a main Buenos Aires train station. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Can Crying Race Be Crying Wolf?

BYLINE:  By By KATE ZERNIKE 

 BODY:
"PEOPLE in academe bruise real easily, and African-Americans at white institutions even more so," Gerald L. Early, a professor of English and African-American studies at Washington University in St. Louis, said recently.
 It is a pity Harvard President Lawrence H. Summers had not been briefed by Mr. Early before he met with Prof. Cornel West in October for their now-famous private chat. 
 Among other things, Mr. Summers suggested that Mr. West put some of the social philosophy expressed in his recent rap CD into something scholarly, and he emphasized his concern that professors were inflating grades. 
It was meant to be a routine meeting between boss and employee, one of dozens Mr. Summers has had since arriving on campus six months ago. But Mr. West saw it otherwise. He very publicly claimed personal disrespect and humiliation, and threatened to bolt to Princeton. And the constellation of stars who are his colleagues in Harvard's Afro-American Studies department rose as one to join him in outrage.
It wasn't just that meeting, several prominent department figures let it be known; Mr. Summers had snubbed them by failing to call on the department and pay his respects when he arrived on campus. They demanded an apology, a public statement of support for the department and affirmative action, and claimed that the gains achieved by members of minority groups in higher education were threatened by a resurgence of the old boy network -- old white boys, that is. 
The Rev. Jesse Jackson raced to Cambridge to stage a press conference, and he demanded to meet with Mr. Summers. The Rev. Al Sharpton threatened to sue and demanded an apology of his own. Even after a special summit meeting called to mend fences, Mr. West continued to vent his hurt feelings in public, calling in reporters last week to insist that he just might leave, anyway. Meanwhile, conservative editorialists mocked what the writer Stuart Taylor, in Slate magazine, called a "feast of victimology."
Surely the chemistry department could not have triggered such an explosion. But then, this was not just an academic dispute. Setting aside the question of Mr. West's scholarship, the debate at Harvard sparked such a stunning display of inflamed sensibilities because it raised many of the deeper, enduring questions about race and the role it plays in black achievement. 
"The question of academe is a smaller subset of the larger question of what does it mean to be a successful black person," said Mr. Early. "How do you get your success, how much does what you're doing empower the black community, and for African-Americans at white institutions, is it important for me to serve the role of showing that you aren't racist?"
Blacks on the more conservative end of the political spectrum are less sympathetic. They blame the Harvard professors for using race to get their way. 
"People with the talent that these people have have so much more to offer the United States than shooting a gun at Larry Summers' feet and making him do the 'I'm not a racist' dance," said John McWhorter, a professor of linguistics at Berkeley and author of "Losing the Race: Self-Sabotage in Black America." "It suggests that too much of modern progressive black thought is dedicated to crying victim rather than to trying to move ahead. These people are doing just fine, but as soon as there's any kind of crisis, the natural conditioned reflex is to pretend to be under siege."
Oddly, Henry Louis Gates, Jr., the head of Harvard's African-American studies department and among those who threatened to leave for Princeton, was previously involved in a very similar fracas. 
Two years ago, he was honored by his alma mater, Yale University, where he had been denied tenure. During dinner, the university's president confessed his professional "jealousy" of Mr. Gates' department at Harvard. The head of Yale's African-American studies program resigned, saying that the comment signaled disrespect. She, too, threatened to move to another university, and the Yale president, like Mr. Summers, apologized for having "unintentionally caused great consternation."
The program chairwoman then consented to stay, and a week later, her program was elevated to department status.
Of course, if some African-American studies departments are politically sensitive, it may be because they started out that way. Back in the 1960's black students at a number of colleges and universities, including Harvard, staged sit-ins to demand that their culture and history be given separate recognition within the curriculum. They won, but because they had done so through political activism, the departments themselves came to be seen as having a political purpose -- to "do your scholarship and trouble the waters," as one scholar said.
The universities, in turn, used black studies departments as instruments of integration, which troubles some black scholars.
"There's always the question, Is my worth being appreciated or am I being used to integrate this school?" said Mr. Early, at Washington University. "It's not the worst reason for being at Harvard or any other school. But you start thinking, that's not why English is here, that's not why philosophy is here, that's not why economics is here. Am I here because these people think African-American studies is an important part of their mission, or am I here as a problem eliminator?"
THIS is precisely the sort of insecurity that plays out around affirmative action: did I get this job, or did I get into this college because of merit or race? Do people see me as an equal, or as an "affirmative action case?"
And this in turn is one of the reasons conservatives of all races generally object to such programs. To them, calling attention to race, whether in preferences or in demanding respect, is a perversion of the proper goal of civil rights: colorblindness.
Shelby Steele, writing in The Wall Street Journal last week, criticized Mr. West and his colleagues for using white guilt as the path to black power. From this standpoint, it might have been a step in the right direction that Mr. Summers -- fresh from a stint in a Democratic White House -- would feel at liberty to have the conversation he did with Mr. West. Instead, last week, Mr. Summers' aides were continuing to mop up after Mr. West's latest interviews, insisting they would do anything to keep him.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
The Stripes Are on Their Sleeves, Not Their Pants

BYLINE:  By THOM SHANKER 

DATELINE: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan 

 BODY:
EACH evening, as Army Special Forces troops rise with the moon to stand sentry in this former Taliban stronghold, a lieutenant colonel named Dave sits on the carpeted floor of the Governor's Palace to advise local leaders on the complexities of turning tribal warriors into a civilian-controlled security force respecting the rule of law.
 Each day, one of the young Special Forces captains is out assessing the city's health care, checking international relief efforts. 
 With such missions, the Special Forces officers are doing what United States troops abroad have regularly done: imprinting images of America on a people who might have only a hazy notion of the nation and its principles. Though the Pentagon deliberately limited the number of troops on the ground, the American military is the most public of the diplomatic missions in the former combat zone. Soldiers are taking up the delicate task of helping reconstruct a civic fabric. 
This is obvious as Special Forces patrol the gritty marketplace of a city struggling to recover from Taliban dictates, or assist relief agencies setting up shop amid the low-lying houses built of local adobe, or train local security forces at a base camp beneath the talcum-dry peaks that encircle Kandahar. Special Forces teams are negotiating their way through a complicated social network of tribal loyalties and tensions, of religious restrictions and inspirations.
Gen. Eric K. Shinseki, the United States Army chief of staff, likes to take note of how military men and women from a diverse democracy set a standard, by their actions, in nations with no history of tolerance or democracy. Bosnia and Kosovo are just the most recent examples.
Others are more skeptical that the military possesses the finesse, the nuanced understanding of the regional issues, to act as surrogate diplomats. "Where I think you have to be careful is that the military can end up making regional policy," said Lawrence J. Korb, director of studies at the Council on Foreign Relations, who served as an assistant secretary of defense in the Reagan administration. Especially among commanders, he said, "they run the risk of believing they can act like a proconsul. That, to me, is the danger."
One diplomatic historian stressed the enormous cultural barriers to changing Afghan civil society through direct American action. "They should essentially be following a military purpose -- providing military protection and military advice," said Gaddis Smith, Larned professor of history emeritus, at Yale University.
Yet, by doctrine and training, Special Forces troops are the exception that proves the rule that the military is not the best group to deal with the finer points of foreign cultures. Alone in the United States military, they train to be proficient in the continuum from combat to civil affairs. Each of the Army's Special Forces groups has a regional orientation, allowing its members to master foreign languages and history. 
Post-combat Afghanistan, then, is fitting into a historic template forged by American troops in Germany and Japan after World War II. "The role of the American military on the ground in Japan and in Germany after World War II was really quite extraordinary," said Alan K. Henrikson, professor of diplomatic history at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. 
Professor Henrikson cited Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the postwar military governor of Germany, whose background in engineering and logistics allowed him to address the immediate needs of reconstructing a civil society: supplying food and fuel, getting a market economy walking toward recovery -- the issues facing Afghanistan today.
In Japan, after the allied victory, General Douglas MacArthur and his staff helped draft the constitution, bringing an American imprint to the character of a former foe.
THIS imprint can be more individual. Generations of French, Italians, Germans and Japanese remember their first meeting with an American soldier -- or at least the American's chocolate or chewing gum.
American troops today also offer a face of diversity. That, too, is something soldiers have done since World War II, or so Hollywood has it, with every Army unit in old movies cast accordingly: a sincere white kid from a Midwest farm, a tough Irish kid from urban Detroit, the Italian, or maybe Jewish kid from Brooklyn and a Southerner.
For an Air Force combat controller named Martin -- the Pentagon asked that only first names be used -- most conversations with Afghans begin warily. They take note of his combat fatigues, but only after taking note of his M4 automatic weapon -- and that only after taking note of the color of his skin. The first question is usually something like, Are you a Jihadist from East or North Africa? No, he says. The African ancestry is correct, but his family has been American for many, many generations. At that point, Martin says, the kids and also the adults reach out and rub his forearm.
Much work of Special Forces here involves teaching military professionalism to tribal warriors, and helping establish a civilian security force. Just a week ago, the biggest firefight in town was a shoot-out between militiamen and the police. 
"A common problem in post-conflict situations is what to do with the paramilitary forces," said Fiona Hill, a scholar on Central Asian issues at the Brookings Institution. She said training local regiments is a priority. But if not monitored, these same forces can become the better-armed units capable of standing up to the central government, pushing Afghanistan back into its inter-tribal conflict once Americas depart.
Senior Special Forces commanders stress they are aware of the political ramifications of their work, and are constantly assessing factional disputes in their territory.
"Now that the fighting is mostly over, we're dealing with those things that are harder to work through," said Captain Matt, a Special Forces team commander. "When you have a pretty quick victory like this, you want everything else to be quick, too. But you can't walk around with a big stick. That just doesn't work on infrastructure. You have to use the easy push rather than harder pull."
The members of Captain Matt's A Team arm for their patrols in full "battle rattle" -- bulletproof vests and automatic weapons. But they assign one soldier on each Toyota to "wave duty" -- to smile and wave back at gaggles of kids who always line their route.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
Fund Manager Moving To New Role at Janus

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer 

 BODY:
The Janus Capital Corporation, whose stock mutual funds plummeted after the Internet bubble burst, has appointed James Goff, a fund manager, to the vacant position of director of research. 
 Mr. 
Goff, 37, managed the Janus Enterprise fund from its inception in 1992 until this month. Last year, the fund lost almost 40 percent of its value. 
 Assets under management at Janus, formerly the best-selling fund group in the country, fell to $193 billion last year from $260 billion.
The company's previous director of research was James Craig, who retired in August 2000. Mr. Craig was also chief investment officer of Janus.
Mr. Goff will train Janus analysts, according to Tom Bailey, chief executive of the fund group, which is a unit of Stilwell Financial of Kansas City, Mo. Mr. Bailey said the move would "ensure that Janus's research-driven culture continues to be instilled."
Janus also appointed Helen Hayes, co-manager of the Janus Worldwide and Janus Overseas funds, as managing director of investments. Jonathan Coleman will take over from Mr. Goff as manager of Janus Enterprise, the company said.

HEADLINE: A Time to Buy Japan Inc.? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Yes, There Are Still Optimists in Japan" (Dec. 30), which discussed how the Japanese yen lost 16 percent of its value against the dollar in 2001: 
 As the article points out, the stocks of major Japanese companies are trading near 10-year lows. And many of these companies have strong brands and well-trained work forces. 
 The combination of a strong dollar and low prices for leading Japanese companies provides American companies with a rare opportunity to purchase such companies at bargain-basement prices.

THEODORE J. SHESKIN
Lakewood, Ohio, Dec. 31

The writer is a professor of industrial engineering at Cleveland State University.

HEADLINE: 'Will & Will,' 24/7 

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif. 

 BODY:
Back in the nation's capital, in Bushworld, singles don't exist. The president and even the Democrats focus on traditional families, parents and children. 
 Here in television's capital, in NBC world, children don't exist. NBC sitcoms and dramas focus on quirky and unsettled singles, battered by work and dating problems, with friends serving as family. 
 NBC has so relentlessly pursued the young-hip-urban singletons beloved by advertisers that it has ended up with a barren prime time.
At the television press tour here, the NBC Entertainment president, Jeff Zucker, was asked by a critic if it was "coincidence or design that there are no children on any NBC show?"
"Obviously, our No. 1 comedy is about to have a baby in 'Friends,' he said. "But the fact is you raise a point that we've talked about, and I would actually like to see us have a show or two that has some kids."
When MTV and Showtime disclosed last week that they were creating a gay channel for cable, one NBC executive joked that there already was a gay channel -- and he worked there. Besides the trailblazing "Will & Grace," NBC has the tortured lesbian Dr. Kerry Weaver on "E.R." and, of course, "Frasier," which gays jokingly call "a friend of Dorothy."
Once families sat in the blue TV light, laughing or crying together. But now the proliferation of sets and taping devices, as well as kiddiecentric cable channels, let parents and kids avoid each other completely. 
We have niche narcissism marketing. You may as well cover your TV screen with a mirror. I watch the Maureen Channel, dramas about workaholic, single, urban, tough-but-vulnerable Irish women, with Gaelic tin whistles on the soundtrack.
Lifetime, now the No. 1 rated cable network in prime time, succeeded with its women-in-distress and disease-of-the-nanosecond movies. (Will and Grace eat popcorn and watch Lifetime constantly.) The Oxygen network has yet to catch on because it tried to do empowering shows for smart women. But exhausted smart women just wanted to watch women do dumb things on Lifetime at night.
"You want the ability to see yourselves and get away from yourselves," says Gene Falk, a Showtime vice president. Mr. Falk and a MTV consultant, Matt Farber -- both gay -- are developing the new gay cable channel. "I want to see mushy romantic moments with people like me," Mr. Falk says. "As a friend of mine says, gay people want trash, too."
Hollywood has come a long way from the days when Cary Grant depicted Cole Porter as straight and Clifton Webb feigned a romantic interest in Gene Tierney in "Laura."
"I can envision everything from comedy shows to game shows to reality shows to relationship shows to issues shows to travel shows to biography shows," Mr. Farber says.
Game shows? "Like the old 'Newlywed Game,' " he says.
Biography? "David Geffen," Mr. Farber offers. "Barney Frank, Philip Johnson," Mr. Falk proposes, adding that the show could be modeled on "Inside the Actor's Studio."
Travel? "Provincetown or Paris," Mr. Farber says.
My gay friends had a mixed reaction. While pleased that their economic muscle is recognized, they worry that the channel might lead to a cabaret of stereotypes. "All Joan Crawford, all the time," one says dryly.
They are also skeptical about how the channel will serve both gays and lesbians, who have a history of friction. "Will they alternate showings of 'Mommie Dearest' and 'Personal Best' "? one friend asks slyly.
Mr. Farber concedes the point: "I'd be lying if I said it wasn't a challenge." And Mr. Falk agrees that "a 21-year-old lesbian is not interested in the same things as a 50-year-old gay man."
"If you offer enough different images, the stereotypes will cancel each other out," Mr. Falk adds. "We don't necessarily see an effeminate character as bad any more. Now you can have a strong effeminate character."
David Ehrenstein, the author of "Open Secret: Gay Hollywood, 1928-2000," is not concerned about gays being ghettoized. "There is already the aura of gay niche marketing in advertising," he says. "Like the Volkswagen commercial where the two guys are driving around town picking up furniture."
Max Mutchnick, the gay creator of "Will & Grace," can't wait to see more ads tailored his way. "We'll go from Coors Light," he muses, "to Coors Light in the loafers."

HEADLINE: States Seek to Counter U.S. Deregulation 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
Sensing a growing deregulatory movement in Washington, state officials have been moving swiftly to fill what they perceive as voids in areas like antitrust, environmental law, consumer safety, telecommunications, banking, health care and energy.
 In recent months, the states have brought suits, rewritten regulations or adopted laws in those areas after perceiving opposition or lack of interest by the Bush administration or Congress. 
 One public break with Washington was a dissent by nine states to a plan by the Justice Department to settle the Microsoft antitrust lawsuit.
In another break, attorneys general from six Northeastern states challenged the administration's plans to loosen regulations that require all industries, including utilities, to upgrade pollution control equipment when they upgrade. 
But there have been many other recent cases of states' intervening on regulations when Washington has not asserted itself, though they have received less attention: 
*Last month, 29 states sued Bristol-Myers Squibb in an antitrust lawsuit that said the company misled the Food and Drug Administration to block the marketing of a cheaper generic alternative to BuSpar, an antianxiety medicine. The agency has taken no action in the case, although the Federal Trade Commission filed a friend-of-the-court brief last week that urged a judge to reject the drug maker's efforts to dismiss the suit.
*Because Congress and federal regulators have not acted to curtail the growth of telemarketing, seven states -- Colorado, Illinois, Indiana, Louisiana, Missouri, Texas and Wyoming -- adopted "Do Not Call" laws last year, in the footsteps of states that had adopted similar laws. The laws generally require telephone solicitors to avoid calling consumers who list their objections to such calls on a registry. The Federal Trade Commission is considering whether to propose a new rule.
*California, Connecticut, Maine, Maryland, Nevada, New Jersey, New York and Vermont recently filed a federal suit to challenge the revisions by the Energy Department of efficiency rules for air-conditioners and heat pumps, saying the rules weaken efficiency standards, increase the cost and use of electricity and add pollution.
*North Carolina and California have outlawed what consumer groups call predatory lending -- loans with excessive or hidden fees, for example. Federal regulators recently clamped down on some lenders, but Washington has not curbed most predatory practices in the face of strong opposition from the banking industry.
*Representatives from 31 state utility commissions have led a so-far successful battle in Congress to block a bill, supported by some administration members, that would deregulate local telephone markets and ease the way for regional Bell companies to enter the long-distance and high-speed-Internet markets.
*Some states have promulgated their own consumer safety standards. Oregon recently increased the standards for baby cribs. Last year, California adopted tough standards for mattress flammability.
Experts and state officials say the states' growing involvement is reminiscent of a movement in the Reagan administration, when the perception of lax enforcement prompted a core group of state prosecutors and lawmakers to form new alliances.
Relations between state regulators and the federal government became somewhat more harmonious in the Clinton administration, although there were episodic disagreements like those over pursuing the tobacco industry and an earlier effort to settle the Microsoft case.
"There is a clear dramatic trend of Republican and Democratic attorneys general expanding the scope of their law enforcement efforts in a more aggressive and proactive way to fill gaps left at the federal level or to address unmet needs," Richard Blumenthal, Connecticut's attorney general and a Democrat, said. "The climate is now very similar to the Reagan years, where there was a retreat at the federal level in many of these areas and in some instances actually a complete abrogation of authority."
Some federal officials have tried to build ties to the states. 
The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, Timothy J. Muris, said the relationship between his agency and the states had been "generally quite cooperative" on merger and consumer cases. Mr. Muris, a senior antitrust official in the Reagan administration, added that on some issues like the state laws restricting telephone solicitations, the states had been ahead of the federal government and had provided important models for nationwide rules.
But the White House has made some moves that alienated the states. One such signal was its announcement two months ago that President Bush would nominate Harold Stratton, a former attorney general of New Mexico, to be the next chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission. 
Mr. Stratton has accused state prosecutors of misusing their authority and being too activist. He was also president of the Rio Grande Foundation of New Mexico, a research organization devoted to "principles of limited government, economic freedom and individual responsibility."
Tom Miller, attorney general of Iowa and a Democrat, said, "Appointing him shows they are not particularly sensitive to our role in light of his previous positions." 
Sensing that the new regulatory battles are shifting, consumer groups like AARP, which represents millions of older Americans, are moving with it. Next month, when the organization opens an office in Louisiana, it will have established local lobbying operations in all 50 states, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico. The organization has been recruiting support from state lawmakers and officials on issues of importance to retired people, including curbs on predatory lending, wider availability of generic drugs and limits on telephone solicitation.
"The impetus for the local movement has come about as a result of the frustration with Washington," said Cheryl Matheis, director of state affairs for AARP, which says it has 35 million members. 
"In the past," Ms. Matheis said, "it was easier to fix a problem at the federal level and you didn't have to go to the states. Now, when you have a problem, and you go to the federal government and don't get anywhere, you can go to the states and attract a critical mass."
