HEADLINE: BIO; 
Like a Tsunami

BYLINE:  By Jacques Steinberg; Jacques Steinberg is a national education correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:
THE highest court in Hawaii had just dealt a setback to the islands' beleaguered native population, and Evan S. Dobelle, the new president of the state university, decided that he had to respond.
 Never mind that he was neither a plaintiff nor a defendant in the case. 
 Dr. Dobelle was angry that the judges had brushed aside the native Hawaiians' claim that they were entitled to some revenue from the state's main airport, which sits on territory that their ancestors ceded to white settlers in the 19th century. But he was more incensed about the timing: the much-anticipated ruling had been issued on Sept. 12, just a day after the terrorist attacks. Dr. Dobelle was sure the judges were trying to bury it. 
And so Dr. Dobelle, who had moved to Hawaii only two months earlier, summoned his senior aides to inform them what he was going to do: convene a news conference to denounce the decision, and announce that the university would immediately spend $1.5 million to improve its teaching of native culture and language. The court might not be willing to do right by native Hawaiians, but the university would certainly try.
"I apologize for not cornering everyone and asking their opinion,o Dr. Dobelle told his top aides inside the mahogany paneled conference room adjoining his office. "I'm just going to assume it's everyone's opinion. It's the right thing to do. And when you know the right thing to do, you don't have to have a discussion.o
For those who have followed his many previous incarnations -- as the self-described "kid mayoro of Pittsfield, Mass. (in his 20's), as chief of protocol for President Jimmy Carter (in his early 30's) and, until last spring, as president of Trinity College in Hartford -- this was vintage Dobelle: self-confident, impatient, maybe a little condescending, but always perched on the moral high ground.
The only surprising thing was that his act was now playing in Hawaii.
Dr. Dobelle, 56, has washed ashore in Honolulu with the quiet calm of a tsunami, jolting a state university that has long enjoyed a reputation for being as laid back and intellectually flabby as a tourist on Waikiki. Yet few here have disputed how he has framed his mission: to take an institution that caters mostly to commuters living at home with their parents (more of a high school than a college, many say), and transform it into a world-class university that attracts thousands of top students from the mainland United States and Asia.
After he has fulfilled the terms of his contract -- which will pay him nearly $450,000 a year for at least the next seven years -- Dr. Dobelle has pledged that Manoa, the university's flagship campus on the outskirts of the state capital, will be on its way to joining Ann Arbor, Charlottesville and maybe even Berkeley in the pantheon of public higher education.
"Change is always hard," said Dr. Dobelle, who has put away his well-worn button-down shirts in favor of the flowery blouses that Hawaiians wear for business and pleasure. "It's particularly hard in a state where the status quo is celebrated, and mediocrity is acceptable. For whatever reason, this institution has not, historically, had the opportunity to compete."
In seeking to reverse that trend, Dr. Dobelle has been a font of big ideas since his arrival in July. He has won permission from the State Legislature to sell $150 million in bonds to help build a medical school, cancer research center and biomedical research complex, which, he said, would generate more than 2,000 medical and construction jobs. 
To help envision that satellite campus, Dr. Dobelle has enlisted the help of a respected planning firm from the mainland, Cooper, Robertson & Partners, which has also been hired by two developers to design plans for the World Trade Center site.
Because the university has only 3,000 dormitory rooms in Manoa for its 18,000 students (most rooms are occupied by those who grew up on the outer islands), Dr. Dobelle has proposed building 5,000 new rooms to help attract students, as well as student-athletes, from the continental United States and abroad. 
"Why can't we have Chinese swimmers, Japanese baseball players and Korean soccer players?" he asked. "We can."
To market the university to that wider audience, Dr. Dobelle has imported another established outsider to serve as vice president of external affairs. He is Paul Costello, who was assistant press secretary to the first lady, Rosalynn Carter, in the late 1970's and press secretary to Kitty Dukakis when her husband, Michael, was running for president in 1988.
But in looking toward the mainland, Dr. Dobelle has hardly neglected those already attending the university. He has pledged to build a small town full of restaurants and retail shops -- again, think Ann Arbor -- adjacent to the main campus, which is now so devoid of commercial establishments that there is little reason for students and professors to hang around after class.
And he has proposed creating a program for honors students that would urge its matriculants to graduate in four years. (Many now take as many as seven years, and the average age at graduation is 25.)
"It's refreshing to have someone with ideas who's talking about making changes," said Mary Tiles, a professor of philosophy at Manoa for 12 years. "But at the moment, it's hard for us to know what's going to be taken seriously and what's going to turn out to be hot air."
Indeed, in seeking to realize his vision, Dr. Dobelle faces numerous challenges. 
For one thing, the percentage of students enrolled in private elementary and secondary schools in Hawaii (nearly 20 percent) is higher than in any other state, according to a recent Associated Press analysis of census data. Partly in response to Hawaiians' historic attachment to religious schools, and partly because of the state's low-rated public school system, the stigma of a Hawaiian public education has attached itself to the university as well: children who have the resources to attend college on the mainland usually do.
Moreover, their recent largess notwithstanding, the State Legislature and governor have cut the university's $800 million budget several times in recent years, prompting its professors to strike for 13 days last spring. (Though the Hawaiian economy plunged after Sept. 11, Dr. Dobelle said he had received assurances from Gov. Benjamin Cayetano that he supports the university's request for more than $300 million in additional construction financing in 2002.)
The much-talked-about aloha spirit, characterized by good will and generosity in its best sense, has also created an insular world of noncompetitive government contracts that are sometimes steered to officials' friends and family, practices that Dr. Dobelle has vowed to stamp out as the university heads into a construction boom.
It was in that spirit that Dr. Dobelle sent letters this fall to more than 200 top administrators, including the dean of the medical school, informing them that he reserved the right under state law to fire them, as he rethinks how the university should be governed. 
"Unless you receive notice to the contrary,o he wrote, "your executive/managerial appointment will end effective the close of business Dec. 16, 2002." 
Dr. Dobelle has said that he cannot realize his dreams if he is surrounded by people he does not trust. 
But in seeking to lift up the university, which has 13 smaller campuses on Oahu, Maui and on the other outer islands, Dr. Dobelle has plenty of existing assets on which he can build.
Though the main campus is dotted with temporary trailers that house many professors' offices, it has the trappings of an island paradise, with Christmasberry trees offering shade and majestic green cliffs rising in the near distance. Also, several of the university's graduate programs are already recognized as international leaders, including those in astronomy, oceanography and Indian and Chinese philosophy.
"We have the capacity to hit home runs," said Dr. Dobelle, whose predecessor, Kenneth P. Mortimer, resigned after eight years. "We're just doing it in empty ballparks. No one's watching us."
Thus far, Dr. Dobelle has enjoyed the support of faculty members, which is somewhat astonishing considering how embittered they were last spring. He has vowed to raise their salaries -- the average full professor earns about $78,000, which is near the national average -- even if he has not suggested where he will find the money.
"He's a whirlwind of fresh air," said Richard L. Rapson, a professor of history at Hawaii for more than three decades. "No one has really been much interested in education here, in the president's seat or in the government." 
Students, too, have been captivated by his fast-paced style, which several described as calibrated to "New York Time."
Though Dr. Dobelle has placed no computer on his chest-level desk, which frees him to pace -- "I need to think at work, not type," he said -- he has pledged to respond to any e-mail message within 72 hours. He often does so before dawn, at home.
Anson Hokama, the editor in chief of the student newspaper, Ka Leo O Hawaii (The Voice of Hawaii), said he decided to test the policy by sending Dr. Dobelle a thank-you note after an interview. "He got right back to me," he said.
"Initially, there were detractors," said Mr. Hokama, 24, a senior who grew up on Oahu and is studying journalism. "They wanted someone with local ties. But if the most qualified person is a haole from the mainland, what can you say? I'd rather have that than a semiqualified local person."

Evan Samuel Dobelle
Born: April 22, 1945
Raised: Pittsfield, Mass.; later, Cocoa Beach, Fla.
Family: Married in 1970 to Kit, who was later chief of staff to the first lady, Rosalynn Carter. One child, Harry, 14, a ninth grader at Punahou, a private school.
Education: Bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees, in education and public policy, from the University of Massachusetts in Amherst; master's in public administration from Harvard University.
Career highlights:
Mayor, Pittsfield, 1973 to 1976: While an aide to Senator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, he decided to return to Pittsfield to run for mayor because of concerns about downsizing at General Electric, a major employer in the city. At age 28, he was elected to the first of two terms. He resigned in 1976 to become environmental commissioner for Massachusetts.
Chief of protocol and assistant secretary of state, Carter Administration, 1977 to 1979: He met Jimmy Carter while a commissioner in Massachusetts. Mr. Carter personally invited him to join his new administration.
Higher education: President of Middlesex Community College in Lowell, Mass., 1987 to 1990; president of City College of San Francisco, 1990 to 1995; president of Trinity College in Hartford, Conn., 1995 to spring 2001.
OUTSIDE INTERESTS: Fishing, watching televised sports, reading.
On adjusting to Hawaii: "You've got a tropical climate. You've got a polycultural people that have a sweetness and openness that is almost embarrassing to exchange. You speak English. You have the protection of a democracy. Anything anyone would ever dream about -- except professional sports."

LENGTH: 849 words

HEADLINE: The Abyss Yawns 

BYLINE:  By Stephanie Gutmann; Stephanie Gutmann is a freelance writer in New York.

 BODY:
OVER nearly three decades, Lewis Fortner has tried to steer generations of students through the slalom course that is four years of college. In private counseling sessions, he has heard a lot of venting and obsessing, and he has learned that the famously anxious freshman year is only "one of the major, articulating points in one's life." The other is senior year.
 "After all, it isn't just the end of four years," says Mr. Fortner, an associate dean of students at the University of Chicago. "It's the end of 16 years or 17 years of education, which is a highly artificial form of existence. At that time in their lives, students can hardly remember a time when they were not in school, so they usually feel some trepidation about this extraordinary change. The abyss of freedom yawns." 
 Seniors manifest that anxiety with "trouble concentrating, distractibility, irritability or disturbed sleep," says Mary Way, director of mental health services at Southern Methodist University in Fort Worth. Seniors are anxious about finding jobs, of course, and about managing their own money, finding insurance and a place to live. "But," Dr. Way says, "seniors also face great sadness and loss in leaving the familiar structure and cocoon of friends, classes and activities."
According to Susan M. Art, a dean of students at the University of Chicago, "seniors often go into a prolonged period of mourning" about leaving. "They can't believe this is going to end, that they're not going to continue to have this life of going to class, the library and meeting with friends."
A student may even fail a course to forestall leaving the nest. Mr. Fortner has seen this "senior slowdown," too, and says it's like a "kind of academic self-destruction."
"Out of the blue a student who's been exemplary in all ways suddenly sets himself up for failure by failing to meet deadlines and generally doing work below what he or she could do." (There is a more positive explanation for the legendary senior slump; midyear, seniors may already have a job or a graduate school berth lined up.)
If it's always hard to leave the nest, for many seniors it's particularly tough this year, as they graduate into a world shaped by the war against terrorism and by recession. Indeed, job prospects are not good. Every year the National Association of Colleges and Employers asks a representative sample of employers in a wide spectrum of industries about their hiring plans for the coming year. In its latest survey, in late December, 20 percent fewer employers said they planned to hire a new college graduate.
How to stay in the nest? One way is to go right back in. At times like this, Mr. Fortner says, students go directly to graduate school "while the economy mends itself." (Also, as long as one is still in school, the undergraduate loan is held in abeyance.)
Kaplan, the test prep company, reports seeing a 20 percent increase in its course enrollment for graduate students from last January to October: 34 percent more for the Graduate Management Admissions Test, usually required by business schools, and 26 percent more for the Law School Admissions Test. (Medical school, which re-quires substantial long-term planning and commitment, depends less on employment opportunities.)
Trudy Steinfeld, director of the Office of Career Services at New York University, says that the uncertain times have encouraged students to reflect more. "We've had a lot more students coming in and questioning what they're thinking about doing," she says.
For reasons emotional ("I want to make a difference") and materialistic ("It's where the jobs are"), a nationwide surge of interest has developed in government work like the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Central Intelligence Agency and the Peace Corps.
"When we had a job fair here on 9/25, the biggest table mobbed was the F.B.I.," Dr. Steinfeld says. "That definitely wouldn't have happened last year. Nobody would sign up for their schedules, nobody would come to their tables."
Since Sept. 11, there has been a sixfold to sevenfold increase in applications for the C.I.A.; 1,100 were received in one day. Well-established nongovernmental organizations like Teach for America, which trains graduates to teach in troubled elementary schools, are doing well, too.
ONE recent evening, a Teach for America alumnus held an information session in an N.Y.U. classroom. The room was full of students who revealed with their tough, practical questions ("Can you choose your city?" "What about health benefits?") that they were there for more than free pizza and soft drinks.
Mathew Harkins, 21, was typical of the students. A liberal arts major, he was resigned to the fact that no one would be clamoring for his talents this year. Mr. Harkins didn't seem unduly panicked about building a career right away and didn't think a year with the Peace Corps (whose information session he had also attended) would set him back.
"Sept. 11 put things in perspective," he says. "It reaffirmed my desire to do something I enjoy. Anything could happen at any moment, so enjoy it while you have it."

HEADLINE: COVER STORY; 
A Film's History Continues, as It Began

BYLINE:  By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
IS this "The Magnificent Ambersons" of Orson Welles' dreams? Clinphiles, film historians and Welles buffs will not doubt be tuning in for their own appraisals tonight at 8, when A&E unveils an eagerly awaited remake of the 1942 movie that was the subject of one of the bitterest chapters in the artistic life of Welles, the celebrated director of classics like "Citizen Kane" and "Touch of Evil."
 Working from Welle's original script - an adaptation of a novel by Booth Tarkington that won the Pulitzer Prize in 1918 - the Mexican director Alfonso Arau has fashioned a lavish three-hour television movie that is considerably longer than the original, which before its release had been cut severely by RKO Radio Pictures, to Welle's eternal consternation.
 Shot in Ireland in the fall of 2000 at a cost of more than 15 million, this sprawling new "Magnificent Ambersons" has a cast that includes Madeleine Stowe ("The Last of the Mohicans"), Bruce Greenwood ("Thirteen Days") and James Cromwell ("Babe"). They portray members of a turn-of-the-century Indianapolis aristocracy contending with all manner of social and economic upheaval as the genteel agrarian culture of the late 1800's gives way to the up-by-the-boot-straps industrialism of the early 1900's. 
 Taking a second stab at such a fabled property - many in the film world regard Welles's "Ambersons" as a kind of ruined masterwork - was daunting, to say the least. Norman Stephens, one of the producers of the new version, estimates that 75 to 80 percent of what is on the screen in the television movie was taken directly from the script by Welles that the producers found in the RKO files.
 "I had seen the Orson Welles film, and it certainly seemed incomplete to me," Mr Stephen said "We read the script, and as someone who has dealt a lot with making literature into film, I thought, 'My God, there's a lot more to the story than is in the film' Then I read the book, and it was a revelation: I really believe that Tarkington got lost in the postwar generation of writers. So all of that inspired us to try to find a way to remake 'The Magnificent Ambersons.' "
 Welles's picture, with a cast headed by Joseph Cotten, Anne Baxter, Agnes Moorehead and Tim Holt, was a financial failure. Pared down by the studio from more than two hours to less than an hour and a half, it did miserably at the box office and lost more than $600,000 for RKO, although it earned four Academy Award nominations. Even so, Welles, who died in 1985, spoke in anguished terms about the project for the rest of his life.
 Welles had already shown his affinity, in "Citizen Kane," for stories of the desparing rich; in Tarkington's novel, he was no doubt drawn to the idea of a proud 19th-century family watching in uncomprehending helplessness as its wealth and power fades. A motif of the parallel love stories - between a middle-aged widow in the Amberson family (Ms. Stowe) and her nouveau riche suitor (Mr. Greenwood), and between the widow's spoiled son (Jonathan Rhys MEYERS) and the suitor's radiant daughter (Gretchen Mol) - is the dawning of the age of the automobile. Mr. Greenwood's character is a manufacturer of motorcars, and there is the sense in the story that this revolutionary new machine all but mows down landed gentry like the Ambersons.
 Buoyed by their enthusiasm for Tarkington's narrative, Mr. Stephens and his colleagues set about the task of revival. The director they first chose was Herbert Ross, who, in the middle of an acrimonious divorce, was forced to withdraw while the film was in preproduction, Mr. Stephens said. (Ross died three months ago.) With elaborate sets under construction in Dublin, they had to scramble for a director, eventually hiring Mr. Arau, best known for his 1993 film "Like Water for Chocolate."
 Mr. Arau may have seemed an unorthodox choice, but to Mr. Stephens his selection was in keeping with the spirit of the project. "We decided there was no point in doing this if we didn't take a risk," he said. "It made a crazy kind of sense to me that we should have a Mexican director directing a piece of Americana."
 Although much of the dialogue would belong to Tarkington and Welles, there was no mistaking who the director was "Alfonso gave this picture a look," Mr. Stephens said. "He wanted it to have a modern feel."
 Indeed, the stamp of a modern filmmaker is all over the movie. One striking liberty Mr. Arau took with the script was to show the birth of the willful George Amberson Minafer (Mr. Rhys Meyers) from the point of view of the fetus emerging from the body of his mother, Isabel, played by Ms Stowe.
 "That is pure Alfonso," Mr. Stephens said, adding that he "loved all the inventiveness, the physicality" that Mr Arau brought to the production.
 Not everyone on the set was similarly smitten. Ms. Stowe, in a recent telephone interview, said she had had serious disagreements with Mr Arau over the emphasis he was giving in the film to an Oedipal conflict between Isabel and George. That emphasis, she felt, went beyond subtle suggestion.
 The dispute was particularly vexing for her because the idea of playing Isabel had so completely enthralled her. "This script came to me and it was the most beautiful thing I'd ever read," she said. "It was perfect, and my heart broke for Isabel."
 With her expectations so high, she was upset, she said, when she discovered that Mr. Arau's embellishments included a scene in which the mother and son engage in a lingering kiss.
 "I think there's a certain incestuous value, but there are more complex things at play," Ms. Stowe said. "I certainly did not feel it was coming from the mother. Alfonso did not agree." Efforts to draw him out, she added, were not appreciated: "His style of working was to not have a lot of discussion."
 Attempts to read Mr. Arau were unsucessful. Mr. Stephens said that while he had not spoken to Ms. Stowe about her objections, he was aware of her unhappiness, particularly about trims made in some pivotal speeches.
 He said that he did not believe the movie was in any way compromised by the disagreement. "I must say, to Madeleine's credit, that she was terrific and totally professional," he said, adding that he hoped Mr. Arau's approach would be vindicated by the viewers. "All we can do is say, 'Look at the end product.' "
 This kind of artistic dispute seems to be par for the course for "The Magnificent Ambersons," a faint echo of a controversy long ago that left a famous young director deeply unsatisfied with the movie he had made.
 As Ms. Stowe said, "A film can break your heartfaster than anything."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
As FatWire Goes, So Goes the Island's Economy

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
MARK FASCIANO and and Ari Kahn started FatWire in the summer of 1996, financing their venture with credit cards and using a spare bedroom in Mr. Fasciano's parents' house in Oyster Bay as their office. Newly minted graduates of the University of Chicago's computer science doctoral program, the two 20-something entrepreneurs set to work perfecting a software program that allows thousands of people at different computers to work simultaneously on the same project.
 Within two years, I.B.M. and Wells Fargo had signed on as customers, and other large corporations were showing interest. Mr. Fasciano hired more programmers, sales representatives and marketers, moving his staff of 30 into leased office space in Port Washington. In 2000, tapping a $9 million infusion of venture capital, Mr. Fasciano tripled his work force and relocated again, this time to still larger office space in Mineola. 
 Deloitte & Touche has recognized FatWire as one of Long Island's fast-growing high-tech companies, and Ernst & Young named Mr. Fasciano as Long Island Entrepreneur of the Year in 2000.
FatWire, which employs about 100 people, is part of a new breed of high-tech companies that the Long Island Association says have added more than 23,100 jobs to the region and helped diversify an economy once overly dependent on defense contractors and aerospace companies.
The success of companies like FatWire was envisioned in the mid-90's by Project Long Island, a $1.5 million job-creation campaign initiated by the association, the region's largest business organization. Begun in 1996 with much fanfare, the campaign wheezed to a close last month, largely unnoticed but nonetheless praised by the association's president, Matthew T. Crosson. 
"Project Long Island was a remarkable success," Mr. Crosson said. "It focused the region on its high-growth technology industries, rejuvenated the business community's confidence in Long Island's ability to not only survive defense downsizing but prosper, and led directly to significant job and payroll increases."
Assigning a grade to Project Long Island is difficult, in part because the association changed its target goals in midflight. The association originally set as its target "the indirect creation of about 28,000 jobs in five industries," Mr. Crosson said. The industries were biotechnology, computers, electronics, health-care information systems, and graphics. In September 1996, the association revised its goal downward, to 22,400 jobs, and eliminated one target industry -- health-care information systems -- when several major companies in that industry changed direction. 
Of course, the gains from an effort like Project Long Island are ephemeral at best; many of the new jobs have already been lost to layoffs. And who can say with certainty whether it was the project's efforts, or simply a vibrant economy, that resulted in the hiring?
In several ways, FatWire exemplifies both sides of the coin. Like many high-tech companies, FatWire's growth has flagged.With the computer industry enmeshed in a prolonged global slump, last year Mr. Fasciano laid off 15 people, a task he described as the hardest thing he has ever done as an executive. But he added that the cuts have kept the company on track, and it is now developing its next generation of software. 
The end of the Project Long Island comes at unlucky time, of course, and the current economic downturn minimizes its benefits. High-tech industries are among those hardest hit, and so the benefits the association is claiming seem oddly out of sync with the economic moment, like a poorly dubbed foreign film.
In an interview earlier this month Dr. Pearl Kamer, the association's economist, described "enormous growth in electronics wholesaling and cable television," seemingly oblivious to the major layoffs announced by Long Island's largest publicly traded companies, including Arrow, Computer Associates and Symbol Technologies.
"Yes, we know we have had some layoffs in the second half of '01, and we may see some continued weakness going into this year," Dr. Kamer said. "But the layoffs in computer-related industries were relatively moderate in comparison with the dot-com implosion."
In Jericho, Brian D. Lee, the managing director of the Long Island office of Insignia/ ESG, the real estate management company, questioned whether the claims of high-tech job growth were justified.
"As someone leasing office space to technology companies, it seems odd to say there is a growth in high-tech jobs," said Mr. Lee, a founding member of LISTNet, the Long Island Software and Technology Network. "Most of the marginal tech companies and dot-coms are closing up shop or downsizing. Currently we are seeing an abundance of job layoffs."
A clear sign that the region's high-tech sector is wobbling is seen at the half-empty Long Island Technology Center in Great River. The Long Island Association, along with other business leaders, had encouraged real estate developers to rebuild the former Grumman test hangar as a showcase for high-tech companies. But they have had a hard time leasing the space and have now opened the center to companies outside the original high-tech niche, renaming it the Long Island Business and Technology Center. The occupancy rate has declined from about 70 percent to 50 percent, Mr. Lee said.
Peter Goldsmith, LISTnet's chairman and a former Grumman project director who served as Mr. Crosson's economic development director for the early years of Project Long Island, said that the campaign's main achievement was in promoting economic diversity as the Island struggled to rebuild an economy weakened by the departure or downsizing of the aerospace and defense contracting companies that had been the backbone of its prosperity. 
"The defense contractors like Grumman were gone or disappearing, and people had lost confidence in Long Island as a place to live and do business," Mr. Goldsmith said. "People thought the economy had tanked and that things were going to get worse, not better. The idea of Project Long Island was to turn around the thought process. We wanted people to think about the fact that the economy wasn't just big defense contractors but plenty of small and midsized electronics companies." 
Keith Banks, an executive vice president of Lloyd Staffing, a Melville company that places permanent and temporary employees at many high-tech companies, said that job-growth figures used by the Long Island Association excluded temporary workers and consultants. If they were included, he said, the job-growth statistics would be more impressive.
"We are dealing with companies that announce layoffs but are still hiring people for short-term projects," Mr. Banks said. "Our information technology consulting division just completed the one of the best years in our history."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mark Fasciano, left, and Ari Kahn founded the FatWire Corporation in 1996, using credit cards to finance the venture. Since then it has grown quickly -- and of late, shrunk slightly, mirroring what has happened in other high-tech companies on Long Island. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Heather Adivari, Robert Riva

 BODY:
Heather Suzanne Adivari and Robert Augusto Riva, who are lawyers, were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York. 
The Rev. Nancy W. Hanna, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony. 
 The bride, who graduated from Cornell, and the bridegroom, a University of Chicago graduate, met at Cornell, where they received law degrees, she cum laude. 
 The bride, 26, will continue to use her name professionally. She is an associate in the New York office of Piper Marbury Rudnick & Wolfe. She is the daughter of Suzanne and John Adivari of Marietta, Ga. Her father is the manager of commercial sales for the Lowe's Home Improvement Warehouse in Woodstock, Ga. Her mother retired as an Atlanta-based regional training manager for the custom decorating department of Sears Roebuck & Company.
The bridegroom, 34, was until last month an associate with Altheimer & Gray in Chicago and is now studying for the New York State bar. He received a master's degree in political economy from American University. 
His parents, Paolina and Joseph Riva, live in Kenosha, Wis. His mother is a cook at Tenuta's, a grocery and delicatessen there, and his father manages Riva Ornamental Iron, part of the Studios of Potente, which designs and remodels church interiors.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOHN LONSKI; 
Rising Debt Brings Rising Risk

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
AMERICANS are swimming in debt these days. Low borrowing costs -- the product of the Federal Reserve campaign to drive down interest rates to keep the economy afloat -- are enticing more people to run up credit card balances, take out loans for new cars or refinance home mortgages. Last week, the Fed reported that consumer borrowing rose in November by $19.8 billion, the biggest monthly increase since the Fed began keeping records in 1943. 
John Lonski, the chief economist at Moody's Investors Service, which tracks corporate and consumer debt, says the rise in consumer borrowing and spending is a mixed blessing. Following are excerpts from an interview on Wednesday.
 VIVIAN MARINO

Q. What has the rise in consumer spending and borrowing done for the economy?

A. Without question, the ability of consumers to continue to borrow and spend has diminished the severity of the current recession. We find that consumer spending has held up much better in the 2001 recession than in the 1990-91 recession and the 1981-82 recession. We can cite a dramatic increase in mortgage refinancing at a pace that seems surprisingly lively, given the recession.

Q. Many credit card companies and automakers have been offering zero-percent financing and other incentives. What are the risks to consumers who accept these offers?

A. You have to remember that these low rates are not going to last forever. The credit card companies, for instance, will eventually start to charge full-market rates, and maybe an annual fee, if you stay on with them. You may not fully realize just how great a burden you'll be facing once the inducement is over.
Also, when it comes to zero-percent financing, the terms might be more restrictive. I think that consumers may find that their monthly payment might be reduced if they move from a three-year, zero-interest loan to a loan that has, say, a 7 percent interest rate but is repaid over a five-year span.

Q. What problems do you foresee because of increased borrowing by individual households? And how will they affect the economy?

A. The record shows that household debt repayment problems will continue to rise with the unemployment rate, so we have to be prepared for a higher incidence of delinquencies regarding outstanding consumer debt as well as home mortgages. We're already seeing that.
In the end, the fact that many households are already highly leveraged will have the effect of slowing the forthcoming recovery.

Q. But with interest rates so low, why shouldn't we borrow more now, provided we can afford to pay it back?

A. If you're confident about the long-term prospects, you probably can go ahead and justify taking on some additional debt, but you cannot ignore that in the near term there is some economic uncertainty. If you lost your job or had difficulty meeting debt payments, you ought not be in a total shock by such a turn of events.
Given the above-average level of uncertainty regarding job opportunities, it behooves consumers to approach everything more cautiously unless they are quite wealthy or very confident about job security. It's reason enough to use debt sparingly. 

Q.Do you anticipate a slowdown in consumer borrowing this year? If so, why?

A. I think it will happen. The still-healthy pace of housing activity will level off and slow the growth for household mortgage debt outstanding. Mortgage yields are unlikely to return to the 6.7 percent low of October 2001. They already are above 7 percent again, and they will most likely edge higher. Higher mortgage yields amid a still-slack labor market suggest that home sales are close to topping off.
 Interestingly enough, there are important segments of the housing sector that have run into a diminished ability to borrow -- the subprime borrowers. Suppliers of credit have reduced the amount of money available, particularly for manufactured housing or mobile homes.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
When Pension and Unemployment Checks Don't Mix

BYLINE:  By DORI R. PERRUCCI 

 BODY:
JANICE SWEET FAIRLEY spent virtually all of her working career at the telephone company, starting as an operator for Michigan Bell, and rising to a manager of data services after the company was reorganized as Ameritech.
 "I was Miss Ameritech to the world," said Mrs. Fairley, who lives in Clark Lake, Mich. But in December 1997, several months before SBC Communications acquired the company, she was laid off as part of a general downsizing. She had just turned 50. 
 But Mrs. Fairley said she received more bad news later, after she learned that her former employer was challenging her right to collect unemployment benefits. 
Ed Greenawald, 59, of Greensboro, N.C., said he ran into similar problems after he was laid off from Wachovia Bank in November 2000, where he was a senior manager. He had worked for the company for 16 years. It was only after he challenged the company's initial refusal to pay unemployment, he said, that he was able to collect partial benefits. 
How did these problems arise? Unknowingly, Mrs. Fairley and Mr. Greenawald had set off an overlooked, 25-year-old provision in the Federal Unemployment Tax Act that requires states to offset or reduce unemployment benefits against pensions to avoid what might be perceived as "double dipping." After she left Ameritech, Mrs. Fairley said, she took a lump-sum distribution on her defined-benefit pension plan and her 401(k) plan and rolled it over into an Individual Retirement Account. Mr. Greenawald said he chose a small lump-sum payment and a monthly annuity, which he started receiving right away.
Because the states, not the federal government, administer unemployment benefits, it is up to each state to interpret the federal unemployment law as it sees fit. 
All states, by law, must reduce unemployment benefits whenever there is an annuity payout from a pension plan that is funded in full by an employer, such as a defined-benefit plan and certain defined-contribution plans that offer annuities, pension experts say. Although most states, they add, no longer count rollovers as the receipt of a pension, and therefore, do not reduce unemployment benefits, about a dozen states still do, including New York and North Carolina. Michigan was once in that category, they say, but it changed its policy in 1999 -- a change that is now being challenged by Mrs. Fairley's former employer. About 20 states, meanwhile, will also offset unemployment benefits if someone is collecting Social Security benefits, pension experts say.
WHILE the federal Labor Department says it has no position on the Social Security issue, it maintains that rollovers should not affect unemployment benefits. "Generally our position is that if the money is not received, it's not deducted from unemployment," said Grace Kilbane, director of the Labor Department's Office of Workforce Security, which oversees the unemployment system. But she added that "it's the states' choice" and that the federal law "gave them lots of options."
Many consumer advocates want all the states to follow the Labor Department's guidance. 
"The rules were written for a time that no longer exists," said Clare Hushbeck, a labor economist in Washington with AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons. "We've gone from assuming 20 years ago that people retire at 65." 
For one thing, Ms. Hushbeck said, more retired workers may want -- or need -- to return to the work force, especially those whose 401(k) investments have shrunk in value because of the stock market's downturn. It is unfair, she said, to make them ineligible for unemployment benefits if they return to work and are then laid off.
AARP is planning to campaign for policy changes in some of the 20 or so states that still apply the pension offset provision against retired workers receiving Social Security, she said.
Rick McHugh, a staff lawyer and Midwest coordinator based in Michigan for the National Employment Law Project, a legal aid group, said that because state interpretation of federal law varied so widely, "there's been no serious efforts to fix FUTA," as the federal law is known. He is representing Mrs. Fairley in her challenge and has handled other pension-offset cases. 
"There's no quick fix, and because of that, it hasn't gotten on anybody's radar screen in Washington," he said. "I think it's out of step with the other policies we have in place in our society, where we generally try to encourage people to accumulate funds for retirement."
Others, however, say the law is fine the way it is. "People who are collecting retirement pay, by and large in the vast majority of cases, are not in the job market, and thus some sort of coordination with unemployment is essential," said Eric Oxfeld, president of UWC Strategic Services, a group in Washington that lobbies for employers on unemployment law. "Pension offset is critical in guarding against double-dipping by workers, especially in a time of high unemployment; it even acts as an incentive in getting workers back to work."
Mrs. Fairley, now 55 and a training manager for NCO Financial Services in Jackson, Mich., said she had not been planning to retire when she chose to roll over her pension instead of leaving it with her employer. "I didn't want to leave my money with them," she said. 
She said she knew she would have to pay taxes and a penalty on withdrawals from her I.R.A., and she even checked with the state's unemployment office to make sure that withdrawals from her new I.R.A. account would not jeopardize her benefits. 
She says she regrets, however, that she never thought to ask whether just rolling over her pension money into an I.R.A. would affect her unemployment benefits. Neither did Mr. Greenawald, now a math teacher at Davidson Community College in Lexington, N.C. "I wish I had been a little more savvy up front," he said. "You just assume the money is going to be there."
And neither had read this advice, posted on the Web site of the Labor Department's Pension and Welfare Benefits Administration (www.dol.gov/dol/pwba): "Receiving a lump sum or other distribution from your pension plan may affect your ability to receive unemployment compensation." Mrs. Fairley and Mr. Greenawald could have left their pensions with their employers, a move that would not have caused a reduction in their unemployment benefits.
Thomas Murphy, a retirement benefits consultant at Buck Consultants in Tenafly, N.J., said workers should become familiar with their pension plans. "Most people don't understand their pensions until they're leaving a job," he said. "Get the summary plan document and read it. If you don't understand it, take it to someone who can, either in human resources, a knowledgeable friend or your accountant." 
HE also suggested learning about state unemployment laws: "Call and ask, 'How will taking my pension affect my ability to receive unemployment? If I leave my pension with my employer, will that affect my weekly benefit check?' "
Mr. Greenawald was fortunate -- his state extended benefits for 12 months, although the payment was reduced to $175 a week from $300 because of the $500 monthly annuity he was receiving. 
Mrs. Fairley, meanwhile, has continued to contest Ameritech's action. She will have to pay back the $6,900 in unemployment benefits she collected in 1998 if Ameritech succeeds in its challenge of the Michigan policy that permitted laid-off workers to roll over their pensions and still collect unemployment. Mrs. Fairley's case and at least a dozen others are now in the state's lower courts, all of them involving laid-off Ameritech workers, said Jack Wheatley, director of the Michigan Unemployment Agency. 
Steve Kauffman, a spokesman for SBC Communications, said the company was confident that the Michigan Supreme Court, which heard testimony in its case in early December, would rule in its favor. The state, he said, has upheld pre-existing state law in 10 circuit courts over the last three years.
Mrs. Fairley says she is willing to wait it out, too. "I intend to keep going. There are lots of others facing the same issue," she said.

HEADLINE: For Women, to Soar Is Rare, to Fall Is Human 

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

 BODY:
IT is not enough for women to succeed in business. They also must fail.
 The fate of Carleton S. Fiorina, chief executive of Hewlett-Packard and the highest-ranked female chief executive in the Fortune 500, could be the test. She is waging a highly public battle to complete a merger with Compaq Computer against the wishes of the heirs of Hewlett-Packard's founders. If she is thwarted, it is almost inevitable that she will leave the company. 
 That failure could, paradoxically, spawn a different kind of victory -- or defeat. The key would be whether she is then viewed as simply another risk-embracing chief executive who was driven out when shareholders balked at the company's stock price, or as a poignant symbol of how women still can't quite make it in the cutthroat, male-dominated corporate world. 
No one, of course, would ask such a question about men. But so few women have made it into the corner office -- the appointment on Monday of Patricia F. Russo as chief executive of Lucent Technologies brings to nine the number of the nation's largest 1,000 companies now headed by women -- that the failure of one is sometimes viewed not only as her own, but also as somehow emblematic of deficiencies of her sex. 
Each departure of a high-level executive woman -- voluntary or with a push -- unleashes a torrent of scrutiny and, often, sweeping conclusions about the female condition in modern society. The talk also resonates in corporate boardrooms.
In the last few years, there has been plenty to talk about. 
Several high-profile women have faltered, including Linda J. Wachner, who was ousted from the top slot at Warnaco in November, six months after the company filed for bankruptcy protection; Diana D. Brooks, who resigned as head of Sotheby's and pleaded guilty to price-fixing last year; and Jill E. Barad, who was forced out of Mattel last year after an acquisition went awry and earnings repeatedly fell short of her promises.
Just below them were women like Karen L. Hendricks, who stepped down as the chief executive of the Baldwin Piano and Organ Company last February after clashing over strategy with a large investor four months before the company filed for bankruptcy protection, and Deborah C. Hopkins, the chief financial officer of Lucent -- and, she thought, chief executive-in-waiting -- who was ousted last May, essentially for being perceived as too pushy.
If the sheer scarcity of women as chief executives guarantees them enormous attention when they are hired, the glare is as great or greater when they are fired. When Ms. Wachner, once the highest-paid businesswoman in the country, was fired without severance for driving the company she had built into a powerhouse into hundreds of millions of dollars in debt, the story landed on the front page of The New York Times and Women's Wear Daily.
THAT kind of publicity can give a board pause when it considers whether to select a woman as chief executive. 
"Can we risk the company on him? Can we risk the company on a her?" is how Ellen M. Hancock, who resigned under pressure in September as chief executive of Exodus Communications, put the distinction. Exodus, a Web site company, sought bankruptcy protection the same month.
Ms. Hancock, a seasoned Silicon Valley executive who worked at I.B.M., Apple Computer and National Semiconductor before taking command of Exodus four years ago, said she hoped to find another such job. "We used to say that men C.E.O.'s had Teflon -- they leave one company and pop up in another," she said. "Whether women can do the same remains to be seen -- I am hoping that I will show up in another slot."
Chief executives like Andrea Jung of Avon Products, Meg Whitman of eBay and Shelly Lazarus of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide have proved that women can run major companies successfully. But they remain far less prominent at the top rungs of the business world than in other high-pressure fields. For years, men excused the dearth of top women executives by calling it a "pipeline problem" -- there were, they said, simply too few women who had enough experience. Given time, women would climb the corporate ladder the same way men did.
But today, 20.6 percent of federal judges are women. So are 13 percent of United States senators and 4.6 percent of neurosurgeons. Only 1.2 percent of Fortune 500 chief executives are women. Carly Fiorina is one. The others are Ms. Jung, Ms. Russo, Anne Mulcahy of Xerox, Marion O. Sandler of Golden West Financial (whose husband, Herbert, is co-chief executive) and Cinda A. Hallman of the Spherion Corporation. And when the sample is broadened to the Fortune 1,000, the percentage drops to less than 1 percent.
The gap between women's equality in business and in other fields is so pronounced that books have been devoted to examining the possible reasons. They range from the inflexibility of work hours at the entry level to the chummy old-boy network forged over golf games and in steam rooms. Experts on "glass ceiling" issues also list women's tendency to shoulder most of the responsibility for raising children and taking care of the house, men's perception that women are less committed to career and less willing to take risks, and the unflattering "abrasive" image that attaches to female ambition.
Some psychologists cite a greater fear of success among women or, a corollary, the idea that career success somehow translates into a loss of femininity and sexuality. And some women complain that they are held to higher standards than men.
Such distinctions could be called "A Boardroom of One's Own" -- a corporate version of the ideas laid out by Virginia Woolf to explain why there were no female Shakespeares in the 17th century.
Ms. Fiorina, however, may not fit into any broad pattern of subtle sex discrimination -- or she ignored and superseded it. When she was recruited to Hewlett-Packard, Ms. Fiorina herself famously stated: "I hope that we are at a point that everyone has figured out that there is not a glass ceiling."
If she succeeds, it will not be because she ran the company in a feminine way; if nothing else, her bold, even stubborn insistence on pursuing the merger defies the stereotype that women are more conciliatory and risk-averse than men.
In a recent issue, Business Week put her on its cover with the headline "Carly's Last Stand." The adjectives used to describe her -- "gutsy" and "bold" and "unflinching" -- were the kind routinely applied to male chief executives who take a gamble with bad odds, not those often used for women, like "emotional" or "shrill." 
No studies exist on whether women chief executives fail more often than men, mostly because the sample is still too small to make a statistical analysis meaningful. 
"There is no data, but I do not think women flame out or burn out at a disproportionate rate over men," said Sheila Wellington, the president of Catalyst, a nonprofit women's research organization. "It's just that there are so few of them that they get a disproportionate amount of attention when they do. And when one person becomes the personification of an entire group, we tend to conclude, if one fails, then they all will."
It would be laughable to see corporate directors debate whether it is safe to appoint other men as chief executives because, say, Jacques Nasser fell afoul of the Ford family and was ousted from the executive suite there. Yet some boards raise such issues when it comes to women, executive recruiters say.
"I recently presented a board with a few ladies, and the 'Carly' question came up: Is she a grandstander?" said Gerard R. Roche, the senior chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, an executive placement firm. "Boards are more apprehensive, even though they shouldn't be."
Betty Spence, president of the National Association of Female Executives, put the perception problem this way: "The Enron collapse is a story about Enron. The Hewlett-Packard story is about Carly Fiorina."
For whatever reasons, some executive women prefer to see things differently.
Ms. Hancock said she felt that the media treated her no differently than any man would have been in her position. "There is more interest in the personality of the leadership now, and a company is identified through its head, whether it is Carly, Bill or Scott," she said, referring to Bill Gates of Microsoft and Scott G. McNealy of Sun Microsystems as well as Ms. Fiorina. "I got more attention on trivial matters -- my clothes, how I wore a scarf -- but in general, I found the media fairly consistent."
Some experts agree, saying that any chief executive who courts celebrity gets it -- and the intensity grows if and when they fail. "The press likes to take down what they put up, and they do it proportionally," said Ed Niehaus, a co-founder of Niehaus Ryan Wong, a public relations firm in San Francisco that has technology companies as clients. "It's not a gender issue."
But any woman who becomes chief executive of a major company is automatically under a giant media spotlight. Men can avoid it far more easily.
"It's not all about disadvantages -- being a woman helps her stand out among the masses of other executives," said Andrea Redmond, an executive recruiter at Russell Reynolds Associates. It can also help some women be chosen for corporate boards, which remain mostly male. Some companies are very interested in recruiting high-profile women as directors, but others, having enlisted one, have returned in recent years to their old-boy networks for new members, some recruiters say.
MS. FIORINA'S gender helped put her on Hewlett-Packard's radar screen. More to the point, Ms. Fiorina did not shy away from publicity once she got the job, using it instead to her own and her company's advantage -- appearing in corporate advertisements, for example. Hewlett-Packard, one of the oldest and stodgiest Silicon Valley firms, reveled in the public-relations coup. 
"The fact that she was a woman was met with a whole lot of enthusiasm at H-P," said Jeffrey E. Christian, the chairman of Christian & Timbers, a search firm in Cleveland that recruited Ms. Fiorina for Hewlett-Packard. "They thought it was kind of cool."
If Ms. Fiorina departs, she will become part of an elite sisterhood of ousted chiefs. But she would also stand with a vast -- and growing -- old-boy network of men who flamed out as chief executives after only a few years and, in some cases, a few months. In 1997, for example, John R. Walter was dismissed from AT&T barely nine months after he was brought in as president and heir-apparent to the chief executive. Lloyd D. Ward at the Maytag Corporation, Richard A. McGinn at Lucent Technologies and Michael C. Hawley at Gillette are among the other chief executives who left under pressure after failing to deliver the performance Wall Street demanded. 
THE turnover rate at the top rose so high in the 1990's that unemployment has become for chief executives what divorce is to politicians -- a status too common to necessarily connote disgrace.
John A. Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm in Chicago, tracks the comings and goings of chief executives in America and has recorded 2,246 departures, voluntary and involuntary, since August 1999. The average tenure, he estimates, is now less than six years. 
"I do not think women C.E.O.'s flame out any quicker than men, though they may face added pressures in the job," Mr. Challenger said. "But I do think we are pushing a lot of people out unnecessarily -- short tenures are now the norm because C.E.O.'s are not given time to make mistakes."
Some may want new posts but are unemployable. Mr. Challenger said, however, that the pressures on chief executives were so high that many chose not to re-enlist. On this issue, he has detected some differences in public perception. "When a man leaves, he is getting the golden parachute to enjoy the good life," he said. "When a woman leaves of her own accord, they say, 'Well, she couldn't take the pressure.' "
The headlines reflect that. When Lewis E. Platt, who preceded Ms. Fiorina as chairman and chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, resigned at 58 and became chief executive of Kendall-Jackson, the winery, the move did not stir splashy coverage.
But when Brenda C. Barnes walked away from her perch as chief executive of Pepsi-Cola North America in 1997, at the age of 43, saying she wanted to spend more time with her family, the decision became a cultural milestone. It unleashed a vast public debate about women's conflicting ambitions for achievement at work and time at home. "It was so much more attention than I ever expected," Ms. Barnes recalled. "I was shocked at the sheer magnitude of the reaction." She is now a member of several corporate boards, including that of The New York Times Company. 
More and more men who leave top jobs cite family reasons, she noted, adding that there was skepticism about the underlying motives, particularly for men. "When I read that, I laugh -- these people are really high-powered people who are unlikely to spend a lot of time at home." 
Yet Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington, sees the trend as positive: "The good thing is that it has become an acceptable cover story, for men as well as women."
Ms. Barnes said she had no desire to seek out another chief-executive job, but others, like Ms. Hancock, do want to stay at the top.
And that may be more difficult. "I don't think Carly will have any problem if she leaves Hewlett-Packard," Mr. Christian said. The fact that the board and the company's senior management supported her would help ease her into another good position, he said.
But, he added, that was not necessarily the case for others. "I think the higher the degree of negative attention, the harder it is for anyone to find a new opportunity, and women do get higher levels of media attention," he explained. "I'll say the unspoken: A lot of companies are still more comfortable with a white male in the job."

HEADLINE: The Talk Of Kabul 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan 

 BODY:
I've got good news and bad news from Afghanistan. The good news is that America doesn't need a lot to satisfy its basic security interest here, which is that this distant land never again be so uncontrolled that a tumor like Osama bin Laden can grow in its midst and then metastasize into the world and threaten us. We really don't need much to get that -- just a loose Afghan federal government, some basic police and army units, a functioning economy and a few institutions.
 The bad news: it's not clear that we can get even that. 
 It is impossible to exaggerate how broken this place is. You know what ground zero looks like, where the World Trade Center once stood? Well, probably half of Kabul looks the same way, thanks to 22 years of civil war. And the "good" half -- with its scant electricity, no phones, no mail, a 10 p.m. curfew and only a bare minimum of food -- looks like a caravan ghost town. We might as well be doing nation-building on the moon.
You see sad and bizarre scenes here: a white donkey galloping down the main street right behind our car; a man with one leg peddling a bicycle; people washing a car with water from a port-a-potty; thousands of refugees crammed into the fetid old Soviet embassy, living in subzero temperatures with nothing but plastic wrap for windows. The central government is so broke it has less money than most American network crews here, so the government can't even pay salaries. "When some ministers come to see me they have to take a taxi," said Lakhdar Brahimi, the senior U.N. envoy here.
This is a travesty. Afghanistan needs a quick infusion of cash. (Maybe the Muslim world, which was so worried about Afghan civilians when America was bombing here, could send some cash now that the bombing is over and people need to eat?) In addition, though, Afghanistan needs a multinational force that can forge a secure environment in its major cities -- so refugees will return home, commerce will resume, and people will consider investing. Such a force could buy the frail Afghan government time to build up an army and police force of its own. Already, Afghanistan's carnivorous neighbors smell a power vacuum developing here, and some, like Iran, have begun brazenly sending people across Afghanistan's borders to buy influence. No good will come from that.
And that brings me to the Bush team. Right now there is a fight within the administration over whether to allow a robust multinational force here, and whether to participate in it ourselves. Let me be blunt: if the Bush team thinks our allies are going to send peacekeeping troops here in any numbers for any length of time without U.S. leadership and participation, they're crazy. And if they think that Afghanistan is going to pull itself together without the aid of such a force -- just pour in money and stir -- they're equally mistaken.
The U.S. won the war in Afghanistan by remote control, with air power, pilotless drones, local tribal fighters and a few U.S. Special Forces. The Bush team now seems to hope that it can win the peace in Afghanistan by remote control as well. It's not going to happen. The Pentagon's reluctance to put troops on the ground here to go cave by cave has already resulted in the vanishing of bin Laden and most of his key aides. A reluctance to create some kind of multinational security force here could end up costing us the peace.
Interior Minister Yunus Qanooni told visiting U.S. Senator Joe Biden, "We expect from the U.S. that it won't leave Afghanistan alone." Interim President Hamid Karzai told me in an interview: "I received delegations from every province after I was elected. I must have received 2,500 people. People from every province asked me to help get a multinational force here. People are desperate for security. One mullah opposed the idea."
I appreciate Mr. Bush's wariness about becoming involved here. We barely know who's who here, and the history of this place doesn't offer much hope. I wandered into an English bookstore in Kabul and was struck by how many books had "Afghan wars" in the title. I picked up one called "A History of the War in Afghanistan" and discovered it was part of a thick two-volume set that covered only the years 1800 to 1842.
Naturally, the Bush team doesn't want to "own" this problem. But unless we at least "rent" it for a while, and make at least a limited commitment to a security force here, for a limited period of time, this country will go right back to what it was: Mr. bin Laden's neighborhood.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
On the Rise: Private Charters

BYLINE:  By DAVIDSON GOLDIN; DAVIDSON GOLDIN is a reporter for New York 1 News.

 BODY:
IN the aftermath of September's terrorist attacks, a growing number of leisure travelers are turning to private planes to avoid the fears and hassles that many people now consider synonymous with commercial flights. 
 Charter companies report business across the board has surged since Sept. 11, with the most notable increases for leisure travel by families and small groups that had never considered private planes before. 
 "It's up about 40 percent for new inquiries, mostly in the East Coast and West Coast and also some of the major Midwest areas," said Jacque Rosser, flight operations manager for the National Air Transportation Association, which represents 800 charter operators. Operators are seeing "more families flying, more women and people who are combining leisure travel with business travel," said Meara McLaughlin, vice president of interactive services for Air Charter Guide, an online guide to private charters. 
Booking a trip is relatively straightforward. Air Charter Guide is a helpful resource on the Web (www.aircharterguide.com), providing links to major charter operators and brokers that arrange trips. Nationwide, Ms. McLaughlin said, there are more than 1,800 companies that book charter flights. And soon, she added, online travel sites that sell seats on commercial planes are expected to offer charter options. 
For the most part, charter prices vary only about 10 percent. But unlike commercial airlines, which charge by the seat, charters charge by the plane -- if all the seats are used, the price per person drops.
After the attacks, the Federal Aviation Administration moved up plans to increase security requirements for private flights -- although the rules are still less strict than those for commercial carriers. Charters generally don't use metal detectors or X-rays, but they do screen passengers and allow pilots to open bags at any time. 
As for safety, though charter pilots must have 10 hours of rest between flights, as opposed to 8 for commercial airlines, the airlines generally have more rigorous maintenance programs. "We hold the airlines to a higher level of safety," said Alison Duquette, an F.A.A. spokeswoman. 

Security and Convenience
Although newcomers to private air travel since Sept. 11 might be motivated by security concerns -- there are no strangers on the plane -- they ultimately wind up talking most about the convenience. 
"To get out of a car and walk to the plane, get on the plane, get off the plane and walk into a car, with no hustle and bustle, is great," said Jay Joel, a trucking executive in Bay Shore on Long Island who used a private plane for the first time in October for a weekend trip to Montreal with his wife and some friends. He chartered a plane, he said, because his wife, concerned about safety, refused to fly on a commercial flight. He booked the trip through Blue Star Jets, (866) 538-8463, www.bluestarjets.com, a broker that doesn't own any aircraft but has access to more than a thousand. 
The Lear 35 jet the Joels took accommodated six people and cost $6,000 round trip, less expensive per person than the approximately $1,155 United Airlines currently charges for a nonstop flight to Montreal in first class. 
The Joels liked their first charter so much that they used a private plane again for a family vacation to Miami over Thanksgiving. This time, though, they recruited another family to bring down the price. The round-trip flight from a private airport on Long Island on a Gulfstream III jet was $15,000 for 10 people (four adults, six children) -- again, less than the approximately $2,000 American currently charges for first class from New York to Miami. 
To be sure, chartering a plane -- no matter how many seats you fill -- is not nearly as inexpensive as an advance-purchase economy ticket. But for people willing to pay the premium for a first-class ticket on a commercial airline, a private plane isn't necessarily more expensive. 
When it comes to booking a trip, travelers have a choice between using brokers (similar to travel agents) and contacting charter operators directly. Paul K. Class, a vice president at Tag Aviation, (800) 331-1930, www.tagaviation.com, said direct bookings offer travelers slightly better prices and faster service in the event of a mechanical problem. 

How Prices Are Set
Charters are priced according to the size of the plane and number of hours in the air. A small jet seating about six passengers like a Lear 35A, costs about $1,800 an hour. A medium-sized jet that seats up to 10, like a Lear 60, costs about $2,500 an hour. A large jet that seats up to 15, like a Challenger 604, costs close to $4,800 an hour and can fly coast-to-coast without refueling. 
"Charters make the most sense for short- and medium-length trips, unless you're a billionaire who can afford to take it across the country," said George-Ann Rosenberg, the public-relations consultant for Washington-based SkyJet, (888) 275-9538; www.skyjet.com. 
"If someone had suggested a charter I might have said they were crazy," said Dean Powell, a New York City photographer who booked his first charter flight through Blue Star Jets in October. "But after Sept. 11, you have to think, because it's a different world." 
Mr. Powell took his wife, two daughters aged 6 and 9 and their nanny on a day trip to Hershey Park in Pennsylvania. The round-trip flight for the five of them on a King Air 200 turbo-prop cost $2,500 -- less per person than the full coach walk-up US Airways fare of $760 to Harrisburg, and without the inconvenience of a connection. 
Commercial airlines use about 900 airports nationwide, while smaller charter flights have access to nearly 5,000 domestic airfields. There are no schedules to work around, no security lines at the airport and you don't need to check the family dog -- pets are welcome, too. (As for meals, the food is extra.) 
Charter prices for trips of more than a few days cost double the time you're actually on the plane. With a short stay, the plane will stay on the ground until your return flight, at a cost of roughly $500 a day depending on the aircraft. But when you stay for a while, the operator may send the plane back to its base and then make a second round trip to pick you up. If a charter company can fill the empty legs, the charter can cost up to 50 percent less. Brokers say that as private air travel becomes more common, prices will fall as more empty legs are filled. But for now, one way to shop around for a private flight is to check whether an operator or broker might be able to fill that empty leg once you book. 
Some veterans of private air travel say they're not surprised at the growing interest in private planes.
"I have some friends who are not as financially secure, but they're trying to change some things around in their lives so they can do this," said Mark Mariani, a Greenwich, Conn., home builder who uses charter flights to get to a second home on Martha's Vineyard. "Since Sept. 11 more people on the fence are going forward with this because of the safety and the convenience."
